DOC.HEAD: Morale Higher Than in Vietnam Despite Griping, Homesickness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report. Note contents of 4th and 17th grafs.
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: This is the second of a two-part series on U.S. military personnel in the Persian Gulf and examines the state of their morale. The first dealt with their concepts of why they are there. ---=

The mail's still slow, the pre-packaged food is monotonous and there are few places to unwind. The flies and scorpions have not retreated before the biggest American force sent overseas in 20 years. But Staff Sgt. Joe Estes, a 25-year Army veteran, said morale after four months in the desert is ``100 percent better'' than in the dark years of Vietnam. There's plenty of griping and a universal desire to go home, especially as Christmas approaches, but there are few serious symptoms of a demoralized fighting force. The ``booze, broads and drugs'' synonymous with Vietnam are forbidden in this conservative Moslem kingdom. Since American soldiers arrived to confront Saddam Hussein and his occupation of Kuwait, only a few have been caught drinking. There have been no reports of drug use or illegal fraternization with Saudi women. Fragging, the GI tactic in Vietnam of getting rid of unpopular officers with a grenade or bullet, is not even mentioned. The draftees of Vietnam and their hatred for the military establishment are long gone. In 1990, the U.S. military is a totally volunteer force. Many soldiers in Operation Desert Shield admit they never expected to fight a war, but they are prepared to do their job, whether it is flying an F-15 fighter, firing a howitzer or washing uniforms. ``You've got a more educated, a more physically fit type of Army you're working with now,'' said Estes, a wiry 42-year-old infantryman from Nashville, Tenn., who was in Vietnam near the height of U.S. involvement in 1967-68. ``Morale's at an all-time high. Confidence is real high,'' he said, watching top-of-the-line M1A1 tanks rumble off the cargo ship Cape Inspiration. Brig. Gen. Steven L. Arnold, assistant chief of staff in the Army Forces Central Command, served two tours in Vietnam. He said the Army had recovered from that traumatizing conflict and subsequent antagonism to the military. ``This is as good a peacetime army as I think has ever existed,'' he said. ``I know people are saying (the troops) are complaining. ... Soldiers are always complaining about things, but that's not an indication of morale.'' As Marine Cpl. Ed Walsh of Las Vegas put it: ``If a Marine ain't griping, he ain't happy.'' Walsh, 21, is with the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force. Arnold said the key to morale is whether ``soldiers willingly do the right thing without being told and ... do it well. That's discipline, and a disciplined force is really a high-morale force. ``When you have forces that are challenged, and you're giving them the type of training that meets their expectations, I think you see a lot of high morale. You see it here.'' One yardstick for morale is mental health. ``We've had very little business,'' said Capt. Frank Mullins, 54, of Mobile, Ala., a psychologist with the Mental Health Unit at the U.S. Navy's Fleet No. 5 Hospital. ``Morale has been excellent from what we've seen. People can complain a lot, bitch and carry on, but morale can be very high.'' Desert Shield is the biggest U.S. military operation since Vietnam, where U.S. strength reached 545,000 at its peak. More than 240,000 American personnel now are in the gulf and 200,000 more will be in place by mid-January. Complaints in a force of that size are inevitable. Two of the biggest problems are monotony and few escapes. ``This is a prison; you can't go anywhere,'' moaned Lance Cpl. Steven Jenkins, 24, of Neptune, N.J., a maintenance man with a Marine air wing. Army Sgt. Kenneth Hetzer, 32, had other complaints after nearly three months in a forward position with the 75th Field Artillery Brigade: Soldiers had holes in their boots, weren't allowed to use the telephone and had to pay $3 for a block of ice. Walsh said that, despite the griping, ``we're really locked on. If war comes, it'd be like uncoiling a snake. ... There's nothing that can stop us.'' Attitudes differ in front and rear units, and between full-time soldiers and the reserve and National Guard units mobilized at short notice. ``Morale was very high and it got higher as we got closer to the Kuwaiti border,'' said Rep. Robert J. Lagomarsino, a California Republican who visited the troops last month with a 20-member congressional delegation. ``The more primitive the conditions, the higher the morale,'' he said. ``The people in the more primitive conditions are the combat infantry, the combat Marine forces that were trained in the desert, so they know what they're doing.'' Army Sgt. 1st Class Thomas Melton, 39, of Florence, Ala., said: ``The guys up there know they've got a mission. Down here, it's just sit and wait for your equipment to come in and get to your location. It's very boring to sit around waiting. That's the big problem.'' Melton has traveled extensively in Saudi Arabia as part of the 207th Military Intelligence Brigade. In the words of Marine Cpl. Carlin Walters, 21, of Vidor, Texas: ``The boredom gets pretty strenuous. It'd be better just to go ahead and get it over with.'' The Marines, all in forward positions near the Kuwaiti border, and Army combat units like the 82nd Airborne Division have reputations for high morale in bad conditions. At the other extreme are rear units with serious problems, like the 1241st Postal Unit from the Alabama Army National Guard. ``We've got a lot of soldiers ready to go home,'' said Sgt. Michael Smith, 32, of Montgomery. ``The morale around here's at the very bottom. If things were different and we were civilians, we'd probably strike.'' For most soldiers, the toughest thing is not knowing when they will go home. ``Either an operation or a go-home date is going to boost morale,'' said 1st Lt. Bruce Lake, 29, of Newport News, Va., a platoon leader with the 24th Infantry Division. With the usual GI diversions banned, the military has tried to keep morale up with sports, movies and music. Mail is the biggest booster. ``Mail equals morale,'' Lake said. Veterans like Estes, who never heard a word of support from the American public while fighting in Vietnam, are overwhelmed by the flood of letters his countrymen send to ``any serviceman'' in Saudi Arabia. Many GIs have found new pen pals, including churches, clubs and schools. ``This place here is just what you make it,'' said Staff Sgt. Jeanne Kendall, 35, of Piedmont, Ohio, an Air Force mechanic. ``We've made it one big party. Bring a guitar and have a singalong.''

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Shevardnadze's Career as Foreign Minister
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's career: -Nearly completed negotiations on the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty to slash superpower long-range nuclear arsenals by up to half. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush are expected to sign the pact at a February summit in Moscow. -Negotiated withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan in 1989 and admitted that the Soviet incursion there was a mistake. -Completed agreement on the reduction of Warsaw Pact and NATO conventional forces in Europe, signed in 1990. -Completed agreement to eliminate U.S. and Soviet medium-range nuclear missiles, signed in 1987. -Acknowledged that the Krasnoyarsk phased-array radar emplacement violated the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. -Oversaw the freeing of East bloc countries in Europe in 1989-90, including the fall of the Berlin Wall and the reunification of Germany. -Took part in the mediation of the civil war in southern Africa, leading to independence for Namibia and the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola in 1989. -Helped end a 30-year estrangement with China in 1989. -Oversaw the restoration of diplomatic relations with Albania and Saudi Arabia in 1990. -Oversaw the improvement of relations with Israel, leading to the re-establishment of consular ties in 1990. -Oversaw the normalization of relations with South Korea and the Vatican in 1990. -Established in 1988 the long-range goal of withdrawing all Soviet troops to within Soviet borders. -Helped forge the closest U.S.-Soviet ties since World War II, with an unprecedented 19 meetings with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Primakov Among Several Possible Replacements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The next Soviet foreign minister will face a different world than Eduard Shevardnadze took on five years ago, but the possible candidates are all dedicated followers of the policy their predecessor set down. Most work in the Foreign Ministry and have experiences as diplomats or scholars, the kind of training Shevardnadze lacked when Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed him in 1985 to take over for Andrei Gromyko. Unlike Shevardnadze's crusade for change the last five years, the next foreign minister will need to maintain and cultivate the Soviet Union's new role as a self-declared mediator, rather than a supporter of revolution. But the new foreign minister still will face Old Guard bureaucrats in some departments at the Foreign Ministry as he navigates new relations with Israel, the Vatican, Japan, South Korea and Germany, among others. The new foreign minister likely will have less financial and military aid to use as tool in his work, with his government facing a flagging economy and budget deficit. And he will need a knowledge of international economics, with his leaders expecting more materially from its foreign friends. Here's a brief look at those considered prime candidates for the job:

Yevgeny M. Primakov (pronounced Pree-mah-kof'), the first possible candidate mentioned in the Soviet press after Shevardnadze's resignation, is a 61-year-old former professor known most recently for his shuttle diplomacy to Iraq looking for a solution in the Persian Gulf. His effort failed after several meetings with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, reported to be a longtime friend. But still it heightened his status as a savvy envoy who at least tried to deal with Saddam. Before becoming a deputy foreign minister last year, Primakov was director of the prestigious Institute for World Economy and International Relations. An expert on the Middle and Far East, as well as having a doctorate in economics, Primakov helped devise the ``new thinking'' foreign policy that Shevardnadze was implementing. Primakov recently was criticized in the Soviet press for being among officials who received new, state-owned apartments without the usual waiting period. But the news didn't seem to tarnish his image; he also was mentioned as a possible candidate for the proposed new post of vice president.

Valentin M. Falin (Fah'-lin), 64, became chief of the Communist Party's international department in 1988, before the party's credibility plummeted and the job lost some influence over foreign policies. Falin is considered a master diplomat and the leading Soviet expert on Western Europe. He rose through the Foreign Ministry's European departments and served as a Soviet attache in Austria and ambassador to West Germany. He was an adviser to Gromyko in 1965, a national legislator on the foreign affairs committee, a member of the government daily Izvestia's editorial board, and member of the party's policy-making Central Committee.

Vladimir F. Petrovsky (Peh-trof'-skee), a deputy foreign minister since 1986, has seen his stock rise since returning from Iraq last month to find a solution to the gulf crisis. The 57-year-old diplomat was in Baghdad while the Soviet Union began dropping its cautionary tone and threatening to support force against Iraq if Saddam didn't pull out of Kuwait. He began his foreign service career as an English translator at the United Nations, later rising under Gromyko. He later became chief of the Foreign Ministry's U.S. department, then head of the ministry's section that deals with international organizations.

Yuli A. Vorontsov (Voh-rahn'-tsof), 61, a rare generalist in Soviet diplomacy, worked in the United States, India and France before being sent as trouble-shooting ambassador to Afghanistan during the Soviet pullout in 1988. His experience includes meeting secretly in 1985 with Israel's ambassador in France to discuss restoration of ties, defending Soviet human rights policies at a rights conference in 1977, and leading disarmament talks in 1985 over U.S. and Soviet intermediate and strategic nuclear weapons. He later was brought back to Moscow and made first deputy foreign minister, solidifying his place in a new generation of flexible, innovative diplomats.

Alexander A. Bessmertnykh (Bes-mairt-nikh'), 57, an expert on U.S.-Soviet relations, was made Soviet ambassador to the United States in April in a sweeping appointment of new foreign service officers. He had served in the Soviet embassy in Washington for 13 years before returning to Moscow in 1983, where he was a deputy foreign minister responsible for the United Nations and North America. He later rose to become one of three first deputy foreign ministers.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze: The Crimebuster Who Became a Statesman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eduard A. Shevardnadze helped create a new era in Soviet foreign policy, marked by sweeping arms control agreements, withdrawal from Afghanistan and the collapse of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. Shevardnadze, who announced Thursday he would resign as foreign minister, was a novice in international affairs when he was chosen by Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the high-profile job in July 1985. He had spent most of his political career working for as a Communist Party functionary. Diplomats and Soviet watchers rushed to find out more about him. He was fairly well-known within the Soviet Union for battling crime and corruption in his native Georgia where was in charge of the interior ministry and the police. Shevardnadze replaced the dour Andrei A. Gromyko who was foreign minister for 28 years and was known as ``Mr. Nyet'' for his tough negotiating stands. The genial, white-haired Shevardnadze quickly reversed gears, implementing Gorbachev's ``new thinking'' and promoting a less aggressive foreign policy aimed at lessening world tensions. Hard-working, well-briefed and quick to learn, Shevardnadze developed good working relations with his Western counterparts and often warm personal relations. It was Gorbachev who won the Nobel Peace Prize this year, but it was the 62-year-old Shevardnadze who did much of the leg work. Former Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov referred to his globetrotting boss as ``the flying Georgian.'' Like Gorbachev, Shevardnadze is a pragmatist rather than an old-style, hard-line communist. Gorbachev recently credited Shevardnadze, a friend dating back to their teens, with helping develop the concept of perestroika during a walk along a beach in March 1985. ``We were walking and talking,'' Gorbachev told the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. ``We compared notes. He said that everything was rotten through.'' ``It was not easy for us to reach those conclusions,'' Gorbachev said. ``We had seen a lot, especially considering that we had seen the war, so we had seen a lot and knew a lot.'' Together, Gorbachev and Shevardnadze closed the final chapter in the Cold War, permitting the unification of Germany and the return of democracy to Eastern Europe and improving relations with the United States. They moved to heal rifts with Japan, South Korea and Isreal, and cooled relations with hard-line regimes such as Cuba and North Korea. When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Soviet Union was among the first to condemn its longtime ally Iraq and call for unconditional withdrawal. In an unprecedented display of superpower cooperation, Moscow has backed all U.N. resolutions aimed at dislodging the Iraqi forces. ``Shevardnadze made a real era in our international policies,'' Sergei Stankevich, Moscow's deputy mayor, said in tribute Thursday. Shevardnadze, a teacher's son, was born in the village of Mamati near the Black Sea on Jan. 25, 1928. He rose through the ranks of the Communist Youth League, and the Georgian Communist Party, became the republic's interior minister in 1965 and its party leader in 1972. Georgia had a reputation for corruption and as interior minister Shevardnadze gained national attention for his key role in one of the republic's most infamous examples of nepotism and bribery. The case involved Otari Lazishvili, who used a personal friendship with a former Soviet general prosecutor to protect numerous illegal economic dealings. Shevardnadze gradually and successfully moved against Lazishvili in 1972. He was then made party boss and continued the crackdown. In his book ``Russia,'' author Robert Kaiser tells how Shevardnadze tested his own regulations against exporting Georgian produce. He filled a car trunk with tomatoes, dressed in peasant clothes and drove north toward the Russian border, bribing border guards en route. A purge of the border patrol ensued. Shevardnadze also pioneered the use of public opinion polls in the Soviet Union, creating in 1966 an Institute for the Study of Public Opnion to provide reliable data about the extent of crime and corruption. He promoted economic reform long before perestroika was a household word, allowing some Georgian enterprises such as restaurants to adopt elements of private enterprise. In 1978, Shevardnadze was appointed a non-voting member of the national Communist Party Politburo which, until recent reforms, wielded immense power over the government of the country as well as the party. In 1985 after Gorbachev took over leadership of the Communist Party, Shevardnadze was made a full member. Shevardnade's wife, Nanuli, is a former journalist.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze's Departure Seen as Attempt to Revitalize Soviet Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The stunning resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze seems aimed at revitalizing the flagging Soviet reform movement and prodding Mikhail Gorbachev into quashing an upsurge by ``reactionaries.'' ``Democrats ... you have scattered,'' Shevardnadze told parliamentarians near the end of a rambling 15-minute speech. Shevardnadze did not directly criticize Gorbachev. But he confronted him with a clear choice: to preserve the fragile democratic institutions of perestroika or to risk crushing them by strengthening presidential powers to cope with the political and economic crisis. Shevardnadze, along with Gorbachev and Alexander Yakovlev, was one of the three pillars of the perestroika reform movement, and it was not clear whether the policy could stand on two legs at this moment of crisis. Gorbachev is asking the Congress of People's Deputies to yet again strengthen the powers of his presidency. Hard-liners are lobbying for him to declare a state of emergency and rule by decree in troubled regions, particularly the three secessionist Baltic republics. Shevardnadze noted in his speech that hard-liners had succeeded in pressuring Gorbachev to replace the moderate Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin with a KGB and an army general, and said he thought he was their next target. Implicit in his speech was the idea that Gorbachev has capitulated to the conservatives, an idea that enunciated later by other reformers. ``I think Mr. Gorbachev should take Mr. Shevardnadze's statement as a real signal that he is ... going too far to the right,'' said Moscow Deputy Mayor Sergei Stankevich. ``I think Gorbachev should make a crucial choice, whether he's going to continue the course he started'' in launching the reforms in 1985, said Stankevich. The hard-liners that Shevardnadze accused of ``persecuting'' him gleefully welcomed his departure. ``It's a step in the right direction,'' said Col. Viktor Alksnis, a leader of the movement that has been urging Gorbachev to declare a state of emergency and rule by presidential decree in tense areas of the country. Shevardnadze called Gorbachev a ``friend'' and soulmate, but his resignation recalled an earlier parting of the ways. The resignation recalled the fiery speech delivered by another reformer, Boris N. Yeltsin, at a closed party meeting in late 1987. Gorbachev drummed Yeltsin out of the ruling Politburo - and now Yeltsin stands as his most formidable political foe, as president of the Russian Federation. Yeltsin, in his speech, said Gorbachev was jeopardizing the reforms by not doing battle with hard-liners, a point very similar to Shevardnadze's. And Yeltsin and Shevardnadze also angered Gorbachev by surprising him. ``For me, Shevardnadze's announcement came as a surprise. That, more than anything else, to tell the truth, hurts me,'' Gorbachev told the Congress, picking his words carefully. Yakovlev pointedly made himself available to reporters in the cavernous white marble foyer of the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. He said he regretted Shevardnadze's resignation, but called the Georgian's prediction of dictatorship ``nonsense.'' ``I wouldn't jump to such a conclusion,'' he said. ``But there are signs that the extreme right is raising its head, and they have a glint in their eyes.'' Another Gorbachev ally, Fyodor Burlatsky, appeared on the floor of the Congress and asked the body to vote to request that Shevardnadze remain as foreign minister. It complied, on a 1,540-52 vote, but a Shevardnadze spokesman said that the decision was ``irreversible.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Bryan Brumley, The Associated Press bureau chief in Moscow, has been covering Soviet affairs since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Four-Year Fight to Free British Hostage John McCarthy Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Bundled-up preschoolers will sing carols in Covent Garden on Saturday to remind shoppers that British journalist John McCarthy will spend another Christmas as a hostage in Lebanon. The Friends of John McCarthy hope the group of 4{ year olds, chosen because they have lived as long as he has been captive, will catch news media attention and give a boost to the campaign for the television journalist's release. ``Christmas is quite depressing, because I think April is right round the corner,'' said Jill Morrell, McCarthy's girlfriend at the time he was kidnapped on April 17, 1986. Ms. Morrell, also a television journalist, has become the reluctant spokeswoman for the campaign and its 9,000 members, who lobby the British government and work to keep McCarthy, 34, and two other British hostages in the public eye. ``It's an uphill battle,'' Ms. Morrell, 33, said in a recent interview at a north London restaurant. ``We're a small campaign...so it takes an effort to get noticed.'' Gunmen kidnapped McCarthy on his way to catch a plane home from Beirut. No group has ever claimed responsibility for the kidnapping. The McCarthy campaign has also taken up the causes of Church of England envoy Terry Waite, taken captive on Jan. 20, 1987, and retired pilot Jack Mann, who disappeared May 12, 1989. A fourth Briton, Alec Collett, disappeared in 1985. A group that claimed to be holding him released a videotape purporting to show Collett hanged, but his death has never been confirmed. There are nine other Western hostages in Lebanon, including Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. Anderson was kidnapped March 16, 1985, and has been in captivity the longest. A small woman with a soft voice, sparkling blue eyes and an easy smile, Ms. Morrell also displays a steely resolve that gained her meetings with Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat and Nabih Berri, leader of Amal, the largest Shiite militia. By staging media events to mark McCarthy's kidnapping and his birthday on Nov. 27, and acting as spokeswoman for his cause, Ms. Morrell has made McCarthy's name, and herself, familiar to millions of Britons. But the last four months of the campaign, which has now lasted longer than she and McCarthy were together, have been particularly tough. Britain's renewed diplmatic relations with Iran and Syria have brought few results. False rumors of McCarthy's imminent freedom have been especially frustrating after the euphoria surrounding the release of McCarthy's fellow captive, Brian Keenan, on Aug. 25. Keenan, a teacher from Belfast, Northern Ireland, spent months with McCarthy and gave Ms. Morrell a detailed picture of his life, much of it very cruel. ``It was like having John back, hearing about him. He is coping very well but the treatment and the misery and the pain, some of it wasn't pleasant,'' she said, her voice trailing off as she sipped a cup of tea. After three years together, Ms. Morrell and McCarthy had been about to buy an apartment and were thinking about marriage. Now, she said, she thought that when McCarthy was freed he might want to meet other women. Like Keenan, ``he might want to experience everything with new enthusiasm and make up for lost time.''

DOC.HEAD: Fraud Charges Still Major Issue in Mexican Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When candidates and parties face off in Mexican elections, the battle often doesn't end at the ballot box. Fraud charges fly for weeks after. Four state elections over the past two months showed the issue of fraud is as alive as ever, despite President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's pledges of clean elections, reforms in electoral laws and promises from his Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, that it's changing its ways. Most accusations are aimed at the PRI, whose 61 years in power have made it synonymous with the government, thus helping it continue to win. What has changed since Salinas took office two years ago is that clear opposition victories are recognized, said Luis H. Alvarez, president of the National Action Party, or PAN. The business-oriented National Action Party for many years was the only significant opposition and, even so, won few elections. With the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party, it remains one of the two main minority forces. ``Here one has to win by knockout, by an ample majority,'' Alvarez said. It's more difficult when the vote is close. ``Now if we win and we show the documentation that we won, they recognize our triumph, but that shouldn't have to be. ``We have to prove it. The one who is robbed has to say, `they robbed me,' and then catch the thief and put him in jail.'' For eight days the rightist opposition party and the governing party claimed victory in the close Nov. 25 mayoral race in Merida. ``If the PRI wins, (it's) fraud; if the opposition party wins, (it's) democracy,'' Yucatan state Gov. Victor Manzanilla Schaffer was quoted as saying of the opposition allegations. PAN's Ana Rosa Payan Cervera was declared the winner after recounts and the inclusion of six disputed ballot boxes. Local governing party officials then said they would challenge the results. ``It is a significant advance, not because the PAN has won in Merida, but simply because they are giving the real results,'' the government newspaper El Nacional said in an editorial. The 1979 electoral law reforms invited more opposition by making it easier for parties to register. Minority parties receive congressional seats according to the percentage of the vote they win and are guaranteed at least 100 of the 400 seats in the Chamber of Deputies. ``Before, the central characteristic of the Mexican elections was their lack of competitiveness. Today, that characteristic has been reduced to the simple absence of credibility,'' Lorenzo Meyer, a leading historian at the prestigious Colegio de Mexico wrote in his front-page column in the newspaper Excelsior. When results aren't credible, the opposition frequently protests by taking over the local city hall. Other times, the results turn tragic. Riot police fired tear gas into a Democratic Revolutionary Party rally Dec. 12 in Tejupilco, in the central state of Mexico, to protest fraud in municipal elections a month earlier. Three people were killed and dozens of others injured in the shooting that followed. Public discontent over fraud was so great by 1988 that Salinas, in his inaugural speech, said the country's most pressing political need was clean elections. Many Mexicans still insist that Salinas himself lost to Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who heads the Democratic Revolutionary Party. Governing party documents released this month say ``the legitimacy of suffrage is an unavoidable element of the new national consensus. It is the final hour for non-competitive electoral systems.'' But Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, a Democratic Revolutionary leader, and Alvarez allege the PRI machinery merely went high-tech. Computerized altering of voter registration lists has become the main means of rigging elections, with opposition supporters disappearing and fictitious names being added, they said. The PRI denies that and argues that opposition parties get the lists from the government for review before elections. Martinez said parties aren't able to check the thousands of names. When he complained that rolls for the Mexico state elections carried the same names several times, he got a meeting with the interior secretary but no change in the list, he said. Under 1989 electoral reforms, a new national voter registration list will be drawn up by next year's congressional elections and meetings of electoral bodies will be public. The new law sets fines and jail sentences for violations. The PRI dominated all four recent state elections, its most notable loss outside Merida being PAN's mayral victory in Saltillo, the Coahuila state capital. If recent elections had been spotless, Alvarez said, the governing party still would do well, ``simply from inertia, custom ... but the opposition would have much greater presence than is officially recognized.'' When turnout is high, as it was in 1988 and this month in Yucatan, the governing party loses, Martinez said.

DOC.HEAD: A Thousand Dollars in the Century's First Decade ... and Its Last
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: ``What can a fellow do with $1,000?'' a young man asks in an O. Henry short story. ``A thousand dollars means much or little,'' replies a character called Old Bryson. That was in the century's first decade. In its last, $1,000 still means much or little, especially during the holidays. What would $1,000 buy in O. Henry's day? ``One man may buy a happy home with it and laugh at Rockefeller,'' Old Bryson said. ``Another could send his wife South with it and save her life. A thousand dollars would buy pure milk for 100 babies during June, July and August and save 50 of their lives. ``It would furnish an education for an ambitious boy. I am told that a genuine Corot was secured for that amount in an auction room yesterday. You could move to a New Hampshire town and live respectably two years on it. You could rent Madison Square Garden for one evening with it.'' These days, a Christmas shopper could buy a Giorgio Armani suit at Saks, 18-carat gold horse cuff links at Tiffany, a 4{-foot long stuffed tiger at FAO Schwarz toy store or 15 pounds of Scottish salmon and 1,282 bagels at Zabar's deli. With a thousand dollars you can buy a 25-foot oak tree, a box seat at baseball's All-Star Game, a Faberge egg made of cocabolo wood, a set of AKG K1000 headphones or 869 subway tokens. With the same amount, the Children's Aid Society can send five homeless kids to camp for three weeks, or two handicapped kids to camp for two weeks. The Coalition for the Homeless can serve 685 meals at Grand Central Terminal. A thousand dollars would buy 20 hours in a stretch limousine; four sessions at La Coupe hair salon with colorist Daniel Galvin; three makeovers by Ilana at Il Makiage. It also would clothe 50 children for winter or provide health exams for 20 children who otherwise would never see a doctor outside an emergency room. A sightseer might charter a twin-engine, five-seat helicopter for 30 minutes; a harried suburban commuter might soar above the traffic to and from work for one blessed day and still have enough for a monthly bus ticket. A tourist could spend anight at the Hotel Pierre in suite 2111, which has a balcony, kitchen and chandeliered dining room but no view of Central Park - that's $1,100 a night, minimum. Or he could spend 40 nights at the YMCA on 23rd Street, provided he settles for a room with no television. A gourmet might invite four guests to join her for dinner at the Quilted Giraffe, where the menu promises dishes such as Wasabi Pizza with Sashimi Tuna and Confit of Duck with Creamy Garlic Potatoes. Or, if she doesn't mind eating while standing, she could treat 500 people to a hot dog and a cup of juice at a Papaya King stand. A thousand dollars would cover a month in a Phoenix House program for drug addicts, but staffer Steve Dnistrian says money isn't the problem: ``If someone gave us a million we couldn't open another treatment center. Nobody wants one on their block.'' Nor can a thousand dollars buy most of the things on Old Bryson's list. The median cost of a happy home in metropolitan New York is $176,700, but a thousand dollars will buy a doll house, fully furnished, wallpapered and carpeted, at Schwarz. A thousand dollars would buy a week's formula for 40 babies in Covenant House's mother-and-child unit, but the average cost of a year at a private college or university is $13,544. And Madison Square Garden now rents for $40,000 a night.

DOC.HEAD: OSHA Case Settled With Record $3.25 Million Fine for USX Corp.
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. will pay a record $3.25 million fine to settle government allegations that it deliberately and repeatedly violated worker-safety standards at two Pennsylvania steel plants. The settlement, announced Thursday, stemmed from allegations leveled last year by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. The agency accused USS, the steelmaking division of USX Corp., of more than 2,000 federal job safety violations. OSHA originally proposed a record $7.3 million fine for the violations, which included hazards the government said were blamed for fatalities and not corrected. The $3.25 million settlement is the largest worker-safety fine to be collected, eclipsing the $1.6 million Chrysler Corp. paid for violations at a plant in Newark, Del. The original OSHA citation charged that Pittsburgh-based USX permitted some of violations at the Pennsylvania plants, even though the company agreed two years ago to eliminate them at all its facilities. In a statement, the company said it agreed to pay the huge fine, in part, to avoid lengthy and costly legal battles over the government's allegations. ``We continue to believe that both Clairton Works and Fairless Works are safe plants. ... Throughout our organization, there is no higher priority than the safety and health of our people,'' Thomas W. Sterling, vice president for employee relations at USS, said in a statement. Clairton Works, near Pittsburgh, and Fairless Works, near Philadelphia, were the two steel plants originally at issue in OSHA's complaint. The United Steelworkers of America, the union representing about 18,000 USX workers, cautioned against the significance of the settlement. ``The agreement confirms the union's contentions that USX willfully allowed safety and health conditions in its facilities to deteriorate to such a point that workers were in serious danger,'' a union statement said. Sterling said the company has already corrected several safety conditions at the two plants and other improvements were now being undertaken. He said that during settlement negotiations with the government, there had been many areas of ``substantial disagreement over the OSHA allegations.'' The union said USX has refused to let the union review safety records or have an input on safety improvements. ``This corporate attitude signals more battles over safety and health at a time when other steel companies have joined with the union in a variety of safety-related programs,'' said Andrew V. ``Lefty'' Palm, the union's chief negotiator in contract talks. OSHA's original citation, issued in November 1989, accused the company of failing to provide safe walking and working surfaces; substandard crane-safety standards; failure to properly guard machines and power transmission equipment; noise violations; failure to keep accurate records of injuries and illnesses; structural flaws; and violations of electrical-safety standards. The citations stemmed from OSHA inspections that began earlier in 1989 following complaints from both the union and employees. OSHA said three workers had died at the two plants in the two years leading up to the inspections; there had been 17 such deaths since 1972. Acting Labor Secretary Roderick A. DeArment said all of USX's 19,000 workers would benefit from Thursday's settlement because it calls for the company to take corporate-wide action to strengthen safety and health protection. Gerard Scannell, an assistant secretary of labor who heads OSHA, said the corporate-wide safety programs will involve hearing conservation, record keeping, crane safety and ``hazard communications,'' which involves employee training. Those programs will be implement at the two plants involved in the original complaint, along with USS facilities in Fairfield, Ala.; Braddock, Pa.; Dravosburg, Pa.; and Chicago. USS has also promised to meet with the state of Indiana, which operates its own OSHA-approved occupational safety and health program, to seek a similar agreement covering its Gary, Ind., Works.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hope will spend another Christmas entertaining U.S. troops, this time amid looming war tensions in the Middle East. ``He's going through piles of material and he's busy rehearsing with Ann Jillian and Khrystyne Haje and Delores (Hope),'' Hope spokesman Ward Grant said Thursday. The 87-year-old entertainer will be joined by the Pointer Sisters, Marie Osmond, country singer Aaron Tippin, former Cincinnati Reds baseball player Johnny Bench and former Chicago Bears running back Walter Payton. The troupe will depart Los Angeles this weekend and plan to return Dec. 29. Their exact itinerary was not disclosed. Hope first entertained troops for Christmas in 1948, during the Berlin airlift. Since then he has spent the holiday with troops in Korea, Vietnam, Lebanon (1983) and the Persian Gulf (1987). ``One of the loves of his life is the GI audience,'' Grant said. --- ROUND HILL, Nev. (AP) - Entertainer Wayne Newton's failure to submit a plan for restoring an erosion-damaged stream on his 241-acre Lake Tahoe retreat will cost him $15,000. The renowned Las Vegas showman also must post a $150,000 bond for missing a May deadline for submitting the improvement plans, the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency said. The bistate agency decided Wednesday to extend the deadline for submitting the land restoration plan until March 1, but also required the fee and the bond. He'll get the bond back once the work is done. Newton acquired the scenic property in 1985 for $2.5 million. --- TULSA, Okla. (AP) - ``Life Goes On'' actor Christopher Burke, Iditarod dog sled racer Susan Butcher and Kansas City Chiefs placekicker Nick Lowery were named to the U.S. Jaycees' Ten Outstanding Young Americans for 1991. Burke, 25, of Point Lookout, N.Y., is an actor with Down's syndrome who plays Corky Thatcher in the ABC series. He is the spokesman for the National Down's Syndrome Congress. Butcher, 36, of Manley, Alaska, is a four-time winner of the 1,158-mile Iditarod race traversing Alaska from Anchorage to Nome. She and fellow racer Joe Redinton are the only people to reach Mount McKinley, North America's highest point, by dog sled. Lowery, 34, holds the National Football League record for most field goals beyond 50 yards (18), and entered the 1990 season with the highest percentage of field goals made in a career. He is active in charity efforts. The 53rd annual awards were given to 10 Americans, ages 21 through 39, based on their contributions to society, personal accomplishment and public service. --- MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - Garrison Keillor said it's not right that he's living outside Minnesota and that he made a mistake by fussing in public about media coverage of his personal life. The writer and radio show host left Minnesota in 1987 after quitting his former long-running radio show, ``A Prairie Home Companion.'' He moved to New York City, where he is host of a new radio show, ``Garrison Keillor's American Radio Company.'' ``I can go live in New York, the same way that a person can go into the Army, but it's not my choice,'' Keillor told Mpls. St. Paul magazine in its January 1991 issue. ``This is where everybody I care about lives. It's where people talk like me and feel the same way that I do. ``Every time I come back, I feel this twinge that my life took a wrong turn,'' the best-selling author of ``Lake Wobegon Days'' said. ``This is not tragic. I'm a very lucky person. But Minnesota is my home and I don't live here, and this is not right.'' Keillor said he left Minnesota because local media ran stories which he considered malicious. He wrote letters to the editor and spoke out on television against the stories. Keillor told the magazine that his public feud with the media ``made matters worse, I'm sure.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actor Buddy Rogers, star of the 1927 film ``Wings,'' helped rededicate a refurbished 1929 hangar that is the last original structure at Los Angeles International Airport. The hangar dedicated Thursday is listed by the city as a historic cultural monument. It sheltered aircraft owned by such stars as Jimmy Stewart and Rogers in the 1930s. Rogers, 86, was on hand ``to lend historic perspective to the day,'' said Tom Winfrey, spokesman for the city's airport department. The actor starred in movies from the 1920s through the 1940s, including ``Wings,'' a silent film that won the first Academy Award for best picture. Roger recalled that his wife of 40 years, actress Mary Pickford, dedicated the original hangar.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Holding Up Renaming of Board Members Pending Probe
DOC.TEXT: A federal finance agency is holding up the reappointment of its regional board members pending an examination of conflict-of-interest charges leveled by a member of Congress. Steve Britt, executive director of the Federal Housing Finance Board, said Thursday that the agency is requiring additional financial disclosure documents from members of the 12 regional Home Loan Banks, which help finance the savings and loan industry. In the meantime, a hold has been put on routine reappointments to the regional boards, he said. The agency's action was disclosed on the same day that Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., complained about what he said were conflicts of interest of a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka. Richard H. Hughes did not fully repay loans from thrifts under his purview, Schumer said. A Dallas business executive, Hughes served on the board of the Topeka bank from 1979 until he was replaced Dec. 13 because he had moved from the bank's district. During his tenure, he received ``multiple loans totaling $6 million from five different thrift institutions within the Topeka region,'' Schumer said in a letter to Daniel F. Evans, chairman of the federal agency overseeing the Topeka bank and 11 other similar institutions. ``Mr. Hughes' case is a perfect example of what happens when the fox is assigned to guard the chicken coop'' and ``epitomizes the inherent potential for conflict of interest that fueled the ongoing thrift crisis,'' Schumer said in a statement. Schumer, chairman of the House Budget task force on urgent fiscal issues and a member of the House Banking Committee, released a statement on Hughes along with the letter to Evans and a report by his staff on the alleged conflicts. Hughes didn't immediately return telephone messages left at his Dallas-based business, Hinderliter Corp. His home telephone number is unlisted. The 12 regional home loan banks raise money by issuing quasi-government bonds and uses it to provide low-cost loans to S&Ls. The Topeka bank covers institutions in Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska and Oklahoma. Until August 1989, government regulators responsible for examining and supervising S&Ls worked for the regional banks. With the passage of the S&L bailout law, those regulators were reassigned to the Office of Thrift Supervision, an arm of the Treasury Department. Britt said the finance board was still examining whether to take action against Hughes or whether the matter was under the jurisdiction of the thrift office. Schumer wrote to Evans that the congressional staff report on Hughes ``is simply shocking.'' He said he will push for the adoption of stringent conflict-of-interest regulations, not just for all directors and officials of the Federal Home Loan Banks, but for officials and directors of banks and S&Ls as well. The staff report said ``throughout 1987 and 1988, Mr. Hughes had delinquent loans outstanding at five thrift institutions in the Topeka district which totaled in excess of $6 million.'' ``The current status of these loans is not available ... but an estimated loss to the FSLIC (Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp.) in the amount of $2.8 million existed with respect to three loans'' at Mid-America Savings and Loan Association in Tulsa, Okla., the report said. It also cited what it called potential conflicts of interest involving Hughes' attempts to acquire two S&Ls while serving on the regional board. They are Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association of Claremore, Okla., and Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hutchinson, Kan. And, the report said, in August 1986 Hughes obtained employment for a business associate, Thomas Sherman, as Tulsa branch manager at American Federal Savings and Loan Association of Andarko, Okla. Sherman quit after board members of the S&L, then under government management, found him doing unrelated work for Hughes. Schumer also criticized Hughes for moving last year to Dallas, which is outside the Topeka district, without informing the Topeka board.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Schools Chief Wants On-Campus Condom Giveaways
DOC.TEXT: They'll still need their parents' permission for field trips, but teen-agers in the nation's largest school system could get condoms next year simply by asking. Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez believes it's a matter of life - or death from AIDS. New York City is home to about 3 percent of the nation's 13- to 21-year-olds, but it has 20 percent of all AIDS cases in that age group. ``We are sitting on a time bomb,'' Fernandez said. If the Board of Education approves Fernandez's proposal next month, condoms would be available on request as early as next spring at 120 schools that enroll 261,000 students. It would be the nation's most liberal public school AIDS policy, said Robin Lewis, spokeswoman for the Center for Population Options, a teen education and advocacy group based in Washington. A public hearing will be held Jan. 16. Since October, outspoken opponents and supporters lined up at board meetings to establish battle lines. ``Chancellor Fernandez is showing an enormous amount of courage and leadership in tackling this issue,'' said Trish Moylan Torruella, education director of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. ``There are alarmingly high rates of HIV among adolescents in New York City, particularly among African Americans and Hispanics.'' Opponents, like Monsignor John Woolsey, a Roman Catholic leader of the 75-member Coalition of Concerned Clergy, say doling out condoms at schools would endorse promiscuity. Eleanor Kelly, a mother of three teen-agers and past president of the conservative group Parent Roundtable, agrees: ``A contraceptive approach ... sends the wrong message and promotes a false sense of security, thereby encouraging more of our young people to engage in high-risk behavior.'' Fernandez said he's sensitive to the moral dilemma, but the issue goes beyond sex. ``I don't disregard, offhand, their point of view as it being a moral issue,'' said Fernandez. ``I'm saying that from my perspective, with my chancellor's hat on, I'm looking at some very horrendous and frightening data that deals with kids living or not living.'' The plan calls for trained volunteers to give away condoms at each public high school. Counseling or parental permission would not be required. Fernandez says that would scare kids away. Fernandez said new AIDS and sex education programs will continue to stress that abstinence is the only guaranteed method of avoiding the sexual transmission of AIDS. But he says adults must be realistic. The city Health Department estimates 80 percent of the New York's young people have had sex by age 19. ``I wish I could stand up in front of my students and tell them `abstain' and have the assurances that by teaching that, that would happen,'' he said. ``But it's not happening.'' The city Health Department says that as of September, 28 percent of the AIDS patients in the city, or about 4,200 people, were ages 20 to 29. Many contracted it as teen-agers. A Gallup poll for New York Newsday showed 60 percent of New York adults approved of the condom plan. Among parents of children in public schools, 54 percent approved and 39 percent disapproved. Elsewhere, students can get condoms at high school health clinics in Chicago, Baltimore and at the Cambridge Rindge and Latin School clinic in Massachusetts. In Mill Valley, Calif., a lawsuit from opponents stalled efforts to distribute condoms. In October, a school board in Easton, Md., rejected a plan for nurses to distribute condoms at two high schools. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta says 56 percent of high school students nationwide have had sex and about 20 percent had four or more partners. It estimates that 1 in every 200 people ages 15 to 24 has the AIDS virus. Other sexually transmitted diseases are rampant in that age group, and 1 million pregnancies a year ``result from the very same behavior,'' said Dr. Lloyd Kolbe, head of the AIDS school health education branch of the CDC. ``Each community needs to address its unique nature and concerns and make decisions based on epidemiology as well as ... values,'' said Kolbe. ``On both sides of the argument, people really are looking to do the best thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Santa Arrives By C-130 in Far North Indian Village
LaserPhoto AG1
DOC.TEXT: On a C-130 Hercules transport plane headed north across the Arctic Circle, Air Force Sgt. Carl Warrings donned his Santa suit and started practicing his ``Ho, ho, ho.'' A half-hour later, he and 1,500 pounds of Christmas presents - including a community washing machine - were lowered onto the frozen tundra outside this Gwich'in Indian village. A few dozen small children, bundled in furs and snowsuits, waited with their parents. It was 45 degrees below zero - warmer than it's been here all month. ``This is good. Usually when Santa comes it's really cold,'' said Kias Peter, the village's traditional chief. The kids flocked around Santa when he appeared out of the belly of the green plane. Ol' Saint Nick then stepped on the back of a dog sled and was pulled the mile or so into town by snowmobile. It was the 24th straight year the Air Force brought gifts, goodwill and Santa Claus from Elmendorf Air Force Base in Anchorage to the 125 residents of Arctic Village. The village is 500 miles north of Anchorage and more than 100 miles north of the Arctic Circle. In return, the village threw its annual potlatch feast to welcome the plane. Caribou stew, salted caribou dumplings, whitefish and other local delicacies were spread out on a table inside the village school. ``We fixed up chairs and tables and put up decorations,'' said 9-year-old Annie James. ``I'm so happy that Santa came.'' ``The whole village participates - men, women, children, everyone,'' said Margaret Tritt, the school cook who supervised the dinner for more than 100 people on Dec. 10. The children sang songs in Gwich'in and English and gave the visitors gifts, from ceremonial leather boots to drawings. The Air Force put on a magic show, and then Santa handed out 54 individually marked presents for the children. He also brought the washing machine and fixings for a Christmas feast. Annie got a toy piano keyboard and sang ``Silent Night'' with it. Her friend Crystal Frank, 8, got two cassettes by New Kids on the Block, her favorite singing group. Five-year-old Rocky John got a jacket. Everybody got candy. Parents had sent their children's Christmas wish lists to Elmendorf, where the 17th Tactical Airlift Squadron organizes the annual visit with help from the Officer's Wives Club. This year Santa's gifts to Arctic Village cost about $2,000, most of it raised at a chili cook-off last fall, said 1st Lt. Robert Allen, the C-130's pilot. The Air Force's Santa trip to Arctic Village began in 1967, when the caribou herds the village depends on migrated too far away. Village leaders wrote Alaska's congressional delegation for help and the Air Force airlifted local hunters closer to their prey, Peter said. The December flight quickly became a holiday ritual in the Episcopalian village. This year was the first that Santa's dog sled was pulled into the village by snowmobile instead of dogs, said Edward Sam, whose dogs have done the honors in years past. This year, he said, he didn't exercise them in time. The Gwich'in are an Athabaskan Indian group, the northernmost known Indians, Sam said. ``We're a little isolated from the modern life. But we get TV that tells us everything - news about the troubled world. And visits like this are nice,'' Sam said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Mounting Effort to Eliminate Lead Poisoning
DOC.TEXT: The federal government, in one of the largest efforts of its kind, is developing a three-pronged effort to wipe out lead poisoning among children. The initiative will involve removing lead-based paint from millions of homes, with a focus on lower-income families. Monitoring lead hazards in homes where children have high levels of lead in their blood and offering nutritional guidance as well as treatment are proposed. And tighter drinking water standards and a ban on lead plumbing fixtures may be adopted. ``This is saying we can eliminate this disease. We don't need children being poisoned by lead in the United States,'' said Dr. Sue Binder, chief of the lead poisoning prevention branch in the Centers for Disease Control. The initiative will require close cooperation among all levels of government and the private sector. ``It will require society-wide effort,'' Binder said in an interview Thursday. The plans may be the largest effort designed to eliminate an environmental disease, she said. But so far, the CDC's recommendations represent only a strategic plan. ``We still need to think through the things we need to do and the details of how to do them,'' she said. CDC's plans are being circulated among top officials at the Department of Health and Human Services. The Environmental Protection Agency also has not announced its plans, but the Department of Housing and Urban Development laid out its plans last week. Lead poisoning can damage the nervous system and lead to mental retardation and other mental disorders. It also can damage the liver, lead to paralysis of the arms and legs and cause convulsions. The effects cannot be reversed. Children are most susceptible because their nervous systems are still developing and are sensitive to lead, Binder said. Their bodes also absorb more lead than adults do, and they are exposed to higher levels of lead because they so often put things, including dirty hands, in their mouths, she said. The HUD plan focuses on removing lead-based paint from homes or covering it over so it is no longer a health threat. The plan includes a financial assistance program and is designed to help lower-income families with children. A HUD study found that young children are living in about 3.8 million U.S. homes that have peeling lead-based paint or lead in household dust. Financial details of the plan will be disclosed as part of the federal budget for next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, 1991. The Health and Human Services' plan is expected to be out in a few months, Binder said. Not all of the details of the plan have been worked out, she said, but it is based on an advisory committee's recommendation for more aggressive monitoring, testing and treatment. Current guidelines say steps - ranging from nutritional education to medical treatment - should be taken when lead in the blood reaches 25 micrograms per deciliter. The advisory committee said intervention should begin when levels of 10 micrograms per deciliter are reached. Different levels of monitoring and testing were recommended for levels up to 25 micrograms, at which point medical treatment should be considered, according to the committee's guidance. ``The committee is saying that environmental intervention, nutritional information and education (about lead poisoning) need to start at lower levels'' of lead in the blood, Binder said. An estimated 250,000 children had lead levels above 25 micrograms in 1984, she said. The EPA is considering tightening federal standards for lead in drinking water and prohibiting the use of lead in plumbing fixtures like brass faucets. Agency sources said a decision would be made early next year. The EPA also is considering banning the disposal of lead batteries in conventional garbage dumps.

DOC.HEAD: FBI: Gunman Wanted to Kill Bush, Send Planes to Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: A man who went on a shooting rampage at a military base said he wanted to kill President Bush and send planes to Saudi Arabia because he disagreed with Bush's actions against Iraq, the FBI said. Robert Craig Anderson, 41, was arrested Wednesday night outside Moffett Naval Air Station. He had driven his car through the base's front gate, taken an air traffic controller hostage and fired more than a dozen shots from a rifle before being caught as he tried to flee, the FBI said. Interviewed later in a hospital by FBI agent John Zent, Anderson said he planned to kill the controller and other Moffett personnel, take over the base ``and dispatch planes to Saudi Arabia as he disagreed with President Bush's present actions concerning Iraq,'' Zent said in an affidavit. Anderson also told Zent ``his intention (was) to kill President Bush,'' the affidavit said. Anderson, a bricklayer from Mountain View, is being held for psychiatric evaluation and waived his right to an attorney, the FBI said. The affidavit did not specify Anderson's disagreements with Bush's actions. It was presented to U.S. Magistrate Patricia Trumbull who ordered Anderson held without bail. Anderson faces seven charges, including assault with intent to commit murder, kidnapping, making a threat against the president, destruction of government property and carrying an illegal firearm. The felony assault and kidnap charges carry a maximum life sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Pig Wars Pit a Kibbutz Against the Rabbis
DOC.TEXT: Mizraa looks like the ultimate kibbutz success story, until you read the small print on the sausages, liverwurst and frankfurters. ``Not of kosher type,'' say the wrappers on many of the products that come out of Mizraa's meat-processing plant. It's the kibbutzniks' way of telling customers that the food contains pork. Now a law is before Parliament that would outlaw the marketing of pork to the Jewish public. The result is an escalation of the long, rancorous war between the secular public and the Orthodox Jewish parties which can make and break Israeli governments. Orthodox Jews revile pork as the most flagrantly non-kosher item on the list of edibles banned by biblical edict. Nonetheless, it is widely available from butchers and restaurants which cater to the secular public. But it's a dish that dares not speak its name, appearing instead under such euphemisms as ``special meat'' or ``white meat.'' So why wait until now to take action? ``We weren't conscious until now of how much it was spreading,'' says Rabbi Menachem Porush, whose Agudat Israel party is sponsoring the anti-pork law. ``The truth is, I don't even know what the thing looks like.'' The ultra-modern meat plant at Mizraa in the Jezreel Valley in southern Galilee earns $15 million a year - 70 percent of the kibbutz's income. Mizraa doesn't breed pigs, but it is Israel's largest source of non-kosher meat, accounting for one-fifth of the industry and exporting its delicacies all over the world. It provides a living for thousands of people at the factory in the Jezreel Valley, the pig farms owned by both Jews and Christians and Mizraa's nationwide chain of more than 300 delis. Moshe Lapidot, Mizraa's chief accountant, says that beyond the money, a principle is at stake. ``We, as secular, free people living in a democratic country, can't accept a small ultra-Orthodox minority trying to dictate ... fanatical religious laws whose time has passed,'' he said over coffee in Mizraa's vast, abundantly stocked deli. The pig law is part of the religious legislation which Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir promised as the price of adding Agudat Israel's four parliamentary seats to his coalition. But it has become a test case of how far the rabbis can enforce religious law. Already, compromises are in the air. Agudat Israel is now prepared to allow pork to be marketed in municipal districts with a Christian population of more than 500 or 1,000. At first, the religious camp refused to consider compensating those who stand to lose income. Rabbi Avraham Ravitz of the ultra-Orthodox Torah Flag party likens it to compensating pimps for income they would lose if prostitution were outlawed. But this week the parliamentary committee was stopped in its tracks by a message from Agriculture Minister Raphael Eitan, who insisted on discussing compensation. Shamir faces a tough choice. The compensation bill could top $500 million, a fortune Israel cannot afford. But if the law is stalled, he could lose Agudat Israel's vital support. The kibbutzniks are fighting back with demonstrations and bumper stickers. Three Mizraa men were arrested recently on suspicion of burning tires in the Orthodox town of Bnei Brak - a protest tactic copied from Palestinian activists in the occupied territories. Such incidents illustrate a widening rift between the kibbutzniks, who regard themselves as the vanguard of secular Zionism, and the Orthodox, who regard themselves as defenders of the Jewish heritage. Last March a prominent Orthodox sage, Rabbi Eliezer Schach, outraged the secular public by declaring: ``There are kibbutzim that don't know what Yom Kippur is or the Sabbath ... and they raise rabbits and pigs. Do they have any links with their forefathers?'' Yom Kippur is the Jewish day of atonement. Mizraa kibbutznik Hadas Sandorowicz says her own forefathers, who helped build Mizraa on Jezreel's swamps, would be horrified to find the law being dictated by ``four non-Zionist fanatics who didn't raise a finger to build this country.''

DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,119.60, down 405.3 points, or 1.68 perent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Guitarist Bernard Addison Dies at 87
DOC.TEXT: Bernard Addison, a pioneer of jazz guitar who played with the greats of his generation, has died at age 87. Addison died Tuesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville, a hospital supervisor said. The cause of death was not disclosed. Addison began first on banjo, then on guitar. Nicknamed ``Bunky'' by fellow musicians, he a fixture in the rhythm sections of big bands fronted by Claude Hopkins, Louis Armstrong, Fats Waller, Fletcher Henderson, Stuff Smith and Mezz Mezzrow. He also played with an all-star roster of smaller groups and led combos of his own in long engagements at notable spots such as 52nd Street's Famous Door, the Cotton Club and the Apollo. He was known as the first to push jazz guitar forward from the confines of the rhythm section.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Wants to Resume Shooting Cats for Brain Research
DOC.TEXT: An Army neurosurgeon is pleading for permission to resume laboratory tests that involve shooting cats in the head, but animal rights activists say the research is useless and cruel. The activists are delaying important work that could reduce U.S. combat deaths in the event of war, Dr. Michael Carey said Thursday. He conducted the cat-shooting research starting in 1983, but a congressional suspension prompted by activists was imposed 13 months ago. ``An anesthetized cat that will feel no pain appears more important to a small number of Americans than does a soldier risking his life for his country,'' said Carey, a reservist now on active duty and heading for the Middle East in two weeks. During the Vietnam war, Carey was with an Army medical unit that performed surgery on 100 soldiers with brain wounds. Death rates of U.S. troops suffering from head wounds were the same in Vietnam as they were in World War II, medical experts say. Tourists see names of the dead when they look at the wall of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, but ``when I look ... I still hear a voice saying, `Help me, Doc,''' Carey said at a news conference. He said his research can help. Critics say it can't. ``How many years is it going to take for him to understand that he hasn't been helping us?'' said Dr. Neal Bernard, president of the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine. Carey's research is ``useless and cruel,'' Barnard said in an interview. Carey ``is using an old research ploy, saying ``I'm the only person with the answer,''' said Barnard. ``His work has been a tremendous waste of money.'' More than 16,000 Americans die annually from gunshot wounds to the brain and 70,000 others suffer serious head injuries from other causes. Using a $2 million Army grant, Carey worked in a lab at Louisiana State University, firing pellets into the heads of 700 anesthetized cats. The goal was to improve treatment for head injuries. Carey was investigating the use of a promising drug when his research was stopped, supporters say. The congressional ban was put in place pending a review of Carey's work by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. A newly released GAO report found the research worthwhile but expressed concern about the management of anesthesia and postoperative care. The GAO concluded the Army should decide whether continuing the research will ``produce additional useful information.'' The Army plans to make that decision soon, said Chuck Deasy, a spokesman for the service's medical research and development command at Fort Detrick, Md.

DOC.HEAD: 1789 Morals Law May Bar Condom Sales on Campus, College President Says
With PM-Condoms-Schools, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The president of Quincy College says he'll use a 201-year-old state morals law to try to keep students from buying condoms on his campus. ``There's a legal question in my mind as to whether condoms are permitted on campus or not, given the responsibility of teachers and administrators to teach chastity,'' President O. Clayton Johnson said. A local schools committee of nurses, teachers and parents has recommended that condoms be distributed on the junior college campus, part of the Quincy school system. Johnson, who says he is morally opposed to providing condoms on campus, added that a law adopted in 1789 also may make distribution illegal. The law orders college presidents to teach such virtues as ``universal benevolence, sobriety, industry and frugality.'' ``I would reject selling them at the college, and then I would ask for a legal opinion whether I have the right to do so,'' he said Tuesday. Peter Chisholm, a spokesman for the state Regents of Higher Education, said the law is out of date. Philip Johnston, the state human services secretary, has recommended that Massachussets high schools distribute condoms to students to fight the spread of AIDS. ``This is a life and death issue and it's something that must be taken seriously by educators and health care professionals,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Acquits Jeweler in Slaying of Two Fleeing Robbers
DOC.TEXT: A jury acquitted a jeweler of charges he went too far in fatally shooting two robbers who had fled his store. After two days of deliberations, jurors late Thursday found Varhag Babayan, 28, innocent of one count of second-degree murder, two counts of voluntary manslaughter and one count of reckless endangerment in the June 16 deaths of Donald Shelton, 33, and Steve Powell, 37, both of Washington. Prosecutors had asked jurors to consider convicting Babayan of voluntary manslaughter in the death of Powell, an amputee who used crutches, if they rejected the second-degree murder charge. Babayan could have been sentenced to up to 45 years in prison if convicted on all counts. Both men were shot several times, each at least once in the back, outside Prestige Jewelers in nearby Bethesda, Md., according to testimony by Ann Dixon, a state medical examiner. During closing statements, prosecutor Robert Dean told jurors Babayan used excessive force in firing his .38 caliber handgun. Defense attorney Edward Genn said although the killings were regrettable, Babayan was defending himself and his livelihood. Babayan testified he believed his actions were justified. He told jurors he reacted instinctively when he chased Shelton and shot him and Powell in a car in the middle of a busy street after the two took the contents of two showcases from his store. ``I knew I had to do something,'' he said. ``I was not going to allow him to get away.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``It's not clear, necessarily, what the response of the Congress would be.'' - Rep. Anthony C. Beilenson, D-Calif., on what would happen if President Bush asked for a declaration of war against Iraq. --- ``It never hurts to build in a little uncertainty about what our intentions are as it relates to Jan. 15.'' - White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater on Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller's statement that U.S. ground forces will not be fully combat ready by the U.N. deadline. --- ``I really believe in the deepest part of my conviction that God does not desire this kind of destruction.'' - Presiding Episcopal Bishop Edmond L. Browning urging Bush not to resort to war to get Iraq out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Military Threatens to Shoot Down Drug-Running Planes
DOC.TEXT: The military is threatening to shoot down airplanes suspected of carrying semi-processed coca leaf, the raw material of cocaine. A communique Thursday from the military joint command said airplanes that refuse to land for inspection or that change their route without notice will be ``captured and-or destroyed.'' The communique said the measure went into effect Tuesday in San Martin department, where the main coca leaf-growing area in Peru - the Upper Huallaga Valley - is located. Dozens of illegal airstrips are scattered in the valley's dense jungle. The communique did not say how the airplanes would be tracked. The military is not known to operate any radar stations in the department. The threat represented what would be the air force's first move toward taking part in anti-drug efforts. Peru is the world's main source of coca leaf. The semi-processed coca leaf is flown mainly to Colombia, to the north, where it is refined into pure cocaine. The U.S. Embassy in Lima said it had no comment on the military's plan. Washington has been pressuring Peru's military to become more involved in fighting drug trafficking in the Upper Huallaga Valley. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration and Peruvian police operate an anti-drug airbase in the valley, but the helicopters that fly out of the base attack airstrips and drug laboratories. The United States offered to refurbish 20 Peruvian air force planes to use against drug traffickers, as part of a 36 million-dollar military aid agreement, but in September President Alberto Fujimori refused to sign the pact. He said at the time that more economic assistance must be tied to the military aid to successfully combat drug trafficking. Army Gen. Mario Brito, head of the department's military forces, told a Lima newspaper that three fighter planes are already stationed in Tarapoto, a jungle city 380 miles north of Lima. He said more airplanes would be moved to the area in the next few weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Testing Finds Harmful HTLV Virus Infections Low in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A relative of the AIDS virus that can cause leukemia remains rare in the United States, federal officials say. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that just 902 of 6.4 million American Red Cross blood donations in 1989 - 0.014 percent - tested positive for HTLV-I virus. The Council of Community Blood Centers, another blood-donation organization, reported a similar rate - 0.018 percent - among its 2.8 million donations from December 1988 through the end of 1989, the CDC said in its weekly research report. The Food and Drug Administration recommended in November 1988 that blood centers test all donated blood for HTLV-I, which causes a vicious form of adult leukemia. HTLV viruses are retroviruses in the same family as HIV. Like HIV, HTLV can be passed through contaminated drug needles or sexual contact. Tests for HTLV-I also turn positive in the presence of a closely related virus, HTLV-II. The second virus hasn't been positively linked to a specific disease, but since doctors usually can't be sure which HTLV virus a person has, blood donors and others testing positive should be counseled as if they had the leukemia virus, the CDC said. Researchers believe HTLV-I and II are equally common, the CDC noted. HTLV-I is common is southwestern Japan, the Caribbean, parts of sub-Saharan Africa and Central and South America. American Red Cross data indicate that HTLV infections in this country are most common among women, blacks, Hispanics and Asians. Risk factors also include intravenous drug use, sexual contact with an IV drug user, Japanese or Caribbean ancestry or sexual contact with Japanese or Caribbean people, the CDC said. Twenty percent of male blood donors infected with HTLV had a history of IV drug use, while 23 percent were born in - or had sexual contact with - someone from the Caribbean. Among female blood donors who were infected, 29 percent had sexual contact with an IV drug user and 17 percent were from the Caribbean or having sex with someone from there.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Won't Delay Implementation Of Ethics Law
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has refused to delay implementation of a new ethics law that prohibits government workers from being paid for writing articles or making speeches. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson rejected the request for a temporary restraining order, saying none of the employees had shown they would be ``irreparably harmed'' if they had to wait for the matter to be heard in court. Two public employees unions and the American Civil Liberties Union, representing 10 government workers, filed suits to prevent enforcement of the ban on honoraria, which takes effect Jan. 1. Jackson's refusal to delay implementation of the provision set the stage for the employees to file emergency appeals. Attorneys for the workers, who earn outside income by lecturing, writing freelance articles or performing religious ceremonies as ordaied clergy, argued that the law unconstitutionally restricts freedom of speech. Justice Department attorney Jeffrey S. Gutman argued that the statute does not violate the First Amendment because ``it's only payment for speech that is prohibited by the statute, not the speech itself.'' Gutman told Jackson that the law may even apply to federal employees who are paid $50 a month to sing in their church choir. He said, however, that the workers are free to continue their outside activities if the receive no compensation. He noted that a 1974 law that has never been challenged in the courts prohibits federal employees from earning more than $2,000 a year for articles, speeches and appearances. ``I find it startling this issue has not been litigated at all,'' said Jackson, who did not rule on the merits of the issue. Lawyers for the National Treasury Employees Union immediately filed a motion for a temporary emergency stay with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. Attorneys for the American Federation of Government Employees and the ACLU, which filed the companion cases, said they would do the same as soon as possible. The law was enacted in November 1989 as part of legislation that prohibited members of the House from receiving honoraria for speeches, appearances and articles. The ban does not apply to the Senate but the Office of Government Ethics says it is enforceable on virtually all federal employees, with a possible civil fine of up to $10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Hospital Staff Shortages Getting Worse
DOC.TEXT: The shortage of X-ray technicians, physical therapists and 12 other types of hospital workers worsened last year, prompting many institutions to offer higher salaries, according to a new survey. ``Hospitals have a growing concern about their ability to maintain adequate services in light of these persistent shortages,'' Barbara Bloom Kreml, human resources director of the Chicago-based American Hospital Association, said Thursday. Many hospitals reported they are boosting salaries to attract and keep workers. Some reported they are cutting patient services, Kreml said. ``One of the areas most affected is rehabilitation services because of shortages of physical therapists, occupational therapists and speech pathologists,'' she said in a statement. ``Increasing compensation costs (salaries) make it difficult for hospitals to keep costs in line.'' The association's survey of 3,706 hospitals found that vacancies were highest for physical therapists, with 16.4 percent of full-time positions unfilled in 1989, up from 15.8 percent the year before. Thirteen other occupations faced growing shortages in 1989, including certified nurse anesthetists, a field in which 10.8 percent of jobs went unfilled last year, compared with 10.2 percent the previous year, the AHA said. ``We're facing an incredible shortage,'' said Betty Colitti, spokeswoman for the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists, based in suburban Park Ridge. She said job advertisements in the group's newsletter have quadrupled over the past four years to 16 magazine-size pages from four and that the average annual salary is $58,000, with nurse anesthetists in some areas of the country making starting salaries of $98,000. Getting certification for the specialty takes a registered nurse two extra years of school and training, Colitti said, adding that more schools and programs are needed to alleviate the shortage. She said 65 percent of the anesthesia in the United States is administered by nurse anesthetists. Other occupations in which shortages worsened from 1988 to 1989, according to the survey: - Clinical perfusionists, 11.5 percent of jobs unfilled in 1989, up from 10 percent the previous year.
