Perfusionists direct and supervise the operation of heart and lung machines, physiologic monitoring instruments and related equipment used in cardiac surgical procedures. - Speech pathologists, 9.9 percent of jobs unfilled, up from 9 percent. - Nuclear medicine technologists, 8.9 percent, up from 7.7 percent. - Respiratory therapists, 8.9 percent, up from 8.8 percent. - X-ray technicians, 7.6 percent, up from 7.2 percent. - Pharmacists, 7.1 percent, up from 6.5 percent. - Pharmacist technicians, 4.1 percent, up from 4 percent. - Licensed practical nurses, 6.5 percent, up from 6.3 percent. - Social workers, 7 percent, up from 5.9 percent. - Lab technicians, 6.4 percent, up from 5.2 percent. - Medical technologists, 6 percent, up from 5.8 percent. They perform chemical, microscopic and bacteriologic lab tests and procedures to gather data for use in diagnosis and treatment of disease. - Medical records coders, 6.6 percent, up from 5.9 percent. They put codes in medical records to classify them under Medicare's pricing system. Shortages lessened in only four personnel categories - occupational therapists, ultrasound technologists, nursing aides and medical transcriptionists.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Will Need Foreign Force for Years
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: No matter what the outcome of the Persian Gulf crisis, a long-term foreign military presence will be needed to ensure stability in the region, Saudi and foreign military experts say. There are varying views about the shape of the foreign presence and how long it will have to stay, but the experts agree it will take years until the Saudi military and armies of other gulf states are able to protect their territory. Much depends on the time Saudi Arabia will need to overcome its manpower shortages and build an army large enough to eliminate the need for foreign protection. Regional security is expected to be the major issue tackled by the Gulf Cooperation Council summit that opens in Qatar Saturday. ``It has to be a robust GCC. We're going to have to cooperate on security, definitely,'' Secretary-General Abdullah Bishara of Kuwait said in a recent interview. The envisioned security arrangements will undoubtedly involve the United States in some form or other, given the need to guarantee oil supplies. U.S. Secretary of States James A. Baker III has talked of the need for a new security structure in the region once the Kuwait crisis has been settled. No one has disclosed any details yet. But the general outline appears to be for a large force, preferably Americans working under a United Nations flag, stationed around Kuwait's border. The smaller emirates will likely provide shore facilities for a large armada, much as they did during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Saudi Arabia plans to more than double the size of their armed forces over the next few years and buy up to $20 billion worth of U.S. weaponry. ``We'll build up our armed forces to the point of adequate and absolute deterrent to any aggression,'' said Prince Fahd bin Abdallah, the deputy defense minister. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, and Saudi Arabia's quick request for outside help, showed how unprepared the Saudis and their neighbors were to defend themselves despite massive spending on advanced weapon systems over the last decade. The invasion also woke the ulf states to the harsh reality that they could no longer afford the squabbling and minimal security cooperation that had characterized their relations in the past. The ruling Al-Saud family had avoided creating a large army, fearing a competing center of power. The 67,000-man regular forces and the 55,000-strong paramilitary National Guard were formed to balance each other. Military experts say the Saudis will need external military support for four to 20 years until they can properly defend their territory. Iraq boasts a military force of 1 million. Although Saudi Arabia has promised domestic Islamic conservatives that U.S. troops will leave as soon as the gulf crisis is over, future security arrangements in the gulf will undoubtedly involve the United States. Thousands of American military personnel are expected to remain in the region on ``training missions'' to help the Saudis absorb the new weapons, including about 700 M1-A1 tanks and dozens of F-15 fighter planes. More than 250,000 U.S. troops are now based in Saudi Arabia as part of the multinational force sent to the kingdom to deter Iraq. The gulf states also face a major dilemma in deciding how to curb the regional ambitions of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein if he agrees to withdraw from Kuwait. If Saddam pulls out with his military intact, Iraq will remain a major threat to Saudi Arabia and the vulnerable gulf monarchies. And unless Saddam's drive for nuclear weapons is checked and his growing arsenal of weapons eliminated, his threat will only increase. Yet if his army is destroyed, the resulting vacuum could lead to a scramble for power among other regional leaders and leave militarily weak gulf states vulnerable. ``The region can never find the same tranquility as before. There's been so much rancor, so much movement of people,'' said a Western military official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Saudis also see other potential threats. To the south, last May's merger of North and South Yemen has created a new regional force. The new Yemen republic's 10 million people outnumber Saudi Arabia's 8 million indigenous people. Yemen's backing for Saddam prompted the kingdom to expel hundreds of thousands of Yemenis who had been working in Saudi Arabia. Traditional enmity has long prevented them from marking their common border and the Saudis plan to build new military bases there. To the north, Jordan has expressed sympathy for Saddam despite its adherence to U.N. sanctions imposed after the invasion of Kuwait. While Saudi Arabia's support for the Palestinian cause has always been more financial than military, the Arab-Israeli conflict is also a major source of regional instability. ``They see themselves surrounded by enemies,'' said a Western diplomat. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Neil MacFarquhar has covered the Middle East for The Associated Press from Cyprus since 1987 and is currently on assignment in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: LIPA Wants To Dismantle Shoreham Rather Than Mothball or Entomb
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Vote scheduled 10:30 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: A state agency wants to end the saga of the Shoreham nuclear power plant by tearing down the idle reactor rather than mothballing or entombing it. The Long Island Power Authority has asked its board of trustees to approve a plan to dismantle and decontaminate the reactor at a cost of $186 million. The authority hopes to ship the reactor's radioactive parts out of state to a certified nuclear waste dump. The authority rejected two more costly options: mothballing, in which the plant would be shut down for 20 or 30 years but could be started up again; and entombment, burying the plant inside a wall. The authority's trustees were to vote on the plan today. If approved it will be submitted to the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission before the end of the year, authority chairman Richard Kessel said at a news conference Thursday. The $5.5 billion Shoreham plant, on the north shore of Long Island about 60 miles east of New York City, was completed in 1984 after 11 years of construction. It received a full operating license from the NRC but only was tested at 5 percent of capacity and never generated electricity. Gov. Mario Cuomo and Suffolk County officials opposed the plant, arguing that Long Island could not be safely evacuated if a nuclear accident occurred. In 1987, Shoreham owner Long Island Lighting Co. agreed to sell the plant to the state for $1 in return for annual rate increases for 10 years. The power authority is overseeing the shutdown. Kessel, also executive director of the state Consumer Protection Board, said that if the NRC accepts the decommissioning plan within the next nine months, the power authority could start dismantling the reactor in October and finish in late 1993. The NRC has not yet ruled on an application filed last June to transfer Shoreham's operating license from Long Island Lighting to the power authority. The commission is waiting for the authority to decide which decommissioning plan to pursue.

DOC.HEAD: New York Times Boosts Price of National Edition in Midwest, Southwest
DOC.TEXT: The price of The New York Times' national edition will go up to 75 cents in the Midwest and Southwest on Jan. 14. The Times had been charging 50 cents for daily copies of its national edition in the Midwest and 60 cents in the Southwest, spokeswoman Nancy Nielsen said Thursday. The higher price reflects the newspaper's higher production and distribution costs, she said. The price for the national edition in the Southeast was raised to 75 cents last September. It still costs 50 cents on the West Coast. The daily paper costs 50 cents in the Northeast, except in the tri-state area near New York where it is 40 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Worldwide Santa Claus Industry Thrives On Fantasy
DOC.TEXT: The old man with the white beard and the red suit meets 400,000 people a year, and most of them sit on his knee. This global gift-giver never seems to tire however, even when grown-ups bounce on his lap and ask for presents. He says hello and goodbye in any of 20 languages. ``The Japanese never ask for a present, only for peace and good health,'' Santa said. ``Although one Japanese woman did ask for a boyfriend. She was 27.'' Santa Claus, or Father Christmas, is on duty in Rovaniemi every day, even through the summer when giant mosquitoes can make life miserable north of the Arctic Circle. Finns call him Joulupukki, the Christmas goat, recalling pre-Christian days when celebrants of year-end festivities wore goat horns. Some shrewd private marketing and generous government help have turned this small-town capital of Finnish Lapland into a center for the rapidly growing Santa Claus industry in the northern hemisphere. In Canada, the post office answers more than 700,000 letters to Santa Claus, including some in Braille. Letters indicating desperate need are referred to welfare agencies. Magnus Hamsund, Norway's principle Santa, makes goodwill trips to the United States and Australia. Greenland's government is setting up a permanent Santa's workshop in Nuuk, the capital, and selling $20 Christmas packages. Profits will benefit a 388,000-square-mile wilderness park, as big as France and Germany combined. About 2,500 handicapped British children were being flown this year to a Santa village in Mora, Sweden. Less than 1 percent of Japanese are Christian and Christmas is not a holiday, but Hirocho, a small town on Hokkaidoisland, has sponsored Santa festivities for the past six years. Town spokesman Kazuhiro Doshita said Masahiko Tsugawa, an actor and toy distributor, has bought a Scottish castle to be rebuilt in Hirocho as Santa's dreamland. In 1927, a Finnish radio announcer broadcast the discovery of Santa's home on the remote Korvatunturi hill. The fantasy charmed the Finns, balancing precariously between the Soviet Union and the West and depending largely on logging to make their way in the world. Today, Santa Claus is Lapland's third most important tourist attraction after midsummer events, when the sun never sets over the arctic, and late winter skiing, when it barely rises. Thirty-five charter flights are bringing British visitors to Rovaniemi this Christmas season, including 12 one-day round trips on the supersonic Concorde. The Concorde flights cost $3,200 per person. Santa's mail service is providing computerized replies in eight languages to more than 500,000 letters with the Finnish post office paying for the stamps. Daniel Nyburg of 50 Everett Avenue, Akron, Ohio, wrote,``I will have cookies and milk for you and dog biscuits for your reindeer.'' Gift shops at Santa's village near Rovaniemi earn more than $4.7 million a year. Entrepreneurs seek to blend the commercial, the cultural and the cute. So far, they say, they have felt no effects of the Western business recession. ``We have not yet managed to spoil the spirit of Santa Claus,'' said Taina Torvela of the Santa Claus Land Finland Association, an umbrella marketing group. ``If we make this only business, it will not work. After all, people need to dream and they have forgotten how. Santa Claus can teach us.'' Lapps or Samis, as the region's aboriginal inhabitants prefer to be called, number only 6,000 of Finnish Lapland's 300,000 people. Some, traditional reindeer herders, have profited by supplying their animals to pull tourist sleighs over frozen lakes. Visitors also drink reindeer milk and eat reindeer meat fried over a log fire, helped by Finns wearing elf suits and conical hats, all in red. ``Follow that elf,'' tourists are told, on their way to stand in calf-deep snow under a pitch-black sky at 8 a.m. to watch schoolchildren dressed in white perform a dance of the forest spirits. London tile distributor Gregory Palmer brought his family to Rovaniemi telling his two sons,``Father Christmas invited us.'' ``We saw him at his home and I sat on his knee,'' said Charles, 5. After four days of Santa Claus activities, James, 2, commented, ``I want to go home.''

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Resignation is Latest Drama to Play the `Palace'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The Communist ...' to CLARIFY date and location of party surrendering leading role; picks up 5th graf, `In July...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin's Palace of Congresses resembles a grand opera house, and Eduard Shevardnadze's surprise resignation as foreign minister was the latest drama of perestroika to play the palace. The modernistic parliament building, built in the early 1960s, for years echoed with the sonorous drone of endless, colorless speeches and monotonous debate that characterized the Brezhnev era, from 1964 to 1982. But in recent years some lively things have taken place at the palace. A little over a year ago, Nobel laureate Andrei Sakharov, near his death, urged the Communist Party to give up its absolute grip on power; this year the party surrendered its leading role during a party congress here. In July, Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, hushed the congress with the announcement he was quitting the party. On Thursday, Shevardnadze took his bow, startling the Congress of People's Deputies by resigning as foreign minister, warning in an emotion-choked voice that ``dictatorship is coming.'' Shevardnadze began his address theatrically: waving a prepared text in the air and then discarding it for what he called ``the briefest and most difficult speach of my life'' - a rambling 15-minute discourse that ended with him storming from the podium stage left. As if it were intermission, the deputies then bounded out of their plush red seats and flooded the white marble foyer of the palace to offer their reviews of the performance and its meaning. Latvian deputy Nikolai Neyland said Shevardnadze had bowed to incessant criticism from hard-line deputies and others who alleged that the foreign minister was risking a repeat of Afghanistan by involving the Soviet Union in the Persian Gulf. But he said the real opposition went deeper. ``They weren't attacking Shevardnadze so much as our foreign policy,'' he said. ``They have been using the Persian Gulf as a pretext to express dissatisfaction that the Soviet Union has lost its superpower image, the Soviet Union has lost allies in Eastern Europe and we supposedly have made too many concessions on arms control.'' Roy Medvedev, a deputy and historian, said Shevardnadze had shown ``weakness'' by caving in to criticism that Soviet leaders such as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and embattled Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov have endured for months. ``If all our leaders reacted to criticism this way, Ryzhkov would long ago have hung himself, Yeltsin would have shot himself, and I don't know what fate Gorbachev would have chosen,'' Medvedev said. ``It's a step in the right direction,'' said an almost gleeful Col. Viktor Alksnis. He is the leader of the hard-line ``Soyuz'' faction in parliament and one of the two conservatives Shevardnadze had identified in the speech as the lawmakers ``with colonels' stripes'' who were persecuting him. ``It's a maneuver,'' offered the other, Col. Nikolai Petrushenko. Before too long, Gorbachev aides began to circulate - in Washington it would be called ``spin control'' - speaking to deputies and journalists to try to limit the damage that Shevardnadze had caused. The next act featured Gorbachev, who told the deputies he would not ``overdramatize'' and then played the betrayed friend, though his shock at Shevardnadze's announcement seemed genuine enough. Rizoali Odzhiev, a hulking deputy from Tadzhikistan who lost a leg in Afghanistan, savored the high drama as a welcome change from earlier years. ``I don't need to remind you what the scene was like in this hall 10 years ago,'' said Odzhiev.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Less Likely To Own Homes Now Than In 1980
With PM-Home Ownership-List
DOC.TEXT: Fewer Americans are getting to own their homes these days as households resemble less and less the traditional family image, the Census Bureau said. In a report issued Thursday, the bureau said 63.9 percent of households across the nation owned their homes in 1989, down from 65.6 percent in 1980. The report, ``Homeownership Trends in the 1980s,'' said a major factor in the decline was a drop in ownership rates for non-married couple families during the decade. Home ownership by families headed by an adult without a spouse present fell from 49.6 percent in 1982 to 46.5 percent in 1989. And that drop occurred for both sexes. Home ownership by families headed by men without a wife present fell from 59.3 percent to 55.7 percent. Home ownership by families headed by a woman with no husband dropped from 47.1 percent to 44.1 percent. A second important change was the rapid growth of non-family households during the 1980s, compared with families, reported Census demographer Robert R. Callis. Between 1980 and 1989 non-family households increased 27.2 percent nationwide to 27 million, while family households climbed just 10.6 percent to 66 million. Families are much more likely to own their own home than are non-family households, which often consist of only a single person. Thus, even though families still are the larger group, the faster growth of non-family households reduces the overall share of home owners. Callis said other reasons also were factors in the decline, including the decision by many young people to stay single longer while pursuing education or careers. Delaying marriage often means postponing home buying. The Northeast, a region of stable population, was the only region to show an increase in home ownership in the '80s, Callis noted, rising from 60.8 percent to 62 percent of households. Home ownership fell from 69.8 percent to 67.7 percent in the Midwest; dipped from 68.7 percent to 65.9 percent in the South and fell from 60 percent to 57.8 percent in the West. Here is a state by state list of the percentage of households that owned their own homes in 1989 and 1984. (Data for individual states were not available prior to 1984).

DOC.HEAD: Nation Spends More On Health Care
DOC.TEXT: Health care spending in the United States rose to a record of more than $604 billion last year, federal officials reported. The amount spent in 1989 added up to roughly $2,400 for every man, woman and child. ``The ability of society to meet other needs is affected by the growing share of economic resources claimed by health expenditures,'' Gail Wilensky, chief of the Health Care Financing Administration, said in releasing the new data Thursday. Health spending in 1989 accounted for 11.6 percent of gross national product, the total of all goods and services produced, and was 11.1 percent higher than it was in 1988. The gross national product rose 6.7 percent over the same period. The share of GNP also was a record. As recently as 1985, the share was 10.5 percent. Federal spending on health programs in 1989 amounted to 14.7 percent of the total federal budget of about $1.1 trillion, up from 14.1 percent of the previous year's budget. Of the total spent on health care last year, 33 percent was paid by private insurance, 21 percent came from the pockets of consumers, 17 percent was paid by Medicare and 10 percent was paid by federal-state Medicaid programs. Other government programs put in 15 percent and other private sources, 4 percent, according to the financing administration's figures. The agency plans to publish a more detailed account of health spending next month.
DOC.HEAD: Saudis Charged Premium Rate For Mail To U.S. Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service was unable to convince Saudi Arabia's national airline to waive international mail rates in favor of the lower fees observed by U.S. carrier for carrying mail to American troops in the Saudi desert, a postal official said. James E. Orlando, head of international services for the Postal Service, confirmed that Saudi Arabian Airlines had charged the service nearly $1.9 million to deliver about 1.05 million pounds of mail addressed to Desert Shield troops from Sept. 1 to Oct. 17. Rep. Benjamin Gilman, R-N.Y., had cited those figures in a letter of protest to the Saudi ambassador and the postmaster general, saying that was too much to pay. Orlando said the was reasonable in that it complied with the rates set by the Universal Postal Union, an international organization of postal administrators. But he noted the Saudis had declined a Postal Service request that the airline instead observe the mail-rate schedule set by the Department of Transportation for U.S.-flagged carriers. The UPU rates are about 2 1/2 times higher than the U.S. rates. Gilman, ranking Republican on the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, recommended in his letter that the Postal Service ``work with the Department of Defense and the State Department to ensure that Saudi Airlines absorb these mail expenses.'' Orlando said that ``the whole issue that Congressman Gilman had, which is whether we should be paying that rate level to the Saudi government in view of the fact that we're over there defending them, as far as I'm concerned is a legitimate issue for the Congress and the administration, but not for the Postal Service.''
DOC.HEAD: Boschwitz Appeal Pays Off for Former Homeless Worker
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Rudy Boschwitz's appeal to colleagues to hire one of his employees has paid off for the woman, who was homeless when he hired her two years ago. Valerie Gaines, a 36-year-old typist, accepted a job Wednesday with Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., one of about 20 lawmakers who responded this week to Boschwitz's letter. ``My Christmas is really full,'' said Gaines, who became an overnight celebrity in Washington in 1989 after Boschwitz hired her. Boschwitz, who was defeated for re-election, leaves office next month. Gaines had had just two job interviews prior to Boschwitz's appeal. ``Valerie hasn't found a new job ... and we need to place her quickly to avoid another debilitating bout with homelessness,'' the lawmaker wrote. The woman's husband has been disabled by two strokes and cannot work, she said. The couple has two daughters, ages 6 and 8. Gaines worked for then-Sen. Lawton Chiles, D-Fla., for two years but lost her job when he retired in 1988. During the three weeks she was jobless along with her husband, their landlord evicted them and their belongings were stolen. Boschwitz's staff hired Gaines not knowing that the address she gave was that of a homeless shelter. She now lives in an apartment in suburban Maryland.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-age White Supremacists Sentenced in Black Man's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Two white supremacist ``skinheads'' who shot a black man at random then laughed as he lay dying have been sentenced to life in prison. Matthew Faessel, 19, and Michael Stringer, 18, convicted of first-degree murder last October, were sentenced Thursday in the Dec. 10, 1988, slaying of Tony Montgomery. They received life terms for killing Montgomery and 18 years for conspiracy to commit murder and shooting into an occupied building. District Judge Robert Schouweiler ordered that the sentences be served consecutively. Faessel and Stringer will be eligible for parole in 26 years. Faessel blamed the killing on alcohol and drug abuse and apologized to Montgomery's family. ``I hope they feel justice has been served,'' he said. Angela Stanley testified that she drove Faessel and Stringer around Reno in search of a black person to kill after the two became enraged when a woan at a party attended by other neo-Nazi skinheads said she once had been raped by a black man. She testified that as she drove past Montgomery, Stringer rolled down a window and Faessel fired the fatal shot from the back seat. She said the two laughed as Montgomery lay dying in the front yard of his sister's home. Stanley, 18, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder and was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: 90-Year-Old Triplets Go for Longevity Record
DOC.TEXT: The Mauss triplets were so tiny at birth 90 years ago that they spent their first few hours in a makeshift incubator - their father's shoebox placed in the warming oven of a coal stove. Maybe it was that odd start in Murray, Utah, on Oct. 16, 1900, that instilled in Vinal, Velma and Vilda Mauss the sense of humor they believe is a key to their near-record longevity. ``Vinal sounds the same as vinyl, but I came first,'' Vinal said Thursday. ``My sisters always had a lot of fun together,'' he said. ``They liked to confuse their teachers by switching seats. I had no trouble telling them apart, but my father sometimes got them mixed up.'' Mauss' son-in-law, LeGrande ``Eli'' Eliason, said when the triplets get together ``it's like a circus.'' ``They love to laugh and tell jokes,'' he said. The trio is still going strong, says Vinal Mauss, as they approach the Guinness Book of Records' mark for oldest triplets. The Massachusetts-born Caughlin triplets - Faith, Hope and Charity - were 93 in 1962 when the first died. ``We are trying to beat that if we can,'' said Vinal, a hardy, dapper man who looks 20 years younger than he is and still works several hours a day as owner of a newspaper distribution business in Walnut Creek, 25 miles east of San Francisco. Vinal, the oldest of the triplets by 10 minutes, weighed only 3 pounds at birth. His kid sisters were 2{ pounds each. But there weren't any real incubators in Murray, Utah, then, so Vinal said their doctor put them in their father's padded shoebox and placed it in the coal stove's warming oven. The three aren't quite sure how they got their unusual names. Family legend has it a friend of their mother heard the names somewhere, and in the excitement or exhaustion of having triplets their parents agreed to them. Believed to be the first surviving triplets in the Western United States, they were curiosities who drew crowds when they were displayed in a booth behind ropes at a Utah state fair in 1907. ``They sold pictures of us for 25 cents each,'' Mauss said. They stayed close over the years, and wrote each other often when Mauss served as a Mormon missionary in Japan from 1922 to 1924 and head of the mission there from 1949 to 1953. The sisters, who live near each other in Midvale, Utah, near Salt Lake City, stay in close touch with their brother. Mauss, a former bishop of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, worked at one time or another as a real estate broker, insurance salesman and funeral director before getting into newspaper distribution. He also played semipro baseball in Salt Lake City and basketball on a Mormon missionary team. He claims to be a man of no vices, but not for lack of trying. He sampled coffee once, but couldn't stand the taste. A cigar made him sick. A glass of whiskey made him throw up. But he doesn't sound at all like a man who has missed anything. ``My only regret is that I didn't get a higher education,'' he said. ``I hoped at one time to be a doctor. I finished high school and had one year of college - night school at Berkeley. ``But I've enjoyed my life. I'm still enjoying it.''

DOC.HEAD: Amtrak Engineers Suspended Without Pay
DOC.TEXT: The two Amtrak engineers involved in the Dec. 12 train crash in Boston have been suspended without pay pending an investigation, and a signal near the crash site has been changed. An ``all clear'' track signal near Boston's Back Bay Station has been changed to require inbound trains to brake to 30 mph, Amtrak spokeswoman Sue Martin said Thursday. A control system will automatically stop trains that are not slowed, she said. Amtrak said in a statement that engineer trainee Richard Abramson 41, of Trumbull, Conn., and chief engineer Willis Copeland, 53, of Bethany, Conn., would be ``removed from engine service.'' But Martin said the suspension was from all duties without pay until the investigation is completed. ``This is a pretty routine procedure,'' Martin said. ``Any time that we suspect that an employee or employees may have contributed to an accident, then they're routinely suspended pending an investigation. This does not mean that they're guilty.'' The new yellow and green signal was installed just west of Ruggles Station, about a mile and a quarter from Back Bay Station, Martin said. The signal was previously green-only, permitting the engineer to reach the maximum legal speed of 100 mph. ``We've basically taken a step that will add an extra layer of protection,'' Martin said. If the engineer does not apply enough brake pressure to slow down after passing the signal, an automatic control system will brake the train and bring it to a complete stop, Martin said. Amtrak also said it was telling its employees that only federal authorities can remove train recorders that monitor speed and braking. Amtrak officials inadvertently prevented a clear reading of the tape by recording on it an electronic tone to mark the last five miles of the trip, federal investigators have said. The Night Owl, traveling at more than twice the speed limit, derailed and slammed into a crowded commuter train, injuring 267 people. The probe, Amtrak said, is focusing on ``what, if any, responsibility they (the engineers) may have had in the cause of the derailment.'' The National Transportation Safety Board also is investigating. The NTSB is focusing on whether the engineers were negligent in their operation of the train or whether, as the engineers maintain, the locomotive brakes were malfunctioning. The Night Owl was traveling at 110 mph at some point in the mile-and-one-fifth stretch of track before Back Bay Station, according to ``black box'' data retrieved from a tape in the locomotive's cab. The maximum speed up to a point about a half mile from the station was 100 mph. Near the station, the speed limit was 30 mph. When the 10-car train derailed along a curve, it was traveling 77 mph, more than twice the speed limit. A review of the information taken from the data recorder showed that the engineers applied the brakes at least once before the crash, the NTSB said. If the investigation finds that Copeland and Abramson were not responsible for the accident, they will return to work and their back pay will be restored, Martin said. Both engineers were hospitalized as a result of the accident. Copeland was released from Boston City Hospital on Dec. 17. According to Martin, he was transferred to a hospital in New Haven. Boston City would not confirm the transfer. Abramson was released from St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Boston Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Guam Hit Hard by Typhoon Russ
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Russ raked Guam today with wind up to 135 mph and pummeled the U.S. territory's southern coast with huge waves that caused severe flooding. No serious injuries or deaths were reported, but power and water service were disrupted in many areas and police reported some looting, Ken Booth of Guam Cable TV said. The storm was the strongest to hit this western Pacific island in more than a decade. Its eye moved within 15 miles of Guam's southern coast early today, and wind hit 135 mph in the south and 90 mph with gusts of 115 mph in central and northern areas, said Lt. Diane Edson of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Fifteen minor injuries and no deaths were reported, Booth said. ``It was quite a blow, but not as bad as had been expected,'' he said. Gov. Joseph Ada said about 500 families in the southern town of Agat were displaced, Booth reported. About 2,500 people sought shelter during the storm. Power and water service remained down in many areas, and officials said it would be three days before full power was restored, according to Booth. Booth said police reported looting in some areas. The duty-free store in the central town of Tumon reported being robbed of $250,000 in Rolex watches and an undetermined amount of other jewelry. There were reports of looting in other areas as well. No arrests were made. Waves cresting as high as 24 feet caused severe flooding in southern Guam, uncovering corpses in the cemetery in the town of Inarajan, Booth said. Several large concrete utility poles installed after the last major typhoon, Pamela in 1976, snapped in half from the force of the waves, Booth said. Russ damaged or destroyed only the few wooden homes remaining on the island. Concrete structures built after Pamela escaped serious damage. Ada said he planned to ask for federal disaster relief assistance. Booth said the capital of Agana looked like a ``war zone,'' with trees, traffic lights, poles and signs strewn about and flooding everywhere. The storm center was out to sea and headed toward the Philippines with sustained winds of 145 mph and gusts of 175 mph, Edson said. It was moving at 15 mph, but was expected to weaken before it reached the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Evacuation Drills Under Way
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: More than 1 million Iraqis fled their homes in the capital today in a major evacuation drill to test the population's readiness in the event of war in the Persian Gulf. The civil defense exercise got under way on schedule at 7 a.m. with air raid sirens blaring across the eastern part of Baghdad, which is divided by the Tigris river. The drill was expected to involve nearly 2 million people. But residents said nearly half stayed home. Iraqi preparations for war have increased since the U.N. Security Council late last month authorized military force to drive the Iraqi army from Kuwait if it does not leave the conquered emirate by Jan. 15. With the first siren today, families began pouring into the streets, some ran to civil defense centers set up by the government and others jumped into their cars and sped away. Hundreds of buses waiting at the civil defense centers took evacuees to points about 10 miles to the north, east and south of the city. The evacuees carried blankets, food and personal documents. The drill was expected to last all day. On Thursday, Basra, Iraq's second-largest city and the closest to the border with occupied Kuwait, was evacuated in a similar exercise. Residents there, said almost the entire population of 1 million people participated in that drill. Among other war preparations in the past couple of weeks, there have been instructions to build bomb shelters throughout the capital, and courses in civil defense and first-aid are being pushed by the government. Government officials have been instructing the population in public announcements to leave their houses carefully locked during the evacuation drills. Police cars were to patrol the city to protect private property. Businesses and all government offices were closed today, the Moslem sabbath, so the exercise did not affect commerce. On Saturday, the western part of the city is to be evacuated in similar drills. The population, also about 2 million, will be moved north, west and south of the city. Government offices also were expected to be closed on Saturday for the drills.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iraqi Missile Test Catches U.S. By Surprise
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi test firing of three medium-range missiles took U.S. military officials by surprise, a newspaper reported today. Preparations and the first launch of the Dec. 2 test were complete before American satellites and sensors monitoring the tense Persian Gulf region noticed it, even though U.S. officials had thought they could detect any Iraqi fueling and prelaunch programs. the Los Angeles Times reported. ``We had no advance warning,'' said an unidentified administration official quoted by the Times. Iraq had warned commercial airliners to keep out of its airspace before the test, but gave no reason. The warning prompted Israel and U.S. officials to prepare their air forces to respond to an attack, the newspaper said. ``A lot of people were in their cockpits ready to go,'' the Times quoted one official as saying. The official said Joseph C. Wilson IV, the chief U.S. diplomat in Baghdad, received a telephone cll from the State Department in Washington after the first missile was fired. The call reportedly informed him that ``the balloon is going up - this is no drill.'' Later, officials reported the launch was a test. The Times said the missiles were launched from a site near Basra, in southeastern Iraq, and traveled more than 400 miles west toward Israel, landing in a remote part of the Iraqi desert. If they had been fired southward, they could have hit U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, and if launched from western Iraq they could have hit Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, the newspaper said. U.S. officials said the missiles were fired from an area that was not being monitored, but Seth Carus of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy said it was odd that Basra wouldn't be under surveillance because short-range missiles could be launched at U.S. troops from there. Hundreds of thousands of U.S. troops have been sent to the Persian Gulf since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Praise Shevardnadze, Lament His Resignation
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The closer their countries to the Soviet Union, the more worried leaders seemed to be by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation. One exception was the hard-line Communist government of China, whose Foreign Ministry would say only that Shevardnadze's dramatic announcement Thursday was ``an internal affair of the Soviet Union. We will continue to develop friendly neighbor relations with the Soviet Union.'' Elsewhere, the announced resignation of the man who helped Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev end the Cold War provoked apprehensions about the future of the Soviet Union and its leader. Gorbachev said Shevardnadze agreed to stay on until a successor is chosen. Germany, fearing that failure of the Soviet president's reforms could endanger East European stability, was especially nervous about Shevardnadze's resignation announcement. ``We can only hope that the reforms are carried out. They are good for the Soviet Union and they are good for the relationship between our people and for developments in Europe,'' said German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Germans credit the Soviets, in particular Gorbachev and his foreign minister, with clearing the way for eastern Europe's sweeping reforms and German unification. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the German foreign minister, said he is confident of final Soviet approval of the treaty guaranteeing German sovereignty, despite the resignation of one of Moscow's leading reformers. Genscher and Roland Dumas, the French foreign minister, urgently appealed for an international effort to bolster Gorbachev's reform program with financial aid. Dumas said he hoped Shevardnadze's ``cry of alarm'' would be heard. ``It will serve as a warning to Western countries and others who are dragging their feet over aid which must be given,'' he said. Dumas said Shevardnadze had privately shared with him his concerns about the future of the Soviet Union but noted ``this is the first time that he says it publicly.'' The foreign ministers of the 12-nation European Community, which recently pledged $2.8 billion in aid to the Soviets, received Shevardnadze's ``with regret.'' A statement said the EC nations ``express their firmest hope that the resignation ... will not entail changes in Soviet policy which might call into question the significant results thus far achieved in international relations ... in the direction of disarmament and peace.'' In Poland, which has a 700-mile border with the Soviet Union, Foreign Minister Krzysztof Subiszewski said the internal situation there can ``in many respects ... cause anxiety.'' ``The decision of Eduard Shevardnadze can be treated as a warning. Internal policy, especially that of a superpower, finds reflection in foreign policy,'' he said. The prime minister of Soviet Lithuania, Kazimiera Prunskiene, told a news conference in Tokyo today that her independence-minded republic is alarmed by Shevardnadze's resignation. She said it may mean that progress achieved by the pro-perestroika forces is being turned back by conservative forces, including sections of the Communist Party and the military. ``His resignation may lead to a situation that is unfavorable for Lithuanian independence,'' she said. There was a worldwide outpouring of praise for Shevardnadze, a welcome guest in many capitals. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar told reporters: ``On a personal basis, I regret this. He is a personal friend and he was very supportive of the United Nations.'' Vatican Radio hailed Shevardnadze as the ``great architect of the Soviet diplomacy that contributed to ending the Cold War.'' Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said he was ``really surprised by the sudden announcement. I would like to watch the situation calmly.'' Australian Foreign Minister Gareth Evans said today that Shevardnadze's resignation raises matters of ``immediate worry'' for Gorbachev's leadership. ``The optimistic view is that it could act as a warning shot to galvanize the reformers, there does seem to be at least an attempt by Mr. Shevardnadze to do just that by the style and the forecefulness of his resignation speech,'' Evans said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III called the outgoing minister his friend, but said Gorbachev had assured him that Soviet foreign policy would continue on course. American Gen. John R. Galvin, NATO's military commander in Europe, said bluntly: ``The Soviets certainly face a bleak winter. I hope what we're hearing now doesn't make it any worse.'' ``All of us in the West want to see the Soviet people continue on a track that will lead to full democracy, free enterprise and respect for human rights,'' Galvin said. ``But this has to be done in a way that maintains order without sacrificing democratic principles.''

DOC.HEAD: New Plume of Steam, Ash from Mount St. Helens
DOC.TEXT: A giant ash plume belched from Mount St. Helens, but scientists said it didn't appear to portend a new eruption of molten rock. Wind carred the ash toward Portland, Ore., 53 miles to the southwest, prompting United Airlines to cancel 21 flights in and out of that city Thursday night. Normal service was to resume this morning, United customer service supervisor Fred Von Pegert said. Port of Portland spokesman Darrel Buttice said the airport remained open Thursday night and the 11 other airlines were flying. The 8,366-foot mountain blew a column of light gray ash and steam 23,000 feet into the air Thursday afternoon, about 30 minutes after a small explosion occurred on the lava dome in the volcano's crater, said Michael Doukas, a U.S. Geological Survey geologist at its Cascade Volcano Observatory in Vancouver. Doukas said it was similar to the latest volcanic ``burp,'' on Nov. 5, when a plume of steam and ash rose 30,000 feet into the sky. Similar bursts occurred last December and January. Doukas said those bursts are significant only in underscoring that Mount St. Helens remains an active volcano. Scientists have theorized such bursts come from either gases bubbling out of solution in molten rock beneath the mountain, or from rain and snowmelt percolating down to hot areas and bursting into steam. The volcano's last significant eruption was on March 19, 1982, when mud flowed from the crater six miles to the north fork of the Toutle River. Since then, the mountain has had a series of ``dome-building'' eruptions in which the mountain quietly adds lava to the heap in its crater. The last of those was in October 1986. The mountain's cataclysmic May 18, 1980, eruption killed 57 people and blew off the top 1,300 feet of the once-symmetrical peak, a lava dome dating to about the 16th century.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Company Helps Japanese Shout Away Woes of 1990
DOC.TEXT: A group of Japanese have abandoned their usual reserve to shout away the frustrations of 1990 in a contest sponsored by an American cough drop company. ``If YOU want a war, YOU go!'' screamed Yoshihiko Kato, the 36-year-old father of three who won the contest with a ear-blasting 115.8 decibel bellow - louder than a passing train. ``President Hussein, please pay my gasoline bill!'' roared Yoshihiro Yamanashi, 30. ``I want a girlfriend. I'll do anything to get one!'' wailed Takeshi Oohashi, 23, who said he has never had a girlfriend. Te self-employed Kato, who said he probably primed his vocal cords shouting at his children, won the 100,000 yen ($740) grand prize of the 10th Annual Halls Year-End Loud Voice Contest Thursday. The Adams Confectionary Products Division of Warner-Lambert KK, the contest organizers, asked contestants to shout their feelings about what happened in 1990 in keeping with the Japanese custom of ``toshi wasure,'' or forgetting the past year. Adams manufactures Hall's cough drops and all contestants received a package of the lozenges to soothe their throats after the contest. The company challenged the shouters to top a ringing telephone (70 decibels) or, if possible, damage a few eardrums (150 decibels). Decibel readings on a sound meter, facial expressions and gestures all counted. Kato's scream registered 115.8 decibels, more than 15 percent louder than the roar of a train passing overhead on an elevated railroad. Kato didn't explain what he meant by his yell. Some thought it was directed against the Japanese government, which heeded strong opposition and dropped a proposal to send troops for non-combat roles with multinational forces deployed against Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was the target of several of the 54 contestants, watched by a few hundred chuckling shoppers during lunch hour at a Tokyo shopping center. Hiroshi Okawa, 32, a company employee, pocketed the $225 second prize with the 114.2-decibel plea, ``The day after a typhoon I crashed my car and I want the money to get it repaired!'' Kazuo Kazama, 28 and unemployed, won the $150 third prize with a cheer for his favorite race horse: ``Go Oguri.'' In a ``unique'' category, with a $150 prize, Miyako Shimizu, a 53-year-old art teacher, won with the help of a picture she had painted of the popular bride of Emperor Akihito's second son, Prince Akishino. She screeched, ``I want to give this picture to Princess Kiko!'' The men's ``unique'' prize went to Shigeru Uchida, a 35-year-old government employee, who yelled, ``7,7,7!'' his lucky numbers from pachinko, the Japanese pinball game.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Against Corrective Surgery for Boy Whose Religion Forbids It
DOC.TEXT: A Southeast Asian boy shouldn't be forced to have surgery because his family's fear of arousing angry spirits would do him more harm than skipping operations to fix his clubfeet, a judge ruled. Superior Court Judge Lawrence J. O'Neill ruled Thursday the potential psychological and physical harm to Kou Xiong, a 7-year-old Hmong refugee, outweighs efforts to correct the clubfoot condition that doctors say could leave him unable to walk. O'Neill, who had ordered the surgery 10 months ago, said he reversed himself Thursday because psychiatrist David A. Fox said the trauma of going against traditional Hmong religious beliefs could kill Kou and others in his family. Fox, a psychiatrist at Valley Children's Hospital in this central California city of 350,000, spoke with a Hmong shaman in studying Kou's case. ``The system clearly has done the best it can for this child and family,'' O'Neill said. ``The child's family must now do what is best for themselves.'' Kou's parents, Ger and Houa Vue Xiong, oppose surgery because they believe spirits gave their son clubfeet as punishment for a wrong committed by an ancestor. They believe Kou's younger brothers were born with cleft palates because he received care for his feet at a Thailand refugee camp after the family fled the mountains of Laos. Kou, who was carried into court by his father Thursday, walked with a halting gait during a previous court appearance. ``I think the judge or everybody has to know more about people before making a judgment,'' Ger Xiong said through an interpreter after O'Neill announced his ruling. ``They have to respect ... respect the people. We are different.'' A reclusive hill people from northern Laos, many Hmongs had little contact with the outside world before joining a U.S.-supported campaign against communist insurgents in the early 1970s. When Laos' pro-U.S. government fell, thousands of Hmongs fled to the United States. ``This operation was seen by the family as having long-term effects which could cause them disease and financial disaster,'' said the family's lawyer, Joe Reich. If the surgery had been forced on Kou, Reich said, the family would have rejected him and welfare officials could not have placed him with another Hmong family. All 18 Hmong clans in the United States had supported the family's opposition to surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Criticizes U.N. Security Council Resolution on Palestinians
With PM-UN-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today dismissed as meager a U.N. Security Council resolution deploring Israel's plans to deport Palestinians and calling for monitoring of the safety of Arabs under occupation. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz told the official Iraqi News Agency that the resolution ``highlighted the double standards applied by the United States and imposed on the Security Council, which has turned into a tool manipulated by the United States.'' Iraq has proposed a settlement of its 4-month-old invasion and occupation of Kuwait linked to an Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab territories. Washington and its allies in the Persian Gulf standoff rejected the linkage. In his statement, monitored in Nicosia, Aziz said: ``After weeks of shameful maneuvering, the council adopted a meager resolution on one of the most dangerous issues from which the region and the entire world has suffered for many years. ``A more meager statement was issued by that council, binding the Zionist entity (Israel) to absolutely nothing. All that compared to 12 arbitrary resolutions adopted in the past four months by the same council against Iraq,'' he said. President Bush's policy, Aziz said, is designed to protect only ``Bush's partners and his agents among the corrupt oil sheiks for whom he sheds crocodile tears.'' The Security Council vote on the resolution had been postponed several times in recent weeks as Washington sought a text that would not be interpreted as a concession to Iraq. While U.S. approval of the resolution Thursday was a break from traditional American support of Israel, a veto would have jeopardized the international coalition arrayed against Iraq. Washington agreed to the text only after a paragraph endorsing an international Mideast conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict was removed. A call for a properly timed and structured international conference on the 42-year-old conflict was contained in a non-binding Council statement.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Gold Drops
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose against other major currencies in early trading today. Gold fell. Dealers said the dollar was helped by uncertainty over the political future of the Soviet Union after Thursday's resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. The dollar is seen as a safe haven currency in times of turmoil. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.12 yen to a closing 135.70 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 135.55 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.5125 German marks, up from 1.4997 -1.3015 Swiss francs, up from 1.2880 -5.1418 French francs, up from 5.1035 -1.7005 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6920 -1,139.50 Italian lire, up from 1,132.25 -1.1595 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1593 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9035, compared with $1.9080 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $383.25 per ounce at midmorning, from $385.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $383.25, down from $385.00 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 32 cents to close at a bid $382.30. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.16 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.18.

DOC.HEAD: Chilled Milk? Dairy Farmers Try to Keep Cows From Udderly Freezing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Steevens is cq.
DOC.TEXT: To beat the lack of heat, some dairy farmers are using cow brassieres and hair dryers to keep their animals from udderly freezing. ``You've got to try to keep a cold cow comfortable, or you're going to lose a lot of milk production,'' said Barry Steevens, a University of Missouri dairy specialist. Today's forecast called for more cold weather, with highs around zero. Some Missouri farmers use nylon mesh udder supports on animals that calved recently and have udders swollen with milk, Steevens said. Others use hair dryers and towels to keep moisture off the animals. Dairy farmers are better prepared than last year, when a surprise Christmas Eve deep freeze brought temperatures of 20 degrees below zero, chilled further by 24 mph winds, he said. ``It was pure hell,'' Steevens said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow and Rain Greet First Day of Winter
DOC.TEXT: Severe cold remained locked over much of the country, bringing snow and high winds while rain was widespread elsewhere today, the first official day of winter. Snow fell from the Great Lakes to the California coast, where a rare flurry dusted seaside Monterey. Temperatures ranged from the 80s in southern Florida and Texas to a wind-chilled 80 below zero in Montana. Freezing rain, thunderstorms and possible tornadoes were forecast for several states in the South and Mississippi Valley region. Winter storm warnings and advisories were posted throughout the Rockies, northern Plains and the West. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 89 degrees at McAllen, Texas. Other reports at 6 a.m. EST: -East: Albany, N.Y. 37 cloudy; Atlanta 43 drizzle; Boston 40 cloudy; Buffalo 46; Charleston, S.C. 52 foggy; Chattanooga 48 foggy; Cincinnati 53 foggy; Cleveland 47 rain; Detroit 44 foggy; Hatteras 66 rain; Jacksonville 61 foggy; Key West 76 fair; Knoxville 47 partly cloudy; Macon 47 drizzle; Miami 74 partly cloudy; New York 48 cloudy; Philadelphia 47 rain; Pittsburgh 43 rain; Portland, Maine 27 partly cloudy; Richmond 45 rain; Tampa 68 fair; Washington, D.C. 44 drizzle. -Central: Birmingham 52 foggy; Bismarck 16 windy; Chicago 46 foggy; Denver 18 snow; Des Moines 00 snow; Fort Worth 34; Indianapolis 51 drizzle; Kansas City 03 snow; Little Rock 61 cloudy; Louisville 58 foggy; Memphis 67 windy; Nashville 54 rain; New Orleans 71 partly cloudy; North Platte 13 snow; Oklahoma City 12 snow; Omaha 06 windy; Rapid City 17 snow; St. Louis 36 rain; Minneapolis/St. Paul 02 cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 34 foggy; San Antonio 70 foggy. -West: Albuquerque 28 cloudy; Anchorage 30 cloudy; Boise 09 snow; Casper 34 snow; Fairbanks 23 snow; Great Falls 30 partly cloudy; Honolulu 74 partly cloudy; Las Vegas 25 fair; Los Angeles 45 fair; Medford 04 fair; Pendleton 14 fair; Phoenix 43 partly cloudy; Portland, Ore. 14 fair; Reno 04 snow; Salt Lake City 05 fair; San Diego 48 windy; San Francisco 33 fair; Seattle 13 fair; Spokane 02 fair. -International: Calgary 19 fair; Montreal 10 cloudy; Ottawa 10 partly cloudy; Regina 37 fog; Toronto 39 cloudy; Winnipeg 23 fair; Mexico City 52; Acapulco 77 fair; Kingston 77; San Juan 76.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Upholds Chamorro Veto, Accepts Smaller Army Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly early today sustained President Violeta Chamorro's veto of a bill that would have drastically cut the already slashed budget of the Sandinista-controlled military. Mrs. Chamorro has said deeper cuts in spending for the military, a stronghold of the leftist Sandinistas she succeeded in April, could push the country into ``chaos and a bloodbath.'' The Sandinistas have staged crippling strikes against the conservative government's moves to dismantle the socialist economy and institute market-oriented reform. The vote today followed weeks of bickering that had placed Mrs. Chamorro in the position of fending off the conservative deputies she is technically allied with, while defending her adversaries, the Sandinistas. After debate that lasted until 3 a.m. today, legislators voted 69-21 to sustain Mrs. Chamorro's veto. The 51 deputies of Mrs. Chamorro's National Opposition Union, or UNO, had voted unanimously last week to shave $19.6 million from her proposed $78.6 million budget for the army - less than half the budget the military had requested. But 29 members of the coalition, plus one independent deputy, today joined the 39 Sandinista deputies in the 92-member assembly in sustaining the veto after Mrs. Chamorro agreed to cut only $8.5 million from her earlier defense budget proposal. One deputy did not vote. She also agreed to name a civilian defense minister by 1993. The defense job has been held by Gen. Humberto Ortega, brother of former President Daniel Ortega, who Mrs. Chamorro succeeded in April. UNO leaders want Mrs. Chamorro to sack Gen. Ortega and the issue was one of the grievances listed by former Contra rebels who have rioted, attacked police stations and blocked roads in recent months. Mrs. Chamorro has decided to keep Gen. Ortega as defense minister, said deputy Luis Humberto Guzman, head of the budget committee that considered the defense vote. ``She said Humberto Ortega is the only man who has the moral authority and the capability to effect the reductions'' in the army without creating a backlash from angry Sandinistas, Guzman said. The Sandinistas, who ruled the country from 1979 until their defeat in last February's elections, still command a mass movement capable of bringing the country to its knees with strikes. They also have most of the guns and bullets. But Mrs. Chamorro also agreed to reduce the armed forces, now numbering 28,434 troops, to about 16,000 over the coming years, Guzman said. The military had 100,000 men and women under arms when she came to power April 25. Once the largest force in Central America, the Sandinista People's Army is now the fourth biggest, after those of El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala. The army's budget was $190 million this year, the last budget the Sandinista government approved, and military officials presented a 1991 budget proposal of $160 million. Mrs. Chamorro chopped it to $78.6 million, and it fell to $70 million under her agreement with conservative deputies.

DOC.HEAD: Protest March Marks U.S. Invasion Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 people, including backers of ousted Gen. Manuel Noriega and relatives of people killed by American bombs, marched through the capital dressed in black to mark one year since the U.S. invasion. The marchers shouted anti-government slogans and burned a U.S. flag during the four-hour, five-mile march that began Thursday in the downtown business district and ended in Chorrillo, the neighborhood where Noriega's headquarters were located. Heavy U.S. bombing of the area caused most of the civilian deaths and left more than a thousand homeless. The government, which was installed after the invasion, said Dec. 20 could be neither a holiday nor a day of mourning. ``It was an invasion and no Panamanian likes to see his country invaded, with the consequences of deaths and injuries,'' said Foreign Minister Julio Linares. ``Neither can we say it is a day of national mourning because it liberated us from dictatorship,'' he said. He called the date one of ``national reflection.'' ``Those who should reflect are the accomplices of the intervention,'' responded Isabel Corro, spokeswoman for the Association of Families of Martyrs of the North American Invasion of Panama. ``They took power at the cost of thousands of disappeared and fallen,'' she said. President Guillermo Endara, who won May 1989 elections only to have the results nullified by Noriega, was sworn in shortly after the invasion began. The Panamanian Human Rights Committee has increased its casualty figures from the invasion over the past week even as the U.S. Army Southern Command revised its death toll downward. The rights group, which had said 385 died in the invasion, now claims 403 people were killed or disappeared. It gave no reason for the change. The Army, which had recorded 314 military and 202 civilian deaths, now says 345 died, including U.S. and Panamanian soldiers and civilian. The invasion left 1,243 families homeless. Of those 596 remain at a refugee shelter awaiting housing. As the march passed a prison in Chorrillo, guards fired guns into the air to quiet a disturbance by inmates, authorities said. Marchers dispersed, then regrouped to burn a U.S. flag. ``We burned it because they burned our relatives that way the day of the invasion,'' said a Chorillo resident who asked not to be identified. Most Panamanians initially were exhuberant over the end of 21 years of military rule and the overthrow of Noriega, who is jailed in Miami awaiting trial on drug charges. But Endara's support has been weakening and the U.S. military's continued role irritates nationalists. About 10,000 U.S. soldiers are based in Panama to provide security for the Panama Canal. At Endara's request, American troops put down a Dec. 5 police revolt that Endara described as a coup attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stocks Fall, Dollar Higher
DOC.TEXT: News of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignatio sent the Tokyo stock market tumbling today while strengthening the dollar against the Japanese yen. Stock traders said Shevardnadze's surprise announcement shook the stock market with worries about domestic turmoil in the Soviet Union. The market also was rocked by rumors, later denied, that Iraq is planning to pull its troops out of Kuwait, they said. ``Since yesterday, there was also a technical correction,'' said Haruo Ueno, manager of stock trading at Wako Securities. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which shed 351.84 points Thursday, lost 405.34 more points, or 1.6 percent, to close at 24,119.06. Trading was moderate at 350 million shares. Market declines in London, New York and West Germany and the weakening yen also discouraged traders, said Shigeru Akiba, head of equity trading for UBS Philips and Drew International. ``Basically, sentiment is not so good,'' he said. Currency traders also said the market reacted mostly to worries about stability in the Soviet Union. Political worries tend to strengthen the dollar, which is often seen as a safe currency in times of turmoil. The dollar closed at 135.70 yen, up 1.12 yen from Thursday's close of 134.58 yen. Trading ranged between 135.20 yen and 136.35 yen. Except for transactions by companies, such as exporters, with specialized foreign exchange needs, the approaching holiday chased many participants out of the market temporarily, traders said. ``Today, there were not so many market participants, so the dollar fluctuated a lot,'' said Tadashi Sazaki, assistant general manager of the foreign exchange and international treasury division at the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Also today, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said that although the economy shows some signs of slowdown, inflationary pressures are still strong because of effects of higher oil prices and the tight labor market. He said the government is planning no change in monetary policy for now. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 86.92 points as of 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST) from Thursday's 87.97-point close. Their yield stood at 7.115 percent, up from 7.075 percent Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Precede UNITED NATIONS
Israel Accuses U.S. of Weakness Over U.N. Resolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Israeli and Iraqi reaction to resolution
DOC.TEXT: Israel's foreign minister said today the United States showed weakness by catering to Arab desires for a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel, but Iraq dismissed the measure as ``meager.'' The resolution, approved by a 15-0 vote in the council Thursday, urges Israel to halt deportation of Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza and calls on the United Nations to monitor the safety of Palestinians there. U.S. backing for the resolution was seen as an effort to preserve the Arab coalition against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. It was the third time in two months that Washington has failed to exercise its veto powers to shield Israel. Although the resoultion referred to land occupied by Israel since 1967 as ``Palestinian territories,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering kept out language linking the Palestinian issue to efforts to resolve the gulf crisis. Saddam has consistently tried to link efforts to resolve both issues. Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said today that the United States had succumbed to Arab pressure. ``There is a weakness among the Americans that is brought about by America's dependency on the anti-Saddam coalition and by the American obsession that if it is objective and stands by Israel, the coalition is liable to be weakened,'' Levy told Israel army radio. But he praised the Americans for keeping out of the resolution any mention of an international peace conference that would deal with all disputes in the Middle East, including the Arab-Israeli conflict. Such a conference, opposed by Israel as biased toward the Jewish state, is only cited in a non-binding addendum to the resolution. For their part, Palestinian and Iraqi officials claimed that the resolution was too weak. The vote ``highlighted the double standards applied by the United States and imposed on the Security Council, which has turned into a tool manipulated by the United States,'' said Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. ``After weeks of shameful maneuvering, the council adopted a meager resolution on one of the most dangerous issues from which the region and the entire world has suffered for many years,'' he said. His statement was monitored in Nicosia. Palestinian officials also complained that the measure did not do enough to protect residents of the Israeli-held territories, because it did not mention the international conference and failed to provide specific steps for protecting Palestinians. But the resolution was the first step in a ``linkage'' between Iraq's occupation of Kuwait and Israeli rule in the territories, they claimed. ``The linkage between the two problems is that all the U.N. resolutions must be respected,'' said Jamal Tarifi, a pro-PLO lawyer from Gaza. Israel deported four leaders of a fundamentalist Palestinian group last week, the latest of 60 deportations during the three-year Palestinian uprising. Israeli officials had halted the practice for more than a year, however, partly because of strong U.S. complaints. The resolution urges U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to use existing personnel in the region to monitor the safety of Palestinians. Two U.N. organizations operate in the region. One is the Truce Supervision Organization, which oversees the truce between Israel and Arab states. The second is the Relief and Works Agency, which provides medical care, education and other relief to 900,000 Palestinian refugees in the West Bank and Gaza. Pickering told the council the two U.N. agencies have ``separate and well-defined mandates. No activity should be undertaken that would alter these mandates ... and we would oppose any attempt to alter them.'' Since the United States holds a veto in the Security Council, it would be impossible for either the relief or truce agency to begin officially monitoring the Palestinians. Nevertheless, some staffers from the relief agency already act as unofficial monitors in the occupied lands, rushing to trouble spots to prevent or report on human rights abuses by Israeli soldiers. The U.N. relief agency has complained about frequent harassment, arrests and beatings of employees, most of whom are Palestinians. Israel claims the U.N. teams' monitoring is politically motivated to weaken Israeli control and increase international control.

DOC.HEAD: Disillusionment on Anniversary of Romanian Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Romanians today marked the first anniversary of their pro-democracy revolution by holding demonstrations against the government that replaced the fallen Communist dictatorship. About 10,000 people gathered in Bucharest's University Square, chanting slogans against President Ion Iliescu. In the western city of Timisoara, birthplace of the violent revolt that drove Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu from power, 15,000 workers held the latest protest in more than a week of anti-government demonstrations. Protesters chanted ``Down with Iliescu'' at University Square. The square was ringed with blue police vans, but authorities did not interfere with the demonstration. During last year's revolution, protesters in the square took on the police and the army on Dec. 21 and some of them were killed. The next day, hundreds of thousands rallied in the streets of Bucharest, forcing Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, to flee. They were captured by the army and tried and executed Dec. 25. The square has since been the site of repeated anti-government protests, some ending in violent clashes with police. The two weeks leading up to the revolution's anniversary have been marked by strikes and protests of the governing National Salvation Front. The Front has lost popularity since introducing economic reforms, including price increases designed to introduce a market economy. In an address to Parliament today, President Iliescu accused government critics of ``a systematic attempt to distort the intentions of the revolution to their own intersts.'' He said the Front, which won May elections and has ruled since the revolution, must press ahead with planned economic reforms, despite growing opposition throughout the country. More than 100,000 students and hundreds of professors are estimated to be on strike nationwide. There have been isolated strikes by truck drivers, teachers, medical workers and others in various parts of the country. A strike by navigators at the state airline, Tarom, has paralyzed all internal flights and stranded many international travelers in Romania. In Timisoara, the site of clashes on that preceded the revolution, 75,000 workers from most of the town's industries have been on strike for a week. At a rally of 15,000 workers Thursday, Claudio Iordache, vice president of the National Salvation Front, announced his resignation after being booed from the speaker's balcony on Opera Square. Iliescu told Parliament that 1991 would be ``a decisive year for all our reforms.'' He said, ``We must prove we are ready for a ... democracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Negligence by City, Former Yankee, Caused Dancer's Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A jury has ruled that both the city and former New York Yankee infielder Andre Robertson were responsible for a 1983 car crash in which a former ballerina was paralyzed. After the Thursday verdict, State Supreme Court Justice Ira Gammerman instructed the jurors to return today to determine how much money Shanikwa Dawn Nowlin should get for her injuries and future costs of medicine, medical equipment and health care. Nowlin, who at 14 had been the youngest member of the Dance Theatre of Harlem, is seeking a total of $20 million. The jury found that the city was 67 percent responsible for the crash because of improper placement of a warning sign of an upcoming curve on the West Side Highway. The panel found that Robertson was 33 percent responsible because he exceeded the 40 mph speed limit as he entered the curve. The accident broke Nowlin's back and left her paralyzed from the waist down. Nowlin, now 31 and a Dallas lawyer, testified that Robertson was traveling about 65 mph, but taxicab driver Charles Stone testified that he witnessed the former shortstop's 1983 Buick Riviera swaying and swerving at 80 mph. In the courtroom in her wheelchair, she said she was happy the jury found in her favor. Lawyers for the city had suggested that Nowlin was negligent for not telling Robertson to slow down. In testifying about the accident, Nowlin recalled: ``All of a sudden I heard Andre scream. He pushed on the brakes real hard and the car crashed to the left. Then it jerked to the right. We hit the wall on the other side and my back just snapped.'' The day of the crash, she said, was the last fun day she had. Robertson, 33, who left baseball in 1989, testified last week at the trial. He now works in a steam generating plant in Orange, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Shakes Balkans, One Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with at least 15 injured, aftershocks reported, quake also felt in Romania, school classes interrupted in southern Yugoslavia. Pickup 10th pvs, `Northern Greece...'
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake early today shook Greece, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Romania, killing one person, injuring at least 15 people and damaging buildings, authorities said. The Salonica Seismological Institute said the temblor measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and was centered in the village of Goumenisa, about 35 miles northwest of the Aegean coastal city of Salonica. The spokesman, Vasillis Papazachos, said the temblor was followed by several smaller aftershocks. Pat Jorgenson of the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif., said the quake measured 6.1 on the Richter scale. It was also felt in Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Romania, news reports said. A police spokesman in the Greek town of Edessa, 20 miles west of the epicenter, said a 60-year-old woman was killed there. ``She was crushed when a wall collapsed on her. The rest of the house remained standing,'' said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said 10 people were treated and released from Edessa hospital, while two others remained hospitalized. Many houses in Edessa suffered minor damage, and two apartment buildings were near collapse, said the spokesman. A police spokesman at regional headquarters in Salonica said three people suffered slight injuries in Goumenisa and three houses collapsed. He said telephone communications with the town were disrupted. He said the temblor ``was felt throughout northern Greece and lasted about 20 seconds. People here in Salonica were rushing out of their buildings in panic.'' The quake caused minor injuries and damaged houses in southern Yugoslavia, the Tanjug news agency reported. The quake forced the interruption of classes at schools in the southern Yugoslav republic of Macedonia, Tanjug said. No injuries or damage were reported in Bulgaria and Romania. Northern Greece is a seismologically active region. An earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale struck Salonica in 1978, killing 40 people. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A magnitude 5 quake can cause considerable damage, while a 6 reading can cause severe damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Indiana Shotgun Slayings Bring Fear, Boost Gun Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf: `That was ... ' to CORRECT that Toll Road collector not fatally shot. Balovski and Baloski as brothers cq in 5th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GRY1
DOC.TEXT: A rash of seven shotgun killings is scaring people into carrying guns or staying indoors at night as police try to nab the killer before another attack. Gun sales are skyrocketing in the largely blue-collar area of northwest Indiana after the slayings within a 20-mile radius since late October. At Jack's Gun Shop in Burns Harbor sales of firearms and ammunition have jumped fivefold since last week, owner Jack Batz said Thursday. ``We saw a big increase because people realize these are senseless killings,'' Batz said. The latest victims were brothers Ilija ``Eli'' Balovski and George Baloski, who were killed with shotgun blasts to the head in their Gary tailor shop Tuesday. The store is just down the street from a pawn shop where owner Robert Ribicki has armed himself. ``Life's too damn precious for this kind of junk,'' said Ribicki, who carried a .38 Colt revolver strapped at his waist just under his jacket. ``I just hope they catch this guy, I don't care if they blow him away.'' Police believe the killings were carried out by the same gunman. They were looking for a man described as white and between 20 and 35 years old, Portage police Sgt. Warren E. Lewis said. ``We have evidence to tie all the shootings together. We have several suspects at this time,'' Lewis said. ``I can't say that we are close to an arrest.'' He declined to discuss the evidence, but sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said shell casings from the latest killings match those from earlier slayings. A special police unit was formed to investigate the shootings that occurred in a parking lot, at gas stations, a garage, a motel, a bank and on the street. Ribicki, who sells a variety of merchandise, including shotguns, says all five people working there now carry guns. ``I've had customers come in and when they see my gun they say, `You guys finally got smart,''' he said, adding that his gun sales have tripled since the shootings began. Some people don't welcome the increase in people carrying guns. ``I can see some poor sucker getting his head blown off approaching a car to ask for directions to Burger King,'' said Willy Carbins, 40, who was waiting for his teen-age son to get off work at a gas station less than a block from the site of the latest shootings. The Gary Police Department also doubts the wisdom of fearful citizens carrying guns. ``People are always going to panic a little when something like this occurs,'' department spokesman William Burns said. In the hands of the inexperienced, guns lead to accidental injuries or thefts that put more weapons in the hands of criminals, he said. The shotgun killings began Oct. 30, when a man and a woman were gunned down and at least three other people were fired at in separate incidents in the nearby towns of Griffith, St. John and Cedar Lake. Then there was a lull broken with the Dec. 13 death of a man working at a gas station in Portage. That was followed by the slayings Saturday of a man and a woman in separate attacks in Portage and Gary, and the shooting of an Indiana Toll Road collector the same day. Some in this steel mill city on the southern shore of Lake Michigan were blase about the string of killings. ``That's not uncommon. In Gary, people go around killing each other for no reason,'' said local resident Denise Moss, 23.
