But as news and rumors about the attacks spread, people began to take precautions. ``People are just nervous, just scared and people have a reason to be,'' said Louis Ruffin, 44, who did electrical work for the slain brothers. He said he won't go outside after 10 p.m. and rarely ventures out alone after dark. ``I'm not afraid of nobody, but I know I can't do nothing with a shotgun, except get killed,'' Ruffin said. ``This has put a damper on a lot of Christmases.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Charged Premium Rate For Mail To U.S. Soldiers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS for 2nd item in a0470, PM-Washington in Brief, to correct typo in lede, restore dropped word in 4th graf, tighten wording in last 2 grafs.
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service was unable to convince Saudi Arabia's national airline to waive international mail rates in favor of the lower fees charged by U.S. carriers for carrying mail to U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf, a postal official said. James E. Orlando, head of international services for the Postal Service, said Saudi Arabian Airlines charged nearly $1.9 million to deliver about 1.05 million pounds of mail to Desert Shield troops from Sept. 1 to Oct. 17. Rep. Benjamin Gilman, R-N.Y., sent a letter of protest to the Saudi ambassador and the postmaster general, saying that was too much to pay. Orlando said the charge was reasonable in that it complied with the rates set by the Universal Postal nion, an international organization of postal administrators. But he noted the Saudis had declined a Postal Service request that the airline instead charge the rates set by the Department of Transportation for U.S. carriers. The UPU rates are about 2 1/2 times higher than the U.S. rates. Gilman recommended that the Postal Service work with the Defense and State departments ``to ensure that Saudi Airlines absorb these mail expenses.'' The congressman is the ranking Republican on the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee. Orlando said the question of whether the rates were fair given that the U.S. troops are defending Saudi Arabia was ``a legitimate issue for the Congress and the administration, but not for the Postal Service.''

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Makes Upbeat Farewells
LaserPhoto BX4
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis remained the eternal optimist in an farewell address that expressed few regrets for a volatile political career that has declined rapidly since his failed bid for the presidency. Despite two years of political troubles since he won the Democratic presidential nomination in 1988, Dukakis sounded upbeat as he said goodbye. ``I consider myself the luckiest man on the face of the earth,'' the governor said Thursday, repeating the phrase the ailing baseball legend Lou Gehrig used to bid farewell to fans in Yankee Stadium. Dukakis, 57, received a standing ovation from supporters and administration officials in the Massachusetts House, where he launched his political career. His wife, Kitty, his children and his mother joined him in the packed chamber. The three-term governor was relaxed and unsentimental, taking indirect swipes at President Bush. ``We should feel terrific. As a nation and as a people, we should be leading, both at home and abroad,'' Dukakis said. ``But we don't feel terrific, do we? On the contrary, we seem to be having a collective political nervous breakdown in this country.'' Repeating some of his campaign themes, Dukakis called for a national health care program, and warned that something must be done to pay off the national deficit. ``I made a lot of mistakes in the 1988 campaign, but few were as bad as my failure to make the case for the kind of fundamental change that we, as a nation, must seek,'' Dukakis said. The governor conceded that Massachusetts has had its share of fiscal problems. ``That doesn't mean that we here in Massachusetts can smugly point the finger at our brethren in Washington,'' Dukakis said. ``We've had more than our share of troubles over the past two years.'' The state has been plagued by financial woes since Dukakis returned from the national campaign trail, and the governor's administration has said that it will leave a deficit up to $100 million. But Dukakis said Massachusetts has tried to deal with its budget deficit. ``We've made the cuts,'' he said. ``We've done what wasn't popular. It hasn't been fun, and it hasn't been easy. But we've done it - and so must the nation if we are to provide the kind of leadership for the world and the kind of future for our people that we want for ourselves and for all mankind.'' Dukakis was first elected governor in 1975, but was defeated by Edward J. King after his first term. He came back to defeat King in 1983, and won the Democratic nomination for president in 1988. Shortly after losing the presidential race, Dukakis said he would not run for governor again. He leaves office Jan. 3, and will be replaced by Gov.-elect William Weld, the first Republican governor the state has had since the early 1970s. While his long-range plans are unclear, in January he leaves for Hawaii, where in the spring semester he will teach at the University of Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: Political Turmoil in Soviet Union Doubles Pace of Emigration
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The number of Soviet Jews immigrating to Israel has nearly doubled in recent days, reflecting new fears of political turmoil in the Soviet Union, officials said today. Israel is using every available plane to bring in Soviet immigrants from European transit points and expects as many as 6,000 to arrive between Thursday and Sunday, the officials said. In the past three days, more than 1,500 Soviet Jews have landed in Israel daily, compared to the previous daily average of about 800, said Gad Ben-Ari, a spokesman for the Jewish Agency, a quasi-governmental group that handles immigration. ``No doubt the growing wave is in part a response to the worsening situation in the Soviet Union and the debilitation of the government,'' said Jewish Agency chairman Simcha Dinitz. Apprehensions grew after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze resigned Thursday and said in his farewell speech that the Soviet Union was moving toward a dictatorship. Alexander Bronstein, 55, a chemistry professor from Moscow, said many Soviet Jews feared the liberal emigration policies of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would soon end. ``The resignation of Shevardnadze is bad for Gorbachev, bad for democracy and bad for U.S.-Soviet Union relations,'' Bronstein told reporters at Ben Gurion International Airport today. ``It is certainly possible that the gates may close.'' Yurevich Gertsovich, 50, a librarian from Minsk, said she came as soon as she could because she feared emigration would be halted. ``Nothing good has ever come out of waiting. The more you wait the worse things become. So we got out, all of us,'' said Mrs. Gertsovich, who arrived with 15 relatives. Dinitz said he hoped Shevardnadze's resignation would not affect immigration. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has said he did not think there was reason for special concern. Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu predicted that the increased pace of Soviet immigration would continue because of the political upheaval in the Soviet Union. ``If we planned for 500,000 Jews (arriving) next year, it is quite possible that with a radical change in the situation in the Soviet Union we will have to absorb twice as many in a short time,'' Netanyahu told Israel radio. Already, the pace of immigration is causing problems in Israel, including housing shortages and unemployment among the immigrants. Officials are fearful the thousands arriving also will overwhelm schools and social services. At least 160,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel in 1990. They reach transit stations in Warsaw, Budapest and Bucharest by air or overland. From the transit stations, Israeli planes, most of them from the national carrier El Al, take them to Tel Aviv. El Al spokesman Nachman Kleinman said the airline has been sending extra planes since midweek because of the great increase in the number of Soviet Jews reaching the transit points. ``They are leaving with any means they can,'' Kleinman said. For security reasons, Israel tries to get immigrants out of the transit stations and to Tel Aviv the same day. Transport Minister Moshe Katzav has issued a special permission this week to allow El Al flights to land during the Jewish Sabbath, which lasts from sundown today to sundown Saturday. El Al nornally doesn't operate during that period because Jewish law forbids work on the sabbath.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Official Questions Safety Of C5-Bs
DOC.TEXT: A retired Air Force official said cargo jets used extensively in Operation Desert Shield in Saudi Arabia have not been thoroughly inspected, a newspaper reported today. Retired Lt. Col. Lawrence B. Welborn told the Los Angeles Times that the Air Force only looked at a fraction of the Lockheed C-5B aircraft frames they later told Congress they tested for defects. A Lockheed spokesman said the plane does not have structural flaws, but said he was unfamiliar with the details of the Air Force's inspections. ``The tests previously performed by Lockheed and validated by the Air Force metallurgists established the metallurgical soundness of the C-5Bs,'' the spokesman said. Welborn said he was in charge of the inspections in 1986 at Altus Air Force Base in Oklahoma. In a sworn affidavit and in an interview with the newspaper, Welborn said that only one area of one C-5B's frame was exposed for testing on Dec. 6, 1986. Three C-5Bs were supposed to be tested. The test, he said, only took a few hours. To fully test the entire structure of the three planes would have taken several days, he said. Welborn's affidavit - taken by Claremont, Calif., attorney Herbert Hafif -was received by Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., who was on the oversight and investigations subcommittee that requested the 1986 inspections. Dingell demanded Thursday that the Defense Department investigate whether the Air Force misled Congress. Possible structural flaws were brought to the attention of Congress in 1986 by three former Lockheed employees represented by Hafif. Those employees claimed that because of a defective oven, the jet's mainframes were overheated, causing cracks and voids in the metal. After Congress' request for the inspection in 1986, Gen. Lawrence Skantze, then the Air Force's procurement chief, reported to the committee that the ``structural integrity of the 24 suspected forgings was confirmed.'' Diagrams of the test points were presented to the committee. But on Thursday, Skantze said he had no firsthand knowledge of the inspections but was assured at the time that the inspection had been completed. ``Given the gravity of the issue, I am appalled that our people would have assured me the job was done correctly, if indeed it was not done,'' he told the Times. Last month, a Los Angeles jury awarded the employees a $45.3 million award in a civil case claiming they were fired after trying to tell Lockheed management about the flaws. Lockheed has asked for a new trial.

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-One Soldiers Injured in Ethnic Clash
DOC.TEXT: A fistfight among ethnic groups in an army battalion stationed in the Ukraine escalated into a gunbattle that injured at least 21 soldiers, news reports said today. The fighting broke out Thursday among members of a railroad battalion stationed in Chop, on the Ukrainian border with Czechoslovakia, Tass said in a report based on a local newspaper and the Ukrinform news agency. ``An inter-ethnic quarrel broke out among Armenian, Azerbaijani, Chechenian, Uzbek and Turkmen soldiers, who began shooting at each other,'' the report said. The official Tass news agency, quoting the Ukrainian newspaper Robochaya Gazeta, said the fighting lasted several hours and that 21 soldiers were hospitalized ``with grave injuries,'' including nine with gunshot wounds. It said several officers were also wounded in the shootout. The independent news agency Interfax said at least 100 soldiers were involved in the clash. It said most of the injuries occurred when a guard unit accompanying an officer trying to break up the fight opened fire. ``The men of the guard squad acted efficiently in night-time conditions and shot only at the legs of attackers in order not to kill them,'' Tass said. Interfax said the military procurator in the Ukraine has ordered an investigation into the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Member Convicted on 5 Murder Counts
DOC.TEXT: A religious cult member has been convicted of murder for participating in the ritual killing of a five-member family. A Lucas County Common Pleas Court jury found Ronald Luff, 30, guilty Thursday of five counts of aggravated murder in the April 17, 1989, deaths of Dennis Avery; his wife, Cheryl; and their three daughters. Each had been bound with duct tape and shot, then pushed into a common grave inside a barn in Kirtland, about 30 miles east of Cleveland, where the cult members lived. The Averys' bodies were found in early January at the farm where Jeffrey Lundgren lived and led the cult. The jury deliberated for 7{ hours before issuing its verdict. Defense lawyer J. Ross Haffey said he expected to appeal the verdicts after a Jan. 7 hearing in which jurors decide whether Luff should be put to death. Luff had pleaded innocent by reason of insanity. Lundgren, a defrocked lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, has admitted to firing the shots that killed the family. He said scriptures told him to kill the family members because they were sinners. He has been sentenced to death. Although Lundgren killed the Averys, Luff was a willing participant, prosecutors said. Lundgren had told Luff and other cult members that the Averys had to die before the cult could go on a wilderness outing to see God. Luff has testified that he thought Lundgren was a prophet who was going to lead his family to Zion, a place where man and God could live in peace. Testimony indicated that Luff helped dig a pit and gather rocks that would be thrown on top of the Averys' bodies to keep them from rising in the barn's soft dirt.

DOC.HEAD: Saving the Earth Can Be Funny, Book Says
DOC.TEXT: The environment's ruin may be serious business, but who says you can't have a chuckle over global warming? ``50 Simple Things You Can Do to Pave the Earth'' is a spoof of the national best-seller ``50 Simple Things You Can Do to Save the Earth.'' In it, comedian Darryl Henriques suggests that it's time we uit being so glum and have fun with energy conservation. Duplicating the original book's format of nature-saving tips, ``Pave the Earth'' urges earth-minded people to save the gray water left over from laundry, baths and dishes. ``You can sell graywater to the Navy to pour around their ships to make them invisible,'' the book helpfully suggests. Under another heading, ``Pave the Earth'' says it's time Americans replace lawns with artificial turf. ``If all the water used on lawns was diverted to raising cattle, we could produce at least 10 billion more steaks per year,'' the book says. ``Would you rather mow the lawn or barbecue a steak?'' The book finds a silver lining in the greenhouse effect: ``As earth's atmosphere heats up, mangoes will soon be growing in Minnesota. Cold climate residents will no longer have to travel to the tropics.'' At the book's conclusion, Henriques says his jokes shouldn't be taken as insensitive. ``It has been demonstrated that humor can have a positive impact on disease,'' he writes, ``and it is my fervent hope that it can also help to heal the earth.''

DOC.HEAD: Canal Security Stepped Up Against Possible Iraqi Sabotage
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with measures taken against Romanian ships, UPGRADES sourcing, REORGANIZES. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Suez Canal authorities have stepped up security against a possible Iraqi attempt to scuttle a vessel in the waterway to block it, canal officials said today. The measures include assigning cement carriers to the rear of canal convoys so that if they are sunk other vessels would not be blocked. Once sunk, cement carriers are extremely difficult to clear because of the wet cement. The canal is important for oil shipping as well as for the United States and other countries massing warships in the Persian Gulf region. Because the canal carries much of Western Europe's oil, an extended blockage would hit that region's economy hard and could be almost ruinous to Egypt's. The canal annually earns more than $1.5 billion in foreign exchange for Egypt. Canal security has been tighter since Egypt condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and sent troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force deployed in the gulf region to defend against further Iraqi advances. Intelligence sources in Cairo said today the new canal measures were in line with a security upgrade ordered nationwide on strategic installations like the canal, the Aswan High Dam in southern Egypt and vital industries. Canal officials said authorities recently began careful checks of the itineraries and ownership of cement-carrying ships, particularly those coming from the Far East or the gulf region. Today, a Romanian ship carrying cement, the 38,000-ton Beius, was the last of 30 ships to transit the 101-mile long canal. It origin and destination were unclear. The canal officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Suez Canal Authority took the additional safeguard of dispatching two tugboats to follow the Romanian ship through the waterway. They said more Egyptian harbor workers and stevedores than usual have been boarding all cement-carrying ships. Such workers provide dockside and harbor services at the southern and northern ends of the canal, Suez and Port Said. In addition, they report to Egyptian intelligence on anything unusual found aboard ships. As a rule, Suez Canal Authority pilots steer ships through the waterway. Despite its value to Egypt, President Gamal Abdel Nasser in 1956 scuttled two ships carrying concrete and stones in the waterway to block it. He aimed to hurt Western economies in reprisal for a concerted military attack on Egypt by Britain, France and Israel. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened in August to punish Arab states that sided with Kuwait in the crisis. Recently, pro-Iraqi Palestinian hard-liner Mohammed Abbas extended the threat to the United States and Kuwait's other Western allies. Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, leads the Baghdad-based Palestine Liberation Front, which hijacked the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro in 1985 and killed a wheelchair-bound American passenger, Leon Klinghoffer.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Traumatized Driver Can Get Benefits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, `The lawyer ...' to UPDATE with Laidlaw Transit lawyer not returning phone calls seeking comment.
DOC.TEXT: New York's highest court has granted workers' compensation benefits to a school bus driver who suffered severe psychological problems after seeing the wreckage of a fatal car crash. The state Court of Appeals awarded the benefits Thursday to Rose Wood, who was driving a busload of kindergartners to school on April 29, 1986, when she came upon a car accident in which two teen-agers she knew were killed. In its 7-0 decision, the court said psychological pain brought on by witnessing a tragedy can be considered an accidental injury and can be subject to the same compensation as a physical injury. The court said, however, that compensation isn't necessarily due all employees who suffer mental pain after seeing an injury to someone else at work. ``What the court seems to be saying is that the closer you are to being an active participant, the more likelihood you have of winning the case,'' said Thomas Dunne, lawyer for the Workers' Compensation Board. Wood, then 50, was the first person on the accident scene and saw the mangled body of one of the victims, the court said. Wood remained at the scene until emergency help arrived and then continued on her route, the court said. Within weeks of the accident, Wood began suffering from insomnia, nightmares, anorexia, depression and chest pains, the court said. Less than two months after the accident, Wood was involved in a near-collision between her school bus, again filled with kindergarten children, and an automobile. Wood then was hospitalized and treated for stress, the court said. Wood, of Coxsackie, about 25 miles south of Albany, couldn't return to the job she'd held for 12 years. She has been out of work since and remains under treatment, said her lawyer, Brendan Quinn. Wood then sought workers' compensation benefits from her employer, Laidlaw Transit. An administrative law judge for New York's Workers' Compensation Board rejected Wood's claim to compensation for lost wages. But the full compensation board overturned that decision and awarded benefits. The bus company took the case to the Appellate Division of state Supreme Court, which dismissed the award. That court said that while Wood's disability arose in the course of her job, she technically was not involved in an accident. The Court of Appeals, however, said there was no question that Wood's psychological and emotional problems were a direct result of her job. Judge Judith Kaye said that Wood, as a school bus driver, had job responsibilities that ``distinguished her from others who might have passed on the road.'' ``Rose Wood was by virtue of her employment an active participant - more than a third party merely witnessing another's injury,'' Kaye said. ``The feeling on (Wood's) part that she should have been able to help, but couldn't, precipitated her psychological injuries.'' It's now up to the compensation board to determine how much Wood can receive in benefits, Quinn said. If she's granted full disability, she can be compensated at two-thirds of her salary for the 4{ years since the accident - about $45,000, Quinn said. The lawyer for Laidlaw Transit, Leo Hacker, did not return telephone calls to his office Thursday or early today.

DOC.HEAD: Report Shows Vicki Long Got $20,000 in Church Funds
DOC.TEXT: The Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta said it won't seek to recover more than $20,000 in church funds that went to a woman whose affair with the nation's highest-ranking black Catholic led to his resignation. An audit of the archdiocese and two parishes, conducted by a public accounting firm, revealed Thursday that about $5,835 from the individual churches went directly to Vicki Long or to her creditors to pay her rent, utilities or charge cards. The archdiocese paid $14,556 in medical expenses for Ms. Long through the summer of 1990, but the audit said no archdiocese funds went directly to her. The archdiocese initiated the audit after the resignations last summer of Archbishop Eugene Marino and the Rev. Michael Woods, a Sandy Springs priest who said he had a sexual relationship with Ms. Long. Ms. Long denied the relationship with Woods, but claimed she was married to Marino and filed a paternity suit in 1987 against another priest, the Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus. A blood test later showed Keohane did not father her daughter. Ms. Long said she was sexually exploited by Keohane and Marino, and also claimed to have been molested by a nun in Columbus. Marino, once the nation's highest-ranking black Catholic, has undergone therapy at an undisclosed location since his resignation. The audit report said money from two churches - St. Pius X Parish in Conyers and St. John the Evangelist Parish in Hapeville - went both to pay medical bills and directly to Ms. Long or her creditors. The audits began with May 1986 records and went through June 1989 for St. John and August 1990 for St. Pius X. The Rev. John Walsh of St. Pius told the archdiocese last fall that he had paid Ms. Long with funds set aside for the poor. There was no indication of a relationship between Walsh and Ms. Long. Woods was pastor at St. John the Evangelist, where Ms. Long was a lay minister, for 10 years before moving to St. Jude's Parish in Sandy Springs two years ago. A review of St. Jude's records showed no money had gone to Ms. Long. An archdiocese spokesman, the Rev. Peter Dora, said the church would not discipline Woods or Walsh for disbursing the money, nor would it try to recover the funds from Ms. Long. But he said she will not receive any more money ``directly or indirectly from the archdiocese of Atlanta or any of its components.'' The audit did not review the personal finances of Marino, who is believed to have contributed more money to Ms. Long over a two-year period. ``Archbishop Marino pretty well lost his life savings,'' Dora said. ``Likewise, Father Woods is destitute.'' Dora said the audit uncovered only one previously unrevealed archdiocese expense for Ms. Long - $47 that he said was for flowers sent to her during an illness. The financial review was published Thursday in the archdiocese newspaper, the Georgia Bulletin. It was headed by Coca-Cola Co. President Donald Keough and conducted by Coopers & Lybrand public accountants.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item on Rolvaag to CORRECT age in lead to 77, sted 78.
DOC.TEXT: Former Minnesota Gov. Karl Rolvaag, who was elected 28 years ago by the narrowest margin in state history, died Thursday at age 77. Rolvaag had been seriously ill for the last month with a heart condition. Rolvaag was lieutenant governor for eight years before running for governor in 1962. He won the election by 91 votes, but did not take office until March 1963 because of a five-month recount. He served as governor until 1967. President Lyndon Johnson appointed Rolvaag ambassador to Iceland in 1967 after he lost his 1966 re-election bid for governor.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcast Pioneer Karl Wyler Dies
DOC.TEXT: Broadcast pioneer Karl O. Wyler, who began singing on radio as a teen-ager and went on to own radio and television stations in El Paso, has died at age 84. He died Thursday night, apparently from a heart attack, officials said. Wyler first became involved in broadcasting in 1921, when he conducted his four-piece orchestra, The Merrymakers, over ham radio airwaves. He went on to own radio and television stations KTSM. In 1977 he was named Pioneer Broadcaster of the Year by the Texas Association of Broadcasters. ``I looked up to him for years and years. He was one of the great men in broadcasting,'' said Richard Pearson, general manager of rival television station KVIA. ``This man built an empire of AM, FM and television when nobody else believed in it. I had the greatest respect for him.'' Besides his broadcast business, Wyler was long active in El Paso civic affairs. About 300 guests turned out April 5, his 84th birthday, when he was honored by the El Paso Community Foundation for his contributions to the city's children and the needy. Survivors include his wife, Glyn; and his son, Karl O. Wyler II.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Agree to Permit Weekend Opposition Rally
DOC.TEXT: The government today gave permission for the first legal oppostion rally in Albania and said all statues and symbols bearing the name of Soviet dictator Josef Stalin should be removed. Authorities also said enterprises and institutions bearing Stalin's name should receive new ones, the state ATA news agency reported. It said this was decided ``taking into consideration that historic circumstances have changed.'' Workers on agricultural cooperatives and residents in housing blocks named after Stalin should similarly decide on new names, the report said. Clusters of Tirana residents watched all morning as workers toiled to dismantle the marble-covered pedestal in a central park on which a statue of Stalin had stood for decades. The statue itself came down at midnight. A second Stalin statue at the Stalin Textile Combine in Tirana was also taken down overnight. Stalin, who was born this day in 1879, was the father-figure of the harsh brand of communism that Albania's founder Enver Hoxha imposed on his country for 41 years. ``Now let's take down the statue of the dictator who ruled here for 50 years,'' said one youth, referring to a giant bronze statue of Hoxha that towers nearby over Tirana's showcase Skanderbeg Square. Demonstrators in northern Shkodra last week reportedly blew up that city's giant statu of Hoxha. Authorities there took down a Stalin memorial in August. Flowers have been planted on the spot where the statue of Hoxha once stood. In Shkodra, hundreds of windows smashed in the violence were boarded over, and soldiers stood guard today around the vandalized Communist Party headquarters. The decisions to permit a rally Saturday by the new opposition Democratic Party and to remove Stalin statues indicated pro-reform forces were gaining the upper hand in the ruling Albanian Labor - or Communist - Party. The rally would be the first officially sanctioned protest not sponsored by the Communists, who for decades suppressed any opposition. Several thousand students rallied in Tirana last week to demand democratic change and hail the founding of the first non-Communist party and police did not itervene. Sali Berisha, a founder of the Democratic Party, said Saturday's rally would press opposition demands for the release of all political prisoners, as well as for the postponement of free elctions scheduled for February. The Democratic Party says it does not have time to organize by polling day, set for Feb. 10, and wants the elections delayed until April or May. To date, the Communists have used their power over official media to keep public silence about the new party, meaning it must rely on word of mouth to propogate its cause in a backward nation with poor communications. On Thursday, there was another indication of the swift change under way in Europe's last Stalinist state. Hoxha's 71-year-old widow Nexhmije lost her last political post, quitting her chairmanship of the Communist-led Democratic Front for what were termed reasons of age. She was replaced by Premier Adil Carcani, touching off speculation that he might resign as head of government. The ruling Communist Party promised a government reorganization when protesting students forced democratic reforms earlier this month, but so far no changes have been announced. The Communists' policies, however, remain secretive and opaque, and they also have indicated they are prepared to use tough tactics to maintain power. Demonstrators arrested after last week's violent riots in four cities, including Shkodra, have received tough jail sentences of up to 20 years. In an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. today, a Justice Ministry official denied Democratic Party allegations that the accused were not receiving adequate defense from lawyers. The concept of rule by law is new to Albania, which only decided earlier this year to reconstitute the Justice Ministry abolished under Hoxha.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Soviets Must Accelerate Pace of Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Four leading Western economic institutions said today that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev must accelerate the pace of reform in his country or run the risk that the effort could fail. The long-awaited study, the most comprehensive look yet by the West at the crumbling Soviet economy, called for economic pain in the form of wage controls imposed on workers at the same time price controls are removed from a variety of goods. It said such bitter medicine was the only way to stabilize the chaotic situation in the Soviet Union, where consumers in major cities are faced with massive shortages of food and other essential products. ``The authorities face an enormous task, involving reforms of the legal, financial and trade systems and also of vital sectors of the economy, especially agriculture, distribution, energy and manufacturing,'' said the report. It was prepared by the International Monetary Fund with help from three other organizations. ``These changes cannot be made in a matter of weeks,'' the study concluded. ``But the imperative is to make sufficient progress at the beginning so that reform is seen as an irreversible break with the past and the process gains an unstoppable momentum.''

The Western experts conceded that the plan they were putting forward could not be implemented without economic pain, but said they knew of no other way to transform the Soviet system. ``Ideally, a path of gradual reform could be laid out which would minimize economic disturbance and lead to an early harvesting of the fruits of increased economic efficiency,'' the study said. ``But we know of no such path, the more particularly given the difficult starting conditions.'' But the study said that Gorbachev had passed the point of no return in his efforts, saying it would probably be impossible to reinstitute a centrally planned economy even if he wanted to. Therefore, the experts urged the Soviet leaders ``to move rapidly to give substance to their commitment to a market economy.'' While calling for technical assistance to help the Soviets in their efforts to discard seven decades of a planned economy, the study said that massive amounts of Western aid would not be useful right now. It said that without the implementation of a major and far-reaching reform program, direct Western aid would be ``of little or no lasting value.'' The 50-page report represented a victory for the Bush administration, which has argued for months that massive amounts of Western aid would be wasted until Gorbachev made more extensive moves to reform his economy. However, it cited certain specific areas where Western technical expertise and investment could be of value. ``Immediate new investment could have a quick payoff for the USSR and the rest of the world'' in the energy and environment sectors, the report said. It cited modernization of nuclear plants, improvement of oil drilling technologies and updating the Soviets' gas pipeline systems as projects where foreign investment would be most useful in the short term. Foreign assistance also could be ``particularly useful'' in retailing and distribution, two areas that will be critical in the transition to a market economy, the report said. The United States and other countries already have dispatched experts to help the Soviets remove the bottlenecks in their crumbling distribution system. In addition to the IMF, other groups participating in the study were the World Bank and two European-based economic agencies, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. President Bush met with IMF Director Michel Camdessus and World Bank President Barber Conable on Thursday to discuss the report, which was ordered up by Bush and other leaders at the seven-nation economic summit last July in Houston. The study represented a compromise last summer between demands by the French and Germans for an immediate $15 billion Western aid package and resistance to direct economic aid by Bush and the other summit leaders. Today's report, however, indicated that no large sums of public money were called for in the current period. Instead, it said, ``A large part of this technical assistance should be provided by the private sectors of Western countries with the role of public sectors being limited to filling any important gaps.'' Due to the breakdown of the distribution system, food shortages are appearing in Moscow, Leningrad and other major Soviet cities, particularly those farthest from agricultural regions. Germany and a number of other European countries have embarked on food relief programs for the Soviet Union. The United States has offered the Soviets $1 billion in bank guarantees to help them buy U.S. grain and is coordinating a program to encourage the private sector to supply medical supplies and drugs to relieve shortages. ``Food aid, if targeted and successfully delivered to the regions most affected, could alleviate present distress,'' the study said. But it added, ``an early implementation of economic reform would make the single largest contribution to alleviation of shortages.'' The report, which took five months to prepare, portrayed a system that was even more backward than expected and practically paralyzed in its stumbling efforts to implement Gorbachev's restructuring program. Inflation is accelerating at a pace that is difficult to measure, with the old centralized order being replaced by a chaotic system of bartering and black marketeering, it said. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration did not believe the surprise resignation Thursday of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze would derail the efforts to get Western technical assistance to the Soviet economy. He said the United States would discuss the report with other summit countries - Germany, Japan, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - in order to coordinate efforts. Finance ministers and central bank presidents of the seven nations are expected to meet in Washington in late January. In addition to the $1 billion in food credits, the administration also announced last week that it supports a move to make the Soviet Union a ``special associate'' of the IMF and the World Bank. That would qualify the country for technical help but no direct loans from the two lending organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Charged With Giving Cocaine to 2-year-old Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A woman was arrested for giving her 2-year-old daughter cocaine on at least two occasions. Police said they found Maryland Brown's daughter under the influence of cocaine Wednesday when they showed up at Brown's home to arrest her for allegedly giving it to the girl before. Brown, 22, was charged with two counts of first-degree reckless endangering and two counts of delivering cocaine. The girl was hospitalized, but officials declined to give her name or condition. The investigation had begun last week when the girl was treated at a hospital for cocaine withdrawal, police Sgt. Martin P. Hageman said. Ivory L. Johnson, director of the state Division of Child Protective Services, said he child was released from the hospital into a relative's custody while police investigated her mother. ``Detectives obtained enough evidence to arrest her and upon returning to the suspect's home, discovered the child had been returned to the mother,'' Hageman said. Brown was held at the Women's Correctional Institution in Claymont in lieu of $44,000 bail.

DOC.HEAD: 82-Year-Old Woman Arrested On Drug Violation
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested an 82-year-old woman for investigation of drug trafficking after sheriff's deputies found a half-gram of cocaine and drug paraphernalia in her home, officials said. Juanita Jackson was arrested Thursday for investigation of possession of cocaine for sale and maintaining a place for drug trafficking, Riverside County Sheriff's Sgt. Patrick McManus said. She was released today on her own recognizance from the Riverside County jail, according to a county jail clerk who declined to give her name. Another woman, Lisa Marie Soltz, 28, was arrested at the same time for a parole violation. Lake Elsinore is 60 miles southeast of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Precede DHAHRAN
Eight Soldiers Poisoned by Home-Brewed Alcohol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with soldiers hospitalized since Sunday, other details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Eight American soldiers have been poisoned by home-brewed alcohol and hospitalized since Sunday, one in very serious condition, the U.S. military command said. The soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division are the first known casualties of home-brewed liquor since U.S. forces were deployed in Saudi Arabia, a Moslem country which bans all alcohol. Today's statement from the U.S. Central Command said the soldiers, who were not identified, suffered from methanol poisoning, which is a problem associated with faulty home-brewed alcoholic beverages. Methanol poisoning, which can lead to blindness or death, was a serious problem during Prohibition in the 1920s. The eight soldiers from the 372nd Transportation Company, 29th Transportation Battalion, 101st Combat Support Group, are all recovering, the command said. Army officials are investigating the incident. Since U.S. troops arrived in Saudi Arabia in early August, a small number have been disciplined for having alcoholic beverages. Even though alcohol is illegal in Saudi Arabia, it is available on the black market, and beer, wine and hard liquor are brewed at home by some expatriates working in the kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Sunken Barge Threatens River Commerce
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 7 grafs with barge search resuming today. Picks up 6th graf pvs: `The barge ...'
DOC.TEXT: A salvage crew dragged the bottom of the Allegheny River today in search of a sunken barge that paralyzed part of the nation's busiest inland port for a third day. A four-mile stretch of the rain-swollen river was closed Wednesday and Thursday from Point State Park in downtown Pittsburgh northeast to the Highland Park Bridge, Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Rhea Giacoma said. ``One little barge like this is more of a nuisance than anything else,'' said John Reed, spokesman for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. ``But if you don't know where it is, it could create a much bigger problem. ``Someone comes tooling along and hits that barge and then you've got a few more of them sunk.'' A tugboat crew used a 15-foot pole to probe the river for the barge, but the search was suspended Thursday afternoon because it was inadequate to search the river that has swollen to 40 feet deep with recent rains. The Coast Guard asked the barge's owner, Azcon Scrap Corp., to resume the search today with better equipment. Ms. Giacoma said the salvage crew today is using a bucket able to reach the river bottom, ``and there's a diver on board who'll go down if they hit anything.'' The barge's owner, Azcon Scrap Corp., was paying for the search. The barge broke loose from its moorings at Azcon's scrap yard last Friday and floated about 400 yards downstream. Two barge workers jumped to safety before the steel barge sailed over a dam, got stuck in the river mud and bent at a 45-degree angle. Ms. Giacoma said the barge broke free from the dam Tuesday during more than 2 inches of rain, and sank somewhere. Most barges that ply the Allegheny River remained at their moorings Thursday and there was little activity at U.S. Army Corps of Engineers locks at Pittsburgh, Oakmont, Natrona Heights and Freeport, corps civil engineer Dave Turcsanyi said. The locks transport an average of 5,500 tons of coal, steel, sand, gravel, petroleum and other goods each day, Reed said. If the barge isn't found today, companies that depend on the Allegheny River to ship their goods will begin to feel the pinch as customers such as electric utilities switch to other suppliers, Reed said.

DOC.HEAD: Dumas Urges Cambodia to Accept U.N. Peace Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Hun Sen fainting, hospitalized in satisfactory condition. Pickup 7th, `While acknowledging...'
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas implored Cambodia's Supreme National Council today to accept a United Nations peace proposal and said that time is running out to find a solution to the conflict. Opening a meeting of the 12-member council, Dumas said the proposal, adopted Nov. 26 by the five permanent U.N. Security Council members, was a compromise text. ``It can be improved, but it cannot be put into question,'' he said. ``We are proud of it.'' Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen fainted during the meeting and was rushed to hospital. Dumas said later he was in satisfactory condition, apparently suffering from fatigue. It was not known how long Hun Sen would remain at the Val de Grace military hospital. The Cambodians were meeting with France and Indonesia, which co-chair the International Conference for Peace in Cambodia, the framework for signing a peace accord. A U.N. representative was also present at the meeting. Dumas tried to counter criticism that the Security Council plan would give the United Nations too great a role in running the country. The plan calls for the United Nations to administer Cambodia during an interim period before free elections, and for the Supreme National Council to act as titular head. Hun Sen has already said the plan gives the United Nations, which would head key ministries, too much power. While acknowledging the U.N. representative would have ``strong powers,'' Dumas stressed that ``it is in no case a real tutelage as long as the Supreme National Council embodies the sovereignty of Cambodia.'' He said, however, that unresolved quarrels among the four Cambodian factions made it ``indispensible'' to give the U.N. representative final decision-making power to avoid paralysis. Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas presided over the meeting with Dumas. Representing the three Cambodian factions were Communist Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan, the non-Communist leader of the Khmer People's National Front, Son Sann, and Prince Norodom Ranariddh, son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk. If the four Cambodian parties accept the proposal, the Paris conference would be reconvened to sign a final peace accord. But French officials have expressed skepticism that today's meeting, expected to last one day, could win consent of the rival factions. The Vietnam-backed Phnom Penh government, which has six of the council's 12 seats, has already objected to key aspects of the accord, including the designation of the United Nations as administrator of Cambodia. The proposal was adopted by the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union, China and France. At its only other meeting in September in Bangkok, the council broke up in a dispute over its composition. Hun Sen objected to efforts by Sihanouk to be president of the council, saying that would alter the balance in favor of the resistance. Dumas said time is running out. ``The international community cannot indefinitely work out the fate of Cambodia if Cambodians themselves do not have the political will to do so,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Demands County Increase Relief to Stave Off Hunger, Homelessness
DOC.TEXT: Three indigent people have sued Los Angeles County, saying the county's relief payments are insufficient to ward off hunger and homelessness. The lawsuit against the county Board of Supervisors claims that the maximum payment of $312 a month, established after another lawsuit, is grossly inadequate to feed, clothe and shelter the indigent. The allotment allows $200 a month for housing, $95 for food, and $17 for transportation, personal needs and clothing, according to the lawsuit filed Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court. The suit asks that the board be ordered to ``immediately raise the monthly grant amounts by amounts sufficient to enable indigent recipients to meet their basic subsistence needs.'' It does not specify how much money that is. ``The general relief program is the final safety net for aid and assistance to many destitute people,'' said the plaintiffs' lawyer, John Brinsley. ``This monthly allocation has not been increased since mid-1988 and is significantly below the federal poverty line.'' The county continues to be ``the provider of last resort,'' said Deputy County Counsel Patrick Wu. Wu said he had not seen the lawsuit and could not comment further on it. Brinsley said the supervisors ignored an increase recommended by their own elfare director and chief administrative officer, voting to keep payments the same. Those representing the plaintiffs in the class-action suit include the Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles, the Inner City Law Center and Western Center on Law and Poverty Inc. Three relief recipients - Elizabeth Mendly, Rudy Johnson and John Butts Jr. - are named as plaintiffs. But the suit specifies that ``plaintiffs bring this action on behalf of themselves and all those similarly situated.'' Some 50,000 poor people receive relief payments each year in Los Angeles County, according to the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Juveniles Arrested in Drive-By Shooting of Five Youngsters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with police chief comment on earlier dispute between youths; picks up 6th graf pvs, Residents of; Xaziver in 15th graf is CQ
DOC.TEXT: Police today blamed group rivalry among teen-agers for the shooting of four adolescents and a 6-year-old who were wounded on their way home from school by gunshots from a passing car. A 16-year-old and two 14-year-olds were arrested today in connection with Thursday's shootings. Police said they were looking for two other teen-agers as well. Police Chief Isaac Fulwood blamed easy access to firearms and a breakdown in values for the shooting. ``I don't know whether it was drug-related or not, but I doubt it,'' he said. ``Don't make everything drug-related; it cheapens the violence.'' Fulwood declined to say what the altercation was about, but said it was the kind of argument that at one time would have been settled by a fist fight. The availability of firearms has given young people other options, he said. The altercation, he said, occurred 1-1/2 to 2 weeks ago and police were alerted that there might be trouble on Thursday. ``We did get a call earlier in the day and we took some steps,'' Fulwood said, adding that policemen were sent to the area. Lt. Reginald Smith, a police spokesman, said police had been dispatched to the junior high school attended by the four victims when they ``heard something was going down.'' The injured youngsters, the oldest of whom was 15, were in a group of children standing near a picket fence in a residential area of northwest Washington when the drive-by shooting occurred, police said. Their conditions this morning ranged from fair to serious. All were expected to survive. Residents of the city were shocked by the shootings despite the skyrocketing violence Washington has experienced in recent years. Most of the 471 homicides this year have been at night and related to drugs and family violence. The city has never had a serious problem with gang warfare or daylight killings. ``When it comes to innocent babies, it's going too far,'' said one woman who rushed to the scene from work after her daughter called and described the incident. John Olden, 13, Clarence Richmond, 14, and Brian Lewis, 12, were admitted to Children's National Medical Center in critical condition, hospital spokeswoman Barbara Cire said, but their conditions were upgraded to serious. Troy Gray, 15, and Xaziver Paul, 6, were admitted in serious condition, but later were listed in fair condition. ``I ran up and saw them there, and they were all shot,'' said a sixth grader who was nearby when the shootings occurred. ``They leaned against the cars and checked to see where they had been hit.'' Two children were shot in the chest, two were shot in the abdomen and one was shot in the arm, said Dr. Marty Eichelberger, director of emergency trauma services at the hospital. ``There are five kids, and there are a lot of holes,'' Eichelberger said. ``When they all came in, it was a challenge to even learn which of the youngsters were in the most serious condition.'' He said the two younger children's injuries were more superficial than those sustained by the others. Witnesses said the children either collapsed after being shot or staggered toward cars. Officials said the four older youngsters attended a junior high school near the site of the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Tells Troops War Is Increasingly Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, ``The only, to insert dropped word `begin'.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told U.S. troops today it is increasingly likely war will be needed to oust Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait, and that ``absolute, total victory'' is the only option if war breaks out. ``It increasingly looks like he's not getting the message and we'll have to use force,'' Cheney said in a pep talk to troops in the northeast Saudi desert. ``The only acceptable outcome, if hostilities begin, is absolute, total victory,'' Cheney continued. Gen. Colin Powell, who was visiting the troops with Cheney, said he still hoped for a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis. But he drew roars of applause when he vowed: ``When we launch it, we will launch it violently, we will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we can get it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.'' Cheney and Powell, fresh from three days of strategy sessions with field commanders in Saudi Arabia, were somewhat evasive when asked by troops whether American ground forces would be ready to fight by the Jan. 15 deadline for Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. Those questions were raised this week by the deputy commander of Operation Desert Shield, who said Wednesday still-arriving ground troops might not be combat ready until well into February. Asked by an airman how long the United States would wait to attack if the deadline passed without an Iraqi withdrawal, Cheney said: ``While I can't tell you a specific date, for obvious reasons, when that would happen, I can say that we are eager to get this wrapped up as quickly as possible.'' Cheney added that U.S. military officials do not think ``waiting indefinitely is going to solve the problem.'' This week, military analysts said that if United States attacks Iraq, the assault could begin with a massive air strike - followed by a short pause to give Saddam a chance to surrender. That scenario gained credence Wednesday when U.S. military officials conceded that some vital American ground forces might not be ready by the Jan. 15 deadline. The likelihood of starting with air strikes has been discussed for some time by military officials and others who believe the United States - because of its long-term political interests in the region - must keep damage to Iraq to a minimum. After Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, there was considerable talk that a U.S. attack would start with massive air strikes. But Bush administration officials later told Congress that any U.S. assault would include a massive air, land and sea campaign. Powell said this week, ``We're looking at an air, land and sea campaign. But ... it doesn't mean we're going to do it all at once.'' A pause after an initial air strike makes sense for several reasons, according to military and private analysts, who spoke on condition of anonymity. First, it would save thousands of lives and damage on both sides if Saddam decided he could not win a war and surrendered after an air assault, averting a bloody ground war, these analysts say. ``We're going to have a country called Iraq in the region when this is over no matter how it ends,'' one senior Army official said. ``Doesn't it make sense that we would not want to totally destroy their country, which in effect would totally destroy any chances of relations with the government?'' Also, since more than half of the 510,000 Iraqi troops are in southern Iraq and Kuwait, a protracted war likely would leave much of Kuwait in ruins. ``We could very well end up destroying the country we're there to save,'' the Army official said. Those who predict the air strike scenario if war erupts got unexpected support Wednesday from the deputy commander of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf. Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller said ground forces that are still arriving in the gulf area to join the 280,000 already here might not be combat-ready until well into February. The Pentagon reacted Thursday to Waller's comments about readiness by saying U.S. air power in the region would be ready by Jan. 15. A senior Pentagon official who often discourages speculating about possible combat scenarios even reminded reporters that military leaders have raised the possibility of opening any hostilities with a phase of air attacks. Waller, however, said his advice would be to delay any hostilities until all U.S. forces were ready. The commander of the Army component of the American deployment, Lt. Gen. John Yeosock, said Thursday he envisioned a war with Iraq ``to be the highest, (operational) tempo battle ever recorded.'' But he also said any combat plan was subject to continuous change. That philosophy would leave room for endorsing a powerful air strike followed by a pause - provided Bush was ready to follow up with an all-out campaign if Saddam did not give in. ``Clearly, my intention is not to have a protracted war,'' Yeosock said.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Cocaine Kingpin Threatens To Wage War On Drug Agents
DOC.TEXT: A fugitive cocaine kingpin named in a 131-count indictment has threatened to make ``war'' against federal agents pursuing his organization, according to a warning issued to agents by U.S. Customs Service and Drug Enforcement Administration officials. A teletype distributed to the federal agencies quotes accused cocaine kingpin Juan Garcia-Abrego of saying: ``If they (drug agents) want war, we'll give them war.'' Federal agents learned of the alleged threat from the man, who is believed to be in hiding in Mexico, through a ``previously used and highly reliable'' informant, the San Antonio Light reported today. The informant reported the ``war'' threat to Customs agents in Brownsville on Monday. ``This threat, intended to suggest physical harm will be made against any federal law enforcement official going into Northern Tamaulipas, Mexico, was made because of the recent indictments that have been issued against the heads of this major criminal organization,'' the teletype says. ``The (Brownsville) source believes the threat is real and constitutes a serious concern to any federal enforcement officer.'' Garcia-Abrego, 46, is accused of being the head of a formidable narcotics ring thought to be responsible for the state's largest cocaine seizure, a nine-ton cache found last year in a Harlingen safe house. The indictment against him was unsealed Dec. 12 in Dallas. Armando Ramirez, resident agent-in-charge of the Brownsville DEA office, said Garcia-Abrego's threat would not hamper efforts to arrest him or seize his property. ``This guy is going to have to stand on his mother's shoulders in order to intimidate us,'' Ramirez said. ``He knows where our office is, and if he has any problems he can come to us.'' Garcia-Abrego and his top lieutenants face life in prison if arrested and convicted of running a continuing criminal enterprise and drug conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Asks for Car, Gets Junk
DOC.TEXT: When physician Howard Sauder asked his staff for a sports car for Christmas, he didn't expect to arrive at his office party to find his Nissan 280Z neatly wrapped outside. Too bad it was a 1982 model. Too bad it came straight from the junkyard. ``I know that's what I asked for, but I never thought they would go to this,'' Sauder said. ``They're a pretty nutty crew.'' Office Manager Janet Briggs said the staff first considered a Matchbox car, especially when Sauder suggested they find second jobs to buy his present. Workers at the Middle Creek Garage joined in the joke, offering the car at no cost and even a free tow to the party Thursday. The tow truck was used again, when Sauder politely declined the gift. ``Maybe next year I'll ask for an airplane,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Gives Out $11,000 to Skid Row Residents
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious benefactor known as the Cadillac Santa handed out $11,000 to a Skid Row throng. ``It was like the Israelites crossing the Red Sea,'' said Clancy Imislund, director of the Midnight Mission at Fourth and Los Angeles Streets. The annual visit of the philanthropist Thursday drew more than a thousand poor people to the corner. The self-styled Santa, who always drives up in a new Cadillac, handed out money for a half-hour with the help of several assistants. ``He gave about $11,000 in brand new $10 bills,'' Imislund said. ``He went through all of his dough and there were people still coming from Skid Row.'' Imislund said the man will not divulge his name. The mission director said the visit provides excitement for people not used to such generosity. ``It isn't the $10,'' Imislund said. ``It's the `Santa's coming' feeling.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Waits Until Day After Christmas To Hear Arguments To Remove Creche
DOC.TEXT: The dispute over whether a Nativity scene should remain in front of City Hall this holiday season may be moot by the time a judge gets around to hearing arguments - one day after Christmas. A federal judge in San Jose has agreed to hear arguments Dec. 26 to decide whether the wood-carved manger scene implies governmental endorsement of Christianity over other faiths. In similar cases, the U.S. Supreme Court has allowed Nativity scenes or other religious displays when they were surrounded by other secular holiday decorations. The Monterey display, depicting the birth of Jesus, had been a traditional holiday decoration outside City Hall for nearly 30 years until 1989 when it was moved to a Roman Catholic church to avoid a legal dispute. But this year the Nativity scene went back up outside City Hall, prompting the American Civil Liberties Union and Victor Ringel, a 13-year-old Jewish boy, to sue.

DOC.HEAD: Police Investigate Explosive In Package To Tabloid
DOC.TEXT: Police said Friday they are investigating an incident in which an explosive was found in a package delivered to the offices of The Sun, a London-based tabloid. The explosive was mailed to the headquarters of Rupert Murdoch's News International organization, publishers of The Sun, News of the World, The Times and the Sunday Times, in Wapping, east London, said a Scotland Yard spokesman. The Sun offices were evacuated until bomb disposal experts had removed the package, said the spokesman, who demanded anonymity. The package contained an eight ounce stick of gelignite but had no means of detonation, he said. Jane Reed, News International's director of corporate affairs, said the package had been mailed from Australia. ``The package apparently slipped through the national post office and local security checks and was finally discovered by one of The Sun's secretaries,'' she said. She said the letter enclosed with the explosives referred to somebody in north London who had links to Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Kills One, Injures 40
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook the Balkans early Friday, killing a Greek woman, causing homes to collapse and injuring at least 40 people, authorities and news reports said. The Salonica Seismological Institute said the temblor measured 5.5 on the Richter scale. The U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif., said it recorded the quake at 6.1. Its epicenter was in the village of Goumenisa, about 35 miles northwest of Salonica, the seismological institute said. The quake was also felt in Yugoslavia, Romania and Bulgaria, according to news reports. A spokesman at the Salonica institute said more than 30 aftershocks followed the main quake, the largest measuring 3.5 on the open-ended Richter scale. The quake occurred in the Serbo-Macedonian zone, which begins in southern Bulgaria and winds into northern Greece, a seismologically active region. The zone includes the Cressna fault. A police spokesman in the town of Edessa, about 20 miles west of the epicenter, identified the dead woman as 69-year-old Anastasia Deltsou. ``She was crushed when a wall collapsed on her,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The main regional hospital in Edessa reported that more than 25 people were treated for injuries and five of them were hospitalized. A hospital spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said area medical centers treated and released at least 15 other people. According to police reports, 11 houses in towns and villages near the epicenter either collapsed or became uninhabitable. Three fell down in Goumenisa. The quake also caused minor injuries and damaged houses in the southern Yugoslavia republic of Macedonia, on the border with Greece, the Tanjug news agency reported. There were no reports of damage or injuries in Romania and Bulgaria. A spokesman at the Salonica institute said the temblor ``seems to have been the main quake, although we are gathering data to make sure it was not a foreshock.'' An earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale struck Salonica in 1978, killing 40 people. A temblor measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale preceded it by less than a month. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 5.0 can cause considerable damage, and one measuring 6.0 can cause severe damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Antiquities Director Dies of Heart Attack at 54
DOC.TEXT: Sayed Tawfik, Egypt's chief archaeologist and chairman of antiquities, has died of a heart attack at age 54, friends and newspapers reported Friday. Tawfik, a former dean of archaeology and professor of Egyptology at Cairo University, was the author of a half-dozen books on Egyptian antiquities. As chairman of the Egyptian Antiquities Organization, he was in charge of all restoration and conservation work on Egypt's vast legacy of pyramids, tombs, temples and other relics threatened by time, pollution and the demands of an exploding population. But among Egyptologists, Tawfik is remembered most as an excavator, especially for his work on a windblown bluff overlooking the ancient royal burial grounds of Sakkara south of Cairo. He began the excavation eight years ago. In 1985 he uncovered an unknown burial ground from the time of Pharaoh Ramses II, tombs hidden 33 feet below the desolate hillside that yielded a rich store of data about some of the most important officials of the Egypt of 3,250 years ago. Friends said Tawfik was at Sakkara on Thursday. That night he suffered a heart attack and died instantly.He was buried on Friday. Tawfik spoke of his love for Egyptology and excavation in an interview on Tuesday, his last. ``Each time I excavate, I'm rewriting history,'' he told The Associated Press. ``Imagine that before I began the dig in Sakkara, we never knew Ramses II had a history there. History is a puzzle, and I'm helping to write new chapters.'' Tawfik became chairman of antiquities in December 1988 after a 10-month battle over who or what caused a boulder to fall from the shoulder of the Sphinx, which cost Tawfik's predecessor his job. Widespread concern persists over the future of the half-man, half-beast statue at the foot of Giza Plateau. But Tawfik remained optimistic to the end that the Sphinx would survive. He made weekly visits, including one Tuesday morning. ``I think the restoration work going on at the Sphinx is wonderful. I'm so happy with it,'' he said. ``Some weeks I go once to the Sphinx, sometimes three times. If I don't go to make sure everything is going well, the Sphinx might sleep. And one day I'll go and it'll be gone. I must be vigilant, fight to save the Sphinx.'' Despite his workload, Tawfik refused to abandon his love for excavation. ``Excavation is life, and what's so wonderful is each time you go down, you are a discoverer,'' he said Tuesday. Survivors include Tawfik's German-born widow, Frieda; his son Tarek, an Egyptology student at Cairo University; and daughter, Sophie, a pupil at a German school in Cairo.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Protests Army Patrols in Port City
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian Supreme Council said today it has sent a note to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev protesting Soviet army patrols in the port city of Klaipeda and demanding the soldiers be removed. The Klaipeda garrison commander notified Lithuanian authorities on Wednesday that armed units would begin patrolling the streets and have the authority to check people's documents, the Tass agency said. ``This order is a flagrant violation of the laws and the rights of citizens of the republic of Lithuania, as well as a political provocation with the intent to heighten tensions and to create ptential conflicts,'' said a copy of the note made available to Western news agencies. The patrols were ordered in response to clashes between civilians and Soviet soldiers and sailors in Klaipeda, a Baltic seaport with a large military presence, according to an editor of the Elta news agency. They have the authority to check identity documents of both soldiers and civilians, and arrest those who resist. Lithuania - which along with the other Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia has declared independence - said the orders issued by the Soviet military were not valid on the territory of the republic. The note called on Gorbachev to ``revoke the mentioned directives of the Soviet army authorities and to punish them for their willful behavior which is accompanied by the threat of armed violence.'' The Supreme Council also released a statement calling on Lithuanians to remain calm and not to get involved in conflicts with the patrols.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Says Jan. 15 is Not `Attack Day' for Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Scowcroft comments on Jan. 15 deadline; editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said today that the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait ``is not an attack day'' for American forces in the Persian Gulf. Instead, said Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser to President Bush, ``What it tells Saddam Hussein is that after the 15th - he'd better get moving now - after the 15th of January, he is at risk. ``It doesn't say he is going to be attacked this date or that date or whatever,'' Scowcroft said. ``What it says is, he is at risk of the mandate of the Security Council after the 15th of January.'' Scowcroft's comments came a day after Bush warned that Iraq would be trounced in any war with the United States. ``If we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked,'' Bush was quoted as telling lawmakers Thursday. Jan. 15 is the date set in a United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing all means necessary to expel Iraq from Kuwait if it hasn't withdrawn voluntarily. Bush said earlier this week that the U.N. mandate must be implemented on schedule. Scowcroft made his comments in an interview with The Associated Press and reporters from other news agencies. He said he was not trying to raise or dampen expectations of military action on Jan. 15. ``All I'm saying is the 15th is an authorization date. That's the way to describe it. What I'm saying is the 15th doesn't mean the troops and aircraft start to move on the 15th,'' Scowcroft said. On Thursday, Bush told lawmakers that Saddam does not understand the military threat he faces. However, some congressional leaders expressed concern about the fallout from fighting. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, just back from the Middle East, said he and members of his group detected ``considerable support among the masses'' in Arab countries for Saddam. ``And that is a reality with which we must deal, even though the governments of some of those countries are allied with us at this time,'' the Maine Democrat said. Furthermore, he said, he told the president that allies in the region - particularly Egypt and Saudi Arabia - were fearful of a broader conflict that would bring Israel into the battle, thereby complicating the scenario with Arabs pitted against Israelis. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said it was an open question whether soldiers from Arab countries would fight those from another. Bush met with two delegations of lawmakers who visited the Persian Gulf. He was meeting later today with John Major, Britain's new prime minister. Major opened the day with a series of television interviews in which he stressed that the question of war was ``in Saddam Hussein's hands.'' ``A complete withdrawal is necessary, a partial withdrawal won't do,'' Major said in an interview on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the president would welcome a strong endorsement from Congress along the lines of the United Nations resolution that authorizes military force against Iraq unless it withdraws from Kuwait by Jan. 15. On the other hand, he said Bush told lawmakers, ``If you're going to debate this for months and not reach a conclusion and argue about it, then that may not be that helpful, or if you're going to water it down ....'' Fitzwater added, ``I'm sure that every committee up there has got 40 brilliant little staff guys running around drafting resolutions.'' Rep. Anthony C. Beilenson, D-Calif., said he believed there should be a declaration of war before the use of force. However, Beilenson said, ``It's not clear, necessarily, what the response of the Congress would be. The president feels ... that it's his decision to make.'' Rep. George W. Darden, D-Ga., said Bush told the lawmakers in direct terms that he was willing to use force. ``He told us, `I am determined to do whatever is necessary to accomplish the purpose of getting Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait.'' Rep. Elton Gallegly, R-Calif., said Bush talked bluntly about the consequences facing Saddam. ``The greatest potential for preventing any kind of an armed confrontation is to make sure that Saddam Hussein be made really aware that, to quote him (Bush), that, `If we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked,''' Gallegly said. Another person at the meeting confirmed that Bush made the remark.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Judge Shuts Gotti for Bail Hearing
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today closed a bail hearing for John Gotti, ruling that the alleged mob boss's rights to a fair trial override the right of the press and the public to attend the proceeding. ``The central aim of a criminal proceeding must be to try the defendant fairly,'' U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser said. Glasser ordered the bail hearing to proceed and said he would reopen his courtroom later today to announce whether Gotti and his two co-defendants would be freed on bail or detained. ''It is better to err, if err we must, on the side of generosity to the defendant's rights,'' Glasser said in closing his courtroom. The news organizations that had sought to keep the hearing open awaited the judge's written decision before deciding whether an appeal would be filed. Defense lawyers maintained Gotti's right to a fair trial would be compromised if the hearing were held in open court and the public allowed to listen to secretly recorded tapes of some of the accused mobster's conversations. ``While it is true that the First Amendment guarantees to the public and the press a qualified right to attend criminal trials, that right is secondary to defendants' superior Sixth Amendment right to a fair trial,'' Gotti defense lawyer John L. Pollok said in a written motion to keep the hearing closed. Pollok also maintained that if reporters have access to the tapes, ``the pre-trial media disclosure of evidence, not yet even determined to be admissible at trial, will so poison the atmosphere already surrounding this case as to make selecting a fair and impartial jury and conducting a fair trial in New York virtually impossible.'' Nancy Richman, an attorney representing the city's major news organizations, argued there have probably been more words written about Gotti in recent years than about any other criminal defendant. ``Nevertheless, Gotti has been acquitted three times in the past five years, earning him the nickname the `Teflon Don,''' Ms. Richman wrote. Gotti, 50, and his co-defendants - alleged underboss Frank Locascio, 58, and reputed mob counselor Salvatore Gravano, 45 - have been behind bars since their Dec. 11 arrest on racketeering and conspiracy charges. Law enforcers said they have a half-dozen tapes in which Gotti and the other two men are heard discussing obstruction of justice and violence. Prosecutors maintained the defendants - the alleged three top members of the Gambino crime family - are responsible for a number of murders, are a threat to potential witnesses and the public and should remain in jail without bail. A fourth defendant, 61-year-old Thomas Gambino, an alleged captain in the crime family, is free on $500,000 bail. He was accused of illegal gambling and loansharking.

DOC.HEAD: No Relief From Arctic Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th graf, `In Nevada ..., to UPDATE with state offices closing in New Mexico, police urging people to rescue drunks in snow, power outage in Wyoming; ADDS 1 graf to UPDATE with flooding in Arkansas. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DX2,FLS1
DOC.TEXT: Freezing cold iced the West today, bringing snow to the seaside city of Monterey, Calif., while rain pelted the Midwest and Northeast as harsh weather ushered in the first official day of winter. The Arctic storm that chilled Western states most of the week butted against warm humid air over the South to create a band of freezing rain from central Texas to the Great Lakes, with up to an inch of rainfall possible. Rain was forecast from Louisiana to southern Maine and the entire state of Ohio was under a flood watch today. Snow fell from the Midwest to the California coast overnight and temperatures dipped as low as wind-chilled 80 below in a mountain pass near the Idaho-Montana border. Thousands remained without power in the Seattle area for the fourth day and some who resorted to burning barbecue briquettes were hospitalized with carbon monoxide poisoning. All of Montana had subzero temperatures today, with lows down to 45 below. ``We still have cold air coming down from the north,'' said Randy Calaway of the National Weather Service in Great Falls. In Nevada, temperatures fell below zero as far south as a town called Caliente, the Spanish word for hot. Fountains on the glittery Las Vegas Strip beat back fingers of ice in 20-degree temperatures. Ice and snow prompted New Mexico Gov. Garrey Carruthers to close state offices in Santa Fe today, giving more than 6,000 state workers an early holiday. Eight inches of snow fell at Gallup, N.M., where a recreation center was converted to an overnight shelter for stranded travelers. Gallup Police Chief Frank Gonzales issued an appeal to citizens to help drunks found outdoors. ``Different people calling us report drunks laying out on the sidewalks and that the snow is covering them,'' Gonzales said. ``I wish they would help us by taking them inside, and we could pick them up then.'' In Wyoming, temperatures down to 40 below caused an electrical transmission line to contract and snap early today, leaving an estimated 10,000 people in the Jackson area without power. The outage prevented the Jackson Hole Ski Resort from operating. San Francisco had a record low for the date Thursday at 34 degrees, falling one degree below the 1908 mark. In Monterey, to the south, the snow was a rare occurrence. ``I think it was really great. I really like snow,'' said Althea Heard-Thompson, a restaurant manager who described the 15-minute snowfall as ``really light, large flakes'' that melted quickly. In Los Angeles, free blankets offered on Skid Row were gone by noon Thursday, and all city shelters were filled. In downtown San Diego, a homeless man apparently trying to keep warm suffered severe electrical burns after crawling into a transformer box, police said. The storm system was blamed for at least 13 deaths since Tuesday, in Washington, Iowa, Oregon, California and Oklahoma. Snow fell heavily in the Sierra Nevada, with up to 1{ feet at Mammoth Mountain ski area, where less than a week ago the resort opened a soup kitchen for seasonal workers left jobless by lack of snow. In Colorado, snowfall closed Wolf Creek pass and the Wolf Creek ski area.
