But the weather thrilled ski industry officials. ``This is clearly a holiday bonus,'' said Cathy Kruzic, spokeswoman for Colorado Ski Country USA. ``It's wonderful powder.'' Washington state, first hit by the Arctic storm, got no relief today. ``We're packed wall-to-wall,'' said Calvin McVey, director of the 206-bed Gospel Mission homeless shelter in Seattle, where another 145 people slept on the floor. About 18,000 homes and businesses remained in the dark overnight and utility spokeswoman Teri Van Duine said some could be without power for the weekend. Five people came to Virginia Mason Medical Center in Seattle with carbon monoxide poisoning after using charcoal briquettes indoors or improperly ventilated portable heaters and generators, spokeswoman Rena Shawver said. Sinking temperatures and winds gusting to nearly 60 mph snapped power cables in Utah and up to 2 feet of new snow prompted avalanche warnings. Physicians say the wind-chilled temperatures are not to be taken lightly. ``Below a minus 25 degrees wind chill, that's when it's dangerous,'' said Dr. Robert Harms, an emergency room physician at a Sioux Falls, S.D. hospital. ``If you have exposed skin, it can freeze in one minute or less.'' Weather-related traffic deaths killed four people in Northern California, five in Oregon and one in Oklahoma. In Washington, a man was fatally crushed by a falling tree and a homeless man froze to death in Seattle. An 11-year-old girl in Iowa was killed when the truck she was riding in lost control on an ice-covered highway and was hit by a truck. On the eastern side of the Arctic front, heavy rain caused the Ohio River to flood low-lying roads. Two teen-agers rescued a 79-year-old woman near Whipple, Ohio, when her car stalled in 5 feet of water. A Marietta attorney said he may have to hire a boat to get guests to his daughter's wedding Saturday because of flooded roads. Fifteen people were evacuated from their homes in northeastern Arkansas early today when a line of strong thunderstorms caused flooding in the towns of Paragould and Bono.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Officers See Profit Potential in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CarolAnn, one word, in 9th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Down the hall from where military brass are laying war plans for the Persian Gulf, scantily clad women in (and partly out of) Army uniforms are staring out from the pages of a new offering at the Pentagon bookstore. It's the 1991 ``Operation Desert Shield Calendar,'' an eye-catcher amid the bookstore's drab volumes on military history and weapons of war. In large, glossy, color photographs - one for each month, plus extras for good measure - the female models pose with some of the trappings of war: rifles, pistols, hand grenades, ammunition cannisters, helmets, sand bags and dog tags. ``Miss February'' wears a flight suit pulled up just to her hips and has a pilot's helmet pressed against her bare chest. ``Miss December'' sprawls on an Army-issue canvas cot in the sand, attired in camouflage underwear that hardly looks like Army issue. The privately published calendar sells for $12.95 but it is unlikely it would be allowed into Saudi Arabia under the strict laws against public displays of female flesh. At the bottom of its cover, below a deeply plunging neckline, is the statement ``A portion of the proceeds will be used to assist hostage and military family support groups.'' And on the inside is a message ``to the men and women of Operation Desert Shield'' from the project's co-founder, James J. Rooney Jr. It says in part: ``This calendar, reminiscent of the pinup posters of wars long past, represents but a small gesture of appreciation for your sacrifices and suffering.'' At a phone number listed for Rooney's company, RML & Associates Inc. of Hawthorne, Calif., callers are referred to the project's promotion director, CarolAnn Merritt. She said Rooney and his business partner, Rogelio Morales Jr., are Air Force officers trying their hand at their first publishing venture. ``It was done in good faith,'' Ms. Merritt said, adding that although no money is in the till yet from the calendar's distributors and marketers, ``We hope we'll be able to donate thousands'' of dollars to the Yellow Ribbon Foundation, which she described as a private group aiding hostage victims' families.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Leaders To Hold Off on Millionaire Surtax
DOC.TEXT: Democratic House leaders no longer plan to present a surtax on millionaires as the first order of business when Congress convenes next month, but the proposal may resurface later, aides said Friday. Instead, Democrats are focusing on piecing together a package aimed at promoting ``economic growth and tax fairness,'' said one aide to a top Democrat. They hope to have the legislation ready by the time President Bush presents his State of the Union address on Jan. 29, the aide said. ``Don't focus too much on whether it's H.R. 1 or not,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. H.R. 1 is the number assigned to the first bill introduced in the House at the beginning of a session of Congress. The 102nd Congress convenes Jan. 3, when lawmakers are likely to introduce their first bills. The official said Democratic leaders still had not decided what would be in the economic growth package, but would not rule out a surtax on millionaires. Until now, Democratic leaders had spoken of making the session's first bill a tax hike on the rich. The issue was a big political winner for Democrats during this year's budget battle with the White House. They used the proposal - and Republican opposition to it - to characterize the GOP as the party of the wealthy. But Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, told Bush this week that he would not immediately pursue the surtax, an aide to the Illinois Democrat said Friday. Bush told Rostenkowski on Tuesday that he would not include his plan to cut capital gains tax rates in the fiscal 1992 budget he will send Congress on Feb. 4, the aide said. Democrats have fought the capital gains tax reduction, arguing it would mainly help the rich and that it would diminish government revenues. Bush, who has twice waged losing battles to reduce the tax levied on sales of property, said publicly Tuesday that he would abandon the idea because he could not find savings elsewhere to pay for it - as required under new budget procedures. ``If Republicans want to make a big fight over capital gains or other proposals that disproportionately benefit upper-income people, we'd start talking about countermeasures,'' the Rostenkowski aide said. ``If not, it might be better for everyone to focus on recession and war.'' The millionaire surtax proved so popular this year, however, that rank-and-file Democrats say they will push for it anyway. ``It will be spent a dozen times over in the first week of Congress,'' said Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y. ``Everybody who has a plan to expand labor programs, education, unemployment insurance, whatever, will pay for it with the millionaire surtax.''

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Downgrades Loans to Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank said Friday it no longer was counting on payments from Iraq and was starting to put aside reserves to cover $51.4 million owed by Iraq. The bank, owned by 154 countries including Iraq, lends about $21 billion a year and is the biggest single source of aid to the Third World. The United States holds the largest block of shares. Iraq's foreign debt totalled $23.7 billion last year, according to the Central Intelligence Agency. Despite its wealth from oil, Iraq borrowed heavily because of its long war with Iran. The bank's decision, effective last Monday, was announced Friday. It put Iraq on ``non-accrual'' status, normal practice when a country is six months behind on its payments. It means that payments from the debtor country are no longer listed on the bank's books, since payments have not actually arrived. There are $10.2 million in payments overdue from Iraq: $7.1 million principal and $3.1 million interest. The bank also will put aside 1 percent of the debt each month as a reserve, in case it is never repaid. Other countries froze Iraq's assets following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. As a result, President Saddam Hussein's government has been unable to make payments, the bank said in a statement. After 75 days of not paying, Iraq lost the right to new loans from the bank. Eight other countries are also on non-accrual status because they have been unwilling or unable to pay: Syria, Liberia, Zambia, Somalia, Peru, Panama, Nicaragua and Guatemala. Two others, Guyana and Honduras, have paid up and returned to normal status, so that they are once again entitled to borrow from the bank.

DOC.HEAD: Canal Security Stepped Up Against Possible Iraqi Sabotage
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Security has been increased in the Suez Canal to thwart a possible Iraqi attempt to sink a vessel and block the strategic waterway, canal officials said Friday. The canal is important for oil shipping as well as for the United States and other countries who are massing warships in the Persian Gulf region. The new security measures include putting any cement carriers at the rear of canal convoys, so that if they are sunk they would not block other vessels. Once sunk, cement carriers are extremely difficult to clear because of the wet cement. The canal carries much of Western Europe's oil and an extended blockage would hit that region's economy hard. It could be almost ruinous to Egypt, which is dependent on the more than $1.5 billion in foreign exchange earned annually by the canal. Intelligence sources in Cairo said Friday the new canal measures were in line with a security upgrade ordered nationwide on strategic installations like the canal, the Aswan High Dam in southern Egypt and vital industries. The measures have been in effect since soon after Egypt condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and sent troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force deployed in the gulf region. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has threatened to punish Arab states that sided with Kuwait in the crisis. Canal officials said authorities recently began careful checks of the itineraries and ownership of cement-carrying ships, particularly those coming from the Far East or the gulf region. On Friday, a Romanian ship carrying cement, the 38,000-ton Beius, was the last of 30 vessels to transit the 101-mile long canal. Its origin and destination were unclear. The canal officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Suez Canal Authority took the additional safeguard of dispatching two tugboats to follow the Romanian ship through the waterway. They said more Egyptian harbor workers than usual have been boarding cement-carrying ships. Such workers provide dockside and harbor services at the southern and northern ends of the canal, Suez and Port Said. In addition, they report to Egyptian intelligence on anything unusual found aboard ships. Despite the canal's value to Egypt, President Gamal Abdel Nasser in 1956 scuttled two ships carrying concrete and stones to block the waterway. He aimed to hurt Western economies in reprisal for a concerted military attack on Egypt by Britain, France and Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Make Another Effort in Court to Reconnect Woman's Feeding Tube
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with another denial of request to reconnect feeding tube. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: `One last ...'
DOC.TEXT: Courts rejected two separate requests today to resume feeding Nancy Cruzan a week after nourishment was halted to the woman who's in a vegetative state. The Missouri Supreme Court today denied a second request by anti-abortion activists who oppose euthanasia, and a Cole County court ruled that Yvette Williams, a Kansas City woman who also asked the state to restore sustenance to Ms. Cruzan, has no standing to file suit. Her request was previously denied by a Missouri appeals court. One last legal recourse remained for those seeking to reconnect her feeding tube. A hearing was scheduled this afternoon in U.S. District Court in Kansas City to consider a lawsuit to order the state to reconnect the tube. The Rev. Pat Mahoney, director of the Center for Christian Activism in Boca Raton, Fla., alleged in that suit that Ms. Cruzan's civil rights were violated when the tube was disconnected. The 33-year-old Ms. Cruzan, the central figure in the first right-to-die case considered by the U.S. Supreme Court, has been in a persistent vegetative state since suffering massive brain damage in a 1983 traffic accident. On Thursday, the Missouri Supreme Court and the Missouri Court of Appeals-Southern District in Springfield denied requests to reconnect the tube. Meanwhile in Jefferson City, about 15 protesters staged a rally in the office of state Attorney General William Webster. Andrew Burnett, a spokesman for the group, said the protesters would not leave the office until Webster intervenes in court with a motion to replace Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube. But Deputy Attorney General Jim Deutsch said the office had no legal standing in the case. The office defended Missouri law to the U.S. Supreme Court as it was required to do, Deutsch said. Once the high court ruled on the issue, the state was no longer an appropriate party in the case, he said. Food and water was removed from Ms. Cruzan seven days ago at a Mount Vernon rehabilitation center. Her condition remained listed as deteriorating today. Rehabilitation center spokeswoman Barbara Shoun said demonstrators pitched tents on the lawn outside the main entrance and endured a night of freezing rain and temperatures in the mid-teens. Police did not plan to remove the tents, she said. The Lawrence County sheriff's office said five of the 19 demonstrators jailed Tuesday for trespassing and unlawful assembly posted$1,000 bond each Thursday and were released. The others remain in custody, invoking the name Nancy Cruzan and promising to stay there, fasting, until she is fed or dies. A week after they won approval for the the removal of their daughter's feeding tube, Joe and Joyce Cruzan have no regrets about their decision to let her die, their lawyer, William Colby, said. ``Knowing Nancy as only a family could, they knew she wouldn't want to go on in her present condition. They know they've done the right thing,'' Colby said Thursday. After a probate judge ruled on Dec. 14 that her feeding tube could be disconnected, doctors said she would die within two weeks. ``It's getting late. She will be dead if we don't move quickly,'' said Randall Terry, founder of the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue. ``Oh, man,'' Terry said after the state Supreme Court's decision on Thursday, ``Isn't there one judge in this state with the moral integrity to save this woman?'' After a ruling to disconnect the tube was overturned by the state Supreme Court in 1988, Ms. Cruzan's parents appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. The high court ruled that the tube could only be disconnected if there was ``clear and convincing evidence'' that was what Ms. Cruzan would want. At a hearing last month, former co-workers testified Ms. Cruzan told them she would never want to live in a vegetative state.

DOC.HEAD: Genetically Engineered Drug Approved for Rare Immune Disease
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a new genetically engineered drug to treat a rare, life-threatening immune disorder that strikes mostly boys. People with chronic granulomatous disease, or CGD, are missing a key element of the immune system, leaving them susceptible to bacterial and fungal infections and reliant on high doses of antibiotics. The FDA said the new therapy is the first approved genetically engineered form of gamma interferon, a naturally occurring, infection-fighting protein produced by certain types of white blood cells. Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco, Calif., will market the drug under the brand name Actimmune. The drug needs to be injected only three times a week in most cases, which means ``we can now expect patients to have a more normal day-to-day life,'' said Dr. Louis Sullivan, secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, which includes the FDA. Fewer than 400 Americans have CGD, federal health officials said. Because it is so rare, the drug was developed under the FDA's ``orphan drug'' program, designed to encourage development of drugs to treat rare diseases. About 80 percent of children with the disorder suffer unusually frequent or severe infections within their first two years of life. Sometimes these infections can retard normal growth or lead to death, the FDA said. Common side effects of the drug include headache, fever, rashes and chills, but these were transient, the FDA said. Long-term effects of the drug are not known, but will be evaluated in post-marketing studies, the FDA said. However, because the drug has been shown to cause miscarriages in animals, the FDA said it should not be used during pregnancy unless its benefits clearly outweigh the potential risks.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Talk show host Oprah Winfrey is giving $50,000 to help a church in its annual holiday grocery giveaway to the poor, the church said. ``Because she is a very caring person who reaches out to the poor, she immediately responded,'' the Rev. Cecil Williams, pastor of Glide Memorial United Methodist Church, said Thursday. Glide Memorial has distributed thousands of bags of groceries to the poor since 1979. But Williams reported earlier this week that holiday contributions were down 37 percent from 1989 and asked the public for donations. Winfrey learned of the appeal through poet Maya Angelou, a member of Glide Memorial, and called Williams to say she would be sending a check, the church said. The church planned to start its holiday giveaway of more than 10,000 bags of groceries today. The church said that while donations have declined, the need for the groceries has risen. --- DETROIT (AP) - Now that the United States and the Soviet Union have made up after all these years, Mayor Coleman Young has decided the city can do the same with one of its most famous suburbs. Young, 72, will head west and Dearborn Mayor Michael Guido, 36, will head east for a one-day job swap as part of the Michigan Municipal League annual Mayor's Exchange Day. The May affair will underscore the good relationship between Young and Guido, Young spokesman Bob Berg said Friday. The cities have co-existed uneasily since the early 1920s, when automotive pioneer Henry Ford built the massive Rouge complex in Dearborn. Blacks were hired at the plant but were discouraged from living in the suburb. Today, only about 5 percent of Dearborn's approximately 100,000 residents are black. More than 70 percent of Detroit's population is black. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - The rock band Van Halen filed a federal suit against 2 Live Crew claiming the rap group used a Van Halen guitar riff on their controversial album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be.'' The U.S. District Court suit filed this week seeks more than $300,000 for copyright infringement and unfair competition. At issue is guitarist Eddie Van Halen's famous refrain in the 1978 hit record ``Ain't Talkin' 'Bout Love.'' The suit claims 2 Live Crew used the music for a song called ``The Funk Shop'' on the rap group's album. The suit was filed on behalf of Van Halen and Warner-Chappell Music against 2 Live Crew and Luke Records. Debbie Bennett, spokeswoman for the rap group and Luke Records in Coconut Grove, Fla., was not immediately available Friday for comment on the suit, a receptionist said. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Country singer Rodney Crowell says his family celebrates Christmas with a live tree, recycled wrapping paper and by having trees planted for friends instead of sending Christmas cookies. Crowell says 'tis the season to think about stewardship of the Earth, and offered a few tips on how to do so. The Grammy-award winning singer-songwriter and his wife, singer Roseanne Cash, are among the Nashville music community's most outspoken environmentalists. Besides planting their own tree in the backyard of their Nashville home after Christmas, Crowell said his family tries to make sure when the tree lights are on, that other lights are off. And he says they use candles as much as possible. ``To acknowledge the beauty of the human spirit, love and the Christ-child part of Christmas to me is about compassion,'' Crowell said in a recent interview. ``When you develop compassion for human beings, it's a trickling off and you develop compassion for plant life and for animal life in the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Baghdad Evacuated in Bombing Drill, Saddam Predicts Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Saddam predicting victory if a war occurs, Germany investigating companies for possible violation of trade sanctions.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
LaserPhoto GO1
DOC.TEXT: Air raid sirens blared and about 1 milion Iraqis carrying blankets and food streamed out of Baghdad early today in an evacuation drill to test the nation's readiness for war. As Iraqis jammed roads out of the capital, U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today in Saudi Arabia that war with Iraq was increasingly likely. ``Absolute, total victory'' is the only option if war breaks out, he said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was no less confident, predicting victory in any war with the U.S.-led multinational forces. He also stood by his refusal to pull out of Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline. Germany's ZDF television network broadcast the Saddam interview today, saying it had been conducted in Baghdad on Thursday. ``In the event of war, there will be great losses, not just in terms of human life. Those who now say yes to war will be responsible,'' Saddam said. ``Allah is on our side, so we will defeat the aggressors.'' In Germany today, the government said it was investigating U.S. suspicions that German companies are violating trade sanctions against Iraq. One firm denied giving Iraq sensitive nuclear know-how and equipment. The government confirmed a report that Washington has given it a list of German companies suspected of violating the U.N. embargo. Government spokesman Dieter Vogel said the U.S. allegations were being investigated but no proof has been found of deliveries that violate the sanctions. President Bush was to meet later today with John Major, Britain's new prime minister. In several television interviews today, Major said the question of war was ``in Saddam Hussein's hands.'' Also today, the U.S. military command said eight American soldiers have been poisoned by home-brewed alcohol and hospitalized since Sunday. The soldiers, from the 101st Airborne Division, are the first known casualties of home-brewed liquor since U.S. forces were deployed in Saudi Arabia, a Moslem country that bans all alcohol. During the evacuation drill many Iraqis stayed home, residents said. Participants ran on foot to civil defense centers in Baghdad or sped out of town in cars. Hundreds of buses waiting at centers took Iraqis to shelters north, east and south of the city. Roads leading out of the capital were jammed with thousands of cars, trucks, buses and even carriages pulled by tractors.The drill began at 7 a.m. and ended five hours later. Iraq has been preparing for war since the U.N. Security Council authorized force to remove Iraq from Kuwait if it does not leave the emirate by Jan. 15. Iraqi media carry instructions for building bomb shelters and courses in civil defense and first-aid. U.S. officials have suggested Iraq's cities could be bombed heavily in the event of war. Gen. Michael Dugan, the air force chief of staff, was fired in September for revealing contingency plans that involved bombing Baghdad. The evacuation drill today was conducted for the half of Baghdad that lies on the east bank of the Tigris River, but only about 1 million of the 2 million residents participated, said residents, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A second exercise Saturday will cover west Baghdad. Basra, Iraq's second-largest city with a million people, was evacuated in a similar exercise Thursday. In Saudi Arabia, Cheney told troops that war was closer. ``It increasingly looks like (Saddam's) not getting the message and we'll have to use force,'' Cheney said. ``The only acceptable outcome, if hostilities begin, is absolute, total victory.'' Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, said that if an attack were lauched: ``We will launch it violently, we will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we canget it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.'' Bush met with members of Congress on Thursday and told them he believed Saddam was underestimating U.S. power and intentions, several legislators said. Saddam must be made aware that ``if we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked,'' Rep. Elton Gallegly, R-Calif., quoted Bush as saying. Bush's remark was confirmed by another person at the meeting. A Pentagon spokesman said 10,000 more U.S. troops reached Saudi Arabia this week, bringing the American force to 280,000. The spokesman, Bob Hall, said U.S. intelligence sources put the Iraqi force in and around Kuwait at 510,000.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wounded During Son's Gun Safety Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: A son trying to demonstrate handgun safety wounded his father when the pistol fired. The bullet hit John Theis, 73, above his heart and lodged in his shoulder Wednesday night. He was treated at Los Robles Medical Center and released Thursday afternoon. ``The doctor told him he should go out and buy a lottery ticket today,'' his wife Helen said. Mrs. Theis said her son Mark, 28, was visiting them when he decided to take the gun to his residence in Canoga Park. His girlfriend protested so he offered a demonstration of handgun safety. He removed a bullet clip from the automatic pistol, accidentally leaving a single slug in the chamber. The weapon discharged as he was flipping one of two safety mechanisms, sending a .45-caliber slug ricocheting off a table, through a cookie tin and into his father's chest.

DOC.HEAD: Former Head of Failed Thrift Agrees To Pay $16 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 2 to CORRECT Dixon's middle initial to R, sted L.
DOC.TEXT: The former president of a Dallas thrift whose failure could cost taxpayers $2 billion agreed to plead guilty to fraud charges and pay $16 million in penalties and restitution, the Justice Department said today. The Justice Department's plea agreement with Edwin T. McBirney III, former president and chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association, was made public a day after a federal court jury convicted another Texas S&L operator, Don R. Dixon. ``Federal prosecutors have dealt a one-two punch to the savings and loan crooks this week,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. ``McBirney's agreement to plead guilty, coupled with yesterday's conviction of Don Dixon, caps a year of relentless and unprecedented pressure on thrift thieves,'' Thornburgh said. McBirney, who was indicted in July on 17 counts, agreed to plead guilty to four counts of bank fraud, filing a false corporate tax return, causing a false statement to be filed by Sunbelt and misapplying $250,000 in Sunbelt funds. The bank fraud count stems from a $700 million deal to finance the purchase of real estate in Southern California by a Sunbelt subsidiary. McBirney agreed to admit that he arranged a fraudulent $30 million reciprocal loan arrangement with Western Savings Association, another Dallas thrift, to help finance the real estate deal, the Justice Department said. He could be sentenced to up to 15 years imprisonment under the terms of the guilty plea. McBirney, 37, also agreed to pay $7.5 million in restitution and $8.5 million to settle civil claims by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The Justice Department announcement did not say when McBirney, who agreed to cooperate with the government's continuing investigation of the S&L scandal, would appear in federal court to enter the guilty plea. Sour loans made by Sunbelt, and its merger in 1988 with a healthier S&L, are expected to cost the government $2 billion in bailout funds, regulators say. On Thursday, Dixon, another Dallas S&L operator, was convicted of illegally spending money from his Vernon Savings and Loan Association on prostitutes and a California beach house. Dixon, 52, could be sentenced to as many as 115 years in prison and fined $5.75 million for his convictions on 23 fraud counts.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Council Argues Over Car Fuel-Efficiency Rules
DOC.TEXT: Administration officials at odds over energy conservation met Friday with President Bush, trying to sway him on alternative car fuels and other possible ingredients of his national energy strategy. Energy Secretary James Watkins, who made a presentation Friday at the meeting of Bush's Economic Policy Council, is recommending that the strategy include both increased fuel efficiency standards and a requirement for greater use of nongasoline fuels. Those proposals are supported by the Agriculture Department, and by Environmental Protection Agency Administrator William Reilly. But other advisers, including White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and chief White House economist Michael Boskin, are fighting the proposals on grounds that they would be costly and involve excessive government regulation. Others siding with Sununu, according to officials who spoke on condition of anonymity, include Bush's domestic policy adviser Roger Porter and budget director Richard Darman. After Watkins spoke Friday, Porter and Boskin ``pounded away'' at what they consider the unreasonable options, one participant said. Many planks of the proposed strategy have received consensus approval from the various government agencies involved in the talks. Members of the Cabinet-level council agreed to meet again with Bush on the sticky issues remaining after he returns Jan. 1 from his holiday stay at Camp David, Md., officials said. Considerable discussion Friday centered on whether auto manufacturers should be required to increase production of cars that can use alternative fuels, said one official. He characterized the debate, with Bush present, as a ``healthy discussion'' that did not reach the acrimonious levels of a council meeting on the subject last week. The strategy contains 45 different measures dealing with the nation's future energy needs and how to avoid reliance on foreign oil The document, expected to be finished early next year, comes at a sensitive time on the international front in light of the crisis in the oil-rich Persian Gulf. Among the options that have not produced argument within the administration is a proposal to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration and development. Bush has long supported such a move, but it is expected to run into heavy opposition in Congress and from environmentalists.

DOC.HEAD: Short-Term T-Bills Drop to Lowest Rate in 2{ Years
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Friday's auction to their lowest level in nearly 2{ years. The Treasury Department sold $10.0 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.52 percent, down from 6.78 percent on Monday. Another $10.0 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.57 percent, down from 6.77 percent earlier this week. The auction, which normally would have been held next Monday, was pushed up to Friday because of Christmas Eve. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 6.51 percent on June 20, l988, and six-month bills averaged 6.50 percent on May 16, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 6.72 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,835.20 and 6.89 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,667.90.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Logo Delays Delivery of Magazine to Gulf Troops
With AM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A shipment of magazines for U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia is being held up for about a week because they are wrapped in a cover bearing cigarette advertising unaccompanied by a required disclaimer, the Pentagon said Friday. The approximately 101,000 magazines were the first shipment to be collected by Operation Desert News, a Charleston, S.C., organization that distributes reading matter to U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf. The shipment was held up, however, when the organization decided to have the magazines wrapped in special covers with the name of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. on the front and the trademark of the company's Camel cigarettes on the back. The wrappers should have had a disclaimer stating that the federal government was not endorsing the sponsor or its products or paying for the covers, said Maj. Maureen DeCiantis, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Central Command at MacDill Air Force Base, Fla. ``In this case it was not done, because Desert News didn't know they had to do it, and we didn't know they had a tobacco company as a backer,'' DeCiantis said. Pentagon officials found a solution to the problem Friday. ``We're going to print the declaration on the front and take the camel off the back,'' said Lt. Col. Henry Wyatt, a spokesman for the Defense Logistics Agency, which oversees the shipments. He said it was expected to take about a week. The magazine publisher who organized the shipment said he was vexed by the delay. ``It's magazines that we're sending. We're not sending cigarettes,'' said Tim Karnes, publisher of Auction Guide and the organizer of Operation Desert News. Karnes said the magazines, which include Life, Fine Woodworking and Modern Drummer, were donated to the organization by the publishers. ``Everybody involved knew that R.J. Reynolds was the sponsor,'' Karnes added. All the magazines, some of which contain cigarette advertising, were approved by the Defense Department, he said. The covers were printed Wednesday at Quebecor Printing USA in St. Cloud, Minn. ``I don't think the advertisement about cigarettes should jeopardize the ability to provide this reading material, which is just desperately needed for morale,'' Karnes said in a telephone interview from Acapulco, Mexico, where he was vacationing. Reynolds is the organization's only corporate sponsor so far, although Karnes said the group was seeking others. Karnes said the organization submitted a rough draft of the first page of the cover, which may not have contained the R.J. Reynolds identification, and did not submit the back page. He said the organization did not realize any disclaimer would be needed.

DOC.HEAD: Former Trump Exec Says Trump Attorneys Threatened Him Over His Book
DOC.TEXT: Developer Donald Trump isn't waiting for the publication of a book exposing the underbelly of his casino empire to try and squash the story, the author says. The book, ``Trumped: The Decline and Fall of Donald Trump'' was written by former Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino President Jack O'Donnell. It is due to be published May 1. O'Donnell, the chief operating officer at rival Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel, said Trump attorneys barged into his Resorts office unannounced on Wednesday and tried to intimidate him. Trump on Thursday denied the charge. ``Jack O'Donnell is a man who is a disgruntled former employee,'' Trump said in a telephone interview from New York City. ``He went to work for Merv Griffin. I'm surprised Merv Griffin would allow him to write such a book. But life is full of surprises.'' O'Donnell said in a statement that Trump has threatened to disclose ``defamatory and untruthful allegations'' if the book is published. O'Donnell declined to elaborate. O'Donnell angrily resigned from Trump Plaza in April, saying he could no longer stand working for Trump. Trump's casinos have undergone a difficult year. Both Trump Plaza and Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay have lost business to Trump's third casino, the Taj Mahal Casino Resort, which opened April 2. The Taj Mahal is scheduled to file for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code as part of a restructuring of its $675 million in debt. Trump said he would wait to read the book before deciding whether he would pursue any legal action.

DOC.HEAD: Protests, Attempts at Legal Intervention Mark Right-to-Die Case
LaserPhoto JF1
With AM-Vegetative State
DOC.TEXT: Three years after Joe and Joyce Cruzan asked the courts to let their severely brain-injured daughter die with dignity, her impending death has become a focus of protests and legal maneuvers by strangers. Nineteen people were arrested Tuesday after they burst into the Missouri Rehabilitation Center and tried to reach Nancy Cruzan's room to reconnect her feeding tube, which was removed Dec. 14. Anti-euthanasia activists had no success in asking various courts to force the state to resume feeding Ms. Cruzan. Their appeals were rejected Friday by the state Supreme Court, Cole County Court and the U.S. District Court. Missouri's highest courts rejected other appeals Thursday. About 15 demonstrators continued a round-the-clock vigil on the hospital steps Friday, praying, singing and holding signs that read ``Please Feed Nancy Cruzan.'' From their daughter's heavily tinted window on the second floor, Joe and Joyce Cruzan can see the demonstrators, but avoid contact with them. ``I would have thought the protests would have bothered them but they are in so much pain from what would cause us all pain, having a child die. Really, that is their focus,'' said the couple's attorney, William Colby. Ms. Cruzan, 33, has been in a persistent vegetative state since a car accident on Jan. 11, 1983. Doctors said her condition is irreversible, and her parents won court approval last month to remove the feeding tube. Doctors expected Ms. Cruzan to die within two weeks of the tube's removal. Her condition was listed as deteriorating Friday, a week after the tube was removed. Colby said the Cruzans have received a ``massive outpouring of support'' from people across the country. ``The mail and calls that we've received have been 40- or 50-to-1 in strong support of the family,'' he said. At the same time, anti-euthanasia activists have converged on the red-brick rehabilitation center in this southwestern Missouri community of 3,400 and claimed the Cruzan case as an extension of their cause. Fourteen demonstrators remained jailed Friday, giving their name as Nancy Cruzan and vowing to stay there and fast until she is fed or dies. ``This may be the most important story in the pro-life history,'' said Bob Jewitt, a spokesman for Operation Rescue, a group best known for its anti-abortion protests. Ms. Cruzan's court-appointed guardian, who told a probate judge that letting her die was in her best interest, called Operation Rescue founder Randall Terry and the other demonstrators ``publicity-seeking scofflaws.'' ``They are acting through ignorance. They have no idea of the facts of her situation,'' said Thad McCanse, a Carthage attorney. Doctors say Ms. Cruzan is oblivious to her surroundings, cannot speak and does not feel emotions or pain. She suffers from a variety of ailments, including severely contorted limbs, vomiting, bleeding gums and diarrhea. Dr. Ronald Cranford, a Minneapolis neurologist who has examined Ms. Cruzan, called her a ``prisoner of medical technology'' who has no hope for recovery. ``The question is, will the withdrawal of feeding tubes become more widespread in letting people like Nancy Cruzan die? Absolutely,'' said Cranford, chairman of the American Academy of Neurology's ethics committee. Demonstrators such as Yvette Williams, a part-time caretaker of severely disabled children who was a plaintiff in one of the lawsuits, have expressed concern over such prospects. ``Our laws protect life,'' Miss Williams said in a statement. ``What is happening here offends me. I cannot in conscience be a party to the killing of Nancy Cruzan.'' McCanse disagreed. ``What's inhumane is maintaining her feeding tube so she can live another 30 or 40 years with extensive, irreversible brain damage. If there are any barbarians involved in this, it's the people making a circus out of this,'' McCanse said. As the ethical debate rages on around them, the Cruzans have been at Nancy's side virtually since the tube was removed. The couple, who have two other daughters, do not regret their decision, Colby said. ``Knowing Nancy as only a family could, they knew she wouldn't want to go on in her present condition. They know they've done the right thing,'' Colby said.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Meets Gorbachev; Role In Gov't Considered
LaserPhotosMOSB6-8
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to separate first two grafs, tighten. Pick up 9th pvs, `It also ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with Eduard Shevardnadze Friday, reportedly to discuss some way of keeping his longtime ally in the government following his sudden resignation as foreign minister. In parliament, reformers turned Shevardnadze's unexpected resignation into a rallying cry. A parade of speakers echoed the 62-year-old diplomat's warning that hard-liners were pushing the country toward dictatorship. Gorbachev talked privately with Shevardnadze for two hours about the Persian Gulf crisis and conventional arms reductions in Europe, presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko told reporters. Ignatenko called the session ``an ordinary meeting between the president and his foreign minister,'' the independent Interfax news agency said. Presidential aide Georgi Shakhnazarov said Gorbachev also had planned to ask Shevardnadze why he resigned: ``Was it political motives, or personal motives? And depending on the answers, it would be possible to decide whether to ask him to continue working in that role, or in another role, or to agree on something else.'' It was not clear whether Gorbachev intended to ask Shevardnadze to continue as foriegn minister or to take another post. A Shevardnadze aide said Thursday the resignation was ``irreversible.'' Earlier Friday, Tass quoted Shakhnazarov as saying Shevardnadze would stay ``on Gorbachev's team,'' but offered no other details. There was no further word late Friday about the meeting or whether Gorbachev had reached any decision about the foreign minister's job. Shevardnadze made no public comment. It also was not known whether Shevardnadze would take part in a Moscow arms control summit Feb. 11-13 between Gorbachev and President Bush. On Thursday, Shevardnadze stunned Gorbachev, the parliament and the world community by resigning. In what he called ``the briefest and most difficult speech of my life,'' Shevardnadze said reformers had ``gone and hidden in the bushes'' and ``dictatorship is coming.'' ``No one knows what kind of dictatorship it will be, what kind of dictator will come, and what order things will take,'' Shevardnadze said. His resignation prompted worldwide concern over the future of reform in the Soviet Union. Hard-liners have urged Gorbachev to impose a state of emergency in republics ridden by ethnic conflict and separatist movements. Gorbachev has asked the Congress to consider constitutional amendments to strengthen his power to deal with such trouble spots. The hard-liners also had criticized Soviet endorsement of a U.N. resolution on the use of force in the gulf, but their main criticism was over domestic issues. A Ukrainian lawmaker shook up the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies on Friday afternoon by saying a ``right-wing reactionary coup'' was brewing. ``Reactionaries, centralists, and imperialists have united and are on the attack,'' lawmaker Vladimir Chernyak said. ``At the head of the coup stands Gorbachev. It's possible he himself doesn't know it. By demanding for himself more and more powers, he is creating the legal basis for a dictatorship - maybe not for himself personally.'' Chernyak, an economist elected from Kiev, said hard-liners already have succeeded in forcing Shevardnadze and former Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin from their jobs. ``Why does Gorbachev respond to the right and not the left? There's no mystery. The whole thing is that Gorbachev is the son of his party and a defender of its interests,'' Chernyak said. Gorbachev sat forward in his chair, listening intently to the Ukrainian. Chernyak also called for direct elections for a new president and parliament. A representative of the Inter-Regional Group - a reform faction of lawmakers whose members included the late human rights campaigner Andrei Sakharov - called on Gorbachev to reject pressure from hard-liners. ``We share the alarm of Foreign Minister Shevardnadze about the possibility of the breakup of democratic processes in the country and the danger of the establishment of a reactionary dictatorship,'' said Vitaly A. Chelyshev. Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak, a prominent reformer, took the podium to say Shevardnadze's warning was ``more than serious.'' He said people were losing faith in the ability to solve problems democratically. ``If that is so, then only dictatorship is left.'' However, army chief of staff Mikhail Moiseyev disputed Shevardnadze's warning of a ``coming dictatorship,'' and said there was no reason to impose a state of emergency as is feared by some. ``It is most regrettable that he did this as such an unsuitable moment, when the Congress has to discuss more important tasks (and) find mutually acceptable decisions to consolidate all forces and extricate the country from grave crisis,'' Moiseyev said, according to Tass. In their meeting, Gorbachev also planned to ask why Shevardnadze never consulted him before resigning, the president's aide said. ``Shevardnadze was his companion, a person he worked with, placed trust in. So if he was leaving, he should have said something,'' Shakhnazarov said. Shevardnadze has won international praise since being appointed in 1985 by Gorbachev, who won this year's Nobel Peace Prize for foreign policy successes. Under Shevardnadze's stewardship, the Soviet Union pulled its troops out of Afghanistan, negotiated cuts in nuclear arsenals, allowed East European countries to oust Communist regimes and ended antagonistic relations with Cold War foes.

DOC.HEAD: Shooting of Kids Doesn't Faze Classmates in Washington
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Xaziver in 17th graf is CQ
DOC.TEXT: In parts of the nation's capital, violence doesn't seem to rattle the kids anymore. Not even the classmates of four junior high school students shot after class - along with a 6-year-old girl - by rivals firing from a passing car. ``They look at it like, `It's just the neighborhood,''' said a teacher Friday at the imposing cinder-block Shaw Junior High School. ```It's another day at the office. No big deal,''' he said, requesting anonymity. In many communities, the day after a multiple shooting of children - the youngest 6 and the eldest 15 - would have meant a rush of counselors into the local schools to calm the fears of students who must walk the same tough streets. But not here. Here, the students generally did not mention the shootings. And teachers made no special effort to draw them out, the one teacher said as students chatted animatedly during lunch period. Three arrests had been made. Two of the students were released from the hospital. Three remained, all improving. This is the city that has had a record 471 homicides this year, 30 of them juveniles, according to the police count. This is the city that has seen an additional 1,163 people shot, 204 of them juveniles. Thursday's shootings resulted from an altercation a week or two ago between two loosely organized groups of young people, said Police Chief Isaac Fulwood, but he declined to say what it was about. When asked if the dispute involved drugs, as 40 percent of the homicides this year have, Fulwood lashed out: ``I don't know whether it was drug-related or not, but I doubt it. Don't make everything drug-related; it cheapens the violence.'' He blamed easy access to guns, pervasive violence on television, and a breakdown in values, saying the altercation between the groups would have been settled in the old days by a simple fist fight. Family breakups and the lack of parents inculcating values in their children have led to a society that believes ``anything goes in order to get what I want,'' Fulwood said. The chief said he has spoken to young people about shootings and he has found they show ``no remorse, not the first tear. There's no sense that there's anything wrong.'' The attack about 3 p.m. Thursday involved multiple gunshots by shooters in a car passing by the victims. Police arrested three juveniles - one 16 and the other two 14 - before dawn Friday. Two other 14-year-old suspects were still at large, Fulwood said. No names were released because of their ages, and the chief said no decision had yet been made on whether to try any as adults. Three were arraigned Friday in juvenile court. All five victims were treated at Children's National Medical Center. Xaziver Paul, 6, and Troy Gray, 15, were discharged Friday, spokeswoman Barbara Cire said. Brian Lewis, 12, was listed in good condition. John Olden, 13, and Clarence Richmond, 14, were in fair condition, all improved after first being termed in serious condition. Two children were shot in the chest, two in the abdomen and one in the arm, said Dr. Marty Eichelberger, director of emergency trauma services at the hospital. ``There are five kids, and there are a lot of holes,'' Eichelberger said. Fulwood praised the principal of the junior high school, Dr. Percy Ellis, and the school staff, saying they were ``pivotal'' in tracking down the alleged assailants. Ellis declined reporters' requests for interviews. The shootings didn't come as a complete surprise to police. Officers went to the junior high school earlier Thursday when officials ``heard something was going down,'' said Lt. Reginald Smith, a police spokesman. Instead, it happened about eight blocks away, as the victims stood near a picket fence in the Shaw residential area of northwest Washington. Shaw is one of the city's poorest neighborhoods, but it is expected to experience an economic upturn next year when a subway station opens. Already it's a mixture of low-rise, single-family townhouses - some of them with small but carefully manicured yards and Christmas decorations draping the front doors - houses subdivided into apartments and boarded up buildings. A baseball field is near the intersection where the shootings occurred. There's a large playground a block away. A 28-year-old man who moved out of the neighborhood five years ago and returns only to visit his parents said he wasn't surprised to hear of the shootings. ``That's the atmosphere around here,'' said the man, who would not give his name. ``We're trying to move them out to where we're living in Maryland,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Law Prevents New Buildings From Casting Shadows on Historic Boston Common
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis couldn't stop clouds from blocking the sun over historic Boston Common Friday, but he signed into law a bill to prevent new buildings from shadowing the common for more than one hour a day. ``The good Lord is casting a shadow over us all here, even as I speak,'' Dukakis said before he signed the bill, standing at the edge of the park. Commons are found in many New England towns. Boston Common was established in 1634, when the city's first settler, a hermit named William Blackstone, agreed to sell 45 acres to the town of Boston. Boston Common was first used as a pasture for citizens' animals. Later, it was a training site for the militia and the site of public hangings. Today, the common is a popular tourist attraction. It's located on Beacon Hill, just below the gold-domed Massachusetts Statehouse. Senate President William Bulger, who represents parts of Boston, sponsored the bill, which he said will give ``a greater protection for this particular important part of our lives.'' The new law also applies to the common in the nearby town of Lynn. The bill's sponsors added Lynn to the measure to bypass a requirement that the city first approve the measure. Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn had opposed the bill, but went along with it after it was amended slightly. The lame-duck governor said one thing he will miss in leaving office next month is looking out on the common from his office window. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic presidential candidate, did not seek re-election as governor this year. Republican William Weld was elected and will be inaugurated on Jan. 3. ``I can tell you that there have been many occasions where for a variety of reasons I have needed a certain amount spiritual uplifting,'' Dukakis said, ``and there's nothing like walking over to that window and looking down.''

DOC.HEAD: Monthly Red Ink 62 Percent Increase Over Year-Ago Level
DOC.TEXT: The federal government ran up a $48.1 billion deficit in November, a 62 percent increase over a year ago, due in part to the Persian Gulf buildup and a failing economy, the Treasury Department reported Friday. Combined with the October deficit, the imbalance for the first two months of fiscal 1991 totaled $79.5 billion, up 42.5 percent from the comparable period of fiscal 1990. Economist Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm, said the weakening economy is resulting in declining tax revenues. ``It's really getting to the point where the deficit is starting to balloon because both personal and corporate taxes are starting to fall off,'' he said. ``Receipts in November were $6 billion less than they should have been in a normal economy.'' The government collected $27.2 billion in individual income taxes last month, a 21 percent decline from November 1989. At the same time, corporate income taxes were down 46 percent to $1.3 billion. At the same time, defense spending increased 18 percent from a year ago, to $29 billion, reflecting the military buildup in the Middle East. And spending on the savings and loan bailout jumped to $2.8 billion, up 220 percent from the $879 million outlay in November 1989. Overall, receipts totaled $72.8 billion in November, up 2.3 percent from the same month last year. Spending, however, jumped 20 percent, from $100.9 billion in 1989 to $120.9 billion last month. The deficit is the difference between the two. The Bush administration already has conceded the fiscal 1991 deficit will set a new record. Budget director Richard Darman has projected the imbalance at between $250 billion and $300 billion. The Congressional Budget Office, on the other hand, forecasts a $320 billion gap this year. The deficit in fiscal 1990 was $220.4 billion, just shy of the $221.2 billion record set in 1986. As usual, the biggest spending categories were the military, Social Security and other programs of the Department of Health and Human Services and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $5.1 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $292.2 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $21.5 billion for the month and $41.0 billion for the year. They are projected to total $262.2 billion for the year. Other HHS payments, including Medicare and Medicaid, totaled $17.8 billion in August and $35.1 billion for 1990 so far. They are projected to total $210.4 billion in fiscal 1990. Interest on the national debt amounted to $21.9 billion for the month and $40.0 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $287.0 billion for the entire year.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Rally on First Anniversary of Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Romanians rallied on the first anniversary of the revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, but the marches were tinged by frustrations over increasing economic hardships. Rallies in Bucharest and Timisoara, the cradle of last year's revolution, capped a week of protests against Ceausescu's successors. Romanians are frustrated with the lack of improved living standards since 1989. About 15,000 people gathered in Bucharest's University Square, chanting slogans against President Ion Iliescu. Another 15,000 workers rallied in Timisoara, 300 miles northwest of the capital. The two weeks prior to the revolution's anniversary have been marked by strikes and protests against the National Salvation Front government. The Front, which took power during the revolution and won subsequent May elections, faces sliding popularity over its plans to reform the economy that include raising prices on basic goods. ``Illiescu is a liar'' and ``He will fall, down, down, down,'' the Bucharest crowd chanted. In an address Friday to Parliament, Iliescu said the government must press ahead with reforms, despite growing popular opposition. ``We must prove we are ready for ... democracy,'' Iliescu said, adding that 1991 would be ``a decisive year for all our reforms.'' On University Square, where police shot and killed demonstrators last Dec. 21, crowds knelt and lighted candles in memory of the uprising's 1,039 dead. After a minute of silence, the anti-government chants continued. In Timisoara, protesters also chanted, ``Down with Iliescu'' and ``Down with communism.'' About 75,000 industrial workers in Timisoara, where the uprising began Dec. 16, 1989, have been on strike for a week. They rally daily in the city. Other strikes have included more than 100,000 students and hundreds of professors. A protest by navigators at the Tarom state airline has paralyzed internal flights and stranded many international travelers. Many Romanians are disillusioned with the results of the revolution, feeling little has changed in a country plagued by shortages. Critics also charge that Front leaders - many of them former Communists - still harbor authoritarian tendencies. Echoing the battle cry directed at Ceausescu one year ago, the crowd in Bucharest chanted ``Timisoara, Timisoara.'' The bloody suppression of pro-democracy demonstrators began the popular unrest in Bucharest last year. ``A year ago the army, police and Securitate (secret police) made a pact with the devil to bring Iliescu to power,'' said one speaker at the Bucharest rally. The square was ringed with blue police vans but no incidents were reported. The large, open area between Bucharest University and the National Theater was where last year's revolution took hold of the capital and protesters died challenging police and the army. The next day, hundreds of thousands rallied in the streets of Bucharest, forcing Ceausescu and his wife Elena to flee. The couple was captured by the army and summarily tried and executed Dec. 25. The square, which is also the capital's central intersection, has since been the site of repeated anti-government protests, some ending in violent clashes with police. Rally organizers said the demonstration would continue through the night until Saturday morning but many were disappointed by Friday's turnout. ``We are so few because the government lies to people through television,'' said one woman. Others blamed the cold, snowy weather - a sharp contrast to spring-like days that preceded last year's events. At one point, the crowd began chanting ``Long live King Michael,'' referring to the Hohenzollern monarch, forced to abdicate by the Communists in 1946. He lives in exile in Switzerland. His daughter, Princess Margarita, who watched Friday's rally from a balcony of a luxury hotel overlooking the square, said she thought a restoration of constitutional monarchy in Romania was ``possible.'' ``The people need a father, they need a figure, a symbol of unity,'' said Margarita, 40, in Romania on a three-week aid mission to orphanages and other charities.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Announces Project to Clean Up Rio's Bay
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday announced a $500 million project to dredge and clean up Rio's picturesque Guanabara Bay, polluted by years of chemical waste-dumping. The federal project, to begin next month, includes the construction of underground drains, recycling plants and waste treatment facilities, said Eliana Farias, a spokesman in the Social Action Ministry. Scientists say it will take until the year 2005 to finish the cleanup. The bay, known worldwide for the picture-postcard Sugarloaf Mountain rising at its mouth, will also be dredged to halt a 50-year erosion of its banks, Farias said by telephone from Brasilia. The cleanup will occur in conjunction with ``Project Rio.'' That $390 million campaign, financed by the World Bank, is underway to clean Rio's waterways and beaches and upgrade the city's sanitation department, Farias said. ``The great surprise of next summer will be that we'll actually have clean beaches and water to enjoy,'' said Rio state Gov. Wellington Moreira Franco. Today, the bay receives an estimated 100 tons of chemical waste from oil refineries daily. Ocean tides carry some residue out to sea, but much of it washes up on the shores of Rio's famous beaches, including Copacabana and Ipanema. The environmental effort was planned shortly after Rio was chosen as the host city of the 1992 U.N. World Environment Conference. Leaders from more than 100 countries are expected to attend and discuss issues including climatic changes, ozone deterioration and rain forest preservation.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
With Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Here are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

The White House raised doubts Friday that the United States would attack Ira immediately if it fails to meet next month's deadline for withdrawing from Kuwait. ``January 15 is not an attack day at all,'' said Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser. --- In Saudi Arabia, U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told troops that war was closer. ``It increasingly looks like (Saddam's) not getting the message and we'll have to use force,'' Cheney said. ``The only acceptable outcome, if hostilities begin, is absolute, total victory.'' Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, told the troops that in the event of an attack: ``We will launch it violently, we will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we can get it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.'' --- Iraqi President Saddam Hussein predicted victory in any war. He also stood by his refusal to pull out of Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline. ``In the event of war, there will be great losses, not just in terms of human life. Those who now say yes to war will be responsible. Allah is on our side, so we will defeat the aggressors,'' Saddam told Germany's ZDF television network. --- British Prime Minister John Major said in Washington that Iraqi troops will have to be ``forcibly removed'' from Kuwait if Saddam does not agree to withdraw them peacefully. Major said a partial Iraqi pullback would not be acceptable. --- A million Iraqis heeded air raid sirens and jammed roads out of Baghdad in an evacuation drill to test readiness for war. Residents, clutching blankets and food, jumped into cars or rushed to special centers where they caught buses to evacuation camps set up outside the capital. --- In Germany, the government said it was investigating U.S. suspicions that German companies are violating a trade embargo against Iraq. One firm denied giving Iraq sensitive nuclear know-how and equipment. The government confirmed a report that Washington has given it a list of German companies suspected of violating the U.N. embargo. --- The U.S. military command said eight American soldiers have been poisoned by home-brewed alcohol and hospitalized since Sunday. The soldiers, from the 101st Airborne Division, are the first known casualties of home-brewed liquor since U.S. forces were deployed in Saudi Arabia, a Moslem country that bans all alcohol.

DOC.HEAD: FEC Dismisses Complaint Against Pro-Israel Lobby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs top 9 grafs to CORRECT that the ``black book'' complaint is an undecided case separate from the case the FEC decided, picking up in 10th graf pvs, Although the
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission voted unanimously to dismiss allegations that pro-Israel lobbying groups broke election laws by illegally coordinating their activities, according to documents released Friday. The commission said its six members ``find no reason to believe'' the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) violated lobbying rules in connection with 27 political action committees around the country. The vote was taken last year but was kept secret because an unrelated complaint involving AIPAC and other organizations is still pending, said commission spokesman Fred Eiland. The agency disclosed its findings only after lengthy arguments with the complainants, who requested publication of the material under the Freedom of Information Act. The complaint, filed Jan. 12, 1989, was brought by several former U.S. officials who have long argued that AIPAC exercises undue influence on Congress and skews U.S. foreign policy in Israel's favor. They accused AIPAC of failing to disclose what they said was its coordination of the 27 other PACs. In the undecided case, the same plaintiffs contended AIPAC should have registered as a political action committee because, they said, it targeted political candidates for election or defeat based on their position toward Israel. This case involves the alleged use of a ``black book'' containing vital information on every Senate and House race. AIPAC responded that such activities were internal communications with its 55,000 members and protected by Supreme Court rulings. In the case that it decided, the FEC said there was not enough evidence to show that AIPAC and the other pro-Israel committees were affiliated. Although the 27 PACs received information regarding congressional races, ``it appears that each respondent PAC makes independent decisions regarding which candidates to support,'' the commission said. The plaintiffs demanded that AIPAC be forced to register as a public action committee and disclose its activities - a move that would have hampered behind-the-scenes lobbying with Congress and the administration. Among the plaintiffs were: one-time ambassador to Saudi Arabia, James E. Akins; Paul Findley, who says he lost his seat in Congress in 1982 because of an AIPAC campaign, and George Ball, who served as undersecretary of state in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations. The complaint relied on large measure on news reports about the activities of the lobbying group, in addition to two internal AIPAC memoranda. AIPAC's 125-page response, accompanied by hundreds of pages of exhibits, said, ``No one directs American Jews to become active in liberal organizations or conservative organizations, or in political campaigns, or to give to candidates or to form political organizations of their own.'' The FEC found that the similar pattern of political contributions by the 27 PACs resulted from their focus on candidates who support Israel and did not reflect collusion between them and AIPAC.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam, in Interview, Predicts Victory in Any Gulf War
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein said in an interview broadcast Friday that U.S. forces would not be able to sustain a prolonged war with Iraq and President Bush would be forced to order a retreat after American casualties mounted to 5,000. Saddam, in the interview on Germany's ZDF television network, refused again to pull out of Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for avoiding force. But the Iraqi leader also claimed to be interested in holding talks with the U.S. government. ``From our side, the door for a dialogue still remains open,'' said the Iraqi president. ``We are for a dialogue. Without it, there is no understanding.'' ZDF broadcast the interview Friday evening, saying it had been conducted in Baghdad the day before. ``In the event of war, there will be great losses, not just in terms of human life. Those who now say `yes' to war will be responsible,'' Saddam said. ``Allah is on our side, so we will defeat the aggressors.'' The Iraqi leader made his comments in Arabic and they were translated into German by the television network. The Associated Press in turn translated the remarks into English. ``When 5,000 Americans have fallen, (President) Bush will have to end such a war, not because they (the troops) are bad, but because he is a bad leader,'' said Saddam. ``He is sending the soldiers to their death without reason.'' Asked whether he would pull his troops out of Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations, the Iraqi chief answered ``no.'' ``We are certain that even when Bush pushes his country into war, which he plans, he can't keep it going,'' Saddam said. He accused the U.S. government of aiming to conquer the holy places of Islam by sending troops to the desert of Saudi Arabia, and said Bush was failing to try to solve the true problems of the region. ``So, we say to Bush, `leave our country,''' Saddam said. ``If there are problems among the Arabs, they can solve them the best by themselves.'' Asked whether a war with the United States and the rest of the multinational force would mean ``suicide'' for his country, Saddam responded: ``We are Moslems and don't believe in suicide.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday in Saudi Arabia that war with Iraq was increasingly likely. ``Absolute, total victory'' is the only option if war breaks out, he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Moving Tribute: Golden Anniversary of West's First Freeway
LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: In a rare mood, Southern Californians praised a freeway instead of cursing it, as the ``granddaddy of freeways'' celebrated its 50th birthday Friday. Though the 8.2-mile Pasadena Freeway, the first in the West, looks like a museum piece, the sunken six-lane freeway is among the state's safest, despite thrill-ride curves and floor-it, sudden-stop ramps. The first five-mile section of the freeway opened Dec. 30, 1940. In a small park beside one especially harrowing curve, the California Department of Transportation celebrated the anniversary with a sign denoting the span's significance. Almost predictably, the celebration's marching band caused some passing motorists to swerve in the narrow-gauge lanes. Joining the festivities were descendants of construction crew members and the Gabrielino Indians who transferred the land to the state in a 1940 ceremony, public officials and the University of Southern California Marching Band. Sally Stanton Rubsamen, the 1940 Rose Queen who dedicated the ribbon of concrete a half-century ago, recalled trips to school using successively longer parts of the newly completed surface. ``It was a free-way then,'' she said. Adding that she now commutes daily from Pasadena to Los Angeles, Rubsamen said: ``The lanes are a bit narrow, it's a little curvy, it's beautiful, but some of the on ramps and off ramps are atrocious.'' Nearly 130,000 cars a day roll over the Pasadena Freeway, which meanders from downtown Los Angeles to Pasadena through the Arroyo Seco. The dry gulch was surveyed, but not used, for a road in 1895. When first proposed, the freeway's promise was Pasadena to downtown in 10 minutes. Some trips now take more than an hour. Although roads called parkways were already built in the East, and the autobahn was about to cross Germany, no one new what to call what was then billed as ``the cutting edge of transportation development.'' ``Stopless Motorway'' was one suggestion. It was built in 33 months at a cost of $1 million-plus a mile. Freeways today cost $100 million per mile. It was originally designed for travel at 45 mph; without traffic, some commuters whip around its curves at 70. ``It was the new thing in transportation engineering,'' said Alfred Himelhoch, an engineer on the project. ``We didn't know too much about it because we were on the cutting edge.'' Himelhoch, who has since worked on nearly every freeway in the Los Angeles area, recalled the trepidation of starting work on the new project. ``It's scary to work on any freeway,'' he said. Public reaction to the project was not divided by the protests surrounding modern freeway construction, he added. ``It was a new venture and people didn't know as much about a freeway. The discussion as to merit and impact on the community came later.'' Himelhoch said each lane is 10 or 11 feet wide, falling short of today's 12-foot standard. Motorists sometimes have 10 feet to accelerate to 55 miles per hour, and some exits require cars to slow to 5 mph while still in the slow lane. But Himelhoch said safety was the main goal of any freeway, more important than moving people. ``Freeways are three times as safe as surface roads because of the divider between directions and the ramps which bring cars smoothly onto them,'' he said. The Pasadena Freeway's safety rate is 1.84 reportable accidents for every million vehicle miles traveled, one of California's best, state officials said. The Los Angeles freeway system contains 4 percent of the surface area of California's roads, but carries more than 40 percent of the state's traffic. Though celebrating the route that paved the way for 4,047 miles of future freeways, officials Friday hinted at the end of the freeway age. ``Fifty years ago this magnificent and ambitious project was the answer to the transit needs of a growing and increasingly mobile population,'' said state Sen. Art Torres. ``But today our needs are drastically increased, and the demands of the environment must force us to look beyond.'' Torres advocated a light rail system and a proposed monorail that would run 58 miles along the Los Angeles River to Long Beach. ``Perhaps more freeways are not the answer,'' Torres said.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Sue Defunct Storefront `Investment Company,' Officers
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges Friday against the bankrupt Latin Investment Corp., an uninsured storefront ``bank'' whose collapse threw more than $6.8 million in deposits into jeopardy. The SEC lawsuit, filed in federal court in Washington, also sought a court order freezing the assets of three top officers of Latin Investment Corp., which catered primarily to Latin American immigrants. The Washington-based corporation's assets were frozen Dec. 15 when it was forced into involuntary bankruptcy. The SEC said it had contacted the government of El Salvador to locate any assets there that would be subject to a freeze order. Also named in the lawsuit were: LIC founder Fernando Leonzo of Vienna, Va.; the corporation's secretary, Leonel Salinas of Falls Church, Va.; and vice president Jose A. Cortes of Arlington, Va. The three men also sit on the board of El Latino, a weekly Hispanic newspaper and LIC subsidiary. The SEC's civil complaint was filed just three days after Leonzo invoked his Fifth Amendment rights against self incrimination and refused to answer questions under oath, according to documents filed by the agency. ``Many of the investors put much of their life savings in LIC, relying on materially false and misleading representations of LIC, Leonzo, Salinas and Cortes,'' the complaint charged. According to the complaint, LIC - founded in 1982 - had about 3,500 investors who had placed about $6.8 million with the investment company as of August 1990. But the Wilson International Center, a private community group that is helping victims of LIC's collapse, said the amount in jeopardy was more like $13 million in deposits - an average of more than $3,700 apiece. The SEC lawsuit sought a court order requiring full restitution to investors who were defrauded. The lawsuit also sought a restraining order to keep the three officers from destroying any documents or transferring assets. The complaint alleges that LIC, which operated without a bank charter or government banking insurance, misled investors into thinking their funds would be safe and available on demand. The SEC also alleged that the three officers did not disclose to investors that they received more than $500,000 in loans, some of which was used to pay for their homes, from the investment company. As of August, none of those loans had been repaid, the SEC said. Leonzo, through his lawyer Charles Pearson, denied the SEC allegations. ``We have a different version of events, and that will certainly come forward in due time,'' Pearson said. ``We're not trying to hide anything. What we're trying to do is repay depositors.'' Last week, a federal bankruptcy judge ordered - without opposition from Leonzo - that the company be liquidated.

DOC.HEAD: Bitter Cold Makes Life Difficult for Ranchers, Livestock, Even Dogs
With AM-Storms Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Ranchers broke up ice in cattle troughs and workers stayed busy repairing brittle rail, telephone and plumbing lines as record low temperatures gripped northern and central Nevada on Friday. The Arctic storm that chilled Western states most of the week pushed temperatures in Reno to minus 7, snapping a 22-year record of 3 degrees below zero. ``Pretty near froze to death out there this morning,'' said Bob Wallis, who works at the Blue Diamond Ranch in Eureka, where Friday's low plunged to minus 12 degrees. Even after 40 years of range roaming, ``you never get used to that,'' Wallis said. Wallis said that despite the cold, the cowboys at the 6,000-head ranch were checking the cattle's health each day. ``They get pneumonia and stuff when it gets this cold, and we go out and doctor them,'' he said. ``That's all I do is doctor.'' Others were keeping the herd stocked with fodder and breaking up icebergs that formed in water troughs, he said. In Reno, even thick-furred Malamute dogs balked at going outside. Plumbers reported a brisk business. ``We're all booked up,'' said a dispatcher at ABC Plumbing. ``The phones started ringing at 4 a.m., and we're still getting them.'' While plumbers scrounged around in flooded basements, the cold slowed down telephone workers installing lines for special teen-ager gab phones that parents had ordered for Christmas. ``Being as cold as it is, nothing works,'' said Kelly Sanford of Nevada Bell. ``Everything is just nearly frozen. Your nose freezes, your cheeks freeze, your glasses fog up. ``But actually, it is invigorating,'' she said. ``It's so brisk, you're above the rooftops, you see the city, the mountains.'' Worker Terri Martinez said sales was ``not good at all'' at the Ice Cream Factory in Ely, where a 26-degree-below-zero reading shattered the record of minus 13 degrees set in 1968. ``They haven't been for almost two months. That's why we're closing Saturday until March,'' Ms. Martinez said. Mary Ann Brown, spokeswoman for Southern Pacific Railroad, said the cold was more of a nuisance than a major headache. ``We're having a little bit of a problem with broken rail in a few spots, but nothing major,'' Ms. Brown said. ``It's common when the weather's so cold like this.'' But was it really too cold for Malamutes? Not according to Dr. Debbie Brigmon, a veterinarian in Anchorage, Alaska. ``Well, let's just say that up north it gets 70 below, and there are dogs that live year round outside in that,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney, Powell Give Tough Pep Talks, Say War More Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Scowcroft saying Jan. 15 ``not an attack date,'' inserting 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, ``It increasingly
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday a U.S. attack against Iraqi forces is growing increasingly likely. He promised cheering troops they won't sit indefinitely in the desert and ``absolute, total victory'' is the only option if war begins.
