Joining Cheney in hawkish pep rallies with troops in the northeast Saudi desert was Gen. Colin Powell, the Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman, who said he still hoped for resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis without war but then drew roars of applause when he pledged: ``When we launch it, we will launch it violently; we will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we can get it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.'' Cheney said he was not optimistic Washington and Iraq would hold top-level talks on the crisis, let alone resolve it, by the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Saddam Hussein to withdraw his army from Kuwait. President Bush has threatened to attack if that deadline isn't met, and the two sides have been unable to agree on dates for talks in Baghdad and Washington. ``It increasingly looks like he's not getting the message and we'll have to use force,'' Cheney said of Saddam. In Washington, meanwhile, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft said that Jan. 15 ``is not an attack day at all'' but a warning to Saddam that after that date ``he is at risk.'' ``One of the important points we're trying to get across to him is that we haven't blinked so far, we're not blinking now and we will not blink,'' Scowcroft said in an interview with The Associated Press and reporters from other news agencies. Cheney and Powell, fresh from three days of strategy sessions with field commanders in Saudi Arabia, were asked by troops whether American ground forces would be ready to fight by the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. The troops apparently were well aware of the controversy stirred by the deputy commander of Operation Desert Shield, Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller, who said Wednesday that still-arriving ground troops might not be combat ready until well into February. Asked by an airman how long the United States would wait to attack if the deadline passed without an Iraqi withdrawal, Cheney said: ``While I can't tell you a specific date, for obvious reasons, when that would happen, I can say that we are eager to get this wrapped up as quickly as possible. ... We do not think that waiting indefinitely is going to solve the problem and I'm confident we'll move as soon as we can to wrap it up.'' But he did not say when he believed American forces would be ready for such an attack. Powell said at one point, ``I think we're ready now,'' only to say seconds later that some forces were still arriving and would not be combat ready for some time. At their first two stops at a sprawling installation that includes huge Air Force and Army camps, Cheney promised the troops that if fighting begins, ``there will be the freedom and flexibility to run a first-class military operation all the way.'' In an apparent reference to Vietnam, he said U.S. forces ``won't have their hands tied behind their backs. There won't be sanctuaries where the enemy can take cover.'' The troops applauded. Cheney and Powell also offered Christmas greetings and promised the troops they had the support of Bush and the American public. But they spent most of their time talking tough. ``The only acceptable outcome, if hostilities begin, is absolute, total victory,'' Cheney said. Powell added, ``When we go in, we go in to win, not fool around.'' Asked how the United States would respond if Saddam used chemical weapons, Cheney said Bush would have at his disposal ``a full spectrum of capabilities. ... The response of the United States will be overwhelming and devastating.'' Virtually all of the troops at the appearances - even some out of uniform in shorts and T-shirts - had gas masks strapped to their waists. Cheney and Powell had been scheduled to split up and fly by helicopter to Army and Marine camps, respectively. But strong, swirling winds grounded the helicopters so the plans were altered. Most of the troops seemed happy to see their bosses, although Cheney and Powell faced complaints about the uncertainty of the deployment length and the loss of extra food allowances paid to troops who live off base in the United States. At the first stop, Airman R. L. Miller said he wanted the crisis resolved immediately. ``There are two ways to go - north or home,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Probing Accusations German Firms Broke Iraqi Sanctions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government said Friday it is investigating U.S. suspicions that German companies have broken U.N. sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait. One German firm denied the allegations. Washington has given Bonn a list of 50 German companies suspected of violating the embargo against Iraq, the news magazine Der Spiegel said. The magazine said the information came from U.S. wiretaps of ``Iraq's overall telephone traffic and intercepting Telefax messages.'' It did not identify its sources. The Bonn government confirmed it received a list of suspected embargo violators and that the allegations were being examined. But government spokesman Dieter Vogel said so far no proof had emerged that any of the companies made deliveries in violation of U.N. sanctions. ``It's turned out the list at least partially concerns mistaken information,'' said Vogel, who did not elaborate. The Economics Ministry spokesman, Dieter Franzen, said the government was ``in closest contact (with the U.S. embassy) and are trying to pursue even the slightest suspicion.'' Der Spiegel reported that U.S. officials suspect one German firm, Interatom, of supplying Iraq with ``highly sensitive'' nuclear training and equipment. The magazine said two other German firms, which it did not identify, are believed to have helped Iraq with nerve gas production. Interatom and its owner, the giant electronics conglomerate, Siemens, angrily denied the magazine's report. ``Der Spiegel's claims are simply false,'' said Interatom spokesman Herbert Mayer from the company's office in Bergisch Gladbach near Cologne. Siemens said in a news release that Interatom had signed a contract to help Iraq build a processing plant for industrial piping but the business had nothing to do with nuclear technology. The contract involved only ``generally accessible engineering knowledge,'' the release said. ``We're not crazy. We don't deliver things that don't correspond with the political interests of the West,'' said Mayer. He said the program later was suspended after Interatom ``received an indication from the (German) government which urged extreme caution because Iraq was looking for military technology.'' Interatom specializes in atomic energy plan construction and uranium enrichment, but is also involved in non-nuclear engineering. Mayer also said Interatom had workers in Iraq when Saddam Hussein's forces took over Kuwait on Aug. 2. He said the Interatom workers were trapped in Iraq and the last one returned on Dec. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Clarence `Kelly' Johnson, Leading `Skunk Works' Aircraft Designer
DOC.TEXT: Clarence L. ``Kelly'' Johnson, creator of Lockheed Corp.'s secret ``Skunk Works'' that created America's first production jet fighter and a generation of spyplanes, died Friday. He was 80. Johnson, who led the design of the U-2, the SR-71 Blackbird and more than 40 other airplanes and spacecraft, died at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank after a long illness, Lockheed said. The illness was not disclosed. Using titanium and sleek shapes, Johnson's designs broke the ``thermal thicket,'' the high-heat problem of supersonic flight, said Donald Lopez, a senior advisor at the National Air and Space Museum in Washington, D.C. Use of titanium alloy on the SR-71 rather than standard aluminum made flight at high speed possible despite 800-degree Fahrenheit temperatures. The Blackbird flies at more than 2,000 mph and above 85,000 feet. ``The skin would glow sometimes,'' Lopez said of the Blackbirds, recently retired by the Air Force. ``Pilots could feel the heat coming in.'' Johnson organized the Skunk Works in Burbank in 1943 to build the XP-80 Shooting Star, the United States' first production jet fighter. Many designs bore his mark: the P-38 Lightning in World War II, the Constellation transports, the Hercules cargo planes, the P2V antisubmarine patrol aircraft, the Agena spacecraft, and the F-104 Starfighter, the first production aircraft to fly at twice the speed of sound. The U-2 was the first plane able to make a sustained flight above 60,000 feet, and the YF-12 and SR-71 Blackbird remain the fastest and highest-flying planes in the world. The Blackbird's maximum speed and altitude remain classified. The Air and Space Museum saluted Johnson in its gallery of pioneers. Born in Ishpeming, Mich., on Feb. 27, 1910, Johnson was the seventh of nine children of Swedish immigrant parents. From his father, a carpenter and bricklayer, Johnson developed a respect for tools. According to Lockheed, he knew by the time he was 12 that he wanted to build airplanes. He studied aeronautical engineering at the University of Michigan, and worked as a consultant on the aerodynamic design of cars that were to run in the Indianapolis 500. He went to work for Lockheed the same year he received his master's degree, 1933. He went on to head the Skunk Works for 30 years. The secrecy of the Skunk Works is so great that even the origin of the name is shrouded in mystery, although it apparently was derived from Al Capp's cartoon strip, ``Li'l Abner,'' which featured a moonshine distillery called the Skonk Works. Johnson retired as a senior vice president in 1975 and retired from Lockheed's board of directors in 1980. Tony LeVier, the Skunk Works' former chief test pilot, described Johnson as a stern father figure with a direct line to the Pentagon. And his planes, LeVier said, ``flew like a dream.'' ``My God,'' he said. ``They were advanced.'' Johnson is survived by his wife Nancy, a brother and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: Army, Navy Record Best-Ever Safety Results
DOC.TEXT: The Army and the Navy said Friday the past year was their safest on record. Private vehicle accidents remained the biggest killer of soldiers and sailors. The Army said 353 servicemen and women were killed in accidents during the budget year ended Sept. 30, including those that occurred off-base and off-duty. The time period included the first rush of troops to the Persian Gulf. More than two-thirds of the deaths were from private automobile accidents. In the comparable period a year earlier, the Army had 369 accidental deaths. There were 732,000 Army personnel on active duty at the end of accounting period. Total Army accidents were down by 1,348 from the previous year, to 8,647, and deaths from aviation accidents fell from 35 to 33. Col. Steven Raho, deputy director of Army safety, attributed the safety improvement to a variety of factors, including increased effort by the Army to design safety features into new equipment rather than adding the features after production. The Navy, which had 579,000 personnel on active duty at the end of the budget year, said it recorded 255 total deaths from accidents, including 206 not related to Navy operations. That was down from 339 total Navy deaths the year before, of which 47 occurred in the April 19, 1989 explosion aboard the battleship USS Iowa. Two-thirds of total Navy accidental deaths were from private vehicle wrecks. The Navy had 39 deaths from aviation accidents, including those involving Marine Corps aircraft. The Navy total of 30 deaths from aviation was the lowest on record, as was the Marine Corps total of nine. The Marines do not publish lists of accidents from ground activities, and the Air Force said it was not yet prepared to release its statistics on fiscal 1990 accidents and deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Protests Army Patrols in Baltic Port
With AM-Soviet-Politics
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian lawmakers demanded an end to Soviet army patrols in the Baltic port of Klaipeda, and the city's mayor labeled the military action a ``gross interference'' to civilian life, Tass reported Friday. Col. Ivan Chernykh, commander of the Klaipeda garrison, told Lithuanian authorities that armed units would have the authority to check people's documents and make arrests, the official Soviet news agency said. The patrols began Thursday. They were ordered following clashes between civilians and Soviet soldiers and sailors in Klaipeda, which has a large military presence, according to an editor with the independent Elta news agency. Tass quoted Chernykh as saying soldiers with submachine guns were patrolling the streets in cars. The Lithuanian Supreme Council, or parliament, sent a note to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to protest the patrols, and the lawmakers demanded their removal and that officers involved be punished. ``This order is a flagrant violation of the laws and the rights of citizens of the republic of Lithuania, as well as a political provocation with the intent to heighten tensions and to create potential conflicts,'' said a copy of the note distributed to Western news agencies. The note asked Gorbachev to ``revoke the mentioned directives of the Soviet army authorities and to punish them for their willful behavior which is accompanied by the threat of armed violence.'' The parliament also asked Lithuanians to remain calm and not to get involved in conflicts with the patrols. Vytautas Cepas, the mayor of the city of 200,000 people, told Tass the imposition of this ``special regime'' was nothing but an open provocation and ``gross interference in the purely civilian life of the city.'' Chernykh said the patrols were justified. ``Hooligan actions, insults to servicemen and the attempts to penetrate the territory around the monument to Lenin, guarded by soldiers, take place every day,'' he told Tass. Lithuania said the orders issued by the Soviet military were not valid on the territory of the republic. Lithuania and the other Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia have declared independence from the Soviet Union. In Latvia on Friday, about 500 representatives of the Soviet army from the three Baltic republics and the neighboring Kaliningrad region of Russia appealed to the Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow to introduce presidential rule in the country, Latvian radio reported. Constitutional amendments adoped in March say the president can decare a state of emergency ``in the interest of providing citizens' security.'' Under presidential rule, local governments could be disbanded. The army representatives warned the Baltic republics that any attempt to cut off power, water or heat to military installations would result in the seizure of the facilities by the armed forces, Tass reported from Riga, the Latvian capital.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Campaigns Publicly for Secretive Stealth Aircraft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 4th graf with General Dynamics shakeup of A-12 management
DOC.TEXT: Navy officials, hoping to overcome a wave of damaging revelations about its A-12 stealth attack plane, launched a public campaign Friday to rescue the $50 billion program. Navy officials went public with arguments for continuing the development program, which is classified secret, just two weeks before Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's target date for deciding whether to cancel it. In a move that underscored the economic stakes involved, the companies holding a $4.8 billion contract to build the first A-12 prototypes - General Dynamics Corp. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. - announced Thursday they were notifying about 8,000 workers that they could lose their jobs if the project is killed. And on Friday General Dynamics announced a shakeup of its A-12 management. It reassigned the A-12 program director, Charles Anderson. His replacement is Ted Webb, the former head of the successful F-16 fighter jet program, who retired last year. The contractors were ordered by the Navy last week to correct the project's flaws by Jan. 2 or face the possibility of being held in default of the contract terms. The Navy cited a failure to supply parts on time for final assembly of the prototypes, and it questioned whether the A-12 design was suitable. Cheney has given the Navy until Jan. 4 to ``show cause'' why he shouldn't terminate the entire project, whose schedule delays and cost overruns he called ``intolerable.'' Cheney nonetheless said he remains convinced that a new carrier-based attack plane with radar-evading capabilities is urgently needed. The Navy calls the A-12 its top priority in weapons development. The aircraft, dubbed the Avenger after the World War II fighter, is supposed to replace the A-6 Intruder, a carrier-based attack plane that the Navy says is growing obsolete. Capt. Mike Currie, who is responsible for ensuring that the A-12 now on the drawing boards is produced according to the Navy's specifications, told the Association of Naval Aviation on Friday that the plane is vital to U.S. security interests. ``It's not a matter of wanting a new gee-whiz airplane,'' he said. ``We just need more airplanes.'' Vice Adm. R.M. Dunleavy, the Navy's air warfare chief, introduced Currie's presentation to the aviator's group by telling the friendly audience ``The future of naval aviation is at a crossroads. We need the A-12 - you've got to believe that.'' Neither Dunleavy nor Currie would comment on the economic and other controversies surrounding the A-12, including the recent firing of the Navy admiral in charge of the program and the disclosure that the program is the focus of a criminal investigation. Currie said in an interview on Thursday that the Navy was eager to publicly build a case for continuing the A-12 project, which already is at least $1 billion over budget and 18 months behind schedule. There also are questions about whether the contractors can build the aircraft to Navy specifications. A key technical problem is limiting the weight of the aircraft while making it sturdy enough to withstand the pressures of landings on aircraft carriers. Currie said the A-6 lacks the speed, maneuverability and radar-evading technologies to survive against the ``projected threat,'' a euphemism for the Pentagon's secret forecast of how effective future Soviet air defenses may be. He said 90 A-6s are deployed in the Persian Gulf area as part of Operation Desert Shield. Computer models show that the A-12 is the best - though also the most expensive - of several possible successors to the A-6, Currie said. It also is the only one under active development. ``Of course airplanes are always better on paper,'' he said, adding ``I'll believe it when I see it.''

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Council Examines U.N. Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: A Cambodian peace plan giving the United Nations a strong role in an interim government was examined by the nation's four warring factions Friday. One official warned time was running out to settle the conflict. ``The world has changed. Other priorities can and will require our attention,'' said French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. ``The international community cannot indefinitely work out the fate of Cambodia if Cambodians themselves do not have the political will to do so.'' But Dumas said he was encouraged that no one issued an outright rejection of the proposal. The meeting of the 12-member Supreme National Council of Cambodia was expected to continue Saturday, said Dumas, who urged acceptance of the U.N. plan. Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen collapsed during the talks, apparently from fatigue, and was hospitalized. He was reported in satisfactory condition Friday. The council, meeting for the second time since its creation three months ago, is composed of six representatives of Hun Sen's Vietnamese-backed government and two from each of the three factions in the resistance coalition, which includes the Khmer Rouge. The other factions are those of resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk, represented in Paris by his son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, and another non-Communist grouping headed by Son Sann. Dumas said the peace plan, agreed to Nov. 26 by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, was a compromise text that could be improved but not ``put into question.'' The International Conference on Peace in Cambodia adjourned in September 1989 after a monthlong effort failed to reach a settlement. The Khmer Rouge was toppled from power by a Vietnamese invasion in December 1978. Khmer Rouge guerrillas, aided by China, have since waged a war against the government of Hun Sen, joined by the smaller armies of Sihanouk and Son Sann. In his opening remarks, Dumas tried to ease criticism that the proposal gives the United Nations too great a role in running the country. The plan calls for the United Nations to administer Cambodia during an interim period leading to free elections, while the supreme council acts as titular head. Hun Sen has already said the plan exceeds the authority of the U.N. charter. He also said that ``serious measures must be taken to suppress the foundations'' of the communist Khmer Rouge, the strongest member of the three-party resistance coalition. Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan, a member of the Supreme National Council, was among those seated at the negotiating table Friday. Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said the questions posed by the council members Friday related mainly to the relationship between the council and the United Nations during the interim period, various aspects of a cease-fire and withdrawal and the elections. The special U.N. representative, Raffeudin Ahmed, also present at the meeting, will add points raised at the Paris meeting to the final U.N. proposal, Dumas said. Dumas acknowledged the U.N. representative would have strong powers, but said ``it is in no case a real tutelage as long as the Supreme National Council embodies the sovereignty of Cambodia.'' However, unresolved quarrels among the four Cambodian factions made it ``indispensable'' to give the U.N. final decision-making power ``to avoid paralysis of the process leading to elections,'' he said. It was not immediately clear whether progress had been made to resolve a dispute over the leadership of the council. At its only other meeting, in September in Bangkok, the council broke up in a dispute over its composition. Hun Sen objected to the bid by Sihanouk to be president of the council. Sihanouk, who supports the Khmer Rouge, said recently he wanted to be ``neither president, nor member'' of the supreme council.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Orders Break With Cult Of Stalinism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 10th pvs, `The change...' to add background on the country's polirical situation. Pick up 11th graf, `Tirana was...'
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday began dismantling the cult of Josef Stalin, ordering all statues and symbols bearing his name removed. It also reportedly gave permission for the first legal opposition rally. The decision to excise Stalin from public life came on what would have been the Soviet dictator's 111th birthday. Authorities also ordered the renaming of all streets, institutions and even a city named after Stalin. Albania became the last Eastern European state to reject the symbols of Stalinism. The Communist leadership made the decision ``taking into consideration that historic circumstances have changed,'' the state news agency ATA said. Before the order was issued Friday, workers already had removed the imposing bronze statue of the dictator that had stared down at Tirana residents since before his death in 1953. Clusters of Tirana residents watched all morning as workers finished the job, dismantling the marble-covered pedestal from its place in a central park. Another giant statue was toppled at a textile works in Tirana overnight. Friday's decison, announced by ATA, called for the renaming of Qyteti Stalin, the last city in Europe named after Stalin. Also Friday, the Albanian leadership gave its permission for a rally by the new opposition Democratic Party on Saturday, according to opposition sources. It would be the first legal opposiiton rally in Albania since the Communists took power in 1944. Several thousand students rallied in Tirana last week to demand democratic change and to hail the founding of the first non-Communist party. Police did not intervene. The significance of Stalin's demise was not lost on Albanians, who were repressed for decades by the iron-fisted rule of Enver Hoxha, the Albanian Communist who adored Stalin. The change ``should have happened a long time ago,'' said an Albanian journalist on condition of anonymity. It is not clear, however, just how far Albanian leaders are willing to go toward creating a true democracy. Albania's nascent opposition has encountered numerous obstacles, most of all the ruling party. Opposition leaders say local Communist officials still hinder party activists travelling to provincial cities. There is also entrenched support for the Communists in the media, with few details on the newly recognized Democratic Party appearing in news reports. And the ruling Communists are playing tough, cracking down on riots in four cities last week with a massive show of army and police force and handing out tough sentences of up to 20 years to those arrested. Tirana was the last capital in Europe to boast a monument to the Soviet dictator, whose personality cult led to the murder of millions on the continent. ``Now let's take down the statue of the dictator who ruled here for 50 years,'' said one bold youth watching the workers Friday. He was referring to a giant statue of Hoxha that dominates the nearby central square. Dismantling Hoxha's legacy will prove complicated. Although he has been held responsible for cruel repression in the 1950s and the isolationist policy that has brought Albania's economy close to collapse, Hoxha achieved national unity and independence for virtually the first time in the Balkan nation's turbulent history. His name is emblazoned on buildings, streets, and memorials throughout Albania and his books and portraits adorn every institution. Yet President Ramiz Alia, who took over after Hoxha died in 1985, appears to be pushing his reforms through despite the presence of hard-liners in the secretive ruling elite. The end of Stalin's cult came one day after Hoxha's 71-year-old widow, Nexhmije Hoxha, lost her last political post as head of the Communist-led Democratic Front, officially retiring because of old age. She was replaced by Premier Adil Carcani, who is in his late 60s. Rumors persist that Carcani will step down soon as head of government. The Communists promised a government change when they bowed earlier this month to demands for more democracy, but so far no changes have been announced. A party conference Dec. 26 is expected to give some indication of the party's new policies. It is supposed to decide a program for elections scheduled for Feb. 10, in which the Communists will face opposition for the first time since taking power in 1944. The newly founded Democratic Party is pushing for postponement of the elections, arguing it has insufficient time to organize. To date, the media have reported no details of the new party's program. The party is also negotiating with the government to publish its own daily newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Editorial Recant
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of The Philadelphia Inquirer's Dec. 12 editorial that sparked controversy within the newspaper's staff: Two stories from yesterday's newspaper: -The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approves Norplant, a contraceptive that can keep a woman from getting pregnant for five years. -A black research organization reports that nearly half the nation's black children are living in poverty - and that the younger the child, the more likely he or she is to be living with a single mother on welfare. ``Growing numbers of them will not succeed,'' the study's author says. As we read those two stories, we asked ourselves: Dare we mention them in the same breath? To do so might be considered deplorably insensitive, perhaps raising the specter of eugenics. But it would be worse to avoid drawing the logical conclusion that foolproof contraception could be invaluable in breaking the cycle of inner city poverty - one of America's greatest challenges. The main reason more black children are living in poverty is that the people having the most children are the ones least capable of supporting them. (The black middle class is growing, but its birth rate is very low.) This trend, as Children's Defense Fund president Marian Wright Edelman has said, ``practically guarantees the poverty of the next generation of black children.'' Now there are many ways to fight back - from better prenatal care to better schools. But it's very tough to undo the damage of being born into a dysfunctional family. So why not make a major effort to reduce the number of children, of any race, born into such circumstances? (More hites than blacks live in poverty, though poor blacks make up a higher percentage of people who are more or less permanently on welfare.) No one should be compelled to use Norplant, which involves a doctor implanting matchstick-size capsules in a woman's upper arm. But there could be incentives to do so. What if welfare mothers were offered an increased benefit for agreeing to use this new, safe, long-term contraceptive? Remember, these women already have one or more children. And they can change their minds at any point and become fertile again. (This is not Indira Ghandi offering portable radios to women who agree to be sterilized.) At the very minimum, Norplant, which will probably cost $600 to $1,000, should be made available for free to poor women. All right, the subject makes us uncomfortable, too. But we're made even more uncomfortable by the impoverishment of black America and its effect on the nation's future. Think about it.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Warns of Fuel Shortages
DOC.TEXT: Cuban President Fidel Castro said a possible Persian Gulf war and continued Soviet troubles threaten to sever the nation's oil supplies, the official news agency Prensa Latin reported from Havana on Friday. Castro also warned more stringent fuel conservation measure could be necessary. Cuba, he said, ``should be prepared for greater limitations than those of the present, including the possibility of zero fuel supplies in the worst-case scenario,'' Prensa Latina reported. Due to reduced supplies of cut-rate oil from the Soviet Union, Cuba has implemented a 10 percent energy-savings plan to prevent blackouts, but new austerity measures might be needed to avoid electricity failures, Castro said. Castro predicted crude oil could go as high as $80 a barrel if war breaks out in the gulf. ``The situation for more than 100 countries would be catastrophic, because they are poor countries indebted to the limits of tolerance,'' Castro said in an address to more than 500 university students from Latin America, Europe, Asia and Africa. ``These are uncertain times, and not only for Cuba, but for a large part of the world,'' Castro said. The Soviet Union, with its own economic problems, has threatened phased reduction of overall economic assistance to Cuba, estimated by some at $4 billion to $5 billion a year. Cuba has about 11 million residents.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arabs Slain; Bodies Found in Cave
DOC.TEXT: Police searching a cave in the occupied territories on Friday found the bodies of two Arabs allegedly killed by fellow Palestinians as suspected collaborators with Israel. Arab reports said the search was launched after the victims' families received letters signed by underground Palestinian leaders saying their sons were killed because they aided the Israelis. They letters reportedly said the bodies were buried in a nearby cave. The victims were identified as Adnan Ijbarah, 28, and Ashraf Farhan, 22. Arab reporters said masked activists kidnapped the victims from their homes in Kalkilya in the occupied West Bank on Nov. 26. They said the two had been killed with sharpened tools. Their deaths raised to 321 the number of Palestinians killed by their fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. At least 779 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the three-year uprising and 57 Israelis have also died in the violence. Elsewhere in the occupied lands, at least eight Palestinians were wounded by army gunfire during stone-throwing clashes, including a 19-year-old woman who was shot twice in the back, hospital officials said. Also Friday, security forces announced they had uncovered a ring of Druse youths in the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights who are suspected of spying for Syrian intelligence, army radio said. The radio said the investigation began a month ago when two Druse youths attempted to cross illegally into Syria. One of the youths was killed and the other captured in a clash with the army. State prosecutors plan to present formal charges against ``several'' youths from the Golan village of Majdal Shams, the radio said. The Druse religion is an offshoot of Islam.

DOC.HEAD: Scowcroft Says Attack Not Automatic on Jan. 15
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 3-6: ``Bush, meanwhile,'' comments from magazine interview
DOC.TEXT: The White House raised doubts Friday that the United States would attack Iraq immediately if it fails to meet next month's deadline for withdrawing from Kuwait. ``January 15 is not an attack day at all,'' a senior official said. Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser to President Bush, said the Jan. 15 date was ``an authorization date'' that tells Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``he'd better get moving now. After the 15th of January, he is at risk.'' Bush, meanwhile, underscored his determination to expel Iraq soon. ``It can't drag on with indecision and it can't stop short of the U.N. mandate (that Saddam completely leave Kuwait),'' Bush said. ``See, that argues very forcefully against some of these scenarios that call for somebody to compromise: We'll give him something for this, give him something so he saves face. That is not in the books.'' Bush made his comments in an interview with U.S. News & World Report. On deciding whether to go to war, Bush said, ``On this question, I've got it boiled down very clearly to good vs. evil. And it helps if you can be that clear in your own mind.'' He said his view was reinforced by an Amnesty International report detailing human rights abuses in Kuwait. ``It helps one come to a recognition that the right must prevail,'' the president said. The Jan. 15 deadline was prescribed in a United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing all means necessary to expel Iraq from Kuwait unless it withdraws on its own by then. ``It doesn't say he is going to be attacked this date or that date or whatever,'' Scowcroft said in an interview with The Associated Press and reporters rom other news agencies. ``One of the important points we're trying to get across to him is that we haven't blinked so far, we're not blinking now and we will not blink,'' he added. Scowcroft also said Saddam probably was comforted by Thursday's resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who has backed the tough U.S. stand against Iraq. Earlier this week, Bush said he wanted to see the United Nations resolutions ``fulfilled right on schedule.'' Moreover, he said, ``I think at midnight (on Jan. 15) if he's not totally out of Kuwait, the U.N. sanctions must be fulfilled.'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said Friday there was a good prospect that war could be averted. ``I think that the chance that Saddam Hussein will back out of this thing is strong,'' Aspin said at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He said the administration was trying force the issue to a head soon. ``What we're talking about is time lines. Do you bring it to a head now, meaning between now and February - late winter - or do we ... wait for a year to 18 months for the sanctions to work. ``I don't think it's a good policy to try and wait for a year to 18 months to bring it to a head,'' Aspin said. For the second time this week, Bush met with ambassadors from nations that have contributed money and military power to the Persian Gulf standoff with Saddam. The president refused to answer reporters' questions. ``Bah, humbug,'' he said in his best Scrooge imitation. ``In the spirit of Christmas, we're not going to have any questions.'' In his interview, Scowcroft said his remarks were not intended to raise or dampen prospects for military action Jan. 15. ``What I'm saying is the 15th doesn't mean that the troops and aircraft start to move on the 15th. It's an authorization date for the use of all measures, and that obviously is the use of force,'' he said. Asked if the president had a date in mind for military action, Scowcroft replied, ``Not that I know of. He may have.'' ``I hope we don't go to war,'' Scowcroft said. ``What we are not pointing toward is war. What we are trying to do is to make it clear to Saddam Hussein what it is he faces.'' In Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said a U.S. attack against Iraqi forces is growing increasingly likely. Gen. Colin Powell, the Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman, accompanied Cheney on a visit to U.S. troops in the gulf. Powell said he hoped for a peaceful solution but drew roars of approval when he pledged ``When we launch it, we will launch it violently; we will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we can get it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.''

DOC.HEAD: White House Fears Shevardnadze Departure May Hurt Soviet Reform
DOC.NOTE: EDs; INSERTS grafs 3-8: ``President Bush,'' comments from magazine interview
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Friday the resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze was ``troubling'' and expressed concern that Moscow might back away from its program of reforms. The administration's second-day analysis of Shevardnadze's departure reflected clear unease about what lies ahead in terms of internal divisions in the Soviet Union and U.S.-Soviet cooperation on the Persian Gulf and arms control. President Bush said there was no evidence that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was changing his gulf policy. ``I've talked to Gorbachev at length about it ... and I would be very surprised if he shifted, and I see no evidence of it,'' the president said in an interview with U.S. News & World Report. Bush said he was surprised by Shevardnadze's resignation, adding that ``we have great respect'' for him. As for chances for a Soviet dictatorship, a fear expressed by Shevardnadze, Bush said, ``I don't know. ``I know that there has been concern there about the appearance of anarchy and dissolution of the state ...'' Bush said he discussed Gorbachev's problems with him during a meeting last month in Paris. ``I think he is still committed to reform and openness but beyond that I can't go,'' the president said. Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser to President Bush, said one person who would be happy about Shevardnadze's resignation would be Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Shevardnadze has been a strong supporter of the U.S. stand in the Persian Gulf. ``But if you're Saddam Hussein, naturally, anybody who's removed from the scene who has had that policy would be welcome'' to go, Scowcroft said. He discussed Shevardnadze's action in an interview with The Associated Press and other news agencies. ``There is no doubt that it's troubling in some respects,'' Scowcroft said. ``He has been, if not the architect, the implementer of much of the foreign policy changes that we've seen over the past several years.'' But, Scowcroft added, ``We don't base our policy on personalities. The basic architect, (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev, is still there, but I think the concern is whether or not he thinks there is a shift in direction internally, and we feel strongly that the reforms should continue.'' Specifically, he said Shevardnadze's warning of a dictatorship emerging in the Soviet Union was troubling. He noted that the foreign minister, in his resignation speech Thursday, ``pointed right at the uniformed colonels and blamed them for wanting to reverse some of the perestroika (reform) programs.'' Bush and Gorbachev tentatively are set to meet in Moscow Feb. 11-13 for the signing of a treaty, still be negotiated, to slash strategic nuclear weapons. Shevardnadze has been a key player in the arms talks. Asked if the summit timing might be affected by Shevardnadze's departure, Scowcroft said ``At this point, I would say no, but ... we have to wait and see what the impact of the change in the Soviet Union may be in policy terms, and it may not be any at all.'' As far as the Persian Gulf is concerned, Scowcroft said ``our perception is that President Gorbachev is strongly of the same view'' as Shevardnadze in backing the United States. ``I think there's no doubt that he (Shevardnadze) was strongly, strongly in favor of the role that the Soviet Union has played in the gulf policy,'' Scowcroft said. ``There's no question about that. Whether it will be diminished by his departure, it's hard to tell at this point.''

DOC.HEAD: Warring Liberian Parties Agree to Choose Interim Government
DOC.TEXT: Liberia's three warring factions agreed Friday to hold a conference inside that country within 60 days to choose a caretaker government. The ``all-Liberia'' conference was announced in a statement at the end of two days of talks in Banjul, Gambia. The talks in this West African country were intended to allow the combatants to negotiate an end to the yearlong civil war, which has left more than 12,000 civilians dead. The rival parties apparently were unable to agree on anything except the conference at the Gambian talks, which were mediated by the Economic Community of West African States. It was not clear how the meeting was affected by the absence of rebel leader Charles Taylor, who sent only a representative. The agreement to choose a new interim government put in question the role of a temporary administration already installed in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, under the sponsorship of the West African community. Taylor had refused to join the government led by Amos Sawyer, calling it a puppet of Liberia's West African neighbors. The two other warring factions both have seats in Sawyer's administration. A major aim of the Banjul meeting was to negotiate how a West African intervention force already in Monrovia would police a cease-fire agreed Nov. 28. Friday's statement said another meeting would be held within 30 days to discuss monitoring the cease-fire. In the meantime, the three armies said they would remain in positions they held when the fighting stopped. The participants also were to discuss disarming the warring sides. Friday's communique said the interim government to be chosen at the ``all-Liberia'' conference would organize the disarmament. Signatories to Friday's agreement are the National Patriotic Front of Taylor, breakaway rebel leader Prince Johnson and remnants of slain President Samuel Doe's army led by Brig. Hezekiah Bowen. Taylor's men are spread throughout Liberia outside of Monrovia. The West African soldiers have confined Johnson's and Bowen's men to separate barracks around the capital. Taylor started the war with a Christmas Eve invasion from Ivory Coast to oust Doe, who was accused of corruption and repression. Doe was captured and killed earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Croatia Adopts New Constitution Authorizing Secession
DOC.TEXT: The Croatian Parliament adopted a new constitution Friday that would give the country's second-largest republic the right to secede, media reports said. The move is likely to worsen the traditionally tense relations between Croatians and minority Serbs in the republic. The new constitution follows an electoral victory last spring by the center-right government over Communists who had been ruling the republic. The new document provides for Croatia to secede from Yugoslavia if two-thirds of the legislature votes for such a proposal, the reports said. They said a state-wide plebiscite would then have to be held. If a simple majority of the electorate votes in favor of secession, the motion would be upheld. Friday's vote was preceded by an acrimonious debate over minority rights between ethnic Serbian and Croatian deputies in the legislature, the national Tanjug news agency reported. It said that 16 deputies representing Croatia's 500,000-member Serbian minority walked out of the parliamentary session before the vote to protest what they claimed was the failure of the new constitution to guarantee their national identity. Also on Friday, ethnic Serbs in Knin, a town near the central Adriatic coast, proclaimed the autonomy of their Krajina area, saying they would remain part of Croatia only if the state stays within Yugoslavia. ``This is a great day for all Serbs,'' said Jovan Raskovic, political leader of the Serbian minority, as he raised the Serbian flag over Knin castle, radio Belgrade reported. Since August, one policeman has been killed and several others wounded in inter-ethnic violence in Krajina. The Croatian authorities have vowed not to permit any part of the republic to break away. They deny the Serbs' accusations of discrimination, contending the Communist government in Serbia is manipulating local Serbs to destabilize Croatia. The northern state of Slovenia, the most prosperous of Yugoslavia's six republics, is due Sunday to hold a referendum on secession. Slovenia and Croatia advocate turning Yugoslavia into a loose confederation of virtually independent states. The Slovenian ballot is strongly opposed by Serbia, the country's largest republic, which favors the continuation of Yugoslavia as a federation with a strong central government.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Wins Concessions for Nicaragua's Sandinista-led Military
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Chamorro, trying to keep peace with her leftist opponents, convinced the legislature Friday to accept a budget limiting cuts for the Sandinista-led army. But she won lawmakers' support by, among other things, promising to remove the leftist Sandinista army commander, Gen. Humberto Ortega, by 1993. The legislative vote, following a veto of larger cuts by Mrs. Chamorro, represents a major defeat for conservatives in her coalition. They had fought for greater reductions. However, Mrs. Chamorro had said that without the concessions to the military, the country could be faced with disturbances. Mrs. Chamorro's early months in office were plagued by Sandinista-sponsored general strikes, forcing her to sign a compromise social pact with her political opponents and touching off a backlash in her own coalition. On Friday, national legislators voted 69-21 to sustain Mrs. Chamorro's veto of the bill they previously approved that would have shaved $19.6 million from her initial $78.6 million army budget for 1991. The budget approved Friday provided $70 million for the military. Twenty-nine members of Mrs. Chamorro's coalition switched their vote to join one independent deputy and the 39 Sandinista deputies in sustaining the veto. One legislator in the 92-member body did not vote. The army's current budget, the last approved by the former Sandinista government, was $190 million this year. Presidential secretary Antonio Lacayo called the vote ``a rotund defeat for the extremists'' in the 14-party United National Opposition, or UNO. The coalition supported Mrs. Chamorro in her February election win over Sandinista incumbent Daniel Ortega, the army commander's brother. Former Sandinista party president Sergio Ramirez said the vote represents an upset for ``a spurious opposition.'' Five UNO parties voted against Mrs. Chamorro's veto. Deputy Humberto Castilla, a hard-liner who voted against the veto and lower cuts, said he rejected Mrs. Chamorro's offer because ``they are very vague.'' Vice-President Virgilio Godoy, who has opposed Mrs. Chamorro's concessions to the Sandinistas, called the veto ``a serious mistake.'' UNO mayors and former Contra rebels launched a wave of riots, protest blockades and building takeovers in November in eastern Nicaragua. They demanded removal of Gen. Ortega as army chief. In a prepared speech Friday, Mrs. Chamorro promised to replace Gen. Ortega by 1993. She said she will replace him with a civilian only ``when I feel that the process of military reduction has surpassed the stage that I consider critical and risky to the country.'' She said the general is the only man who has ``the moral authority and the capability to effect the reductions'' in the size of the army without creating a crisis, assembly budget committee president Luis Humberto Guzman said. Mrs. Chamorro has said any drastic changes within the armed forces could produce Sandinista discontent and shatter the country's fragile internal peace. Mrs. Chamorro has promised to cut 3,000 soldiers during 1991. She has reduced troop strength from 100,000 to 28,434 since she took office April 25.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-US Forces, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``It increasingly looks like (Saddam's) not getting the message and we'll have to use force. The only acceptable outcome, if hostilities begin, is absolute, total victory.'' - Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. --- ``We will launch it violently, we will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we can get it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.'' - Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff. --- ``While I can't tell you a specific date, for obvious reasons, when that would happen, I can say that we are eager to get this wrapped up as quickly as possible. ... We do not think that waiting indefinitely is going to solve the problem and I'm confident we'll move as soon as we can to wrap it up.'' - Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, when asked how long the United States would wait to attack if the deadline passed without an Iraqi withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Experts Project Up to 480 Deaths in Holiday Traffic Accidents
DOC.TEXT: Safety experts on Friday projected between 380 and 480 people will die in traffic accidents on U.S. highways during the four-day Christmas holiday. The National Safety Council each year estimates the number of holiday traffic fatalities for the heavily traveled holiday period, which began at 6 p.m. Friday and ends at 11:59 p.m. Tuesday. Last year, 372 people died during the three-day Christmas holiday. This year's projection is higher because Christmas falls on a Tuesday, extending the holiday period an additional day, said council statistician Terry Miller. Safety officials say the death toll could be lower than in previous four-day Christmas periods because high gasoline prices may deter people from making long car trips or from going to social events. ``People may just decide to limit their driving to necessary errands, going to the store and other things of that nature,'' Miller said. ``But it's hard to predict people's behavior in such situations.'' The council makes its projections by comparing the average number of traffic deaths each day of the current year with historical figures on traffic fatalities during past holiday seasons. The council also projects that between 350 and 450 people will die in on the nation's roads during the four-day New Year holiday period.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptian Reinforcements Strengthen Arab Force Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the anti-Iraqi Arab force welcomed Egyptian reinforcements Friday and said the multinational force has everything it needs to go to war. ``The troops are ready,'' said Lt. Gen. Khalid Bin Sultan of the Arab -Islamic armies deployed on a defensive line in front of American, British and French troops in eastern Saudi Arabia. ``With what we have right now, I am completely satisfied, whether it's our Arab-Muslim forces or our friendly forces,'' the Saudi officer said. ``We are ready to do what our supreme commanders tell us to do.'' Earlier this week, American Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller, second-in-command of Operation Desert Shield, said his ground troops might not be ready until mid-February. Other senior commanders, however, said they are prepared to apply force to back up a Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait. On Friday, Khalid, a nephew of Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, greeted an armored brigade of about 5,000 soldiers and 94 tanks of the Egyptian 4th Armored Division. When in place, the division will boost the number of Egyptian troops to about 27,000 - the largest of the Arab forces in Saudi Arabia. The 4th Division is specially trained in fighting urban battles, which is what the recapture of Kuwait City would entail. However, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has said his forces would only be used to defend Saudi Arabia and would go into Kuwait only in a peacekeeping role. Established in 1956, the division fought against Israel that year and again in 1967 and 1973. It crossed the Suez Canal in the 1973 war, surprising the Israelis who thought the maneuver was impossible. The division also trained with the U.S. Army's 24th Mechanized Division in a 1988 joint operation called Bright Star. Khalid called the Arab show of force opposing Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait as a battle of ``right against tyranny'' and pledged to help the defeated country ``even if we become martyrs to restore what is right.'' The general spoke to a formation of troops who had arrived Wednesday. They had rolled their American-made M60 battle tanks, M113 armored personnel carriers and M109 self-propelled howitzers onto a lot in Yanbu, a port city on the Red Sea. ``We are here to defend the right and defend the peace. The whole world is with us,'' said Major Gen. Salah Halaby, commander of the Egyptian forces in Saudi Arabia. Capt. Alla Eldin Ahmed, a company commander, said chances of war are about ``50-50'' as a Jan. 15 U.N. deadline approaches for Iraq to quit Kuwait or face a military response. ``I'm ready for any fight,'' said Ahmed. ``This is the best brigade in the Egyptian Army.''

DOC.HEAD: Smallest City in Smallest State Struggles for Survival
DOC.TEXT: The smallest city in this country's smallest state is in danger of dying and needs a transfusion of state funds to survive, a commission reviewing the community's financial health said Friday. Even if the state of Rhode Island takes financial responsibility for the schools of Central Falls, this gritty mill city of 17,000 could expire, members of a state review commission said. ``The clock is ticking. We don't have much time. If you have a heart problem and you don't get a transplant, what's the alternative?'' asked James Mahoney, vice chairman of the Central Falls Review Commission. The city, named for the Blackstone River falls that powered the birth of the modern textile industry, is wedged between several larger communities just north of Providence. It the city is dissolved, the state would assume responsibilty for the health, welfare and safety of community residents. A draft report by the review commission said the state is not prepared to assume that responsiblity. Although the smallest in the state, this ethnically diverse, mile-square community also is among the most densely populated in Rhode Island and is one of the 10 most densely populated cities in the country. Mahoney is fiscal adviser to the Rhode Island House of Representatives. He helped assemble this year's state budget that gave Central Falls $500,000 in aid but also mandated an examination of the city's fiscal health. In its report, the commission painted a stark picture of the city's problems: a possible $7 million deficit this year in a budget of $21 million. Next year's shortfall could be $11 million. Because education accounts for more than half the city's budget, a state takeover of the schools could allow Central Falls to resolve its fiscal troubles, said Daniel W. Varin, state planning director and chairman of the review commission. Varin said he would like to see the state have a large say in the schools but not total management control. Mayor Thomas Lazieh said he liked Varin's idea. He also said he liked the commission's suggestion that Central Falls sell its water system to neighboring Pawtucket and share public services such as police, fire and libraries with neighboring municipalities. But he rejected the idea of dissolving the city. Lazieh said maintaining an independent city was the cheapest way of getting services to its residents. The commission said it, too, opposed dissolving the city - at least for now. Despite the highest property tax rate in the state - $54.75 per $1,000 of assessed valuation - the commission said Central Falls ranks 35th among the 39 cities and towns on spending per person for city services. Textiles long ago moved away, leaving old mill buildings and three-decker tenements and little land to develop - the crux of Central Falls' problem. Little vacant land means little chance to increase the property tax base. Still, there is much ethnic pride in Central Falls, home to immigrants including French-Canadians, Irish, Poles, Syrians and Portuguese. ``You had to speak a little French and Syrian to get by where I grew up,'' said Bill Benson, the city's dog officer. City Council President Albert Laroche said the city got a ``bum rap'' beginning in the early 1980s with national attention as a cocaine trafficking center. ``Really, no one here in the city wants to dissolve the city,'' Larouche said. ``I've no intention of moving anywhere else. It's the furthest thing from my mind.''

DOC.HEAD: Civilian Launch Capsizes With U.S. Sailors Aboard
DOC.TEXT: A civilian launch bringing sailors back from shore liberty to the carrier USS Saratoga capsized off Haifa, Israel, the Pentagon said Friday night. Lt. Col. Quentin Banks, a Pentagon spokesman, said he had no further details and no word on possible casualties. The incident happened about 5 p.m. Haifa time, about 10 a.m. Washington time.

DOC.HEAD: Stage Was Set In November For Interest Rate Cut
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT prime rate to discount rate
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve set the stage for its recent interest rate reductions at a mid-November meeting of its monetary policy committee, according to minutes of the meeting released Friday. The central bank has permitted a lowering of its federal funds rate four times since October and on Wednesday dropped the discount rate from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, the first decline in four years. The 0.25 percentage point decline in the federal funds rate on Oct. 29, to 7.75 percent, was in response to the federal budget-cutting agreement between the Bush adminsitration and Congress. But the Federal Open Market Committee noted weakening economic activity at its Nov. 13 meeting and agreed to another ``slight reduction.'' The move, the minutes said, was designed to ``provide some insurance against a deep and prolonged recession without incurring a substantial risk in current circumstances of fostering intensified inflationary pressures.'' And, the minutes said, the committee agreed to give weight ``to potential developments that might require some slight further easing'' until the next meeting which was held last Tuesday and was followed by the discount rate reduction and the lowering of the federal funds rate to 7.0 percent. Between the two meetings, the federal funds rate fell to 7.5 percent on Nov. 16 and to 7.25 percent on Dec. 7. The rate is the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans. The discount rate is the interest the Fed charges banks. The minutes show that the committee members were concerned about ``the growing signs of a softening economy, the related vulnerability of many business and financial firms to added financial strains and the increased reluctance of institutional lenders to accommodate less than prime business borrowers.'' The committee vote was unanimous. The Fed's monetary policy-setting arm is comprised of the seven board members and five of the 12 presidents of the Fed's regional banks. There currently is one vacancy on the board.

DOC.HEAD: DEEP FREEZE!
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 1st graf to CORRECT to its, sted it's; Picks up 2nd graf, `On the first ...' ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Winter made its entrance Friday on howling frigid winds generated by an Arctic cold front. On the first official day of winter the cold front ushered snow and bitter cold temperatures into the Mississippi Valley and the southern Plains. Temperatures plunged below zero from the northern Plateau and the Great Basin to the upper Mississippi Valley, turning gasoline to gel and stranding motorists by the hundreds. Three cities reported all-time record lows Friday morning. Casper, Wyo., hit 41 below zero, Redding, Calif., dropped to 17 to tie their record and Sacremento matched its all time low of 21 degrees. Amtrak's ``Empire Builder'' from Seattle to Chicago was delayed by the cold. The train that left Seattle on Tuesday arrived in Fargo, N.D., 24 hours late. ``It's cold enough to crack (rails) when the ice builds up,'' Amtrak spokesman John Jacobsen said. ``Sometimes it just separates the rails, but whether it actually cracks a rail or simply separates a rail, you can't operate a train. You have to wait to get a repair crew there.'' As the cold moved south, the temperature dropped 24 degrees in 30 minutes in Page, Okla., a small town in the Ouachita National Forest. It was 2 below in Amarillo, Texas, and 6 above in Lubbock. Snow extended across much of the Great Plains at midday spreading into the middle and upper Mississippi Valley. Strong northwesterly winds brought bitter Arctic air into the center of the nation resulting in dangerous wind chill factors. Jamestown, N.D., reported a wind chill of 70 below zero, while winds at Grand Forks produced a wind chill of 76 degrees below zero. Winter storm warnings, watches and advisories were posted into Saturday from the northern Plains to the southern Plains and the Mississippi Valley for heavy snow and debilitating wind chills.. Friday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 50 below zero at Worland, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Survives Censure Motion
DOC.TEXT: A conservative coalition protesting legislative practices failed Friday in an attempt to bring down the Socialist government of Premier Michel Rocard, who narrowly survived a no-confidence vote last month. The Intergroup bloc claimed Rocard's government showed ``contempt'' for the parliament by including proposed legislation in recent votes of confidence. If the vote of confidence passes, the bill is also approved. The censure motion received 218 votes from the 577-seat National Assembly, 70 votes short of the number needed to dissolve the government. Neither the centrists nor the Communists agreed to back the motion. Intergroup is made up of the Rally for the Republic and the Union for French Democracy parties. In November, a censure motion, the first the Communist Party agreed to back, was five votes short of passing. It was filed to protest a new 1.1 percent social services tax to replace an existing tax paid by employers and employees.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Holds Evacuation Drill; Cheney Says Conflict More Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf after 5th graf pvs, `It doesn't ...,' with details of capsized navy vessel off Israel. Picks up 6th pvs, `Saddam Hussein...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX9,14
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of Iraqis heeded air raid sirens Friday and jammed the rads out of Baghdad in an evacuation drill to test war readiness. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said armed conflict is increasingly likely. Gen. Colin Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, added that any attack on Iraq would be swift and decisive. He and Cheney visited U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. ``When we launch it, we will launch it violently,'' Powell said. ``We will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we can get it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.'' However, Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser to President Bush, said Jan. 15, the U.N. deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait, is just ``an authorization date.'' ``It doesn't say he is going to be attacked this date or that date or whatever,'' Scowcroft said in an interview in Washington with The Associated Press and other news agencies. Off Haifa, Israel, at least one U.S. sailor was killed when a navy vessel ferrying about 100 seamen to the USS Saratoga capsized early Saturday. The sailors, on shore leave, were returning to the aircraft carrier, deployed in the Mideast as part of the multinational force against Iraq. Cause of the accident was not immediately known. Saddam Hussein, meanwhile, predicted an Iraqi victory in any war with the multinational force arrayed against him and stood by his refusal to pull out of Kuwait. He spoke in an interview on German television. ``In the event of war, there will be great losses, not just in terms of human life,'' Saddam said. ``Allah is on our side, so we will defeat the aggressors.'' The Iraqi government is believed to have a large arsenal of chemical weapons and missiles, along with its powerful army. In Bonn, the German government said Friday it was investigating U.S. suspicions that German companies have continued sending supplies to Iraq, despite the U.N. embargo. A German magazine said one company supplied Iraq with nuclear training and equipment, while two others have helped Baghdad with nerve gas production. Der Spiegel said Washington has given Bonn a list of 50 German companies suspected of violating the U.N. embargo. The Bonn government confirmed it received the list and said the allegations were being examined, but that so far it had no proof. Sirens blared in Baghdad Friday and residents, clutching blankets and food, jumped into cars or rushed to special centers where they caught buses to evacuation camps set up outside the capital. Roads leading out of the city were jammed with thousands of cars, trucks, buses and even carriages pulled by tractors. The evacuation drill began at 7 a.m. and ended five hours later. It was conducted for the half of Baghdad that lies on the east bank of the Tigris River. But only about half the area's 2 million people participated, said residents, speaking on condition of anonymity. They said people locked their doors and watched television rather than get stuck in the traffic jams. A second exercise Saturday will cover west Baghdad. Basra, Iraq's second-largest city with a million residents, was evacuated in a similar exercise Thursday. ``It is useful. If a war broke out, God forbid, we need to be out of our areas,'' Samir Abdul Aziz, 45, a dentist, said at one evacuation camp. Iraq has increased its preparations for war since the U.N. Security Council authorized force to remove Baghdad's troops from Kuwait if they have not left the emirate by Jan. 15. Iraqi media now carry instructions for building bomb shelters and courses in civil defense and first aid. In Saudi Arabia, Cheney told U.S. troops that war was drawing closer. ``It increasingly looks like (Saddam's) not getting the message and we'll have to use force,'' Cheney said. ``The only acceptable outcome, if hostilities begin, is absolute, total victory.'' Cheney said U.S. military officials don't think ``waiting indefinitely is going to solve the problem.'' About 280,000 U.S. troops are stationed in Saudi Arabia as part of the nearly 400,000-strong multinational force. They face about 510,000 Iraqi troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. In the interview with Germany's ZDF television network, Saddam was asked if he would pull his troops out of Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline. ``No,'' he answered. ``We are certain that even when Bush pushes his country into war, which he plans, he can't keep it going,'' said Saddam. He did not elaborate. In other developments: -The U.S. military command said eight American soldiers have been poisoned by home-brewed alcohol and hospitalized since Sunday. The soldiers, from the 101st Airborne Division, are the first known casualties of home-brewed liquor since U.S. forces were deployed in Saudi Arabia, a Moslem country that bans all alcohol. -Some U.S. troops went on a low-level alert for a possible chemical attack Friday after reports of a missile test-firing. The Pentagon later said that Israel held an unannounced missile test hundreds of miles away. It would not comment on the alert. An NBC television crew, in the radio room of a U.S. Coast Guard patrol boat about five miles off eastern Saudi Arabia, videotaped an exchange about the missile firing which appeared to indicate Iraq had fired the missile. But in Washington, a Pentagon official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he had no information indicating that Iraq had fired a Scud missile.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Allowed To Pass Sunken Barge
DOC.TEXT: Choppy water prevented a salvage team from reaching a sunken scrap barge Friday, as a result continuing to threaten ship traffic in part of the country's busiest inland port. The Coast Guard opened 4 miles of the Allegheny River to a coal barge but said the waterway would remain closed to most ships, especially tankers carrying fuel or other liquids, until the rusty craft was located. ``That coal barge is going through at its own risk, and if he were to dump the load of coal in the river it wouldn't be significant environmental damage,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Rhea Giacoma. An Azcon Scrap salvage crew Friday afternoon suspended the search for the barge until Saturday because of rough water about 4 miles northeast of downtown Pittsburgh near the Highland Park Dam. The crew was confident the barge was below the dam Friday because of an unusual current about 40 feet from the river's north bank, said Richard Spine, Azcon's executive vice president. An undertow prevented divers from going underwater and a strong surface current prevented the search tugboat from getting near enough to drag the river at that spot, he said. The 4-mile section of the rain-swollen river was closed to all ships Wednesday and Thursday. Commerce on the Monongahela and Ohio rivers was unaffected. Ms. Giacoma said the Coast Guard would review requests for passage on the Allegheny River to determine if their cargo could damage the river in an accident. The barge has been loose on the river since Dec. 14, when it broke free as it was towed to the Azcon Scrap Corp. yard for dismantling as scrap steel. Two employees jumped to safety before the steel barge sailed over a dam, dug into the river mud and bent at a 45-degree angle. Record rainfall on Tuesday washed it further downstream. When the barge's location is confirmed, warning buoys will be placed in the river and the waterway will reopen to all traffic, Ms. Giacoma said. Spine said the spot where the barge apparently sank is away from the river's main shipping channel. ``If there is such a thing as a convenient place for a barge to sink, this is it,'' he said. If the barge can be lifted from the river bottom, it will be chopped up as scrap steel, Spine said. Four U.S. Army Corps of Engineers locks above the sunken barge reported little activity Friday because most barges remained at their landings, waiting for the river to open, said Corps civil engineer Jim Mershimer.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Refuses Bail for John Gotti
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT to Reputed sted Alleged; Picks up 2nd graf, `U.S. District ...,' SUBS grafs 3, grafs 6 to CORRECT to co-defendant sted codefendant
DOC.TEXT: Reputed crime boss John Goti was denied bail Friday and will spend Christmas in jail while facing charges of murder, racketeering and conspiracy. U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser of Brooklyn decided against bail after a three-hour closed hearing. During the proceeding, prosecutors played secretly recorded tapes they say show Gotti and his two co-defendants are a threat to the public and should be held without bail. Glasser reopened the courtroom after the hearing to announce his ruling. ``I have concluded that the government has sustained its burden by clear and conclusive evidence,'' Glasser said. ``There are no conditions of release that would reasonably assure the safety of any other person in the community.'' Gotti, 50, and his co-defendants, alleged underboss Frank Locascio, 58, and reputed mob counselor Salvatore Gravano, 45, have been jailed since Dec. 11. Federal agents arrested them on murder, racketeering and conspiracy charges. Law enforcers described the three as the leaders of the Gambino crime family, reputedly the most powerful criminal syndicate in the country. A hearing was set for Jan. 18. Media lawyers had argued for an open hearing, noting Gotti has been acquitted of crimes three times in the past five years despite media coverage. His acquittals have earned him the nickname ``the Teflon Don.'' Prosecutors allege Gotti engineered the slaying of his predecessor, Paul Castellano, to seize control of the Gambino crime family.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Paralyzed Dancer $14.3 Million
DOC.TEXT:
A jury awarded $14.3 million Friday to a former ballerina who was paralyzed from the waist down after a 1983 crash in a car driven by former New York Yankee infielder Andre Robertson. The state Supreme Court jury decided Thursday that Robertson and the city were responsible for Shenikwa Dawn Nowlin's injuries. Nowlin, 31, was the Dance Theater of Harlem's youngest member when she was 14. She is now a Dallas attorney. The jury found the city liable for 67 percent of the award because a sign warning of a curve on Manhattan's West Side Highway was too near the bend for a driver to react in time. The jury also found Robertson 33 percent liable because he exceeded the speed limit. ``Nobody can be compensated for the kinds of injuries I received,'' Nowlin said later, outside the courtroom. ``If I had it to do over again, I'd be walking and not sitting here. No money can pay for what has happened to me.'' Nowlin's spine was broken when Robertson smashed his car into a highway embankment around 5 a.m. on Aug. 18, 1983. The two, friends since they were students at the University of Texas, had been to a nightclub and were on their way to take pictures of the Statue of Liberty. Robertson, 33, is out of baseball and now works in a steam generating plant at Dupont's Sabine River Works in Orange, Texas.
Robertson's attorney, Daniel McNamara, said his client's insurance will cover about $25,000 of the award. He said Robertson can't afford the balance so the city by law will be liable for almost the entire award. It wasn't immediately known if the city would appeal the award.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Explodes in Lima, Wounds Three Guards
DOC.TEXT: A powerful car bomb exploded before dawn Friday at the city's most exclusive shopping mall, injuring three private guards. Police suspect Maoist Shining Path guerrillas in the attack. The blast in the mall's indoor parking lot buckled the garage walls and blew a large hole in the roof of a bingo parlor. The explosion was heard more than five miles away. Police said the car was packed with at least 65 pounds of dynamite. The three guards were wounded by flying glass. The explosion shattered windows 150 yards away and ripped Christmas decorations from the outer wall of the 10-story building. It blew out display cases in dozens of stores. The bomb also broke the face of a clock in a church tower across from the mall in the upper-class neighborhood of San Isidro. The mall was nearly deserted at the time of the blast. During shopping hours, the complex would have been packed with members of Lima's elite society. Neither of Peru's two leftist rebel groups claimed responsibility for the bombing, but police said it was similar to other attacks by the Shining Path. The Shining Path has exploded numerous car bombs in Lima in recent years. Most of the attacks have occurred late at night, apparently to avoid wounding passersby.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Files Charges Against Storefront Bank
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges Friday against an uninsured storefront ``bank'' whose collapse threw more than $6.8 million in deposits of recent Salvadoran immigrants into jeopardy. The commission also obtained a temporary order from U.S. District Court freezing the assets of three top officers of Latin Investment Corp. of Washington. The corporation's assets were frozen Dec. 15 when it was forced into seeking bankruptcy court protection from creditors. A bankruptcy judge as ordered the company liquidated. The commission said it had contacted the government of El Salvador to locate any assets there that would be subject to a freeze order although the countries have no formal cooperation agreement. A hearing on the commission's request for an injunction against the defendants was scheduled for Jan. 14. ``There is evidence to suggest that individuals who were nominally drawing salaries of slightly in excess of $20,000 a year have acquired very expensive real estate in the Washington area. We intend to go after that real estate if we establish liability and try for the recovery of assets that may have been improperly diverted,'' said commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden. Commission officials said they had referred the Latin Investment matter to Washington, D.C. local officials when it first came to light in 1987. Breeden said if Latin had been chartered as a bank, supervised by local bank regulators and under federal deposit insurance there would have been little for the commission to do. William McLucas, head of the commission's Enforcement Division, said District of Columbia officials assured the commission on several occasions in 1988 that they were taking steps to ensure that Latin would get a bank charter. The city's Office of Banking and Financial Institutions was closed when called late Friday for comment. According to the complaint, Latin Investment, founded in 1982, had about 3,500 investors who had placed about $6.8 million with the investment company as of August this year. Investors have said they deposited money with Latin because it had tellers who spoke Spanish. The Wilson International Center, a private community group that is helping investors, said the amount in jeopardy was more like $13 million in deposits, an average of more than $3,700 apiece. The complaint alleges that Latin, which operated without a bank charter or government banking insurance, misled investors into thinking their funds would be safe and available on demand. Also named as defendants and as the target of various requested court orders were: founder Fernando Leonzo of Vienna, Va.; the corporation's secretary, Leonel Salinas of Falls Church, Va.; and vice president Jose A. Cortes of Arlington, Va. Leonzo, through his lawyer Charles Pearson, denied the commission allegations. ``We have a different version of events, and that will certainly come forward in due time,'' Pearson said. ``We're not trying to hide anything. What we're trying to do is repay depositors.''
