DOC.HEAD: Ceremony That Turned Fatal Claims 13th Victim
DOC.TEXT: A woman has become the 13th person to die from injuries apparently suffered when a butane lantern filled a small house with carbon monoxide fumes during an all-night religious ceremony, authorities said. The woman, Consuelo Ponce, 40, died Thursday at the Social Security Hospital, said state coroner's office and state public ministry officials. Ms. Ponce was taken to the hospital in a coma on Dec. 13 after attending a religious ceremony in a shantytown neighborhood in this border city south of San Diego. After the deaths there was speculation victims had been poisoned by food and fruit punch consumed during the ceremony that began Dec. 12, the feast day of the Virgin of Guadalupe, patron saint of Mexico. But tissue and blood tests on the 12 who died earlier indicated they had not consumed alcohol or another toxic substance, authorities said. The victims had gathered at the home of Federico Padres Mexia, a self-styled spiritual leader who claimed he could perform miracles and had communicated with God. Padres, 61, and another survivor remain hospitalized in a coma Thursday, said Leonardo Cortes, a state public ministry spokesman. An autopsy was to be held to determine Ms. Ponce's cause of death. Authorities earlier determined the other 12 died of asphyxiation from carbon monoxide emitted by the leaky butane gas lamp used to light the unventilated house. Authorities also believe the fatal level of carbon monoxide may have been aggravated by the burning of Epsom salts during the ritual, which the victims' survivors said was intended to cleanse their souls or change their luck.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to include writethru designation
Authorities Hunt Indiana Shotgun Killer; Fear Casts Cloud Over Christmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf `Police from...' to CORRECT that task force formed Dec. 14 sted day after first killing; Picks up 1th graf pvs, `Since then...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GRY1, CX2
DOC.TEXT: A police task force worked Friday to narrow a list of suspects in seven shotgun slayings in northwest Indiana, where merchants are arming, schools are locking doors and fear has spoiled Christmas for many. Police are putting out extra patrols to protect vulnerable late-night businesses in this small town, where two of the killings occurred last week, the latest in the string of slayings that began Oct. 30. The latest victims are two brothers who were killed Tuesday in a tailor shop. All the attacks - shotgun blasts at close range - have occurred in late afternoon or after dark within a 20-mile radius of Gary, a blue-collar industrial city about 10 miles west of Portage. Two victims were killed at gasoline stations, another at a motel desk, another near a bank cash station, one in a parking lot, and two at the tailor shop. ``They don't know when he's going to hit next, if he's going to hit again,'' said Karen Klenk, general manager of Lees Inn of Portage. Mrs. Klenk has doubled night clerks and advised them to be extra cautious with late-night visitors to the motel, which is less than a mile from the Howard Johnson Motor Lodge where a desk clerk was killed Dec. 15. Several Gary-area elementary schools kept their doors locked during classes this week, but Mrs. Klenk and other area residents say there's no real protection against sudden violence. Gary Stasik, manager of a Portage gasoline station, said he is ``angered at the person out there, the SOB who is trying to ruin people's lives, ruin people's Christmas, ruin the lives of the survivors.'' Investigators believe one man is responsible for all the killings. The first victim was a Hammond man who was gunned down Oct. 30 in a parking lot in Griffith. One other person was killed that night, a woman who was closing a Cedar Lake gasoline station, and two others were shot at but missed. Police from northwest Indiana joined the Indiana State Police and FBI investigators in a task force of more than 30 investigators on Dec. 14. Since then, hundreds of tips have poured in, said Portage police Sgt. Warren Lewis, spokesman for the task force. Police are focusing on several suspects, Lewis said, but he declined to give any details. Police believe the assailant is a man somewhere between 20 and 35 years old who drives a boxy white car. He may have suffered recent emotional trauma, Lewis said. Police released a composite sketch and psychological profile that says friends or relatives might recognize him by a recent change in his life or comments he has made about the killings. Experts in the Lake County crime lab are examining shotgun shells left behind at the scenes of four slayings to determine whether all were fired from the same gun. Dr. Daniel Thomas, Lake County coroner, has said the shells show ``definite similarities.'' In Gary, some merchants said they have misgivings about staying open, even if armed. ``My kids have been after me to close up over here, especially after this,'' said Fran Ostrowski, owner of Fran's Jewelry. ``But I like to work. I hope I'm not pushing it.'' Mrs. Ostrowski runs the business with her husband, Ray. They have kept guns in their small store since they opened 10 years ago in a neighborhood now checkered by vacant windows and boarded-up shops. Ostrowski wears a .32-caliber pistol on his belt and keeps a 12-gauge pump shotgun within arm's reach of his back-room desk. ``It's too late to say, `I wish I had my gun,' after somebody's shooting at you,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope to Visit Brazil at Close of Eucharist Congress
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will attend the closing day of a national Eucharistic congress in Brazil next year, the Brazilian foreign affairs minister was quoted as saying Friday. It will be the pope's second visit to the South American nation, which has the largest Roman Catholic population in the world with nearly 106 million followers. According to ANSA, the pontiff will be in the city of Natal for the close of the congress on Oct. 13. He will also visit the capital of Brasilia. In August, the pontiff will visit Hungary and Poland, ANSA reported. The pope is scheduled to arrive in Hungary on Aug. 16 on a flight from the Polish Marian shrine of Czestochowa, where he will lead ``World Youth Day'' celebrations.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Governor Grants Clemency to 25 Women Prisoners, Citing Battering
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Richard Celeste on Friday granted clemency to 25 women prisoners who he said committed crimes because they were victims of battering or other forms of physical or emotional abuse. The lame-duck governor said he reviewed 105 cases in which ``battered woman syndrome'' was suspected. The Ohio Supreme Court and the state Legislature in March established the syndrome as a defense against murder and other crimes. Most of the inmates were serving time for such crimes as murder, manslaughter and assault. Paperwork and other procedures probably will mean the women won't be released until after Christmas, Celeste said at a news conference. The governor included a stipulation that all of those freed must perform 200 hours of community service in domestic violence programs. He also said each woman must serve at least two years before being released. Four of the 25 women have spent fewer than two years in prison. Of the cases the governor reviewed, 32 were sent back to the state Parole Board for further review and 48 were rejected, he said. He said he was still reviewing about 15 other cases and would announce his decisions next month. Celeste said Ohio was the last state to recognize the plight of battered women when the Ohio Supreme Court in March ruled that evidence of battered women syndrome is permissible at trials. All the cases reviewed involved women convicted of killing or assaulting their mates before the March 7 decision. The new state law permits testimony on the syndrome, a psychological state brought on by long-term abusive relationships and which often leads to severe stress and low self-esteem, among other conditions. Some of Celeste's decisions ran counter to recommendations of the parole board. But he said he read each case at least twice and consulted with court and other officials before he was convinced they were victims. Celeste said the parole board does not cite the criteria it uses in its decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Christians Conduct First Outdoor Service in Hindu Nepal
DOC.TEXT: Nepalese Christians celebrated the Christmas season Friday with their first open service since reforms swept away a strict Hindu tradition in the Himalayan nation. ``We had no chance to celebrate Christmas in the open before the dawn of democracy,'' said Loknath Manaen, secretary of the Nepal Bible Society. About 700 Christians gathered Friday for a three-hour public worship meeting in the heart of Katmandu. Previously, they were forced to worship secretly in unmarked halls and private homes. Last year, 14 Nepalese Christians were arrested for singing carols at Patrang Bari in southeastern Nepal. All were sentenced to six years in prison by the government, then a divine-right Hindu monarchy. Following pro-democracy protests last spring, King Birendra was reduced to a constitutional monarch and freedom of worship was allowed. The jailed Christians were released in June under a general amnesty by the new government. The National Bible Society estimates there are about 50,000 Christians in Nepal. About 90 percent of Nepal's 17 million people are Hindus. Most of the rest are Moslems and Buddhists. Nepal's new constitution still forbids the conversion of Hindus to other faiths.

DOC.HEAD: First Day of Winter Is ... Wintry for Much of Nation
LaserPhotos DXP1, DX3, SE1, XNOV1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to gel, sted jelly; SUBS 5th graf, `The storm ...' to UPDATE with additional death; SUBS 9th graf, ``The problem ...' to correct gelling, sted jelling; INSERTS 4 grafs after 13th graf bgng, ``It's cold...'' to UPDATE with flood threat in Idaho, thousands without gas in Oregon, pipeline rupture in Utah, twisters and thunderstorms in Mississippi and Louisiana. Pickup at 14th graf pvs, `The cold...'
DOC.TEXT: Winter arrived Friday on a sled of arctic air that slipped down across the western two-thirds of the nation, from frosty Seattle to snowy California to the deep-frozen Texas panhandle. The cold turned gasoline to gel in Wyoming, where temperatures plunged to 50 degrees below zero. It snapped power transmission lines, stopped Amtrak's ``Empire Builder'' in its snowy tracks and gave California citrus growers the shivers. Low temperature records were tied or broken in many places, including Denver, which matched a record at 21 below zero; Casper, Wyo, where it was 41 below; and coastal Eureka, Calif., where it was 27 above. In Medford, Ore., the record of 4 below zeo was 15 degrees below the old mark for the date. It was 2 below in Amarillo, Texas, and 6 above in Lubbock. The storm system has been blamed for at least 14 deaths since Tuesday, in Washington, Iowa, Oregon, California, Oklahoma and Mississippi. The most recent death was reported Friday afternoon in Mississippi, where a twister knocked a tree into a house and killed a man. The cold moved south briskly. In Page, Okla., a small town in the Ouachita National Forest, temperatures dropped from 53 to 29 in a span of 30 minutes Friday morning, forecaster Jim Purpura said. ``They have to join the rest of us,'' he said, referring to portions of Oklahoma that had previously been spared the frigid weather. In Wyoming, hundreds of Christmas travelers abandoned their frozen vehicles. Among them were passengers aboard two Greyhound buses stalled by the subzero temperatures. ``The problem is not the road conditions - the roads are pretty dry,'' said Michelle Ryel, a dispatcher with the Wyoming Highway Patrol in Cheyenne. ``The problem is the bitter cold is freezing up these trucks. Their fuel is gelling.'' Eight inches of snow fell at Gallup, N.M., where a recreation center was converted to an overnight shelter for stranded travelers. Gallup Police Chief Frank Gonzales issued an appeal to citizens to help people found outdoors. ``Different people calling us report drunks laying out on the sidewalks and that the snow is covering them,'' Gonzales said. ``I wish they would help us by taking them inside, and we could pick them up then.'' Train travelers were delayed up to 24 hours when the cold stalled Amtrak's ``Empire Builder'' from Seattle to Chicago. The train that left Seattle on Tuesday arrived in Fargo, N.D., around midnight Thursday - one day late. ``It's cold enough to crack (rails) when the ice builds up,'' Amtrak spokesman John Jacobsen said. ``Sometimes it just separates the rails, but whether it actually cracks a rail or simply separates a rail, you can't operate a train. You have to wait to get a repair crew there.'' Between 40 and 50 families in Pocatello, Idaho, were evacuated from their homes when overnight temperatures that dipped to 17-below created ice jams that caused the nearby Portneuf River to rise more than four feet in two hours. More than 3,000 homes in southern Oregon lost their natural gas supply when pressure dropped in a pipeline that supplies the area. Gas company officials said it could take days to restore gas to all the households. The cold also apparently caused a water valve to rupture in the Ogden, Utah City Mall Friday, sending icy water pouring into as many as 20 stores. Thunderstorms and twisters swirled through Mississippi and Louisiana afternoon, overturning a tractor-trailer rig, blowing cars off the road, damaging buildings and injuring at least five people. The cold caused power outages in Jackson Hole, Wyo., and in Arlee, St. Ignatius and Ravalli, Mont. The outages kept the Jackson Hole Ski Resort from opening. But in general, the storm was a boon to the ski industry in the Rockies and the Sierra Nevada. And while subzero temperatures, whipping winds and blowing snow made life a little harder for some people, others took it in stride. ``This is how it's supposed to be,'' said Kathy Walters of West Des Moines, Iowa, as she prepared to go out into the 33-below wind chill. ``It's Christmas. First comes ice, then snow.

DOC.HEAD: Students Collect 7,000 Signatures for Peace Petitions
DOC.TEXT: A group of sixth-grade students hoping to forestall a war in the Middle East have gathered more than 7,000 signatures for petitions to send to President Bush and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``We're old enough to know what's going on,'' said Mary Beth Schultz, 11. ``We're old enough to be afraid.'' The youngsters launched their drive about five weeks ago with letters to 165 Roman Catholic schools statewide, said their teacher, Pat Garcia. About half the schools responded with signatures from students and teachers. The petitions were to be sent to Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., R-Wis., with a request that copies be forwarded to the White House and to Iraq's United Nations delegation. Iraqi troops invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or risk military intervention. ``We urge President Bush and Saddam Hussein to step forward and lead our world to peace,'' the petitions said. The children's solutions to the crisis included dividing oil profits between Kuwait and Iraq and submitting the dispute to an arbitrator. ``Maybe it will work out; I don't know,'' Adrianne Pauley, 12, said. ``At least we tried.''

MOSCOW - President Mikhail Gorbachev forged ahead with efforts to revamp the government and increase his powers after Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze resigned, warning of a slide toward dictatorship. The Fourth Congress of People's Deputies was scheduled to resume discussion today on a Union Treaty that grants limited autonomy to the governments of the 15 Soviet republics. But most of the republic leaders want even greater independence from Moscow. The growing chaos in some areas has led a hard-line faction of the Communist Party, including military leaders, to call for a crackdown. Shevardnadze, 62, in his shocking resignation speech Thursday, lamented the growing influence of lawmakers ``with colonels' stripes'' and said the government was moving toward a dictatorship. ---= WASHINGTON - U.S. officials are worried that the departure of Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Soviet foreign minister will slow progress in U.S.-Soviet relations and perhaps trigger further disintegration of the central government in Moscow. ``This is not a very nice Christmas present from Moscow,'' said one senior U.S. official who emerged Thursday from meetings at the State Department to discuss Shevardnadze's resignation, which sent shock waves through Moscow and Western capitals alike. Despite public reassurances that the resignation won't change the course of superpower relations, there is private consternation among leading official analysts and more open concern expressed by experts outside the government. John D. Steinbruner, a Soviet specialist and director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution, called the move ``a severe polarization of the Soviet domestic situation.'' ---= WASHINGTON - While urging the Soviet Union to accelerate its economic reform efforts, a study of the Soviet economy concludes that massive amounts of Western aid would be wasted if offered now. The study, the most comprehensive look by the West at the economic difficulties facing the Soviets, was being released simultaneously today in Washington, London and Paris by the agencies that undertook the five-month review. Officials in the Bush administration and international lending institutions said the report recommends an infusion of technical assistance to help the Soviets move to a market economy. At the same time, they said, the study warns against massive amounts of immediate Western aid on grounds the money would be wasted because the Soviet economy is in so much disarray. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the report portrays a system that was even more backward than expected and practically paralyzed in its stumbling efforts to implement the restructuring program of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ---= WASHINGTON - President Bush says Iraq's Saddam Hussein does not understand the military threat he faces in the Persian Gulf and must be made to realize his country is going to lose badly if it comes to war. ``If we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked,'' Bush was quoted as telling lawmakers Thursday. However, some congressional leaders expressed concern about the fallout from fighting. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, just back from the Middle East, said he and members of his group detected ``considerable support among the masses'' in Arab countries for Saddam. ---= RIYADH, Saudi Arabia - If the United States attacks Iraq for refusing to leave Kuwait, the assault could begin with a massive air strike - followed by a short pause to give Saddam Hussein a chance to surrender, military analysts say. This scenario gained credence this week as U.S. military officials conceded that some vital American ground forces will not be ready for combat by the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for the Iraqi leader to withdraw his troops from Kuwait or face attack. The likelihood of starting with air strikes has been discussed for some time by military officials and others who believe the United States - because of its long-term political interests in the region - must keep damage to Iraq to a minimum. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, are in Saudi Arabia assessing the U.S. deployment. They were heading later today to the north for pre-Christmas meetings with American troops stationed in the Saudi desert. ---= GARY, Ind. - A rash of seven shotgun killings is scaring people into carrying guns or staying indoors at night as police try to nab the killer before another attack. Gun sales are skyrocketing in the largely blue-collar area of northwest Indiana after the slayings within a 20-mile radius since late October. At Jack's Gun Shop in Burns Harbor sales of firearms and ammunition have jumped fivefold since last week, owner Jack Batz said Thursday. ``We saw a big increase because people realize these are senseless killings,'' Batz said. ---= NEW YORK - They'll still need their parents' permission for field trips, but teen-agers in the nation's largest school system could get condoms next year simply by asking. Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez believes it's a matter of life - or death from AIDS. New York City is home to about 3 percent of the nation's 13- to 21-year-olds, but it has 20 percent of all AIDS cases in that age group. ``We are sitting on a time bomb,'' Fernandez said. If the Board of Education approves Fernandez's proposal next month, condoms would be available on request as early as next spring at 120 schools that enroll 261,000 students. ---= UNITED NATIONS - Jewish groups are lambasting Washington for supporting a Security Council resolution that condemns Israel's deportation of Palestinians, and Israel says it will ``not accommodate'' the United Nations. By joining in the 15-0 council vote Thursday, the United States managed to maintain crucial unity with its Arab allies in the Persian Gulf crisis as the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline approaches for Iraq to pull out of Kuwait or face possible war. At the same time, U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering avoided linkage of the Palestinian issue to efforts to resolve the gulf crisis, as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has been demanding. The resolution asks signatories of the Fourth Geneva Convention to ``ensure respect by Israel ... for its obligations'' under the convention. ---= ARCTIC VILLAGE, Alaska - On a C-130 Hercules transport plane headed north across the Arctic Circle, Air Force Sgt. Carl Warrings donned his Santa suit and started practicing his ``Ho, ho, ho.'' A half-hour later, he and 1,500 pounds of Christmas presents - including a community washing machine - were lowered onto the frozen tundra outside this Gwich'in Indian village. A few dozen small children, bundled in furs and snowsuits, waited with their parents. It was 45 degrees below zero - warmer than it's been here all month. ``This is good. Usually when Santa comes it's really cold,'' said Kias Peter, the village's traditional chief.

DOC.HEAD: Fear of Mass Soviet Migration Hangs over Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Soviet army units enforcing the Kremlin view of life are not new to East Europeans, but the next Soviet invaders may be civilians trying to escape it. A possible mass influx of Soviet citizens fleeing economic chaos and ethnic strife at home has Eastern Europe, which has its own economic problems, balancing empty pockets against humanitarian ideals. ``A `poverty wall' must not take the place of the Iron Curtain,'' Prime Minister Jozsef Antall of Hungary said recently. Six months ago, the Soviet government promised to ease travel restrictions, but an emigration law is hung up in the Supreme Soviet legislature. No one can say when the reforms will come. Similarly, no one knows how many people will leave when new legislation takes effect. Estimates range from the 1990 total of 400,000 refugees to 5 million. Lev Lyubimov of the Soviet Institute of the World Economy and International Relations said currency restrictions and technical limitations on printing passports and visas probably would keep the number of emigres at about the current level. Economic and social reforms also might keep Soviets at home, he said. Soviet troops went into Hungary to stop a popular uprising in 1956 and Czechoslovakia in 1968 to crush the ``Prague Spring'' liberalization. They began leaving only only after peaceful revolutions a year ago. The possible invasion of refugees coincides with Eastern Europe's struggle to transform itself from communism to capitalism. Soviet emigration was discussed at a 34-nation summit in Paris in November. Recent food aid to the Soviet Union from Western nations is at least partially aimed at encourging its people to stay home. East European officials question whether the West is willing to accept its share of Soviet refugees. They fear most of the Soviets determined to emigrate will land in their countries. Poland cannot afford to take Soviet emigres, but will not turn them away, said Barbara Rozycka, a Polish official who attended a conference near Prague recently on prospects for Soviet emigration. ``We don't have enough for our own people, but it's not a question because it doesn't depend on economics, but humanitarian concerns,'' she said. ``The question for Poland is, `How will the Soviet Union disintegrate?' because we're sure it will happen. .. . Poland wants to see a peaceful disintegration.'' Within the Soviet Union, at least 600,000 people in the 15 Soviet republics already are thought to be refugees from ethnic violence. Many may want to leave if a new emigration law allows it. Soviet citizens have not needed visas to travel to Eastern Europe because of the close ties built during the communist years and because the Soviet Union restricted the right to travel. Former Soviet-bloc nations are loathe to impose visa requirements, but also worry about laying themselves open to greater economic strain. Hungary and Czechoslovakia, for instance, are considering whether they should require Soviets to have a minimum amount of foreign currency when they arrive, and also may strengthen border patrols. Currency regulations could stop many Soviets because the ruble, nearly worthless in its own country, cannot be converted abroad. In March, Soviet authorities forbade citizens to export items that might be used for trading, ranging from honey and canned fish to electric wire. ``We think the presence of police and soldiers at the border would deter many'' Soviets from trying to cross illegally into Eastern Europe, said Martin Friedman of the Czechoslovak Interior Ministry. Czechoslovakia expects to accept about 12,000 refugees annually under a new law offering asylum to those facing political, racial or religious persecution. Poland also can expect a large influx. Two million people of Polish origin live in the Soviet Union, mostly in neighboring Ukraine, Byelorussia and Lithuania, Ms. Rozycka said. Hungary is concerned about 200,000 ethnic Hungarians who live on the Soviet side of the 100-mile border and has committed itself to keeping the frontier open. For Romania, the situation is more confused. Nationalists on both sides of the Prut River border want the Soviet republic of Moldavia, annexed 50 years ago, to rejoin Romania. More than 100 ethnic groups are included in the Soviet population of 300 million. Some Soviets already are emigrating to Eastern Europe. Judit Toth, head of the Hungarian Interior Ministry's Refugee Affairs Department, said 55 applied for refugee status in September and 37 in October. Officials are trying to decide whether to return a man who swam the Tisza River border to Hungary. Interior Minister Krzysztof Kozlowski of Poland said in November that tens of thousands of Soviets had overstayed their tourist visits.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Eve In Hollywood: Real Tinsel
DOC.TEXT: It is sort of a tradition for Christmas Eve columns to start with phrases like, ``Twas the night before Christmas ...'' But this one concerns the first Hollywood Christmas of Martin Mull. Mull, actor, guitarist, and an artist whose heart belongs to Dada, was raised in North Ridgeville, Ohio. There, an old-fashioned Christmas meant lots of snow and frozen car radiators and guys full of goodwill, shots and beer. His first old-fashioned Hollywood Christmas, in 1975, was somewhat different. ``The hardest adjustment was being able to get into the Christmas spirit when it's 85 degrees, the air is hanging like pea soup and there are palm trees with lights on them,'' he said. He saw his first Hollywood Christmas parade, full of antique celebrities, chauffeur-driven marching bands, antique cars, and tiny people claiming to have been in a 950 CBS series, ``Kuda Bux, Hindu Mystic.'' ``I watched from a distance of about 15 feet - and I was seeing it on our TV set - and I realized that is the closest I ever want to get to halftime at the Orange Bowl.'' And most every shopping-mall Santa Claus had a Screen Actors Guild card. ``Oh, yes. If you sat in their lap, they'd tell you what THEY want. They'd say, `Listen, if you know anybody at Paramount, I've got a script.' Also, `I don't really do this. I'm not Santa.' Really shattered my bubble.'' He survived all this. He went on to play the evil Garth Gimble of Norman Lear's ``Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman,'' and then Garth's twin, Barth, host of the best talk show ever, ``America 2-Night,'' now in reruns on cable. That started him on his way, to fine films like ``Serial,'' to comedy albums, two of them nominated for Grammy awards, and to various cable specials, among them his acclaimed ``The History of White People in America.'' Alas, things did not go well for his first CBS sitcom, a 1984 effort called ``Domestic Life.'' It expired quickly. His second, ``His & Hers,'' another domestic sitcom, had an even shorter life on CBS last season. No matter. He's working on a third, ``Family Dog,'' an animated sitcom about the life and times of a nameless dog and the family that lives with him. The show isn't yet scheduled for CBS' prime-time roster. Mull is aware that some may consider it CBS' reply to Fox's ``The Simpsons,'' although this is not so. In his show, ``the focus is on a dumb animal, with the accent on dumb.'' In the show, Mull is the voice of ``Dad,'' the head of the clan, with Molly Cheek as the mother of their two kids. It's the first time he has been a voice in a cartoon series. He considers it a good deal. ``I've had some lousy experiences in television ... but this one is a treat,'' he said. ``I don't have to shave. I don't even have to bathe, actually. I do it only out of courtesy to Molly.'' Mull spoke by phone from his home near Santa Monica, Calif., a home he said contained all the old-fashioned Christmas things, including icy frost spray-painted on the window corners. He, his wife, Wendy, a composer, and their 5-year-old daughter, Maggie Rose, plan to spend Christmas quietly. Same goes for New Year's Eve, even if it is the custom during New Year's Eve in Hollywood to go to New Wave clubs, drink a lot of champagne and, as the new year arrives, holler, ``I'M FAABULOUS! I`M FAABULOUS!'' You won't find that at the Mull manse. He doesn't drink nowadays, he says. And he'll stay at home, where there'll be no shouts and wild cries. ``We tend to celebrate New Year's at 10 p.m.,'' he said. ``Because, hey, tomorrow's another day. You've got to get up and the kid gets up early. Besides, I like to think I have a two-hour jump on everyone else in town.'' --- Elsewhere in television... REASON NO. 397 TO CONTINUE BREATHING IN 1991: There will be another, yes, another awards show added to a list so crowded that there is talk of holding an awards show to honor achievement in award shows. Until then, CBS' new ``The Movie Awards'' telecast must suffice. Co-hosted by Kirstie Alley and Robert Townsend, it will be broadcast live on Jan. 30 from Universal City. It will honor movies and actors considered really neat by filmgoers voting in 3,000 theaters. The Big Vote will be held on Jan. 5. End Adv PM Monday Dec. 24

DOC.HEAD: Sky's the Limit for Japan's Pampered Tots
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The girl, hair neatly coiffed, wore a petite pearl choker by Mitsukoshi, black velvet dress by Renoma and white lace gloves. Her escort, in top hat, sported a double-breasted tux by abs d'absorba. Ready for the prom? Not quite. That's still years away for the two pint-size models photographed for a magazine in outfits worth more than $3,500. The Japanese penchant for designer brands and other luxury goods has brought some tots into the world of high fashion. Japan's ultraperfectionist parents and doting grandparents have more money than ever, and fewer children to spend it on. The average number of children per family has dropped from about five in 1945 to 1.5 in 1989. ``There are six pockets - the two sets of grandparents and the parents - who can be counted on to spend money on every child,'' said Toshiro Niizaki, planning director for Seibu department store's children's section in Tokyo. Highly competitive department stores have encouraged the trend by building special kids sections stocked with designer goods. Sunday department store outings and the custom among status-conscious Japanese of giving expensive gifts have done wonders for the boom in kiddy luxury goods. When special occasions come up for youngsters, it often is the grandparents who foot the bill for the gold-threaded silk kimonos that have become de rigueur for ritual shrine visits. The visits start with the 100-day-old child's first blessing. A kimono worn only for that excursion can cost well over $1,000. Subsequent visits during a girl's third and seventh year and a boy's fifth require new kimonos or Western suits. Trend watchers say young parents fond of sports cars, fur coats and diamond rings are willing accomplices. ``When parents themselves are wearing designer clothes, they want their kids to have things that are just as nice,'' said Niizaki, a father of two. ``Young mothers are especially fashion conscious, since they grew up during a `fashion era' introduced by teen magazines in the 1970s,'' said Hideo Takayama, director of the Children's Survey Research Institute in Tokyo. ``They've got the tiresome habit of comparing themselves and their children with others. They want their kids to have the best so everyone will see their kids as being good,'' he said. Their elite tastes aren't confined to fashion: -Disco parties for tots and their mothers are a hit in the western city of Osaka. A 24-year-old mother at one of them with her year-old daughter told a popular weekly magazine she spent about 100,000 yen ($750) a month on the child's clothing and entertainment. -Family gourmet dinners to commemorate special occasions, at up to $450 for a family of four, are popular at major hotels. -Travel agents say six-day family tours to Hawaii and Guam, complete with baby sitter and sometimes a doctor, are fully booked at $2,500 and up. To get their children into the best schools possible, parents send toddlers as young as 1 to preschools. One such institution, run by Tokyo's Seiwa Education Co., picks up and returns tots to their homes or their mothers' offices in luxury cars. School officials say about 50 children are on the waiting list for 120 places. Entrance fees range up to $3,750 and monthly fees to $2,200. Parents say the ultraexpensive clothes are only brought out for special occasions, which makes spending $1,300 for a ministrand of pearls or more than $450 for a tiny three-piece woolen suit and suspenders even more puzzling. ``At our school, we require the children to wear clothes that can get dirty and are easy to play in,'' said Taeko Fukuda, a nursery school teacher. ``I think it's very strange to buy such expensive clothes for fast-growing children.'' Some people are worried by the trend. ``In the past, we didn't believe in being so extravagant. We thought it would make children weak. Today, some mothers seem to view their children as accessories, rather than real people,'' said Takako Shinagawa, a child psychologist and grandmother. Ms. Shinagawa said it's difficult to avoid spoiling grandchildren, however, and added: ``There must be some place with decent prices, but I'm too old to go looking for it.'' Niizaki of the Seibu department store said he does not favor buying luxury clothes for children, even though his department's sales have increased up to 20 percent a year. ``We try not to buy too much,'' he said of his own family. ``You have to teach kids how to put up with waiting. You can't just give them everything they want right away.''

DOC.HEAD: Official Call for Serious Fun
DOC.TEXT: After decades of focusing on work and building the economy, Singapore is becoming serious about having fun. Nothing frivolous, of course, but Goh Chok Tong, the new prime minister, has promised a lighter approach. Goh, 49, took over when Lee Kuan Yew stepped aside last month after 31 authoritarian years. Lee made no excuses for the lack of municipal merriment in his clean, prosperous city-state, but approved carefully patrolled street festivals beginning two years ago. They have become institutionalized, with part of one main street closed an evening each month for a mass party. The biggest of these bashes attract about 250,000 people from a population of only 2.7 million. ``We have got to find new ways of expressing ourselves, and this is not only harmless, it may well do us good,'' Lee acknowledged. Singapore also has discovered fun is good for business. ``It is not just to have fun, it is also because fun products sell better,'' George Yeo said. ``To create fun products, we need fun people, fun events and fun places.'' Yeo recently was appointed acting Cabinet minister in charge of information and the arts. ``It may seem odd, but we have to pursue this subject of fun very seriously if we want to stay competitive in the 21st century,'' he said. Life should be effervescent, Yeo declared, with ``more bubbles in the Singapore champagne.'' Creative services will become very important in economic development and the right milieu is needed to attract creative people, Yeo said: ``In a paradoxical way, fun is serious business.'' In trying to recapture the zest of old Singapore for tourists who complain the nightlife is boring, the government is rebuilding Bugis Street. A raffish neighborhood that contrasted with the rest of this squeaky clean place, Bugis Street attracted drunken soldiers and sailors, transsexuals and other all-night revelers. It was bulldozed out of existence five years ago to make way for a subway station. For decades, there was nothing remotely like it in Singapore. The ambience included hundreds of food stalls, touts and small-time con artists, souvenir peddlers, palm readers and pimps. Bugis Street became naturally seedy over the years, but the copy is a $7.2 million-project sanctioned by the Tourist Promotion Board. In addition to encouraging more fun, officials are determined to shed the country's reputation as a cultural desert and help citizens develop three-dimensional personalities. The new prime minister wants them to be educated, compassionate, gracious and socially confident. The 3-D Singaporean is to be fully operational and contributing to a ``culturally vibrant society'' by 1999, by the government's timetable. Since that target was set six years ago, millions of dollars have been provided for the arts, spending on a scale unprecedented in the 25 years since independence from Britain. By trying to generate more fun, younger political leaders hope to attract a new generation, said Chan Heng See, Singapore's U.N. ambassador. Younger voters did not readily accept the idea of a successful, efficient, hard-working, boring society of conformist, rigid, overly disciplined people. ``Singapore should hang loose a little,'' Ms. Chan said, ``but I think if we start talking of the politics of fun, we immediately destroy the spontaneity of what we are trying to create.''

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Act Creates Uncertain Future for Coal
DOC.TEXT: The coal industry, always battered by economic and labor uncertainties, enters the new year under the cloud of the Clean Air Act of 1990, which could devastate the nation's high-sulfur mines at first and mean trouble for all mines later. ``It's going to hurt some people. It's going to shift the market maybe, and we don't know how,'' said David Branand, director of environmental affairs for the National Coal Association. ``Overall, unfortunately, in the long-term, I believe the Clean Air Act is going to be negative for the coal industry in general, basically because of caps or restrictions on emissions,'' said Gary White, president of the West Virginia Coal Association. The Clean Air Act, which became law Nov. 15, restricts sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-fired power plants, considered the leading cause of acid rain. Those plants, primarily in the Midwest and Ohio Valley, must cut sulfur dioxide emissions by half, or 9 million tons annually, in the next decade. The restrictions, which take effect in 1995 and tighten in 2000, essentially give power plants that now burn high-sulfur coal three options: -They can install scrubbers at a cost of up to $100 million each, which would eliminate up to 90 percent of the sulfur emissions and allow them to continue burning high-sulfur coal; -They can switch to lower-sulfur coal and pay generally higher transportation costs; -Or they can trade or sell pollution allowances, permitting some plants to exceed standards to the extent other plants come in under the limits. ``So much of it depends on what the utilities are going to do, and they're in a state of uncertainty,'' Branand said. Nonetheless, utility officials must decide soon which route they will take. ``If you're talking about installing scrubbers, not only are you talking about a major financial investment, you're talking about a major construction effort to get them installed,'' White said. West Virginia presents a microcosm of the challenges the Clean Air Act poses for the coal industry. The state's high-sulfur northern coal fields stand to lose business because of pollution restrictions. At the same time, the state's low-sulfur southern coal fields are getting ready for a boom. White said he hopes for expansion in the southern coal fields and a minimum loss in the northern mines. But he's more pessimistic about the industry's long-term health, primarily because the law will make it to expensive to build ne coal-fired power plants. The key to meeting the new clean air standards lies in the sulfur content of coal and its ability to produce energy rated in British thermal units, or Btu, said John Randolph, director of the Virginia Center for Coal and Energy Research. Wyoming, Kentucky and West Virginia produce more than half the nation's coal. Coal with a sulfur content of 0.6 percent or less makes up 44 percent of the known reserves in Wyoming, 16 percent in Kentucky and 37 percent in West Virginia. But the coal in Kentucky and West Virginia generally is more efficient than that in Wyoming, Randolph said. The average central Appalachian coal produces 12,500 Btu per pound, while Wyoming coal can produce as little as 10,000 Btu per pound. By 1995, power plants must limit sulfur dioxide emissions to 2.5 pounds per million Btu. Central Appalachian coal with about 1.6 percent sulfur content will meet the new standards, Randolph said. By 2000, sulfur dioxide emissions will be limited to 1.2 pounds per million Btu, so central Appalachian coal would have to have a sulfur content of 0.75 percent or less, he said. In both cases, Western coal would have to be lower in sulfur content to make up for the shortfall in Btu. But while the Western coal is less efficient than Appalachian coal and costs more to transport to the Midwestern power plants that need it, it also is cheaper to produce, industry experts said. In the past year, Huntington-based Ashland Coal Inc. has spent $180 million to buy two companies with major low-sulfur reserves: Mingo Logan Coal Co. in southern West Virginia and Pikeville, Ky.-based Coal Mac Inc. ``We believe Ashland Coal is going to be benefited from the Clean Air Act amendments,'' said Vice President David Todd. We feel optimistic about that. ``Quantifying that is where the uncertainty is.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Homosexuals Seek Legalization, Greater Tolerance
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Homosexuality remains illegal in the Soviet Union after five years of political reform, and attempts to start a gay liberation movement have been denounced by the press with a venom reminiscent of another era. Religion, pornography, gambling and political freethinking, once grievous sins against communist society, flourish under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but homosexuality has stayed underground, one of the last taboos. In the past year, a few dozen Soviet gays and lesbians have begun a campaign to get homosexuality legalized and increase social tolerance. They have achieved some successes, including launching the country's first homosexual newspaper, but Soviet homosexuals say they also have been beaten by youth gangs in recent months and forced by police to undergo blood tests for AIDS. ``There is no real gay liberation movement here, and I am very skeptical there will be one,'' said Dmitri, 33, a scientist. Like other homosexuals interviewed, he asked to be identified only by his first name. ``I am absolutely sure that if they announced a rally ... few people would turn out,'' he said. ``I personally wouldn't. They would photograph us, and that could lead to problems at work, maybe even getting fired.'' On warm evenings, gay men often gather outside the Bolshoi Theater, home of the renowned ballet. When the weather turns raw, they walk around the block to the Sadko Cafe for Hungarian wine, salted fish and mushrooms cooked in sour cream. Sadko has more charm than utilitarian Soviet cafes, and one other advantage: privacy. Its widely spaced tables allow discreet conversation, and lamps reflect dim light onto a vaulted ceiling. The ``golubye'' - literally ``light blue ones,'' Russian slang for homosexuals - are careful to leave in threes and fours. ``It's not a good idea to walk out of here alone, because you can never tell who's waiting around the corner with a stick and a taste for blood,'' said Serezha, 24. Gay activists say youth gangs beat up homosexuals about once a month, and that the attacks rarely are reported to the police because victims don't want to call attention to themselves. Whatever the threat of teen-age toughs lurking outside, the Sadko at least provides a meeting place for the small number - believed fewer than 250 - of open homosexuals in Moscow, a city of 9 million people. Conditions are said to be worse outside the capital and other major cities. ``In small towns, homosexuals are always visible,'' said Dmitri, the scientist. ``They have no place to gather and no place to hide.'' Activists said only a few men had been prosecuted in recent years for homosexual acts between consenting adults and all the cases were in provincial towns. ``There is no reason to believe homosexuality is any less common in the Soviet Union than anywhere else on earth,'' said Vladimir Shakhidshanian. ``It just meets less public acceptance here.'' Shakhidshanian, 50, is the author of a forthcoming book about sex called ``1,001 Questions About THAT.'' The avuncular Armenian dispenses advice about sex in newspapers and on television. During an interview in his cluttered office, he riffled through some of the 8,000 letters he has received from viewers, including many gays and lesbians. Soviet homosexuals ``suffer loneliness, shame and discomfort in their private lives, and ignorance, prejudice and persecution in society,'' he said. He said he knew of no Soviet polls on attitudes toward homosexuality. Shakhidshanian said his letters and interviews indicated that tolerance of homosexuality rose in the early 1980s, under Western influence. ``Then came AIDS,'' he said, ``and turned public opinion strongly against homosexuals again.'' According to official statistics, 565 Soviet citizens, including 74 homosexuals, are infected with HIV, the AIDS virus. The leading causes of the spread of AIDS in the Soviet Union are medical mistakes - including reuse of infected syringes - and heterosexual relations, said Irina Yeremova, an epidemiologist. ``Homosexuals often are blamed,'' she said. The law against homosexuality, dating from the 1930s, sometimes has been used for political purposes, as in the case of the late Sergei Paradzhanov, an Armenian film maker imprisoned in 1972-78. He was convicted of homosexuality, but his real crime was signing a ltter demanding the release of Ukrainian dissidents. Anatoly Sobchak, a former law professor who now is mayor of Leningrad and a member of the national legislature, said he believes the statute will be removed when a new criminal code is adopted in 1991. Technically, it prohibits only male homosexuality, not lesbianism. But lesbians are active in the nascent homosexual rights movement. ``We suffer from the same kind of social intolerance, the same fear of being fired under some pretext, the same desire to live freely,'' said Mila, 33. The movement's leading organization, formed in Moscow in October 1989, is the Association of Sexuality Minorities, which publishes Tema, or Theme, the first Soviet gay and lesbian newspaper. To protect identities, the association keeps no formal membership roll. Activists said it has only 20 to 25 regular participants, but many more supporters. The first three issues of the newspaper, distributed in February, July and November, contained articles on such topics as gay cinema, homosexuality in Russian history. In a scathing article printed by leading newspapers Nov. 15, the government Tass news agency accused the group of harboring not only ``primitive'' homosexuals, but ``necrophiliacs, pedophiles and zoophiles.'' ``Where can you find a fresh corpse to excite a necrophiliac? How much does it cost to have sex with a baby? Why doesn't Moscow have official places for men to entertain themselves with little boys, and girls with girls? For only two rubles, Tema provides its readers with the answers to these and other nasty questions,'' Tass said. Roman Kalinin, Tema's 24-year-old editor, denied the paper had published such information. Tass ``knew perfectly well it was untrue,'' he said. In addition to publishing Tema, the Association of Sexual Minorities collects information on civil rights violations. It reported in September that police and soldiers in the Black Sea resort of Sochi raided a gay cafe and used billy clubs to force suspected homosexuals into a bus. The men were driven to a hospital, where doctors were ordered to test their blood for AIDS, the association said. Activists said Western gay and lesbian groups so far have contributed several typewriters, a small amount of money - under $1,000 - and 7,000 condoms to the association. Kalinin, who spent November in the United States meeting with homosexual groups at the invitation of the U.S.-based International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission, said he believes more aid will be coming. Already, he said, international activists have planned a ``gay parade'' through Red Square for the summer of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Network of Rocketing Trains Spreads Across Europe
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The historic linkup of a tunnel under the English Channel is only one step in a larger plan to connect the great cities of Europe with a network of superfast trains. Rail planners envision sleek trains rocketing through the French Alps, across German plains and, of course, under the channel. On board, they hope, will be travelers fed up with Europe's congested airports and highways. By 2010, they could be riding from Madrid to Frankfurt in less than 10 hours, compared to nearly 24 hours now. ``Train will soon allow what only plane made possible,'' predicts Karel van Miert, the European Community's transport commissioner. He recently introduced an EC plan to create a $205 billion Western European high-speed network over 20 years. The 15,500 miles of electrified track would carry trains running at 120 to 200 mph. The channel tunnel, which linked up in early December, will join London and Paris with a 3{-hour train ride in 1993. It will enable a London banker, for example, to hop a train to Brussels, Frankfurt, Madrid, Milan or dozens of other cities. Environmental worries, ethnic squabbles and high construction costs could derail parts of the project. Finanbody. ``When it will really be done, I don't know,'' said Hughes Corbeau, a rail planner for the French Transport Ministry. ``It's going to cost a lot, and demands concerted efforts from public powers.'' High-speed rail systems - minimum speed 120 mph - already built or under construction in Britain, Germany, Italy, Spain and France form the core of the proposed network. Also foreseen are new high-speed systems or linkups by rail or ferry in Belgium, the Netherlands, Greece, Portugal, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Austria, Ireland and Yugoslavia. The technological star and pacesetter for high-speed rail is the chisel-nosed French TGV, or ``train a grande vitesse.'' TGVs went into operation between Paris and Lyon in 1981, racing along at 174 mph. They halved the rail time between France's two leading economic centers to two hours, and boosted ridership between Paris and southeast France from 12.2 million to 22.1 million in nine years. Julian Andriao, 45, a chemistry professor from Lyon, is a regular rider. He said the train may be a bit slower than an airplane, but makes up for it by saving trips to airports and waiting at check-in lines. ``I came here for a professional meeting this morning,'' he said on a Paris train platform. ``I'll be home in time for dinner with my family.'' France expanded the TGV network last year with a second generation of more powerful trains running east-west. They cruise at 186 mph, but one engine set a world rail speed record of 318 mph. The TGV runs at high speed only on special track. On the 3{-hour trip from Paris to Geneva, it slows to 125 mph on conventional track after Lyon. Railway directors hope high-speed trains can win back airline travelers on trips of 600 miles or less. Hours-long airport delays are increasing, especially at London, Paris and Frankfurt. Transport studies show European air traffic increased 56 percent from 1975 to 1986 and could double by 2000. On the Paris-Lyon run, air traffic fell to 1972 levels after the TGV began operating. The complete train network will not be easy to accomplish, if the planned hookup of London, Paris, Brussels, Amsterdam and Cologne serves as any example. It already has intergovernmental approval and the route lies over flat terrain, so it should be among the easiest to build. However: -Britain refuses to lay special TGV track in the lush, highly populated countryside between London and the channel tunnel, adding 30 minutes to the trip. -Regions of Flemish and French speakers in bilingual Belgium are squabbling over who will get the special track and thus reap the most economic benefit. -In the Netherlands, the shortage of dry land makes it impossible to lay the long straightaways TGVs need to reach full speed. The French Transport Ministry had hoped the line would be operational by 1995. Its most optimistic estimate now is 1998.

DOC.HEAD: Former Game Ranger is `Father' To All Creatures Great and Small
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Foster father Viv Wilson is fond of his orphans even if they do growl and grunt, snarl and snap, hiss and hoot. One even bit off a finger. The 58-year-old former game ranger's charges are lions, hyenas, baboons, crocodiles, snakes and hundreds of birds common to the African bush. ``It's not a zoo, and it's not for financial gain,'' said Wilson, a native South African who set up the home in 1973. ``It's simply a private sanctuary for orphaned, abandoned, confiscated or injured wild animals that, reared in captivity, can't safely be returned to the wilds.'' Chipangali Wildlife Orphanage realizes a dream Wilson had nurtured since working as a game ranger for the British colonial government in Northern Rhodesia, now Zambia. The body of a newborn kudu calf, clubbed to death by a native hunter who also shot its mother, begot Wilson's ambition. He and the hunter met in the brush-studded Chipangali region of eastern Zambia, heavily infested by trypanosomiasis - a disease borne by tsetse files that can be fatal to man and beast. Wilson recalled asking the hunter why he killed the calf. The hunter replied he was only doing his job, killing animals of some species as part of the government's anti-tsetse fly operation. ``I knew he was right,'' said Wilson. ``But I also thought something was awfully wrong.'' When Zambia achieved independence in 1964, Wilson moved to Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, where he was offered a good job in its game department. Nine years later, Wilson founded Chipangali, 15 mies south of Zimbabwe's second city of Bulawayo, with savings and sponsorships. For Wilson, his wife Paddy and their two sons, home was a small thatched roof house and work was tending a few animals in a cluster of pens. This was the beginning of the seven-year war waged by guerrillas against white supremacy. It ended in 1980 with independence under President Robert Mugabe. ``We weren't touched by the war, and if guerrillas were roaming around here, I never saw them,'' said Wilson. ``But we did get quite a few soldiers popping in to drop off pets, mainly monkeys, they'd tired of.'' People continue to deliver animals to Wilson's care. Today, Chipangali is a honeycomb of more than 70 large enclosures and aviaries for ``The Orphans of the Wild,'' the title of a book by Wilson published in 1977. A labyrinth of pebbled paths bordered by gardens of native trees, plants and cactuses lead visitors to Wilson's waifs. ``We've strived to make the setting as naturally African as we can, both for the animals and for people who come to see them,'' Wilson said. His family still lives beneath the thatch-roofed house flanked by enclosures for lions, leopards and monkeys. About 20,000 people stroll around Chipangali's 10 acres each year, a third of them schoolchildren who are allowed to visit free of charge. Adults pay the equivalent of $2. ``We encourage the kids,'' said Wilson, who serves as manager for a trust fund set up to bankroll the orphanage. ``Africans brought up in the rural areas fully understand wildlife because it's all around them. ... But millions of Africans born in cities and towns have never seen a lion, a leopard or a snake.'' Urban children, he said, ``have lost contact with nature. Here, we take them back to the wild.'' The $10,000 needed monthly for Chipangali's upkeep comes from gate receipts, sales of a wildlife calendar, the orphanage's restaurant and fund-raising events such as horseracing. Scores of sponsors, many of them foreigners, adopt animals and send checks as foster parents. ``We still battle,'' said Wilson, who launched Chipangali on $400 a month. ``We can never close, so we must cut our cloth to suit our income.'' Wilson, who as a game ranger survived charges by rhinoceros and bites from poisonous snakes, has had few problems from his creatures. A lion chomped off one of his fingers, a visiting schoolboy was slightly injured by a leopard and some of his 40 employees have been bitten by monkeys. Besides running the orphanage, Wilson has authored three wildlife books, helped produce a 25-episode program for television and written some 60 research papers on African snakes, animals and birds. He was commissioned by the Geneva-based International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources to study ways to prevent the extinction of the jentink's duiker antelope of Liberia, and won the 1987 Rolex Spirit of Enterprise award for his work there. In June, he was among 500 people worldwide honored by the United Nations for environmental achievements. Wilson left Liberia in March just before the outbreak of civil war. He fears the few surviving duiker were destroyed in the conflict. ``That's my next concern,' ' he said. ``As soon as things are settled down I'll go back to see for myself.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs Jan 10

DOC.HEAD: Mommy's a Soldier, Daddy Celebrates First Christmas With Baby
LaserPhoto CX7 of Dec. 20
DOC.TEXT: Cheyenne Vallance-Kirk is celebrating her first Christmas with a sparkling tree, new toys and a loving family. She has everything a baby girl should have - except her mommy. Hollie Vallance is a soldier in Saudi Arabia, waiting for a possible war, wondering about the baby she left behind this summer, a 7-week-old bundle of sweetness, now being cuddled and cared for by her daddy. ``It comes pretty naturally,'' says Anthony Kirk, heating a bottle while cradling 5{-month-old Cheyenne in his arms. ``The baby's teaching me. If you're not doing something right, she'll scream and holler. You've got to figure out what to do.'' ``He's done a remarkable job,'' boasts mother-in-law Sharon Vallance. ``You can just tell she's a real happy baby and that just shows to me that a baby's being well taken care of. ... You know that things are right.'' Kirk is among thousands of Army spouses whose lives have been turned around by Operation Desert Shield, a military operation in which roles are reversed for many families. Moms are toting guns and cleaning tanks in the Persian Gulf, while dads are hauling groceries and washing clothes at home. The separation creates a special strain and sadness in the Christmas season. ``None of us can really get in the holiday mood,'' says Mrs. Vallance. ``It's been real hard just to get the tree and decorate it. ... I think it's real hard (Hollie) missing Cheyenne's first Christmas.'' Still, it will be a special day for baby Cheyenne, with gifts of clothes, quilts, sing-along toys, rattles and a little mirror for her crib. She'll have all the joy but none of the emptiness and fear her family shares. ``We're all scared to death if something happens over there, what she'll be doing and where she'll be at,'' Mrs. Vallance says of her daughter. Kirk, 27, often says he wishes he could trade places with his wife. ``I wouldn't have to worry about Hollie,'' he says. ``I just feel the baby needs her mother more than a father.'' But Cheyenne has been getting plenty of parenting since Spec. 4 Hollie Vallance, a 22-year-old medic, kissed her baby goodbye last August as the Army's 197th Infantry Brigade pulled out from Fort Benning, Ga. Her maternity leave had ended just two days earlier. At first, Kirk continued working at Royal Crown Cola in Columbus, Ga., placing Cheyenne with a baby sitter. ``My boss told me you can't work and take care of the baby, too,'' he recalls. ``I said `You watch me, I'll do it.' It lasted five weeks.'' Father and daughter then moved into his parents' southwestern Michigan home, just minutes from his in-laws. Raising Cheyenne is a family affair. Kirk's six brothers and sisters live at home or nearby. And there are 10 grandchildren. ``We always have little babies around the house, so it's nothing new,'' says his mother, Sonja. Fatherhood, however, was new for Kirk, now unemployed. ``He was sitting here one morning about 5:30, holding her and he had changed her, dressed her and fed her and he looked at me and said, `I don't care what you say, this is a woman's job,''' says Kirk's father, Larry. But he has adjusted, rising before dawn, feeding Cheyenne her formula, changing her diaper, dressing her, soothing her as she starts teething. ``It's made me realize how much time and care a child needs,'' he says. He has learned Cheyenne loves baths and other children. And he jokes about her temper. Kirk dutifully chronicles all these details to his wife in letters, faxes, videos and a few precious phone calls. He tells her how big Cheyenne's brown eyes are, how she's grown into a 16-pound charmer, how she's started crawling, how cute her pierced ears are, how she enjoys looking in the mirror and how her tiny feet already are outgrowing the red Mary Janes that match her red velvet and lace dress. ``I think she worries about missing everything,'' Mrs. Vallance says. ``She's not seeing any of this. I don't think she worries about her care. She has the utmost confidence in him.'' In one letter her mother received, Ms. Vallance told her a Saudi family with a little girl visited her area one day. ``She said she just had to go to her tent. She just broke down. She couldn't take it.'' Kirk and his mother-in-law stay busy. Both attended a support group meeting for families with relatives in the Persian Gulf. ``It just made me feel good to talk about it,'' he says. Both also try to be upbeat. Mrs. Vallance says her daughter is a positive thinker who had no complaints about being ordered to the Mideast. ``She really felt like it was her duty and that's what her job was,'' she says. Last summer, Kirk thought his wife would be home in three months. Then six. Now everyone is hopeful the family will be reunited by Cheyenne's first birthday July 4th. Meanwhile, Kirk and Mrs. Vallance regularly show Cheyenne pictures of her mother. A week before Christmas, Kirk's wife called and reassured him of her safety. ``I told her it didn't matter, I'm still going to worry,'' he says. ``I know someday we'll be back together,'' he adds. ``Hopefully, soon.'' ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - Sharon Cohen is the AP's Midwest regional reporter, based in Chicago.
End Adv Ams Tuesday Dec. 25

DOC.HEAD: LaserPoto Planned
Japanese Geniuses Leave Their Brains to Posterity
DOC.TEXT: Behind the tattooed skins, severed arms and rat skeletons in the university lab rests the world's only collection of famous brains, left to posterity by some of Japan's greatest thinkers. Each of the 120 brains of prime ministers, novelists, artists and scholars has its own container, something like a fish tank, in the University of Tokyo's medical department. Scientists there hope to gain some insight into what makes the brains of famous people special. ``We'd like to get many more,'' said Yutaka Yoshida, curator of the collection. ``I'd especially like to get brains from mathematicians, musicians and singers.'' The collection was begun in 1913, when the family of Taro Katsura, a three-time prime minister, asked that his brain be preserved for study after his death. The newest acquisition is the brain of former Prime Minister Takeo Miki, who died in 1988. So far, the deep-rooted reluctance among Japanese to tamper with the dead has ensured that the museum's resources far outweigh its ability to use them. ``We try, as far as possible, not to cut them,'' Yoshida said. ``We want to keep them in their original shape.'' University researchers have cross-sectioned several brains to allow some visual and microscopic comparisons. Most are undisturbed, however, immersed in amber formaldehyde, gleaming palely behind small handwritten cards giving the names and special qualities of their original owners. Yoshida is a slight, quiet man with 13 years of experience in the lab, which also has diseased selections of human anatomy and wall-hangings of tattooed skins donated by men who wanted to have their body art preserved. As curator, he has renewed efforts to learn from the collection of famous brains. The brain of Hisashi Hamaguchi, an eloquent prime minister assassinated in 1931, looks about the same as that of Natsume Soseki, a famous novelist who died in 1916, or of Yasuko Miyake, a writer who provided the only female brain in the collection. ``Researchers say the fibers in the part of Hamaguchi's brain that controls speech are very complex, very special,'' he said, referring to a part of the left hemisphere that regulates speech and other motor functions in right-handed people. ``You can't do much research, just looking at the outside of the brains,'' Yoshida said. ``We're obviously going to have to start doing histological (microscopic tissue) studies in the future. Yoshida feels some Japanese would protest such studies. ``Somehow, I think the Japanese would want to keep the famous brains the way they are now,'' he said. ``They wouldn't like to have them laying around on lab benches.'' Many universities keep frozen or preserved brains for research purposes, but none has a collection of geniuses, Yoshida said. The Tokyo collection resulted from a preoccupation with the differences between Asians and Caucasians, men and women, geniuses and average people, that emerged during the Meiji Era (1868-1912), when Japan began in earnest to study Western science and technology. Eventually, Japanese medical researchers began to study brains, with some controversial results. The brains of some famous people, they found, were heavier than those of less distinguished thinkers. Japan's heaviest brain of record was that of Torasaburo Araki, a politician and doctor who left 57.4 ounces of gray matter behind when he died in 1942, and Prime Minister Katsura's brain was second at 56 ounces). The average Japanese brain is said to weigh 45.5 ounces. ``It seems as if great thinkers ma indeed have heavier brains,'' says Yoshida. ``But then, so do many criminals, I hear. Maybe they have a different sort of intelligence.''

DOC.HEAD: In Conformity-Minded Japan, How-To Guides are Big Business
DOC.TEXT: How-to guides are wildly popular in teaching everything from dating to dressing in Japan, where pressures to conform can be immense. ``How-to magazines attract Japanese readers, who are always fearful of doing something different, by showing a standard of what people should be doing,'' said Masayoshi Kinjo, editor of the popular men's magazine Brutus. Recently, Brutus described the ``right'' way to behave on a date: ``Order a tea immediately when your date shows up at a coffee shop to meet you. ... Smile even at waitresses and passers-by to better your image. ... Don't order drinks that make you look like a wimp. ... And finally, enjoy sex.'' Many young Japanese have trouble developing close relationships because of scholastic rivalries with other students and their parents' long working hours. Books and television teach them how to do so, said Yasuo Ueda, an associate professor of journalism at Sofia University in Tokyo. Store shelves are filled with how-to magazines, paperbacks, comic books and videotapes. A typical company handbook provides guidance for conduct on the job: ``Shave every morning and clip your nails occasionally. ... Keep shoe polish and a brush in your locker to make your shoes always shiny. ... Bend your head 15 to 30 degrees when you bow, but bow as much as 45 degrees to apologize.'' Researchers say reliance on such material results from an education system designed to make everyone the same through rules that dictate, for instance, the color of underwear and when students may go to the bathroom. Critics of the propensity for conformity acknowledge the education system's role in helping Japan become an economic powerhouse, but fault schools for failing to teach students creativity. ``Being always told what to do, people stop thinking ... and young people have become very passive,'' said Ueda. ``There should be so many different ways for them to live their own lives, but people are making decisions based on a few ... stereotypes,'' he said in an interview. Bunchin Katsura, a well-known storyteller who teaches sociology at Kansai University in Osaka, has had enough of the manuals. ``Could somebody please write a how-to book entitled `How Not to Depend on How-To Books'?'' he said. Young people like the manuals because following them provides reassurance that they are not outcasts from society. Katsura said the degree of reliance on self-help publications became clear to him on Christmas of 1989, when he saw dozens of young men lined up at a hotel checkout counter while their girlfriends waited patiently to the side. He attributed the lobby gridlockto magazines that instruct young men to seal a relationship with the opposite sex with a proposal to spend an intimate Christmas Eve in a hotel room. In Japan, Christmas is celebrated as an occasion to give gifts and to be with friends, not as a religious holiday. About 1,800 how-to magazines are published in Japan each year, in addition to many books, according to the Research Institute for Publications.

DOC.HEAD: Cops and Kids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Kindergarten Cop'' opened Dec. 21.
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Schwarzenegger took the easy job. As the star of the new movie ``Kindergarten Cop,'' Schwarzenegger only had to look like he was ruling a schoolroom of children. As the movie's director and co-producer, Ivan Reitman actually had to wrangle the 30 feisty tots - and coax a lot of comedy out of them and their behemoth co-star. ``Just try to tell a kid to hit a mark,'' said Reitman, the amiable director of ``Twins,'' ``Stripes,'' ``Ghostbusters'' and its sequel. ``You say, `Walk across the room, stop on the line, say your line and go over there and pick up a basketball.' Say that to a 5-year-old, and everything you've said before is forgotten. He hears the word basketball, something to do with a basketball, you call action and - boom! - he runs over and picks up the basketball.'' Having worked with such temperamental talents as Dan Aykroyd and Debra Winger, Reitman, who's also the father of three children, was equal to the task. Although they blew scores of lines and occasionally glanced into the camera, Reitman believes the children in ``Kindergarten Cop'' turned out as solid as Schwarzenegger. In the movie written by Murray Salem and the team of Herschel Weingrod and Timothy Harris, brutish police officer John Kimble (Schwarzenegger) must teach an Oregon kindergarten class so he can help track down a killer (Richard Tyson). A snarling, stubble-faced tower of strength on the Los Angeles streets, Kimble is cowed by the wiseacre infants. He must control them, or blow the case. A simple fire drill proves more difficult to Kimble than an armed robbery; unbuckling a child's suspenders trickier than defusing a time bomb. Having previously collaborated with Schwarzenegger on ``Twins,'' Reitman knew the star of ``Terminator,'' ``Total Recall,'' ``Conan the Barbarian'' and ``Predator'' possessed some comic skills. The trick was to let the stereotype of the former body builder work for ``Kindergarten Cop,'' rather than against it. ``For the first reel or so, it's almost a parody of what he does and what he has done,'' Reitman said. ``It's all very carefully designed - down to the lighting and the camera angles - to bring up sort of a `Terminator' image. ``I thought it would be very interesting - whether you can take the icon and the Arnold cliche and then twist it around in new ways and really believe in this guy right through the end: believe in his situations and get involved with him emotionally and with the people he meets.'' Reitman, 44, and his family fled Czechoslovakia for Canada when he was 4. He has produced ``National Lampoon's Animal House,'' ``Heavy Metal'' and ``Casual Sex?'' In ``Twins,'' he directed Schwarzenegger and Danny De Vito as genetically designed twin brothers. It marked Schwarzenegger's emergence as an actor with more range than a variety of grunts and accented obscenities. ``I thought `Kindergarten Cop' was a great film for him. ... He had felt that he been getting typed - and he needed some more complexities to the characters he was playing,'' Reitman said. ``Here's a guy who looks like a fantasy character at the top, but if it works, he becomes a real multidimensional, complex human being.'' There were two primary challenges in making ``Kindergarten Cop,'' Reitman said: balancing the story's alternating themes of comedy, romance and drama and eliciting credible performances from a bunch of 4-to-7-year-olds. ``There's a thing with child actors,'' said Reitman. ``When you talk to them, they sound fine. But as soon as you give them something that has to be repeated take after take or is printed on a page, there's a very natural tendency to become stilted. And the audition process (in which 2,000 children were interviewed) was very difficult to sit through because of that.'' The 30 children (including the twins Joseph and Christian Cousins, who alternate as student Dominic) were instructed by Reitman the first day to follow five simple rules: Know your character, act natural, be disciplined, listen and don't look at the camera. With three murders in ``Kindergarten Cop'' and a barrage of beatings, Reitman admits kindergartners shouldn't see a film about them. ``I really held back; you don't really see anything,'' Reitman said. ``But it's just intense emotionally. I felt (the violence) had to be there or the film would just peter out at the end.''
