DOC.HEAD: Tower Seeking to Settle Score for Nomination Defeat
DOC.TEXT: John Tower believes his former Senate colleagues did him wrong when they rejected his nomination as defense secretary. Now, he's settling the score. Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb., is a ``genuine boozer,'' Tower writes in a book slated for publication in February. Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., is the ``Senate bully ... a study in arrogance and pomposity.'' Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., ``has a tendency to resort to flatulent indignation.'' Tower, a four-term Texas senator and former Republican chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, suffered the most ignominious defeat in March 1989 when the Senate turned down President Bush's selection of him to head the Defense Department. The defeat came amid allegations that Tower was an excessive drinker, womanizer and held close ties to defense contractors - all charges he denies in the book. The rejection also capped a rancorous period in the new Bush administration and the long tradition of Senate comity in which only eight Cabinet nominees had been rejected in the nation's history. The book, titled ``Consequences: A Personal and Political Memoir'' and published by Little, Brown and Co., is Tower's first extensive response to the damaging blow the Senate inflicted on his Washington career. He leaves several bridges smoldering in the book's wake and fires shots at Republicans and Democrats alike. Tower directs much of the vitriol at Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee who led the fight against the nomination. ``Presidential ambitions were, I believe, a major factor in Sam Nunn's decision to oppose my nomination,'' Tower writes. The former Texas senator goes on to say: ``If Nunn had suspected that he would end up looking like an unscrupulous mudslinger who would stop at nothing to achieve his objectives, perhaps he would have satisfied himself with making a few critical comments expressing whatever reservations he may have felt, even to the point of indicating that I was on probation, and then voting to approve the nomination. ``But Sam Nunn was blinded by his own ambition.'' Nunn's press secretary, Scott Williams, said last week that the senator would have no comment on the book. In fact, calls to Senate offices of the other lawmakers also drew a ``no comment'' reaction. Tower cites several reasons for Nunn's opposition and says the armed services chairman was upset with Bush's selection from the beginning. Tower believes that Nunn, who played a major role in advising 1988 Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis on defense issues, was upset by Tower's attacks on Dukakis' policies. Tower campaigned for Bush in several states. In addition, Tower had advised former President Reagan to veto the fiscal 1989 defense authorization bill, legislation that Congress, led by Nunn, and the Pentagon, headed by then-Defense Secretary Frank Carlucci, had worked out. Tower suggests in the book that Nunn was still smarting from Reagan's decision. ``I did not regard Nunn as an obstacle. And that was a fatal misreading of the situation,'' Tower writes in hindsight. ``What lay before me, however, was not confirmation as secretary of defense, but a political killing field prepared by the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.'' The attacks on Nunn are not limited to the confirmation process. Tower also compares himself to Nunn. ``Unlike Sam Nunn, who has a reputation for being distant and disdainful toward his staff, I treated my aides with friendship and respect,'' Tower wrote. ``In return, I got tremendous loyalty and extended effort. It was not at all unusual to punctuate a long, stressful day with a break at the Monocle.'' The Monocle is a popular restaurant and bar on Capitol Hill. Tower also criticizes the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sen. John Warner of Virginia, who in Tower's eyes failed to live up to his role as the panel's top GOP lawmaker leading the fight for the president's nominee. ``To keep on good terms with Sam Nunn, he ceded the rights of the Republican minority to object to a course of action that was inimical to its best interests,'' Tower wrote. Warner, who argued in several Senate floor speeches for the nominee and voted to confirm Tower, was the lone senator to respond to the book. ``You've got to know John Tower as we do. It's his Texas style,'' Warner said Thursday. Tower's attacks on Exon as a heavy drinker are not new. During Exon's re-election fight against Republican Hal Daub in November, Tower campaigned for the GOP candidate and made the same accusations. Exon denied the charges. Tower does not limit his criticisms to the Senate. The former senator believes that White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray's inexperience in handling the nomination contributed in some ways to its demise. In the end, Tower writes that he didn't resent his rejection as much as he was upset with the way it was done. ``What was happening to me could have happened in an evil, Kafkaesque society,'' Tower writes. ``It couldn't happen in the United States. It couldn't happen in the U.S. Senate.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for AMs Wed Dec. 26 and thereafter

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Leaders in '90: Blue Chips Again
DOC.TEXT: The more things have changed on Wall Street from the '80s into the early '90s, the more one thing remains the same: Big stocks keep soundly thrashing smaller counterparts in the battle for investors' favor. As the bear-market year of 1990 draws to a close, the typical loss suffered by big-name blue chips is far smaller than the declines sustained by the great mass of smaller ``secondary'' stocks. For the latest 12-month period through early December, the composite index of the New York Stock Exchange, where most large stocks are traded, dropped 6.6 percent. Over the same span, both the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market and the American Stock Exchange market value index showed losses exceeding 18 percent. This sort of thing has been happening regularly ever since the mid-1980s, in apparent contravention of a prized doctrine among stock analysts and academic researchers known as the ``small firm effect.'' Over most extended periods of time, their studies have concluded, little stocks are likely to fare better than big stocks, if only because small companies have room for greater percentage growth. Several theories have been advanced to explain why this pattern is no longer holding. For one thing, big stocks got greater benefit from the takeover mania of the '80s than did those of small companies, which had fewer assets to ``restructure.'' For another, big stocks had a special attraction for foreign investors, given their familiar names and their perceived stability. But the most compelling reason of all may be the long-running trend toward index investing - constructing portfolios for pension funds, mutual funds and other large pools of money to look as much as possible like a market index such as Standard & Poor's composite of 500 stocks. Indexers mostly buy big stocks and hold them, since big stocks dominate the makeup of the indexes they try to replicate. Indexing enjoys great popularity as a low-cost way to participate in long-term market gains, without the risk of ``underperforming'' that befalls many managed stock portfolios. It is not so popular in the stock brokerage business, however, since it downplays just about every service Wall Street has to sell, from stock-picking to execution of buy and sell orders. Indeed, John J. Phelan Jr., who retires Dec. 31 as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, cites it as a prime force in the recession gripping the securities industry. ``It has put an enormous cost squeeze all through the system,'' he said during an interview last week, ``right from the money-management end of it to the execution end of it.'' Phelan's view of the near-term future offers little consolation for either brokers or partisans of the small stocks. ``Indexing is going to continue to have an enormous influence in the market for the next three to five years,'' he says. But sooner or later, he maintains, the pendulum that has been swinging away from active money management toward indexing will reach a point where it turns back the other way. ``Just about the time everybody indexes and everybody says money managers can't do better than the market, then we're going to get a whole crop of them doing better than the market,'' he said. ``You know that's going to come, but we haven't gone to that extreme yet. ``Money management is the only business in the world that says `we're mediocre,''' Phelan concluded. ``The human condition is not going to live with that for very long.''

DOC.HEAD: Hopes That Wall Street Pain Yields Gains
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: For stock-market investors and people who work in the securities industry, it hasn't been easy to see much bright promise in the early days of the 1990s. Stock prices have spent most of 1990 in a bear market that surpassed the Crash of 1987 in duration, if not in severity. At the same time, Wall Street itself languished in the fourth year of a stubborn industry slump. The end-of-an-era signals in 1990 seemed hard to miss. In February the firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert, kingpin of the '80s junk-bond boom, abruptly collapsed and disappeared from the scene. Nine months later its foremost financier, Michael Milken, drew a 10-year prison sentence. But in the midst of these backward-looking events, many analysts argue that the ground is being cleared and the seeds being sown for more bounteous times in the investment world as the decade progresses. ``The economy has tumbled into a serious recession,'' said Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co. in New York. ``The financial structure is at risk. Even so, the year ahead could be surprisingly good for Wall Street. ``With an assist from the Federal Reserve, we expect the economy to rebound during the second half of 1991. This has exciting implications for financial markets.'' To put a number on his optimism, David Bostian at Jesup, Josephthal & Co. forecasts that the Dow Jones industrial average will climb to 5,000 as early as mid-decade. ``This recession is providing painful, but valuable, lessons to governments, corporations and individuals that will improve their economic conduct in the 1990s,'' he maintains. ``The new decade will see savings and investment favored relative to consumption and equity favored over debt, to cite only two critical changes.'' Like many optimists in other areas of the economy, Wall Street's bulls are counting on the present crunch ultimately to serve as a purgative and restorative, rather than destructive, force. One central theme in this kind of argument is that the debt mess of the 1980s, with all the problems it has caused, will be cleaned up before too long, but not forgotten. Says Bostian, ``I think the banks may have learned a long-to-be-remembered lesson on the importance of lending for productive economic activity rather than financial speculation.'' What is more, some observers argue, a reborn distaste for credit excess is likely to help foster a long-lasting decline in interest rates. ``Now that recession is clear to everyone, anxiety about inflation will evaporate,'' contends Robert Barbera, economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Back-to-back decades of low inflation are likely to break the back of inflationary expectations. As a consequence, interest rates should decline more than inflation, as `real' rates fall as well. ``For investors who spent the past 10 years in money market funds or certificates of deposit, the collapse of high real rates on cash instruments is not good news. ``We believe that to obtain higher returns in the 1990s, investors will need to accept the volatility associated with stocks and bonds. And these of course would benefit from such a change in strategy.'' Whether they accept such reasoning or not, some analysts suspect there is more pain to be endured before any party gets started. To establish a bona fide bottom to the bear market, they assert, investors in greater numbers will have to be driven from the scene in discouragement or disgust. This ``never again'' mood is not yet manifest in such important arenas as mutual fund activity. Indeed, through the first 10 months of 1990, while the stock market was sagging, investors snapped up $56 billion in new shares of stock mutual funds, challenging a record of $67 billion set in 1987. At past market bottoms, hardly anybody wanted any part of stock funds. Observers looking for extremes of pessimism say the requisite gloom is much easier to find, however, within the securities industry itself, where talk abounds that the good days are forever gone. Aside from the business of money management, executives in the brokerage business these days seem hard-pressed to find any facet of their operations that promises much money to be made. ``Wall Street has been through its own private recession for the past three years,'' says Heinemann. ``Firms have cut back. They have pared their costs.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Yearend Editions

DOC.HEAD: Recession May Produce a Better and Wiser Consumer
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Not so long ago Americans were carefree consumers. Armed with credit cards, they went cheerfully into debt, satisfying needs and whims with few worries about the future. But the broadening recession has made once-spendthrift shoppers timid, as evidenced by a sharp downturn in spending. Yet some observers see a silver lining to these hard times and say consumers may emerge as wiser and more demanding customers. ``If consumers start retrenching and saving more, that might make more money available for investment,'' which could stimulate the economy, said Sandra Shaber, an economist with Futures Group in Washington. The slowdown in consumer spending may just be a mixed blessing. ``It's bad in the sense that it's going to aggravate the downturn in the economy in the short-term,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior adviser with DRI-McGraw Hill Inc., a forecasting concern in Lexington, Mass. ``But in the long-term, a lot of families have been loaded with debt, and they need time to make an adjustment.'' Still, consumer spending - which accounts for two-thirds of the gross national product - must remain buoyant enough for the economy to recover. Over the past few months, growth in consumer credit has dropped sharply. In October, consumer credit was growing at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, down from a 4.6 percent growth rate in September and 5 percent in August. A year earlier, Americans were taking on debt much more freely. Credit rose at an annual rate as high as 6 percet in August 1989. ``The great heyday when consumers were borrowing even more rapidly than what their income growth was came in '86,'' Ms. Shaber said. But for the next two years debt continued to grow but at about the same pace as income, and since the beginning of 1990, it has fallen behind the rate of income growth, she said. Ms. Shaber attributed the recent slippage in consumer debt to a slowdown in income growth that began in 1989 and continued into this past year. ``People have less money to spend and they're going to buy less,'' she said. Other factors also have helped bring consumer spending levels in line with income. The Tax Reform Act of 1986, which phased out the deduction for most consumer debt, made some Americans realize they had to take a more responsible attitude toward spending. Many consumers have put spending on non-essentials such as clothing, furniture and appliances, on hold as the unemployment rate climbs and the Middle East crisis looms as a huge uncertainty. The reluctance to spend money in department and discount stores has forced retailers to become more lean by cutting their inventories and buying less merchandise. With less demand for goods at U.S. factories, production is down, and that has meant layoffs for hundreds of thousands of workers in recent months. It doesn't end there. Consumers who are not working have even less money, so they are scaling back spending and the cycle begins all over again. Harry L. Davis, a professor of marketing at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, found another silver lining: People, having little money to waste on goods that wear out or break down easily, are becoming better consumers. They ``have learned how to say, `No, this quality isn't high enough,''' Davis said. A consumer's decision to put off a big purchase ``may be the result of being to some extent better informed and wanting to buy things that are going to be longer-lasting values,'' he said. This growing sophistication among consumers is putting pressure on U.S. manufacturers to come up with better ideas and products. Automakers must now market their cars based on durability and safety instead of image, while ``McDonald's is spending a lot of time grappling with consumer demands for healthier food,'' Davis said. Manufacturers are not the only ones having to shape up. Retailers, facing tougher competition for fewer consumer dollars, must come up with better merchandise at the right price. They have to improve customer service and make their stores convenient and attractive. ``The consumers are providing more challenge to companies,'' Davis said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Higher Taxes, Saddam's Higher Oil Hits Families Hard
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: If you read the lips of George Bush and Saddam Hussein in 1990, you're probably wondering how you're going to pay the oil and tax bills this coming year. Those two elements of the economic equation suddenly turned into wild cards, but the news isn't all bad. Higher taxes, for one, could help trim the U.S. budget deficit, which many economists call the main problem. Others fear a bigger tax bite will hamper economic expansion. Higher oil prices might revive energy conservation, but it seems doubtful they will last. The Persian Gulf crisis also has prompted the government to speed efforts at developing a national energy policy. But in the short run, the higher tax and fuel bills won't be much fun for anybody except perhaps the tax collectors and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. ``Consumers have to cut back on their spending because they're spending more money on fuel and heating oil,'' said Edwin S. Rothschild, of Citizen Action, a Washington-based consumer group. ``Businesses are having to spend more and people are being laid off. The airlines are having a hard time.'' Rothschild estimated that before this cold season ends, the average household that uses home heating oil will have to pay between $300 and $500 more to keep warm. Consumers also were paying about 30 cents a gallon more for gasoline as the year drew to a close. Experts pointed out, however, that when inflation is taken into account, fuel prices were much cheaper in 1990 than they were in the early 1980s, when the aftershocks of the Iranian revolution pushed oil prices higher. Regardless, the effects of the expensive oil will ripple through the economy, which is already running into hard times. ``It is a major contributing factor to the recession that we are entering,'' Rothschild said. Although many economists and Wall Streeters were proclaiming a recession throughout the fall, the government carefully avoided uttering what has become known as the dreaded ``R-word.'' The administration's deeds spoke louder than words, however, when Bush abandoned his ``read my lips'' pledge of no new taxes. The government instituted a sweeping package of higher taxes on income, gasoline, cigarettes and liquor. The gasoline tax increase of 5.1 cents a gallon added to the burden of higher fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis. Economists say it will hit working people and the poor hardest. During 1990, Americans had to work full-time from Jan. 1 to May 5 before they had paid off their entire tax burden, according to the Tax Foundation, a Washington watchdog group. It's too early to pinpoint the date of ``Tax Freedom Day'' for 1991, but the foundation estimates it will be pushed back again. ``It really can't help but make it even worse,'' Tax Foundation spokesman Bill Ahern said. ``The only thing that could prevent the day from getting worse would be a phenomenal economic recovery for 1991 that doesn't seem to be in the cards. If you look at the taxes ... they are substantial.'' Many economists see the tax burden as a bigger threat to the family budget than expensive oil, because oil is plentiful despite the Gulf crisis. In December, OPEC ministers agreed to reinstate production quotas once the turmoil ends, but oil analysts predict the cartel will have a tough time executing that plan. The American Petroleum Institute, a leading industry trade organization, said if crude prices come down and stay down, the prices of refined petroleum products will have to follow. As 1991 progresses, it could reveal whether the United States has changed any of its energy priorities after suffering the oil shock of 1990. The Energy Department is expected to release a long-awaited energy strategy that will include expanded uses of alternative fuels as well as proposals for drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

DOC.HEAD: Tide of Bad News for Real Estate in 1990
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: It was the year Manhattan apartment prices actually went down and some California builders, staggering under unsold inventories, gave away a new car with each house sold. In Florida, new homes and condos sat empty because retirees could not sell their homes up North. Would-be home sellers in affluent New York suburbs slashed asking prices by $100,000 and more, and still no takers. It was the year when Lucille Ball's mansion in Beverly Hills - an enclave where common economic trends aren't supposed to apply - sat unpurchased even after the asking price was cut from $7.8 million to $5.6 million. It was the year in which even the red-hot Seattle market turned as cool as the squalls off Puget Sound. In short, it was a time when regional weaknesses in home sales - the Northeast since the stock market crash of 1987, the oil states before that - threatened to engulf the country in a national real estate recession. Or at least both coasts. In many parts of the South and Midwest, home prices and sales levels have remained at more modest levels. Sales were up 3 percent during the first 11 months of 1990 at RE-MAX of Northern Illinois, said Betty Hegner, the president of the operation with 116 offices and nearly 2,000 agents. ``I have to say, there are some markets where there definitely is a softening of the market, especially during the last quarter,'' she said. Expensive homes, those priced above $200,000, were selling slowly recently, in part because their owners won't reduce prices, she said. ``But we have a lot of bright spots, too. We think it's a good time to buy.'' Even on the coasts, was it a recession or merely the end of a cycle? That was still unclear in many regions. Take the Northwest, where few could believe that 1989 and early 1990 sales and prices could long be sustained, any more than the increases in California in 1988 could go on forever. ``We had phenomenal appreciation,'' said Maria Bunting, executive vice president of Windermere Real Estate in Seattle. ``For a real estate agent, it was as good as the wildest dreams of what they would like it to be.'' By spring, houses flooded the market as prices peaked. Buyers pulled back. Sellers panicked. And home prices began to fall over the summer. ``It was an adjustment period,'' Ms. Bunting said, describing the region as now having a normal buyer-seller balance. Lower prices brought home ownership closer to millions of people. National Association of Realtors statistics showed a decline from July to October of $98,300 to $92,800 in the median price of a home, the price at which half of the sales were for more, half for less. Jill and Robert McCarty saw both sides of the equation and figure they came out ahead. The couple - he an accountant and she a manicurist - bought their dream house in December - a four-bedroom, 2,100-square-foot new home with a three-car garage in Saugus, an outer suburb north of Los Angeles. They sold their first home, a ``fixer-upper'' they bought six years ago for $105,000 in the working class Sun Valley area of Los Angeles, for $207,000. ``We listed it at $229,000, which would have been the fair price a little while ago, but after two weeks we dropped the price when we saw what was happening,'' she said. Meanwhile, they returned to the tracts in more comfortably middle-class Saugus and found builders cutting prices and throwing in extras with abandon. ``We had been looking for two years up there, and couldn't find anything we could afford,'' she said. ``So when the market got slow, we said let's see what we could do. We got a $310,000 home for $250,000.'' That price included $5,000 in closing costs paid by the builder and another $5,000 in luxury carpet. ``We're never moving again,'' McCarty said. ``We would never have been able to do it if the market hadn't been like this.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Continues To Innovate, Though Recession Poses Threat
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Hard times could put a squeeze on research and development spending by U.S. businesses, but experts warn against cutbacks that divert Americans from the global technology race. ``It's an easy but foolish place to cut,'' said Richard Shaffer, editor of Technologic Computer Letter, a computer industry newsletter. Despite gloomy talk, many experts say U.S. scientists and engineers continue to make breakthroughs in a variety of fields and hold their own in a number of technologies. ``I don't think we're any less innovative and creative than we were 20 years ago, even though some people think we're becoming soft and the Japanese are going to run over us,'' said Donald Wilson, an assistant professor of management at Rochester Institute of Technology. Still, some financially struggling companies have little choice. ``It's self-defeating in the long run, but if you're worried about surviving this year you don't worry about the long run,'' said David Wyss, research director of the economic consulting firm DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc. The need for U.S. companies to maintain research and development spending is especially acute in light of stepped-up research efforts by Japanese companies, particularly in this country. In recent years, many Japanese high-technology companies have opened U.S. research centers, to which they attract U.S. scientists with high salaries. Japanese companies also have boosted research spending at U.S. universities. Wilson said these moves are an admission that the United States is a hub of innovation. ``We're seen as kind of the creative leaders,'' he said. U.S. companies overall spend more than twice as much on research and development as their Japanese counterparts, but a smaller amount as a percentage of gross national product. Japan's Science and Technology Agency says that nation's research and development spending equaled about 2.85 percent of its GNP in 1989, compared with 2.53 percent in the United States. In 1990, U.S. corporate R&D spending is expected to total about $108 billion, with $35.7 billion of that coming from the federal government, the National Science Foundation says. As for the year ahead, a trade group called the Industrial Research Institute is optimistic. Its survey of 137 major research-oriented companies shows 41 percent plan to spend at least 6 percent more on R&D than in 1990. Only 16 percent expect a decline. But, the group notes, ``The respondents' combined R&D as a percent of sales is not expected to change from 1990 to 1991. A sluggish economy, therefore, would restrain actual R&D spending increases.'' The National Science Foundation says it began detecting a drop in annual growth of R&D spending by U.S. companies as early as 1986. Such spending grew 4 percent to 10 percent a year in the early 1980s after adjusting for inflation, but fell to 2 percent to 3 percent a year since 1986, the group says. ``One of the main reasons was simply a slowdown in sales and profit expectations,'' said foundation spokesman John Jankowski. An additional drag on corporate R&D spending has been the decline in the federal defense budget, he said. Some experts believe the recession will force U.S. companies to change the emphasis of their research. ``I think they will try and do more with less, which really means we will see a substantial focusing down. Peripheral areas or (research with) longer-term horizons will disappear,'' said G. Steven Burrill, director of high technology for Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm. David Methe, another Rochester Institute of Technology management professor, says the real danger in a recession is that U.S. companies may lay off research workers. These employees represent ``repositories of knowledge and receptors of knowledge from outside'' that could not easily be replaced, he said. Experts say they don't expect the recession to have the same impact on R&D in Japan, where companies are said to have a much longer-term focus. ``I see them going the other direction,'' with increased research spending, Burrill said. While the total amount of U.S. corporate research spending is important, experts say they are equally concerned - if not more so - about the ability of U.S. companies to turn innovations into products. U.S. companies have long excelled at basic research, but have a spotty history of capitalizing on these breakthroughs in the marketplace. That is an area in which the Japanese appear to have a clear lead. ``When you look at almost any product, the basic work of it was done in the U.S. and Europe, and when the products came out they were Japanese, whether it's CDs or video tapes,'' said Wyss. Experts trace part of the reason to the greater number of engineers in Japan as a percentage of the population than in the United States. Another factor they cite is that Japanese research is often more pragmatic and product-oriented.

DOC.HEAD: After the Binge, A Return to Our Senses
An AP News Analysis
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Viewed as a mechanical structure, the U.S. economy needs retooling, reconditioning, rebuilding. Parts have to be rehoned, bolts and rivets tightened, and the whole works needs a lube job. It hasn't collapsed like the Soviet system, and it isn't likely to do so. It doesn't need junking either, because nothing better has been invented to replace it. But it is badly worn, abused by the greed and grind of the 1980s. The greatest erosion was from debt, and the Resolution Trust Corp. has the job of liquidating or selling off hundreds of collapsed savings and loan associations, with the total bill conceivably reaching $600 billion. Throughout 1990, banks were forced to write off billions of dollars in failed corporate deals, and loans with real estate developers and Third World nations. The total bank bill could only be surmised, but the extent of the damage was illustrated when just one, Chase Manhattan Corp., took a $1 billion charge against earnings to cover bad debts. One of the oddest twists in the credit disaster was that banks themselves found it difficult to raise money; bankers, accustomed to hearing tales of woe from would-be borrowers, had worse problems of their own. Chase, the nation's second largest commercial banking enterprise, was forced to offer 13.017 percent to sell $200 million of notes. Citicorp, parent of the largest bank, suffered the indignity of having its own credit rating lowered. Industrial companies, many loaded with debt, showed the strains. Standard & Poor's Corp. found that dividend increases in 1990 fell to their lowest levels in 20 years, 23 percent fewer than in 1989. The payout money just wasn't there. Dun & Bradstreet said that in the first 11 months of 1990, 55,000 companies failed, up 19 percent from 1989. Also disturbing was that the size of liabilities was up sharply, indicating that more large companies were filing for protection from creditors. Nearly every industry was affected by failures. Failures among real estate companies, which floated the debt; among financial institutions, which helped them raise the funds; and among insurers, which bought the high-yielding debt, rose more than 30 percent. What was the extent of that corporate debts? This: -Nonfinancial corporate borrowing as a percentage of gross national product rose to 67 percent in 1989 from 47 percent 20 years earlier and 39 percent 30 years ago. -In the late 1980s, half the funds raised by nonfinancial corporations came from debt issues, with the other half from equity offerings. But as recently as the 1960s and 1970s, the average was only 24 percent debt. -In the 20 years through 1989, the ratio of interest expense to corporate earnings more than doubled to 40 percent. Since the market plunge of 1987, securities firms had been shrinking their own businesses - disbanding departments that had helped arrange takeovers and junk-bond offerings, laying off workers and closing entire offices. The pace quickened in 1990. With the economy sinking, deal-making was done, and rather than Christmas bonuses, many high-paid employees received pink slips. Consumers were in debt, up to the limit of their Visa cards or the caps on their home equity loans. Personal bankruptcies rose 15 percent in 1990, and would likely rise again in 1991. Late in the year home mortgage delinquencies also rose. Uncle Sam, of course, remained in debt, unable to balance his budget. By some estimates, the budget deficit could exceed $300 billion in the coming year. This, after a tortuous round of so-called budget trimming. Economic growth inevitably succumbed to such impossible circumstances, and the big question now is how deep the downturn will be. The consensus of forecasts, including that from the White House, is that any recession will be shallow and brief, probably ending during the summer. However, many of the forecasts come with a caveat - that never in the post-World War II era have similar conditions been encountered. Forecasters point to the rickety condition of the financial underpinnings and ask if those loans can be repaid in an orderly way; or whether the structural rivets will give way. Clearly, a new era is here. In the old era, credit was cool; in the new, debt is dumb. Businesses seeking to rid themselves of debt are offering lenders equity instead. RJR Nabisco Inc., taken private in the biggest debt-financed buyout ever, offered just before Christmas to trade stock and cash for some of it high-yielding junk bonds. Lenders are biting the bullet and writing off loans that once they claimed were still collectable. Consumers are cutting consumption. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady hinted that legislation affecting banking would be on the agenda for 1991. The administration of President Bush, he said, was committed ``to promoting legislation and encouraging regulations that will allow banks to reshape their activities to operate profitably and soundly in business environment made new by technological changes.'' Meanwhile, businesses and households are seeking to cut waste, work more productively, and get those bills paid. In short, America is banking on a return to the old verities - chief among them the exercise of common sense.

DOC.HEAD: For Big Three Automakers, New Contracts, New Management, Old Problems
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers have fresh management teams and their employees have new contracts, but don't be fooled: The U.S. auto industry is facing old problems requiring action. Car and truck sales tumbled in 1990, profits fell and the specter of losses reappeared. Blue-collar workers wondered weekly if they would be at home or on the assembly line. The industry was declared to be in a recession. In a climate of unprecedented competition that includes Japanese companies building cars in the United States, executives and labor union leaders are looking for new ways to make money. ``We are facing ... an extremely competitive struggle which is not going to go away,'' Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz said. ``The economy can turn around, but the Japanese transplants and the offshore producers will still be there.'' ``We've got to tell the Fords, the Chryslers, the Hondas, the Nissans that we've got a product for them,'' said Joseph Hasenjager, union president at a General Motors Corp. brake component plant in Dayton, Ohio. ``That's the only way you get job security.'' Union and management leaders are hopeful that new three-year contracts between GM, Chrysler Corp. and Ford Motor Co. and the United Auto Workers will create harmony and avoid disputes that could further hurt the industry. The contracts cover more than 450,000 active autoworkers. The companies have committed billions of dollars to provisions for full wages for workers laid off from plants closed because of sales slumps. ``It is essential that we retain the good will we have,'' Ford President Philip Benton said. ``The contract has reinforced that atmosphere.'' The industry will need all the good feelings it can muster - and more - to reverse losses in market share. At the end of November, the Big Three held just over 70 percent of the U.S. car and truck market to about 24 percent for Japanese automakers. In 1989, GM, Ford and Chrysler had a 73.7 percent share to 22.4 percent for the Japanese. The industry appeared to be ready for a recovery in the late summer when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Oil prices skyrocketed, and car and truck sales fell. In the last three months of 1990, the Big Three companies are expected to record their first quarterly loss since 1981. ``Profits are under enormous pressure in North America, and they started out from an abysmal level,'' Benton said. Analysts expect Big Three profits to fall about 75 percent in 1990 from $8.4 billion the previous year. That means intensified competition for the fewer car and truck buyers. GM's is making the challenge from Spring Hill, Tenn., site of its Saturn car project. The seven-year, $3 billion effort is aimed directly at the Honda Civic, Nissan Sentra and Toyota Corolla. But car buying tanked as the first car rolled off the assembly line. Executives predicted that up to one-third of first-year sales would come from owners of other GM vehicles. Saturn's quality control resulted in far fewer cars being shipped to dealers than expected. Some dealers, who had invested millions in Saturn, were asked to delay openings or had only one or two cars on the showroom floor. It didn't make for good public relations in an industry that has stressed vehicle quality, recognizing the reputation of Japanese automakers for reliability. Management shakeups also are part of the Big Three's hopes for revival. Within 10 hours of officially succeeding Roger Smith in GM's top job, Robert Stempel unveiled a new management structure. At Ford, Harold Poling took over from Donald Petersen, but only for three years. At Chrysler, vice chairman Gerald Greenwald took early retirement to head a union effort to buy United Airlines. The bid failed, but Greenwald still received a reported $9 million. As the industry worried about the erosion in Americans' devotion to American cars, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca faulted Greenwald for leaving the struggling automaker. ``He grew up with me. He'd been in the car business for 32 years, same two companies as me - Ford and Chrysler,'' said Iacocca, who delayed his 1991 retirement plans. ``Isn't there anything sacred anymore? Isn't there any loyalty to anything?''

DOC.HEAD: After Billion-Dollar Losses, Steel Industry Rebuilds To Rebound
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Ten years after a flood of low-cost imports devastated America's steelmakers, one of the nation's historic core industries is competitive again. ``It took a great deal of pain and suffering, but the industry is now awake and in some cases remarkably astute and smart,'' said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. The pain came in the form of 200,000 job reductions, hundreds of mill closings and billions of dollars in spending to increase efficiency. The gain is evident in falling imports and rising profits. Lower production costs and a weaker dollar have boosted American steel's competitiveness. U.S. steelmakers now produce a ton of steel in about 5{ man-hours, lowest in the world and nearly half the time it took in 1980. Still, the United States remains the world's biggest steel importer. Foreign rivals - especially Japan and the European Community - aren't standing still. ``The Japanese already were further ahead and they're running at a much faster pace,'' said Hans Mueller, an economics professor and consultant at Middle Tennessee State University. ``The Americans are just catching up.'' In the first nine months of 1990, imports comprised about 17 percent of the U.S. steel market, making America the world's largest importer, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a Washington trade group. Most imports came from Europe and Japan, followed by Canada, South Korea, Brazil and many other countries. The EC and Japan are the world's leading exporters of finished steel. The United States exported about 4.6 million tons in 1989, far less than the top exporters. The relative value of international currencies, more than anything else, will determine the global competitiveness of American steel in the 1990s, said Charles A. Bradford, a metals expert for Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. ``The steel industry may be the biggest beneficiary of the weakness in the dollar,'' he said. ``The biggest cost of an integrated steelmaker is wages. If you compare wages around the world, it's all a matter of the value of the dollar.'' The United States was the dominant force in the international steel market following World War II and led the world in steel production in the 1950s. But Japan and European countries rebuilt their postwar industries from scratch using modern technology. As U.S. mills rusted, imports cracked 15 percent by the 1970s and reached an all-time high of 26.4 percent in 1984. American steelmakers lost about $11.9 billion from 1980 to 1986, when hundreds of mills closed and more than 200,000 workers nationwide left the payrolls. The picture is brighter now. Steelmakers made about $1.5 billion in profits in 1989. The cost of halting production while plants were modernized was a major factor in 1989 and will continue to hurt profits. ``The cost of modernization is taking its toll, but in the long run they're much better off,'' Bradford said. ``This is what you need to do if you want to be competitive.'' In 1980, about 20 percent of American steel was made in modern continuous casters, which turn molten steel directly into slabs, skipping costly and time-consuming steps. Today about 66 percent of American steel is made that way and the figure is expected to reach about 90 percent by the year 2000, said Sheldon Wesson, a spokesman for the American Iron and Steel Institute. In 1989, Japan made about 94 percent of its steel and Belgium about 91 percent in continuous casters. ``The effort goes on. Nobody is satisfied,'' Wesson said. ``The industry says it has spent in the last 10 years perhaps half what it would have liked to spend on mill modernization.'' ``You look at the profit picture and you wonder where the next billion is going to come from,'' he said. ``This is all self-financed. This is all pulling yourself up by the boot straps.''

DOC.HEAD: Automaking, Services Put Nashville Ahead of Recession Curve
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: A city that relies on the auto industry to avoid the recession gripping the rest of America? It's happening in Nashville. Economists said this Southern city took its economic lumps early and has settled into a period of stability as other regions are forced to retrench. The consolidation and weeding out already has occurred. ``I think what has happened in Nashville is that the boom growth levels have slowed down,'' said William Fox, an economist at the University of Tennessee's Center for Business and Economic Research. ``And in that sense, Nashville might have taken its economic lick early,'' he said. Leading the way in Nashville are a budding automotive manufacturing industry, a diversified services sector and an early brush with negative growth economists said. ``Construction, for example, took a beating (in 1989) and a little into (1990),'' Fox said. ``But at a time when maufacturing is generally going down, Nashville is being held up by the auto industry, which is kind of odd.'' Car and truck sales and industry profits dropped in 1990, but two big manufacturers have chosen sites near Nashville for new factories on which they are pinning hopes for buoyant sales. General Motors Corp. built its $1.9 billion Saturn Corp. plant in Spring Hill, about 40 miles south of Nashville. The plant and its more than 3,600 employees and 700 contract workers began making the car in October. More than 3,500 people are employed by Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corp. U.S.A. in Smyrna, about 25 miles southeast of Nashville. Nissan is in the midst of an $490 million expansion that will add 2,000 production jobs for total employment of 5,500 by 1992. The expansion will raise Nissan's Smyrna investment to $1.2 billion. GM embarked on the seven-year Saturn effort to develop a car that could compete with the Honda Civic, Nissan Sentra and Toyota Corolla. Saturn is in the early production stages and has not yet reached full output, unlike aging plants that automakers are closing elsewhere in the country. ``Nissan and Saturn don't look like they'll be a factor in recession,'' Fox said. ``(Saturn) intended to start slowly. Nissan is still in its expansion mode, so they are not influenced by the business cycle,'' he said. ``They very well may be influenced three years from now.'' Nissan plans to build 165,000 Sentras at Smyrna in the 1991 model year. The plant has a production capacity of 180,000 cars a year, Nissan's manufacturing president Jerry Benefield said. The Japanese automaker, which also produces light pickup trucks in Smyrna, will add a third vehicle line - which has not been disclosed - with the expansion. Nashville also is weathering the decline facing other big cities because of a broad and ``recession-proof'' services sector of insurance companies, hospitals and the headquarters of Hospital Corp. of America. ``It has a nice diversified economy, and it's very well located,'' Fox said. ``This place is very well situated for growth and there's no reason to worry about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Things Cool To Normal In Seattle
With BC-Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Credit Boeing for the soft landing. Recessions usually hit this area harder than elsewhere. But this time, economists say, the good fortune of The Boeing Co. should cushion Seattle and much of Washington state from the economic downturn of the rest of the country. In a state where a superheated economy produced an average annual job growth of 5 percent since 1985, economists are forecasting that things might return to normal. Economically, the late 1980s were kind to Seattle. Real estate values soared in a city considered by many to be among the most livable. Jobs were so plentiful that fast-food joints offered $7.25 an hour for flipping burgers. Developers rebuilt the city's skyline with more than a dozen major buildings. Much of that prosperity can be attributed to Boeing, which has 104,700 workers in Washington and accounts for one out of every six jobs, directly or indirectly, in the state. By late December Boeing had received $46.6 billion in new commercial jet business for 1990, approaching a sixth record year of orders. Planes ordered three or four years ago are rolling off assembly lines at a rate of better than one a day. In November, however, state officials acknowledged that the recession gripping much of the country had spread mildly to Washington. State economist Chang Mook Sohn forecasts a net loss of 10,000 non-farm jobs statewide in the first half of 1991, about .5 percent of the 2.1 million member workforce. In Seattle, a real estate market that had seen home prices climb 60 percent to 70 percent from 1987 to 1989 returned to normal, as too many homes were put up for sale for prices too few buyers could afford. Construction also declined, with some commercial developers delaying projects and complaining about an overbuilt downtown. Weak manufacturing and construction in turn have hurt services, the retail-wholesale trade and finance sectors, Sohn said. What happened? Again, Sohn and other economists look to Boeing. From 1983 to 1989, Boeing's employment in this area exploded from 58,000 to 106,000 - 37 percent of all jobs created in Washington during that period were with the planemaker. ``It was the main force behind the rapid immigration to the state and the main force behind the housing boom that resulted,'' said Douglas Pedersen, vice president and chief economist for Security Pacific Bank of Washington. Boeing's employment peaked in 1989 as commercial production became more efficient and defense cuts threatened government projects. While the growth in aerospace jobs appears over for now, Sohn says Boeing's employment isn't likely to fall much further. One of the big differences between the current downturn and previous recessions, Sohn said, is the role of the aerospace industry. In the past, a slowdown in planemaking was an advance symptom of a recession and tended to pull down Washington's economy. ``Aerospace works this time is a buffer rather than a destabilizing force,'' he said. The recession of the early '80s was magnified here by Boeing laying off 22,000 employees as orders and deliveries of aircraft fell. In 1982, 106 aircraft were ordered and 176 were delivered. As 1990 drew to a close, Boeing's orders already had reached 517 airplanes, and it had delivered at least 364. It has a firm backlog of at least 1,850 planes and hundreds more options for purchases, and is booking delivery dates past the turn of the century. The region isn't without its worries, though. The timber industry, for example, is hurting from a slump in homebuilding and higher log prices. The home construction slowdown also has hit here, but again, not as hard as elsewhere. Statewide housing starts for 1990 total 43,600, about 3.8 percent fewer than 1989, Pedersen says. Commercial construction also is lagging. ``There's very little new building under way and little likelihood of more building in the next few years,'' said Jon Runstad, president and chief executive officer of Wright Runstad, a major Seattle developer.

DOC.HEAD: For the Banks It Was Better to Receive Than to Give
DOC.TEXT: All the economy wanted for Christmas was a discount rate cut - or so everyone thought. The Federal Reserve's gift, opened this past week, received a lukewarm reception from the nation's bankers and provided no immediate relief from the threat of recession. The Fed's rate cut was generous by historical standards - a half point to 6.5 percent. It was the first reduction in the lending rate to banks in more than four years. It even arrived early, well before the the first of the year when most prognosticators had expected it. Still, the Fed's generosity was lost on most banks, which declined to pass the easier credit terms on to their customers. Only one big bank, First National Bank of Chicago, cut its prime lending rate in the wake of the Fed's big move. Others, like Citicorp, appeared too weak to respond. The nation's biggest banking company said it would suffer a fourth-quarter loss of up to $400 million from the costs of setting cash aside to cover bad debts and shrinking its staff by 8.5 percent or about 8,000 employees. Citicorp also said it would slash its dividend by 44 percent. Without the major banks to keep the credit lines pumping down to businesses and consumers, the economic rescue mission launched by the Fed could be complicated.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Only the Inflation News Was Good
DOC.TEXT: Statistics released during the week highlighted the economy's ills: -The merchandise trade deficit, swelled by auto imports and the high cost of foreign oil, climbed to $11.61 billion in October, the biggest imbalance in almost three years. -Starts of single-family houses in November fell to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. -Consumer spending in November rose just 0.1 percent, and income growth only matched inflation. Most distressing for the future of the economy was a report showing businesses planned only a slight increase in spending for modernization and expansion in 1991. Inflation, which rose only modestly in November, provided the only good news and cleared the way for the Fed's move. The Fed read the 0.3 percent rise in consumer prices last month as a signal it could safely loosen credit without giving ground in its fight to keep inflation controlled.
DOC.HEAD: WALL STREET: Phelan Prediction, Pru-Bache Hard Times
DOC.TEXT: Hard times continued to dog Wall Street. Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said it would report a 1990 loss of about $250 million, more than double what analysts who follow the company had expected. Its parent, the Prudential Insurance Co. of America, rushed to bolster the finances of the investment firm with a $200 million injection of new capital. John Phelan, who departs the New York Stock Exchange's top post Dec. 31, said in an interview that he expected the recession in the securities business to last another six to 18 months. But the outgoing chairman said the slump would give way to a ``roaring'' recovery by the mid-90s.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: TWA-Pan Am Deal Moves Closer, RJR Trades In Junk
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am and TWA, two of the oldest and weakest airlines, appeared close to a combination that would end their rivalry and mark one of the most dramatic consolidations in the troubled industry. Pan Am Corp. said it had tentatively agreed to an acquisition valued at about $375 million by Trans World Airlines. But Pan Am said it would need an emergency loan to keep flying while the deal was under negotiation. TWA owner Carl Icahn made the purchase offer last Sunday after selling off some prized London routes to American Airlines in a deal that could be worth $625 million to TWA. RJR Nabisco, taken private in the biggest leveraged buyout in history, continued efforts to lighten its debt load. The company said it would trade cash and stock for more than $750 million in junk bonds issued to finance last year's $25 billion buyout. With the stock-for-junk swap, the food and tobacco giant would be left with about $19 billion in debt to manage from the buyout. R.H. Macy & Co., weighed down by debts from a 1986 buyout, completed a minor miracle on 34th Street by selling $119 million in stock to investors. The New York retailer planned to use the cash to retire some of the debts rolled up in the $3.7 billion buyout. Chrysler Corp. bolstered takeover defenses in response to Kirk Kerkorian's purchase of a minor stake in the automaker. Chrysler executives said they were suspicious of Kerkorian's motives. Zenith Electronics Corp. and American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said they were jointly developing a high-definition television system based on a computerized digital signal. The effort is one of six the government is evaluating as a standard for the new television system.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Dixon Conviction, Bush Ruling, Milken Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Don Dixon, one of the nation's most notorious savings and loan figures, was convicted of taking hundreds of thousands of dollars from depositors of his Texas thrift. A jury found him guilty of spending money from Vernon Savings Association on a California beach house and prostitutes. The 52-year-old Dixon Dixon faces a maximum sentence of 115 years in jail and a $5.75 million fine. President Bush's son Neil, under scrutiny for his dealings with a Colorado savings and loan, was found guilty of a conflict of interest by an administrative law judge. But the young Bush averted the ultimate punishment of a permanent ban from the banking business. According to the ruling, he could still accept a future position with a savings institution under certain restrictions. The government's Office of Thrift Supervision charged Bush with a conflict in his role as a director of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. Lawyers for Michael Milken notified a federal court they plan to appeal his 10-year prison sentence for securities fraud. The 44-year-old financier was sentenced last month and has been ordered to report to custody in March.
DOC.HEAD: DISNEY: Steve the Tramp Hits the Road
DOC.TEXT: In the heat of the Christmas sales battle, Walt Disney Co. said it would stop selling a toy figure of a tramp that has infuriated homeless advocates. ``Steve the Tramp'' had been cited by homeless groups as one of the most offensive toys of the 1990 Christmas season. The 5-inch-high plastic figure was one of a series of 14 ``coppers and gangsters'' based on the movie ``Dick Tracy,'' produced by Disney's Touchstone Pictures. ``We feel that the action figure, when viewed outside the fantasy world of `Dick Tracy,' is being misunderstood,'' the company said in a statement.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Dec. 22-23
For Release Weekend Editions Dec 22-23
DOC.HEAD: The Fed's Christmas Card to Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: The campaign to try to brighten up Wall Street in time for the holidays has received some extra last-minute help from the Federal Reserve. But analysts warn that a promise of cheaper money from the Fed and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, by itself is no assurance of a cheery start on the new year. The central bank acted last Tuesday afternoon to lower the discount rate, the charge it sets on loans to private financial institutions, to 6.5 percent from 7 percent, where it had stood for almost two years. The cut did not come as a total surprise to the investment world. But most analysts who had been talking about the possibility were projecting it for some time after Jan. 1. Thus the timing, as much as the substance, of the move was interpreted as a signal that the Fed was stepping up the pace of its efforts to ease credit conditions and relieve the pressures of a developing recession. Among the tools at the Fed's disposal, the discount rate is often described as powerful symbolic and psychological device. But observers are quick to add that it is not a magic wand. In the midst of the last sustained bear market for stocks, the Fed also sent a message of Christmas cheer to investors, cutting the discount rate from 14 percent to 12 percent on Dec. 4, 1981. It was not until the second half of 1982, however, that stocks bottomed out and the economy began its recovery from recession. In today's situation, furthermore, many analysts wonder if cutting the price of money will be enough to get it moving faster through the financial system. ``We're in a credit crunch all right, but it is not being engineered by the Federal Reserve Board,'' asserts Charles LaLoggia, a Rochester, N.Y., investment adviser. ``The credit crunch stems from the fact that the banking system is awash in bad loans which are getting worse by the day. Both bankers and banking regulators are now scared stiff of making new loans.'' A ``credit contraction,'' as described by James Grant in his ``Grant's Interest Rate Observer'' newsletter is ``a kind of malady unseen since the 1930s. ``In a credit contraction,'' he says, ``borrowers are denied. The principal rationing device for loans is not high interest rates but low creditworthiness, the credit of the borrower or the liquidity of the lending institution, or both.'' Such misgivings helped to mute the celebration in the financial world that followed the Fed's announcement. At Friday's close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials stood at 2,633.66, up 39.85 points from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.16 to 180.87; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 4.78 to 373.61, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was u 0.46 at 306.20. Volume on the Big Board averaged 176.70 million shares a day, against 155.85 million the week before. As if to dispel any illusions that the Fed could dictate the level of interest rates, bond traders pushed rates on long-term government bonds higher as the week progressed. Bond traders keep a continuous anti-inflation watch, manifesting their concern every time the Fed takes a step toward stimulus that they suspect might eventually increase inflationary pressures. At the moment, however, most forecasters don't see inflation as a major menace to the markets any time soon. ``Inflation should prove to be much less of a problem in 1991 than it has been in recent years,'' contends David Blitzer, economist at Standard & Poor's Corp. ``We expect to see some of the smallest price increases since the mid-1980s, and have hopes that the gains against inflation will be long-lasting ones.''

For Release Sun AMs Dec 23 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Soviet Economy in Shambles: Cows, Cars, Per Capital Income
DOC.TEXT: In the Soviet Union, 15 million people are on a waiting list for a telephone. Per capita income in this crumbling superpower is roughly that of Mexico, and about one-tenth what it is in the industrialized democracies. The Soviet Union is the world's largest producer of wheat, yet loses a fifth of its crop - 10 times higher than U.S. losses - and must buy grain from the rest of the world to feed its people. Their cows produce only half as much milk as those in Western Europe. The Soviet Union is an utterly backward nation, as portrayed by the first Soviet-sanctioned international investigation of its economy. It lags far behind the West in virtually every facet of life, while squandering its rich natural reources and poisoning its environment. The dispassionate, dryly-written report by the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and two major European development organizations presents a portrait of worsening and inescapable hardship for the Soviet people. More astounding statistics from the long-awaited report, released Friday: - A Soviet household pays only about 3 percent of its income for rent, which has remained essentially the same since 1928. That's about one-tenth what a family in a major industrialized country would pay. In a graphic demonstration of how the system has failed, the report notes that nearly one in five families has been on a waiting list for an apartment for more than 10 years. - In some regions, people are being exposed to environmental health risks 10 to 100 times greater than those acceptable in the West. ``Many of the industrial and agricultural regions of the USSR are on the verge of ecological breakdown, posing an imminent threat to the health of present and future generations,'' the investigators said. - A recent consumer survey showed that nearly 90 percent of basic industrial goods were in short supply. But because there is practically no relationship between supply and demand, stocks of machine tools are 10 or more times higher than in countries with market economies. - As much as 40 percent of perishable crops like fruits and vegetables goes to waste. The problem? Shortages of packaging materials, storage facilities, outdated processing technology and poor transportation. What's more, soil and water are being ruined by environmentally insensitive production methods - and in the process, food is being contaminated. - The Soviet Union has a large manufacturing sector that amounts to roughly the same proportion of its gross national product as similar industries in East and West Europe. But inefficiency is rampant. The Soviets use 50 percent more energy to produce steel than the Japanese, and many factories employ two workers for every one in a similar Western job. - The Soviet Union produces more iron ore, zinc and nickel than any other country in the world. It ranks second in production of gold, aluminum and lead; third in copper production. Yet, with the exception of production of gold, diamonds, platinum and nickel for export, the metal and mining industries ``are characterized by antiquated machinery and technologies with virtually no computerization'' and dwindling resources, the report found. - It produces 22 percent of the world's oil and 40 percent of global natural gas, but the Soviet Union's coal and oil output is falling and domestic energy shortages are appearing. The report blames ``outdated technologies, obsolete equipment and poor maintenance.'' While other oil-producing countries have enjoyed a windfall from the spurt in oil prices brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis, the Soviet Union's oil production and exports have plummeted - denying the country desperately needed hard currency. The investigators concluded after their six months of study that ``the traditional centrally planned system has largely collapsed.'' The bleak picture led the investigators to conclude that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recently approved economic reform plan is too vague and too slow. They called instead for the beleaguered Soviet citizens to take the bitter economic medicine of ending price controls on heavily subsidized basic commodities while accepting wage controls to speed the transition to a market economy. While conceding that unemployment would rise and output would fall, the experts at the International Monetary Fund insisted that Gorbachev must move quickly to estblish private property rights and let market forces drive reform in farming, manufacturing and the crumbling distribution network. ``Ideally, a path of gradual reform could be laid out which would minimize economic disturbance and lead to an early harvesting of the fruits of increased economic efficiency,'' the study said. ``But we know of no such path, the more particularly given the difficult starting conditions.'' While calling for technical assistance to help the Soviets in their efforts to discard seven decades of a planned economy, the study said that massive amounts of Western aid would not be useful right now. It said that without the implementation of a major and fa-reaching reform program, a direct infusion of cash would be ``of little or no lasting value.''

DOC.HEAD: Welfare State's Future Questioned As Recession Looms
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Some of Northern Europe's welfare states wonder how to keep their cradle-to-grave safety nets from fraying in the impending recession. In the post-World War II boom years, the Scandinavian countries, the Netherlands and West Germany introduced programs that spend up to a quarter of the gross national product on welfare. Welfare spending now is outstripping the industrial growth that was supposed to pay the bill. With growth slowing in many European countries, some governments are considering cutbacks. With less money available for welfare, government officials complain more loudly about people abusing the system. Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers says his nation's welfare system, which will cost the government 132.3 billion guilders ($79.6 billion) in 1991, is out of hand. In a recent report, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, citing Holland's high income taxes and generous welfare benefits, concluded that incentives to work are low. The nation has an 11 percent unemployment rate. Dutch authorities recently failed to lure jobless Amsterdam residents to the understaffed flower industry, even after the government offered a car for every four workers to use for commuting, as well as personal use. Denmark spends 40 percent of its budget on the 1.4 million people - 28 percent of the population - who live on welfare. The center-right coalition government of Prime Minister Poul Schlueter hopes it can reduce welfare dependency by stimulating private industry. Denmark has 20,000 people under 40 years of age getting permanent government pensions of 3,709 kroner ($662) a month because of drug or alcohol problems. In Europe, welfare helps the employed as well as the jobless. The system commonly includes free medical insurance, sick pay, disability and old age pensions, and child-care and unemployment benefits. In Sweden, parents can qualify for benefits for taking time off to nurse a sick child. ``The basic thing is that everyone should have basic opportunities to ... take part in all activities within our society,'' said Annchristen Filipson of the Swedish Social Affairs Ministry. Scandinavian taxpayers can hardly be expected to dig deeper in their pockets to pay a greater share of the welfare costs. Their tax rates of more than 50 percent already are highest in the industrialized world. Last October, Sweden's ruling Social Democratic Party made the first cuts ever in a social welfare system now costing 251.39 billion kronor ($45.13 billion), just over one-fifth of the GNP. The government is expected to cut 15 billion kronor ($2.69 billion dollars) from the welfare budget in 1991. The government is also planning to cut sick pay rates from 100 percent to 75 percent of a worker's salary for the first three days in an effort to discourage malingering. Workers take an average 25 days of sick leave a year. The welfare programs are usually funded by taxes paid by employers and employees, and some are getting fed up. Ove Danemar of the Swedish Employers' Federation criticized ``the whole system'' because ``it stimulates people to work less and to take more leisure time. ``The private sector can't bear it any longer,'' he said. ``It's no longer consistent with a modern economy.'' Critics say many of the benefits were begun in good faith but have ended up being abused. During more favorable economic times, the abuse was widely tolerated. But with the Continent entering a recession, there is more clamping down on wasteful spending. Lubbers has vowed to curb Holland's Unsuitability for Work Act, under which nearly 900,000 people get life-long disability pensions of up to 70 percent of their last-earned pay. In the late 1970s, some companies used it by dismissing unproductive employees, passing the social cost on to the government. About one-third of the program's beneficiaries claim psychological reasons for being unable to work. In a recent speech, Lubbers said wryly: ``Looking at the statistics ... one has to admit that ours is a sick nation.'' This spring, the Dutch government is expected to make deep cuts in the housing, education and cultural subsidies that complement the welfare handouts, themselves equal to at least 70 percent of the minimum wage. It has borrowed heavily and diverted money from other programs to cover welfare costs. Only Germany is making large welfare increases, to pay millions of former East Germans who are unemployed. Norway is slightly expanding its 125.8 billion kroner ($21 billion) welfare system, on which almost a quarter of the population depends in some form or other. The Labor government has added about one billion kroner ($166 million) to the bill since coming into office last month and even the right-leaning opposition Progress Party favors the expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Modern Welfare States Guarantee Reasonable Income For All
With BC-Europe-Welfare Woes
DOC.TEXT: When it began, welfare in northern Europe was meant to stop the destitute from becoming a public nuisance. Today's welfare states regard a fair income as a universal right. The 8th-century emperor Charlemagne decreed that his nobility should distribute food to poor peasants to keep them from joining marauding bands of beggars. Europe always has known institutionalized charity, usually under religious auspices, but elements of the modern welfare state appeared only a little over a century ago, when cities were clogged with working families. Mechanization and poor working conditions created the need for health and accident insurance, while economic downturns created a jobless class less easily absorbed than in farming society. Chancellor Otto von Bismarck gave Germany a compulsory health insurance plan in 1883. Similar programs followed there in the next few years for industrial injury, disability and old age. Norway's first state insurance law, which provided accidental injury coverage for all, was passed in 1894, followed by laws in 1906 on medical insurance for the poor and old-age pensions in 1936. In the depression-ridden 1930s, Sweden and the Netherlands set up loosely defined social welfare programs modeled on the New Deal of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The Dutch program quickly became so essential that a minor cut in benefits sparked three days of street riots in Amsterdam in which five were killed. Cradle-to-grave welfare programs were advocated by Scandinavia's dominant left-wing political parties after World War II. ``Everyone has the right to employment, a place to live, education, social security and health and hospital systems. ... The result is a society in which there are few truly rich or poor,'' says a book on social welfare published by Oslo's Aftenposten newspaper. A late arrival on the welfare scene is Finland, a largely agrarian nation where rural societies carried out their own informal welfare functions. It was not until 1957 that Finland passed its first major welfare law, the National Pensions Act. Its comprehensive unemployment benefits law was not voted through until 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Welfare State Systems Fraught With Quirks
With BC-Europe-Welfare Woes
DOC.TEXT: Welfare state benefits can be so lucrative that even the recent offer of cars for personal use wasn't enough to lure Dutch unemployed off the dole. Welfare recipients in Denmark and the Netherlands are frequently entitled to subsidies that help pay their rent, child care, basic furnishings and clothes. Coming on top of cash benefits, those add-ons often mean a welfare recipient has a bigger income than a skilled industrial worker. Authorities in Amsterdam recently offered the use of leased cars to people willing to take jobs in the flower industry in the Aalsmeer suburb. The plan failed because not enough people were interested. Another plan to give jobs to the unemployed in the northern village of Stadskanaal in the vital flower bulb harvest 60-miles away also failed. The unemployed did not want to work that far away from home, even though they were going to be given temporary housing in the region. Desperate bulb growers eventually returned to their illegal but tolerated practice of hiring seasonal workers from Poland. A Dutch Social Affairs Ministry study showed recently that a couple getting 1,611 guilders ($964) a month in benefits would lose 5 percent if either partner were hired in a minimum-wage job that pays the same, mostly because of expenses like commuting that employers won't refund. The prospect of losing welfare subsidies on rent and other basics often means that looking for a better-paid job is barely worthwhile. Both the Netherlands and Denmark provide all parents with child-rearing payments, which take the place of the dependent deduction in the U.S. tax system. Questions have been raised whether rich Danish families should be getting benefits of 5,600 kroner ($1,000) per year for each of their children. Dutch payments are considerably lower. Spurred by high taxation, many welfare recipients, even those on disability pensions, resurface in the so-called ``Black Economy,'' doing off-the-books blue-collar jobs in exchange for cash. The Dutch Welfare Ministry employs dozens of ``social detectives'' who have full police powers to investigate such abuses which defraud the state of tens of billions of dollars in welfare benefits and tax revenue each year. Although the benefits can be many, applying for them can involve a frustrating months-long trip through the bureaucracy to find out which of the many different welfare programs applies. Rigid qualification rules often hinder a recipient's own efforts to seek a job. Dutch unemployment benefit recipients can be barred from attending job training programs because that's considered abusing dole money as an educational grant.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday Jan 6
