DOC.HEAD: AP WORLD SYMPOSIUM: What's in Store for 1991
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: War could be at hand in the Persian Gulf. Eastern Europe is beset by economic problems and ethnic tensions. The Soviet Union is a struggling colossus that may be coming apart. Calls for democracy are heard in black Africa. In South Africa, blacks and whites are negotiating a plan to end apartheid. Closer to home, French separatism threatens Canada once again, two civil wars still sputter in Central America and, in the Caribbean, Haiti is having another try at achieving democracy. As 1990 neared an end, The Associated Press asked some of its correspondents to look forward into the coming year. These are their reports: ---
DOC.HEAD: Canada
DOC.TEXT: TORONTO - Canada's new year is filled with problems: the threat of separation by French-speaking Quebec, an increasingly volatile Indian population and a deepening recession. Coping with it will be the most unpopular government since opinion polling began in Canada half a century ago. The latest polls say 58 percent of Canadians rate Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who need not call an election for three years, as ``the worst'' prime minister or ``one of the worst.'' Support for his Progressive Conservative Party has sunk to 14 percent. A commission created by the Quebec Legislature is holding hearings and will make recommendations in March on what steps to take after the failure of the Meech Lake constitutional accord in June. That accord declared Quebec a ``distinct society'' and provided for other constitutional changes sought by the province. A recent poll shows 73 percent of French speakers in Quebec favor ``sovereignty-association,'' an ill-defined form of partial independence from the central government. An explosion of violence in two Mohawk communities and a long standoff between Indians and the authorities at Oka, Quebec, ostensibly was caused by the village's plans to expand a golf course on land claimed by the Indians. The confrontation, however, was symptomatic of Indian discontent over the glacial pace of Canada's system for dealing with native land claims. Matthew Coon-Come, grand chief of the Cree Indians of Quebec, put the Indian attitude this way: ``If you continue to push people to a limit and the federal government continues to ignore their issues, they will retaliate.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: Mexico-Central America
DOC.TEXT: MEXICO CITY - Central America is emerging from the civil wars and upheaval of the 1980s into what it hopes will be the peace of the 1990s. Civil wars still sputter in Guatemala and El Salvador, but economic issues are edging out insurrection as the major issues for 1991 in Mexico and Central America. The region is buoyed by spreading democracy and financial cooperation from the United States, but held back by problems that have kept it poor: a shortage of arable land, inefficient agriculture, low literacy rates and, although decreasingly, insurrection. High expectations that came with peace generally have not been met. Panama and Nicaragua enjoy U.S. aid and trade again, but are in deep financial holes after years of turbulence, mismanagement, fraud and U.S. trade embargoes. Both are under great pressures from within, and the Nicaraguan government must deal with the recently ousted Sandinista National Liberation Front, still the largest single political party. Sporadic peace talks aimed at ending the 12-year-old civil war in El Salvador are to continue in 1991, but there are no signs of resolving the main sticking point: the role, size and nature of the Salvadoran military. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico hopes a proposed free trade agreement with the United States will help lift his country out of the Third World. Industries that may be hurt are skeptical and political opponents claim Mexico will lose in such a deal. ---
DOC.HEAD: Caribbean
DOC.TEXT: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico - Haiti's first democratic elections open the way for a closer relationship with the United States. The Bush administration welcomed the Caribbean nation's break with authoritarian rule in the Dec. 16 vote and congratulated the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide on winning the presidency. U.S. economic aid to the impoverished Caribbean nation is likely to be restored despite wariness about the priest's leftist rhetoric. The United States suspended $70 million in aid after an election massacre in 1987. Elections are scheduled for 1991 in Guyana, Trinidad and Barbados. President Desmond Hoyte of Guyana, turning away from past nationalistic socialism, continues to encourage foreign investment and economic aid from abroad. In Trinidad, Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson survived a bloody coup attempt by radical Moslems last summer. Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford of Barbados is struggling with a severe fiscal deficit. A bill pending in Congress would allow Puerto Rico to hold a plebiscite in 1991 on whether to become the 51st state, seek independence or retain its 38-year-old status as a U.S. commonwealth. Cuba may have to make further economic adjustments next year because of declining trade with the Soviet Union. Washington is not expected to seek warmer relations with Fidel Castro's communist government. ---
DOC.HEAD: Middle East
DOC.TEXT: NICOSIA, Cyprus - War or peace in the Persian Gulf? Oil glut or shortage? A return to normal in Lebanon or new disruption? New moves toward solving the Palestine problem? Progress or defeat for moderates in Iran? All these questions have global significance, and there are no solid answers. A war over Iraq's seizure of Kuwait could change the balance of power in the Middle East. If the U.S.-led multinational force succeeds in driving Iraq from the emirate and incapacitating Saddam Hussein's military machine, the regional winners would be Saudi Arabia, Iran, Syria, Egypt and Israel. Saddam wins if he keeps Kuwait, withdraws only partially or gets out completely under circumstances that let him claim the invasion led to progress on the Palestine question. If he keeps his million-member armed forces intact, along with his program for developing nuclear weapons, he will be a continuing threat to neighboring oil producers and Israel. Peace could bring an oil glut and prices of $10 a barrel or less. War, by interrupting production in Saudi Arabia and other gulf states, could push prices to well over $50 a barrel. In Lebanon, for the first time in nearly 16 years of civil war, there is optimism that the battered former business center of the Middle East is on the way back to normal. Skeptics abound, however, because armed militias remain active outside the capital, such outsiders as Israel and Syria still intervene and political quarrels continue. Syrian reconciliation with the United States and Britain, and indications that President Hashemi Rafsanjani is gaining the upper hand in Iran, inspire hope that the last Western hostages in Lebanon will be released. Rafsanjani has moderated Iran's revolutionary fervor and improved ties with some Western countries. A desire to end the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising, and better relations between the United States and Soviet Union, could help move Israel toward an international Middle East peace conference, but no one is predicting it. MORE

For Release Sunday Dec 30 and Thereafter

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: MOSCOW - Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be challenged in 1991 as he seeks to prevent the further economic and political collapse of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev's international prestige remains high, as demonstrated by the Nobel Peace Prize awarded him in October and his continuing summits with Western leaders. At home, however, few Soviet citizens have reason to celebrate the traditional New Year holiday. Store shelves are often bare in major cities and many consumer items are scarce throughout the country. Although he has helped reduce world tension by concluding arms agreements, pulling back from Eastern Europe and withdrawing the Soviet army from Afghanistan, Gorbachev has balked at the jump from a planned to a market economy. Many Western analysts say that is essential to boosting production. Six years after Gorbachev began relaxing 70 years of strict Communist Party controls, ethnic unrest continues. Conservatives have urged tougher measures to curb it. Gorbachev prefers a more moderate course: a new Union Treaty that would hold the 15 Soviet republics together as a federation rather than under central control. But some republics refuse to take part in the talks and others oppose his plan to keep economic control in the central government's hands. The Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have declared independence and Moldavia shows signs of following suit. Armenia is boycotting the talks because the Kremlin will not give it control of the disputed Nagarno-Karabakh region. Russia, by far the largest republic, wants to sell its abundant oil, natural gas, diamond and gold for dollars on the world market rather than to the central governmnt for rubles, as Gorbachev proposes. Some other republics are following Russia's lead. ---
DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: VIENNA, Austria - Eastern European countries lurch into 1991 under twin burdens of the communist economic legacy and age-old ethnic jealousies. There are many questions: Will Yugoslavia continue to exist? Can Romania and Bulgaria feed their people? Will Albania avoid bloodshed? Can Hungary and Czechoslovakia make the psychological and economic leap from East to West? Can Lech Walesa change from Solidarity leader to president of Poland? After the uprising against Communist Party rule, 1990 was a year for Eastern Europe to reorganize and take stock. Free elections were held by people who had seldom or never experienced them. Problems hidden under the heavy hand of communism crept to the surface. Yugoslavia's six republics, peopled by ethnic groups with deep mutual suspicions, disagree on politics. They have elected governments that ranging from non-communist oriented to the West, through nationalist to a continuation in power of the Serbian Communist Party. The question for 1991 is whether the fragile federation will survive. Ethnic disputes also sour relations between Czechs and Slovaks, and between Romanians and the Hungarians of eastern Romania. Romanians and Bulgarians start the year wondering if they will have enough food, heat and light for the winter. Albanians hope for their first experience of multiparty politics and an end to isolation. Skyrocketing energy prices make economic reform more difficult and urgent throughout the region. Czechoslovakia embarks in January on a crash program to create a market economy. Hungary's leaders say 1991 will be the most difficult year economically. Poland will follow Walesa's election as president with its first fully democratic parliamentary elections, and continues its painful economic reform. ---
DOC.HEAD: Far East
DOC.TEXT: TOKYO - Much diplomatic activity in 1991 will focus on removing remnants of the Cold War from the Far East, and surging export economies will feel the pinch of a smaller U.S. market. In April, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet president, is to pay his first visit to Japan. Relations between the two nations have been embittered by a dispute over a group of islands off northern Japan the Soviets occupied near the end of World War II. Progress may be slow in resolving two of the region's most troublesome problems. Talks between the premiers of North and South Korea began in September and are to resume early in 1991. No major progress has been made. Cambodian peace talks will continue in 1991 because of international pressure, but experience indicates much more haggling will be required before the government and guerrilla groups agree to end the war. China will remain a country waiting for Deng Xiaoping, 86, and other aging leaders to leave the scene. Recession in the United States could hurt superexporters like Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea. Modest growth is expected in Japan, despite the Tokyo stock market plunge and a worrying land-price bubble. The Philippines can expect an economic crisis caused by natural disasters in 1990 and soaring oil prices. ---
DOC.HEAD: Asian Subcontinent
DOC.TEXT: NEW DELHI, India - It will be a year of challenge for democracy. India is committed to democratic rule, but torn by the worst religious divisions since the subcontinent was partitioned on religious lines at independence in 1947. In the closing months of 1990, the rise of Hindu fundamentalism led to riots between the Hindu majority and Moslem minority that rocked India's secular base. Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's minority government may not survive and Rajiv Gandhi awaits a chance to recapture the job he lost in 1989. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, after succeeding the secular-minded Benazir Bhutto, struggles to preserve an unwieldy alliance that includes Islamic fundamentalists and secular leftists. Afghanistan has never had a true democracy and chances are dim that one will emerge in 1991. The United States and Soviet Union say they will stop arming their proteges in the stalemated civil war and want internationally supervised elections. Moslem guerrillas refuse to deal with President Najibullah of the Soviet-sponsored government, however, and he refuses to resign. Bangladesh, where mass protests forced former Gen. Hussain Muhammad Ershad to resign the presidency in December, will try to conduct its first free and fair elections after 19 years of coups and orruption. The former East Pakistan became independent in 1971. In Nepal, divine-right monarchy was abolished after a popular uprising last winter. Elections are scheduled for spring. MORE

DOC.HEAD: South Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Further economic decline in Australia and New Zealand will affect South Pacific island nations that already expect a year of political unrest and uncertainty. Trade and aid vital to the impoverished islands is unlikely to continue at current levels if the bad times in Australia and New Zealand are prolonged. Australia is in its worst recession since World War II and no recovery is predicted for at least six months. New Zealand, which has one-fifth Australia's population of 17.5 million, is in even worse shape. Elections are due in Western Samoa, Vanuatu, Kiribati and French Polynesia. In Fiji, a regime installed by the army in 1987 says November is a likely time for elections and restoration of parliamentary government. Papua New Guinea, population 4 million, faces further political instability and tribal unrest. Tension seems certain to continue on Bougainville, where armed insurrection has closed the world's largest copper mine and prompted intervention by the army. In American Samoa, Gov. Peter Coleman plans a constitutional review aimed at winning more self-government. Island governments hope to renew an important fishing treaty with the United States in 1991, and plan a showdown with Japan over its refusal to accept further fishing restrictions. ---
DOC.HEAD: South America
DOC.TEXT: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina - South American nations hope to see the fruits of economic austerity programs they imposed in 1990. Argentina, Peru and Brazil brought monthly inflation down to single digits from annual rates of several thousand percent. The first two project inflation for 1991 at 60 percent or less and say their economies should grow by at least 3 percent - the first growth in several years. For Brazil, the continent's largest country and economy, the big question is petroleum. The difference between modest growth and recession may be whether oil prices remain high because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Venezuela has benefited from higher oil prices, which added $3 billion to its export income in 1990 and could increase the gross national product by 6 percent in 1991. Chileans look forward to their first full year of democracy. In March, Gen. Augusto Pinochet left the presidency 16{ years after seizing power in a coup. Chile's economy is small, but healthy. Economic growth is projected to more than double to 5 percent, with annual inflation falling to 20 percent from 30 percent in 1990. Unemployment is stable at 6 percent. Foreign debts are large in the region, but should become less of a burden. Uruguay and Venezuela negotiated arrangements in 1990 that reduced interest payments substantially. Argentina hopes to do the same in 1991. Several countries have trouble spots that could undermine growth and stability. In Peru, the problem is guerrilla conflict; in Colombia, cocaine traffickers; in Chile the pending trials of military officers accused of human rights abuses and corruption during the Pinochet years. ---
DOC.HEAD: Africa
DOC.TEXT: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Demands for democracy and efforts to turn away from disastrous economic policies offer glimmers of hope through the war, famine and despair prevailing in much of Africa. The collapse of totalitarianism in Eastern Europe helped the cause of democracy and multiparty politics on a continent dominated by authoritarian governments. From Kenya to the Ivory Coast, many Africans shouted for democracy in 1990. Some entrenched leaders promised to ease control, including Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya and Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, but many Africans fear their governments will manipulate elections while paying lip service to democratic change. President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa stunned the world by promising to end apartheid and making some reforms, but the initial euphoria faded as political leaders bickered and violence among blacks took hundreds of lives. There seems little hope of change in much of Africa. Civil wars continue in Ethiopia, Somalia, Sudan and Mozambique. Fighting broke out in Rwanda and the regime of Samuel Doe collapsed in Liberia, accompanied by massacres. Many African nations face economic crisis and some are afflicted with famine. While Tanzania, Mozambique and others move away from discredited socialist policies, few African states have devised workable alternatives.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter's Year-End Review Shows 1990 Was Hectic
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says 1990 will go down as ``the most hectic year for a secretary of agriculture in the history of the United States.'' Yeutter noted the months of debate and negotiation as Congress wrote a new farm bill, the wrangling and eventual action on cutting the federal budget, and, of course, the multilateral trade negotiations. Except for the trade talks that are still to be resolved, 1990 stacked up as a pretty solid chapter in Yeutter's book. ``We would make a few changes if we had an opportunity to do so,'' Yeutter said last week. ``But considering the complexities of what's happening and the rapid changes in the world, I feel pretty good about the year.'' Yeutter, a hard-driving 60-year-old, gave his year-end appraisal during a telephone interview with farm broadcasters and later with a group of news reporters here. Despite Yeutter's enthusiasm for his job and accomplishments, there are critics who contend the new farm law is a blueprint for disaster. Yeutter disagrees. ``In my judgment, we emerged with a farm bill package that is certainly respectable and probably a lot more farmer-friendly than most of our farmers around the country now believe or realize,'' he said. ``I think it'll turn out to be a bill that will serve American agriculture very well over the next five years.'' A favorite bone chewed by critics involves the budget-cutting plan approved by Congress in October, which will hold down federal spending by about $496 billion over five years. The Agriculture Department's share of the cut was $13.6 billion. Many farm interest groups, and some members of Congress, complained that agriculture was hit with too much. Meanwhile, Congress finished a five-year farm bill that includes provisions to carry out the spending cuts assigned USDA, mostly in the commodity programs that provide price supports and deficiency payments to farmers. The new farm law will mean smaller subsidies going to farmers in the next five years. Other provisions, including special assessments on some producers, tighten the outlook further. ``A lot of folks pay attention to this supposed $13 billion cut over five years ... which is a somewhat misleading number,'' Yeutter said. ``And they make a simplistic evaluation of the bill that is not really an accurate reflection of a lot of its good features.'' The deep-seated concern of Yeutter's is the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations launched four years ago under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Yeutter, who was U.S. trade representative in the Reagan administration, is a gung-ho advocate of liberalizing GATT rules so that countries can produce and trade to the fullest of their abilities. The U.S. view on agricultural trade is for fewer protective import barriers, a reduction in domestic price supports and a phaseout of export subsidies. Many countries sided with the United States during what was supposed to be the windup of talks in Brussels earlier this month. But the push wasn't enough to convince the European Community to compromise meaningfully on reducing farm subsidies, and the Brussels meeting collapsed. Another attempt may be made in mid-January. Yeutter and other advocates of freer trade have painted optimistic pictures of long-range prosperity for farmers under liberalized GATT rules. But there is a measure of ambivalence among U.S. farm organizations and individuals regarding the Uruguay Round. A few condemn the talks outright as a sellout of longstanding protection for small farmers. Others favor parts of the package, while some go along entirely with the U.S. negotiators. The National Family Farm Coalition, which represents about 40 farm and rural advocacy groups, joined thousands of European farmers who protested the GATT talks in Brussels on Dec. 3. Randolph Nodland, president of the coalition, said the U.S. government ``negotiated a deal behind closed doors that trades away American agriculture for what they hope will be gains in other sectors of the economy.'' The European farmers objected proposals that would reduce EC subsidies and protection from imported commodities. Harvey Joe Sanner, president of the American Agriculture Movement, a member of the coalition, said that ``unelected free market zealots'' like Yeutter and Carla Hills, the U.S. trade representative, have misrepresented the needs of rural America. Both Nodland and Sanner accused the Bush administration of trying to use the 1990 farm bill to eliminate federal farm programs. The National Farmers Union, while not a member of the coalition, is asking the new Congress to change the 1990 farm law to prevent a decline in farm income when its provisions take effect. ``The 1990 farm bill is simply a disaster where rural America is concerned,'' said NFU President Leland Swenson. ``We want a 1991 version of the bill that revitalizes rural America.'' Yeutter said the NFU's campaign for another farm bill was ``a big mistake'' and that the next time around Congress might provide even less money. The way it looks now, Yeutter will have a busy year in 1991, too.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Dec. 23

DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's largest banks cut its prime lending rate by a steep 0.5 percentage point to 9.5 percent. Two days earlier, the Federal Reserve announced they would lower a key lending rate in an effort to prevent the recession from deepening. First National Bank of Chicago, the 13th largest U.S. banking company, said Thursday it would lower its prime rate from 10 percent effective immediately. Earlier in the month, a handful of regional banks took a more cautious step by easing their prime rates to 9.75 percent. The recent decline marks the first prime cut in nearly a year. --- PARIS (AP) - The short-term outlook for the world economy has worsened markedly in recent months, the Organization of Economic Development and Cooperation said. The organization of 24 major industrial democracies said in a twice-yearly report released Thursday, that the rise in oil prices has boosted inflation and curtailed output. It said Eastern European countries face special difficulties, gave a gloomy assessment of the Soviet Union's economic health and singled out the United States as a particular cause of economic concern. --- DALLAS (AP) - A former Texas thrift owner was convicted of taking hundreds of thousands of dollars from depositors and spending it on himself. The jury on Thursday said Don R. Dixon of Dallas was guilty of illegally spending money from his Vernon Savings Association on a California beach house and prostitutes, but cleared him of charges he made illegal campaign contributions. The thrift's 1987 failure cost taxpayers $1.3 billion and was one of the first costly collapses of the savings and loan crisis. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. will report a 1990 loss of about $250 million, more than double what analysts had expected and a further sign of the malaise gripping Wall Street, its parent said. The Prudential Insurance Co. of America also said Thursday it had injected $200 million in new capital into the struggling investment firm, which has abandoned or reduced several key businesses in a major restructuring. The equity infusion is the latest move by a big corporate parent this year to contain losses at firms pummeled by a collapse in merger activity and the junk bond market. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The nation's spending on health care climbed to a record of more than $604 billion last year, federal officials said. The growth rate accelerated in 1989, just as it has done every year since 1986, and the amount spent added up to roughly $2,400 for every man, woman and child in the country. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said the growth in health costs is alarming. It cuts some people off from medical care and puts a heavy financial burden on people who are using the system. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Acquisition of the bankrupt New Hampshire utility that controls the Seabrook nuclear plant was approved by federal stock regulators, eliminating one more roadblock to the power company's reorganization plan. Northeast Utilities wants to acquire Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, which holds the largest stake, 35.6 percent, in the controversial Seabrook plant. The acquisition, approved by the Securities and Exchange Commision on Thursday, is the key part of PSNH's plan to emerge from bankruptcy reorganization. --- ST. LOUIS (AP) - McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. said about 4,000 workers at each company could lose their jobs if the Pentagaon cancels the Navy A-12 Avenger program. The two leading defense contractors, both based in St. Louis, are the prime contractors on the $4.8 billion A-12 program, which the government has threatened to scrap because of cost overruns and schedule problems. A decision could come as early as Jan. 2. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - American businesses, worried about a recession, plan a barely perceptible 0.4 percent increase in spending to modernize in 1991, the most pessimistic outlook for business investment in five years. The 0.4 percent increase, after adjusting for inflation, would follow a projected advance of 4.1 percent for this year, according to Thursday's Commerce Department report. It would be the weakest showing since business investment fell 3.1 percent in 1986. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Americans are less likely to own a home today than they were a decade ago, as the nation's households have edged away from their traditional family orientation, the Census Bureau reported. Nationally, 63.9 percent of households owned their homes in 1989, down from 65.6 percent in 1980, according to the Thursday's report, ``Homeownership Trends in the 1980s.'' A major factor in the decline was a drop in ownership rates for non-married couple families during the decade, the report said. ---

The stock market vacillated through a mixed session Thursday amid new caution over international worries and questions about the interest-rate outlook. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 2.73 at 2,629.46 by the close. Bonds fell moderately. The dollar finished broadly. Gold rose as silver futures jumped. Oil futures showed little change, grain and soybean prices retreated, livestock and meat futures were mostly lower and orange juice prices soared.

DOC.HEAD: Most Banks Haven't Dropped Prime
DOC.TEXT: In a quest to sweeten profits, the nation's banks are holding off as long as possible before they cut their prime lending rate. The normal rush among banks to follow a move in the prime rate didn't develop after First National Bank of Chicago cut its prime 0.5 percentage point to 9{ Thursday morning. In healthier times, the nation's largest banks such as Citibank and Chase Manhattan generally would have followed First National, the nation's 13th largest banking company, by cutting their prime rates as well, economists said. But banks are holding out as long as possible to profit from the difference in their borrowing costs and the interest borrowers pay them. First Chicago's move came one day after the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate, its loan fee to financial institutions, by 0.5 percentage point to 6{ percent, in order to stimulate the economy through looser credit. It was the first cut in that key rate since August 1986. ``Banks are suffering through the worst earnings crunch in many years, and in some cases are experiencing higher funding costs despite the Fed's actions,'' said Fritz Elmendorf, spokesman for the Consumer Bankers Association in Arlington, Va. A cut in the prime is watched closely because bankers use it as a basis for calculating loans to businesses and for determining many types of fixed and adjustable-rate consumer loans. The prime rate reflects a bank's costs of borrowing money, including interest it pays on savings accounts or certificates of deposit. Though bankers deny they're profiting at consumers' expense, economist Howard Sharpe disagreed. ``Yes, consumers are being gouged. But the problem is that if the banks don't stay solvent, the consumer would get gouged even more,'' said Sharpe, chief economist of Sharpe's Capital Market Associates Inc. in New York. Federal bank regulators are pressuring banks to improve their equity capital ratios, which help cushion a bank from failure. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. predicts 180 banks with total assets of $70 billion will fail next year because of declining real estate values and a souring economy. A number of banks are expected to improve capital levels by slashing dividends this quarter in the face of rising loan losses. A delay in a prime rate cut can slightly boost profits and make things a little better for the grim quarter. A decision to delay a prime rate cut ``has very little to do with raising capital,'' said Sharpe. Bankers say the cost of their funds still remains high, despite the Fed's actions. The Fed has cut the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, three times this month to 7 percent. ``The question is why hasn't (the funds rate) come down? Because people are scared. They don't know which bank will be in trouble,'' Sharpe said. Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist for Fuji Securities Inc., said the reason why bank costs haven't declined is that banks must still pay relatively high rates of interest to holders of 3-month certificats of deposit, one of the banking industry's major sources of funds. ``Although there is an appearance that rates have gone down, they have not come down for banks,'' he said. ``The prime rate is set to move in line with the cost of bank funds.'' Earlier this month, a handful of smaller banks cut their prime rates to 9} percent in response to more subtle Fed policies to encourage lending. The National Bank of Canada and Canadian Imperial Bank both cut their prime rates 0.5 percentage point to 12} percent on Thursday, which banking analysts called an indirect result of American lending policies.

DOC.HEAD: Some Retailers Cut Prices More For Final Weekend
LaserPhoto NY38 of Dec. 20.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: With Christmas sales still lagging going into the final weekend of the season, some retailers are intensifying efforts to hook last-minute shoppers by increasing markdowns and putting more merchandise on sale. But analysts said even an eleventh-hour consumer spending spree - which most retailers are hoping for - won't be enough to turn the season around. Sears, Roebuck and Co., the nation's largest retailer, said Thursday it was expanding markdowns to include more merchandise lines and stepping up advertising in hopes of attracting more buyers. ``We are adjusting to the conditions,'' said Matthew Howard, Sears' senior vice president for marketing, who described his company's Christmas sales as ``slightly below expectations.'' Sears, which two weeks ago moved up price reductions on winter apparel lines, added new markdowns on merchandise including exercise equipment, home lighting and electric blankets, Howard said in a phone interview. The retailer was also moving up its annual furniture clearance sale, which traditionally does not begin till after Christmas, he said. It decided to extend a no-interest financing incentive for major appliance buyers through Jan. 1. ``We felt all along that this weekend would be the one that's most critical,'' Howard said. Sales have been at best sluggish for many stores. Burdened by worries about their jobs, the economy and the Middle East crisis, consumers have been spending cautiously and warmer weather has stalled sales of heavy clothing and other winter merchandise. Retailers and analysts reported consumers were generally shunning expensive gifts for cheaper and more practical items. Walter Loeb, a retail analyst and consultant, said he has found retailers are selling more smaller items, such as accessories and cosmetics, this year. Across the country, retailers have had ``sale'' signs up for weeks in an attempt to lure shoppers. Like Sears, they've increased discounts as the days have gone by, and in the last days of the season, some of the price cuts will be heavier. ``Starting last weekend, stores did push the panic button and they're pushing harder to get sales,'' said Jeffrey Edelman, a retail industry analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Inc. ``It's not working all that well - that's the scary part of it,'' he said. However, Howard said Sears' earlier markdowns did produce ``significant, favorable'' results. At J.C. Penney Co. Inc., customers this weekend will see markdowns of 50 percent on some items, spokesman Duncan Muir said. Penney's sales through last weekend ran about even with last year, a disappointing performance, Muir said. ``With what we bought for Christmas, we can't be happy,'' Muir said, referring to the merchandise Penney hasn't been able to move. ``On the other hand, we realize we're in a recessionary environment and it's a difficult period.'' One bright spot for Penney was a pickup in catalog sales, aided by special promotions such as $15 off on a purchase of $75. ``We've got our fingers crossed'' going into the last weekend, Muir said. But Loeb said that while ``a last-minute rush is now developing, I still don't see the enthusiasm, the momentum that would make up for a lot of this lost time.'' Loeb predicted that when Christmas is over, the retail industry's overall sales will be down 3 percent from last year. After inflation is subtracted, the decline will be even sharper. Some retailers, who were satisfied with their sales earlier in the season, seem to have lost some optimism. ``It's certainly difficult and we're looking forward to the weekend ...'' said Ann Barkelew, a spokeswoman for Dayton Hudson Corp. ``The concern always is, `Will we have enough people.''' In the first few weeks of the season, Dayton Hudson had said it was pleased with its results. Through last week, Dayton Hudson's overall sales were about the same as a year earlier, Ms. Barkelew said. Strong business at the company's Target discount stores and Mervyn's apparel chain was offset by poor sales at its Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's department stores. Kmart Corp.'s vice president for marketing, Michael Wellman said of this Christmas, ``It's a season that could be better.'' However, he said, ``It's not over yet - I'm not pessimistic by any stretch of the imagination.'' Kmart has increased advertising during the last week before Christmas, but ``that was all planned'' in advance, Wellman said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to correct cycle designator.
Dixon Built and Lost Vernon
DOC.TEXT: Don R. Dixon bought a savings and loan in his small Texas hometown, built it into a profit-making machine and saw it collapse from gluttony. As the owner of Vernon Savings Association, Dixon collected fine art and antique cars, hosted parties on the Potomac for Washington's elite, jet-hopped to Europe's five-star restaurants and even met the pope. Dixon may pay dearly for those heady days of the early and mid-'80s. On Thursday, he became the latest and most important Vernon executive to be convicted of defrauding its customers and contributing to its $1.3 billion 1987 failure - one of the first costly collapses in the savings and loan crisis. Dixon said during his seven-week trial that Vernon cost him everything: ``I lost a lot of money. I lost my credibility. I lost my career.'' He may now lose his freedom. Dixon faces 115 years in jail and a fine of up to $5.75 million, according to Marvin Collins, U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Texas. He will be sentenced by U.S. District Judge A. Joe Fish on Feb. 19. U.S. Magistrate John B. Tolle Thursday ordered Dixon held without bond until his sentencing after proseuctors argued Dixon had money overseas and might flee. Dixon is not a household name, like Charles Keating or Neil Bush. But he is a one of the most celebrated and written-about figures in the thrift crisis. ``Don Dixon was the highest of the high fliers among the savings and loan crooks,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in Washington after the conviction. Dixon and six other former Vernon officers also face a $540 million civil lawsuit brought by federal regulators. Dixon, 52, grew up in Vernon, a town of 11,000 near the Oklahoma border about 130 miles northwest of Dallas. He got his start in Texas business developing condominiums. During the trial, he said he bought Vernon Savings in 1981 because he was eager to become involved in all aspects of the real estate industry, from financing to marketing. Congress and state legislatures were moving then to weaken the restrictions that had kept thrifts primarily providers of home mortgages. Dixon thought deregulation would save the industry and help him make money. A month after buying Vernon Savings from R.B. Tanner, who had founded it 21 years earlier, Dixon asked the thrift's board to approve the $125,000 purchase of a small Western sculpture. His buying spree was on. Dixon soon moved Vernon's main office to Dallas and then had the thrift buy a fleet of jets, a yacht that he moved from Tampa to Washington, D.C., a Colorado ski chalet, beach houses and a Rolls-Royce and Ferrari dealership in California. The houses were needed as Vernon moved into the lucrative real estate market, Dixon testified during the trial. ``It was important for us ... that the savings and loan appeared to be part of that community,''Dixon said. He became so well-known in southern California that the Roman Catholic bishop in San Diego introduced Dixon to the pope during a trip to Rome that regulators learned was paid for by Vernon. Dixon built Vernon on deposits handled by brokers for institutional investors seeking high interest rates. He increased the thrift's asset base more than 10-fold, including hundreds of condominium units his real estate company was building. The thrift even put Dixon's picture on a promotional $3 bill that also carried the slogan ``In Don We Trust.'' But Vernon's flimsy loan base became apparent when real estate values fell with the price of oil in the mid-'80s. Vernon was the largest thrift failure in history at the time it was seized in March 1987. Dixon was the 11th person and eighth Vernon officer convicted of criminal wrongdoing that contributed to the thrift's failure. Woody Lemons, who was Vernon's chief executive officer, was sentenced in April to 30 years in prison, the stiffest penalty yet handed any figure in the savings and loan crisis.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to correct cycle designator.
Defense Contractors Warn of 8,000 Layoffs If Pentagon Scraps Plane
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. are sending notices to about 8,000 workers who could lose their jobs if the Defense Department scraps the A-12 Avenger bomber program. The defense contractors, both based here, are the prime contractors on the $4.8 billion A-12 program, which has been threatened because of cost overruns and schedule problems. A decision could come as early as Jan. 2. Both companies, like other defense contractors, have been hurt by the broad slowdown in weapons orders since warmer relations between the Eastern and Western blocs. McDonnell Douglas said Thursday it would notify about 4,000 employees at McDonnell Aircraft that they could be laid off as soon as Jan. 2. Officials said the layoffs would not be limited to people working on the A-12 program. Later Thursday, General Dynamics said it also would notify about 4,000 workers at its Fort Worth Division that they could be laid off as early as Jan. 2. General Dynamics President Herbert F. Rogers said the company was hopeful the Navy and the Department of Defense would continue the program. ``The possibility exists, however, that the government will terminate the program,'' Rogers said. ``As a result, we are forewarning affected employees that layoffs could occur suddenly and without as much notice as we have given during our planned downsizing operations.'' McDonnell Aircraft spokesman Jim Reed said that officials on the A-12 team would continue to hold discussions with the Navy and the Defense Department ``to resolve difficulties and assure continuation of this vital national defense program on a mutually satisfactory basis.'' Both companies emphasized to employees that the layoffs would occur only if the program were terminated or changed significantly. Last week, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ordered the Navy to justify the project or kill it because of what he called intolerable problems. Defense Department audits on the program allege that hundreds of millions of dollars in excess payments have been made to the two companies. Earlier this week, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and the Los Angeles Times reported that a separate Pentagon audit concluded that the A-12 contractors have a ``possible chance of bankruptcy.'' Officials of General Dynamics and McDonnell Douglas disagreed with the audits' findings. Both companies have said they were cooperating with reviews of the A-12 and that they believed they had solved the major technical problems that had come up. The A-12 was envisioned as a deep-strike bomber with radar-evading capabilities. It was meant to be the Navy's main carrier-based attack plane for the early 21st century. Just eight months ago, Cheney assured Congress the A-12 project was on schedule and within its then-classified budget. A Pentagon Inspector General's report released earlier this month said Cheney had not been aware of the project's serious problems because senior aides had failed to communicate the schedule delays to him. The project is at least $1 billion over cost and at least 18 months behind schedule. Among the chief technical problems is excess plane weight due to the thickness of the construction material needed to make the plane strong enough for carrier landings, said a Navy report released earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Air Lines Order Pushes Boeing to Record Year
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. said a $1.8 billion order from Delta Air Lines helped it set a company record of $47.7 billion worth of airplane orders this year. Boeing's 1990 tally tops by $1.1 billion its previous high mark of $46.6 billion set last year even though the number of planes ordered fell from 1989. Boeing said Thursday that 543 planes were ordered this year, down from 883 last year. The biggest drop came in orders for the short-haul 737-series - 162 planes this year from 463 last year. But the overall dollar amount of the orders increased because of a sharp rise in orders for Boeing's most expensive jet, the 747-400 jumbo. This year, airlines ordered 172 of the 747-400s, which cost between $125 million and $147 million each. Boeing received orders for 68 of its 747-400s in 1989. Delta's order announced Thursday includes six new 767-300 twinjets, which sell for between $78 million and $86 million each. Boeing also disclosed that Delta placed orders earlier this year for three more extended-range 767-300s, an additional standard 767-300, nine 757-200s and seven 737-300s. Boeing spokesman T. Craig Martin said the previous orders included options Delta converted to firm purchases this year and several jets added to earlier orders during the final contract negotiations for those orders.

DOC.HEAD: Company Will Take $220 Million Charge To Get Out Of Fertilizer Business
DOC.TEXT: Chevron Corp. said it will charge $220 million against fourth-quarter earnings because of its previously announced plan to sell its fertilizer operations. Analysts said they were not surprised at the size of the after-tax charge or the timing of Thursday's announcement because oil companies traditionally take writeoffs in the fourth quarter. Analysts also said they expected Chevron's fourth-quarter profits to rise, pushed higher by the recent jump in natural gas and crude oil prices. Chevron announced last month that it would sell its fertilizer operations, which each year produces 1 million tons of nitrogen fertilizer and 450,000 tons of phosphate fertilizer. The company was not hopeful for the future of the business because of the depressed farm economy. The $287 million-a-year business accounts for less than 1 percent of Chevron's $31.9 billion in revenues. It employes 600 people at plants in Richmond, Calif., Wyoming, Washington and Oregon. Chevron, which hopes to sell the fertilizer operations next year, did not identify potential buyers.

The stock market showed little change today amid strong cross-currents created by a quarterly ``triple witching hour.'' The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 7.92 to 2,637.38 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers and losers ran about even in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 468 up, 469 down and 496 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 74.36 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Trading was heavy at the outset as professional investors engaged in maneuvers involving a group of expiring options and futures on stock indexes. Some of those contracts were settled on the basis of opening stock prices this morning, and others as of the close. The witching hour, which falls on the third Friday of March, June, September and December, was often a turbulent occasion for the market in years past. But recently it has been taking place in more orderly style. Beyond that specialized activity, analysts mostly were looking for an uneventful session, with many investors getting an early start on Christmas holidays. The markets will be open Monday for an abbreviated session ending at 2 p.m. EST, instead of the usual 4 p.m. close. Gainers among the blue chips included Coca-Cola, up \ at 48]; Exxon, up ] at 50}; American Telephone & Telegraph, up } at 31[, and DuPont, up \ at 37}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .34 to 180.66. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .32 at 306.17. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.73 to 2,629.46. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 8 to 7 on the NYSE, with 717 up, 820 down and 500 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 174.70 million shares, against 180.38 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Outlook for Farmers Generally Upbeat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS corn sale total in first graf of third item to 1 million sted 1.3 million. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A series of economic reports by the Agriculture Department in recent weeks points to 1991 as a pretty good year for farmers, although most admit there are uncertainties, perhaps more than usual. One will be the reaction of farmers when they sign up for 1991 crop programs under the new farm law, which gives them more flexibility to plant what they choose. A price for this freedom, of course, is a cutback in the acreage that will be eligible for ``deficiency'' payments, the federal subsidies designed to help support farmers' incomes when market prices decline. Even so, department economists forecast that 1991 net cash income will be in the range of $55 billion to $60 billion. That would compare with a record of $59 billion estimated for 1990. Net cash income is the difference between gross cash income in a calendar year and cash expenses. Although 1990 shapes up as a banner year for farm income, generally, that doesn't mean all farmers everywhere have had it good. And USDA hasn't closed the books on gathering all the statistics on this year. Mitch Morehart of the department's Economic Research Service says in the December issue of Farmline magazine that the seventh annual Farm Costs and Returns Survey will begin in mid-February. The survey will be conducted over six weeks among 24,000 farmers and ranchers in the 48 contiguous states. Information will be gathered on their operations in 1990. Morehart said that of the six surveys so far, the one earlier this year for 1989 was financially the best for U.S. producers. ``The (annual) survey tells us how much it costs to produce various commodities in different areas and helps us maintain a good understanding of the financial strengths and weaknesses of U.S. agriculture,'' Morehart said. For example, here are a few of the highlights from the last survey: -In 1989, net farm income was ``positive'' for 69 percent of the farms, compared with 64 percent in 1988. Generally, that means the farms operated at a profit. -Farm assets averaged $404,209 per farm in 1989, up from $359,575 in 1988. Average net worth per farm was $356,191, compared with $311,343 in 1988. -Farm operator debt was basically unchanged, averaging $48,018 per farm in 1989. -The number of farms with high debt continued to decline to 11 percent with debt-asset ratios above 0.4 at the end of 1989. That means debts amounted to more than 0.4 - or 40 percent - of total assets. Also, 48 percent of the farms had no debt at all. Morehart said the highest proportions of financially vulnerable farms in 1989 were the Northern Plains, Mountain and Pacific regions. The largest increases in the percentages of profitable farms occurred in the Great Lakes states, Corn Belt, Northeast and Appalachia regions. Dairy and tobacco operations led all production specialties with 85 percent reporting positive returns. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An Agriculture Department trade report says food exporters may want to plan ahead for selling products to the over-60 crowd in a number of countries. By the year 2000, one in five people in the developed countries will be over 60, according to United Nations statistics. By 2025, one in four will be over 60. The report, included in the January issue of AgExporter magazine, cited a number of observations based upon reports by U.S. agricultural attaches and trade officers: -In France, older consumers will be demanding more healthful foods, including low-fat, low-cholesterol and sugar-free products enriched with vitamins and proteins. Special dietary food products will continue to be popular, but the senior generation doesn't want products advertised as ``geriatric.'' -In Germany, where 25 percent of the population will be over 60 by the turn of the century, older consumers have purchasing power three times higher than that of the average 20-year-old. Indications point to a growing market for higher quality food products, particularly those with a high degree of convenience such as frozen foods and ready-to-cook meals. -In Spain, consumers are ``fairly conservative in their eating habits'' and most favor fresh foods. So prepared, frozen or canned items are not good bets in the Spanish consumer market. Fresh fruits and vegetables are popular, and prospects appear excellent for sales of natural fruit juices to Spain's older generation. -In Britain, older consumers can be targeted for fresh fish, meat, fresh vegetables, breakfast cereals, brown bread, low-fat butter, sunflower oil margarine, cheese, fruit juices and stir-fried foods. Microwaveable products also have a sales potential in Britain. -In Japan, about 12 percent of the population was over age 65 in 1989. By the turn of the century, about 16 percent will be. But products specifically tailored to the older population are not yet found in Japanese retail markets. One reason older foreign consumers offer less opportunity at present for U.S. foods is that they are traditional eaters. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Soviet Union has bought more corn from the United States, boosting purchases this week to nearly 1 million metric tons, according to the Agriculture Department. Officials said private exporting companies sold an additional 300,000 tons to the Soviets under terms of the current long-term supply agreement between the two countries. A sale of 266,500 tons of corn was announced Tuesday, the first large U.S. grain order in two months. Another sale of 385,000 tons was announced Wednesday. A metric ton of 2,205 pounds is equivalent to 39.4 bushels of corn. The 300,000 tons would be about 11.8 million bushels. ----

DOC.HEAD: Office Supply Chain Agrees To Be Acquired By Office Depot
DOC.TEXT: Office Club, a leading office-supply chain, has agreed to be acquired by Office Depot Inc. in a stock swap valued at $137.8 million. Office Depot is the biggest chain in the United States with 121 stores in the Southeast, Midwest and Texas. The company, based in Boca Raton, Fla., has sales expected to reach $630 million in 1990. Office Club, which announced the agreement Thursday, has 51 stores in nine Western states with sales this year estimated at $285 million. The merged companies could reach $1.4 billion in revenues next year, said Dan Wewer, an analyst for Robinson-Humphrey Inc. in Atlanta. That would be nearly three times the $500 million in sales he estimated for Staples Inc. of Massachusetts, another large office supply chain. ``This combined Club-Depot entity will have more leverage with their vendors and the manufacturers than will Staples,'' Wewer said. Under the proposed deal, Office Club will move its headquarters to Boca Raton but would continue to operate independently, changing its name only in the Dallas-Fort Worth area - the only place both companies operate stores. If hareholders approve the deal, each share of Office Club stock would be exchanged for 1.194 shares of Office Depot, which closed Thursday at $16 a share in national over-the-counter trading. Office Club has 7.2 million shares outstanding. Its stock rose $4.62{ a share to $18.12{ Thursday in over-the-counter trading. The move of Office Club's headquarters to Florida will result in the loss of about 100 jobs, a company spokesman said. Mark Begelman, Office Club's chief executive, would become chief operating officer of Office Depot, according to the companies.

DOC.HEAD: Holiday Layoffs Continue into January for Thousands of Auto Workers
DOC.TEXT: The new year will start off with a two-week extension on holiday vacations for about 41,650 auto workers as the Big Three automakers continue a shutdown because of big inventories and low orders, officials said today. General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. will shut 17 assembly plants for the three-production-day week of Jan. 2. All Ford Motor Co. assembly plants will operate tht week. All the GM and Chrysler plants will remain closed through the week of Jan. 7 except for GM's factory in Wilmington, Del. GM plants down for both weeks include Lansing Reatta, Detroit, Flint, Pontiac East, Lansing B, and most of the Hamtramck factory, all in Michigan; along with Fort Wayne, Ind.; Fairfax, Kan.; Oklahoma City; North Tarrytown, N.Y.; Van Nuys, Calif.; Linden, N.J., and a van plant in Lordstown, Ohio. Chrysler will keep St. Louis, Mo., car and Toledo, Ohio, Jeep plants down through the week of Jan. 14. The company's Sterling Heights car assembly plant will be down through the week of Jan. 21. None of the Big Three assembly plants will operate for the week of Dec. 24 because of the Christmas and New Year's holidays. Autoworkers affected by the layoffs are eligible for United Auto Workers benefit packages designed to provide them with 95 percent of their wages while on layoff.

The stock market was mixed today amid strong cross-currents created by a quarterly ``triple witching hour.'' The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 6.93 to 2,636.38 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 6 to 5 in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 550 up, 656 down and 556 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 104.75 million shares at midmorning. Trading was heavy at the outset as professional investors engaged in maneuvers involving a group of expiring options and futures on stock indexes. Some of those contracts were settled on the basis of opening stock prices this morning, and others as of the close. The witching hour, which falls on the third Friday of March, June, September and December, was often a turbulent occasion for the market in years past. But recently it has been taking place in more orderly style. Beyond that specialized activity, analysts mostly were looking for an uneventful session, with many investors getting an early start on Christmas holidays. The markets will be open Monday for an abbreviated session ending at 2 p.m. EST, instead of the usual 4 p.m. close. Gainers among the blue chips included General Electric, up { at 58; Philip Morris, up [ at 50{; American Telephone & Telegraph, up | at 31, and Ford Motor, up ] at 25~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .16 to 180.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .64 at 305.85.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Shrinks Because of Economic Slowdown
DOC.TEXT: Britain's trade deficit shrank to $1.84 billion in November from $2.02 billion the previous month as imports declined as a result of the nation's economic slowdown, the government said Friday. However, the latest figure was worse than the $1.8 billion deficit the financial markets had been expecting. The figures for Britain's current account, which includes invisible trade such as services, were the same because invisible trade has been in balance. Exports totaled $16.7 billion in November, up from $16.6 billion in October, the Central Statistical Office said. Imports totaled $18.5 billion in November, down from $18.6 billion. So far in 1990, Britain's merchandise trade balance has totaled $32 billion compared with a deficit of $44 billion in the year-ago period.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 371.72 down 0.58 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed In Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in quiet trading this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after two days of losses linked to the slow pace of export sales of U.S. grain. The markets drew support from news that the Agriculture Department offered to subsidize sales of 2 million metric tons of wheat to Egypt and from Thursday's confirmation that the Soviet Union bought 300,000 metric tons of U.S. corn, said John Frazier, director of agricultural commodities trading for Gerald Inc. in Chicago. He said prices also were helped by perceptions that livestock producers in the western states will need to feed more grain to their cattle to sustain them through the current cold spell. Trading activity was extremely light as some traders got an early start on the Christmas weekend, he said. The grain markets will be open Monday until noon and will be closed on Christmas day. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in Marh at $2.61 a bushel; corn was \ cent to { cent lower with March at $2.34\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $1.12\ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to { cent higher with January at $5.70 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were modestly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent to .28 cent higher with February at 76.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .45 cent higher with January at 88.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent to .40 cent higher with February at 49.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .43 cent to .93 cent higher with February at 65 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Globe to Trim Work Force
DOC.TEXT: Citing declines in advertising, The Boston Globe said today it will reduce its work force by 100 full-time positions through attrition over the next five years. The 100 positions represent about 5 percent of the full-time staff at the Globe, which employs 2,075 full-time and 500 part-time workers. Spokesman Richard Gulla says the reduction will be company wide, with no particular department targeted. ``We are experiencing the same economic forces affecting other companies,'' said William O. Taylor, publisher of the Globe and chairman of the newspaper's parent company, Affiliated Publications Inc. ``Advertising is down significantly this year, and the outlook is cautious at best,'' he said. ``We think this is the least painful way to address the need to be as cost-effective as we can for the future.'' The attrition program is another step in an overall cost-cutting effort at the Globe, which began implementing budget cuts in the spring of 1988. It has also included reductions in department expenditures and in hours of some part-time staff. Last week, Taylor said he expected earnings to be down significantly at Affiliated Publications and that the company planned to raise the price of the Globe from 35 cents to 50 cents in April in areas 30 miles outside the city.

DOC.HEAD: Clarence `Kelly' Johnson, Leading `Skunk Works' Aircraft Designer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Clarence L. ``Kelly'' Johnson, creator of Lockheed Corp.'s secret Skunk Works aircraft factory and a leading designer of the U-2 and SR-71 Blackbird spyplanes, died today at age 80. A Lockheed statement said Johnson died at St. Joseph Medical Center after an illness of many years, but did not disclose the illness. Johnson organized the Skunk Works in 1943 to build the XP-80 Shooting Star, the United States' first production jet fighter. Many aircraft and spacecraft bore his mark: the P-38 Lightning in World War II, the Constellation transports, the Hercules cargo planes, the P2V anti-submarine patrol aircraft and the Agena spacecraft, among others. Other designs on which he played a major role included the F-104 Starfighter, the first production aircraft to fly at twice the speed of sound; the U-2, the first plane able to make a sustained flight above 60,000 feet; and the YF-12 and SR-71 Blackbird, the world's fastest and highest-flying planes. The Blackbirds, recently retired by the Air Force, could fly more than 2,000 mph and for long durations above 85,000 feet. Johnson, born in Ishpeming, Mich., on Feb. 27, 1910, went to work for Lockheed as a tool designer in 1933. He went on to head the Skunk Works for 30 years. He retired as a corporate senior vice president in 1975 and retired from Lockheed's board of directors in 1980.

Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.64 percent this week, up from 9.56 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. It was the first increase since rates reached 10.24 on Oct. 19. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.86 percent, down from 7.91 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Giant Omits Interim Dividend
DOC.TEXT: The advertising and marketing giant WPP Group PLC said Friday it won't pay its shareholders a midyear dividend because of weak cash flow. The owner of the U.S.-based J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide advertising agencies said its priority was to conserve cash. WPP has grown into the largest ad and marketing group in the world through acquisitions over the past five years, but has seen growth in its businesses slowed by the economic weakness in the United States and Great Britain. ``We consider that it would not be in the best interests of the company to pay the interim dividend for 1990 and therefore this dividend will not be paid,'' WPP said in a letter to shareholders. The interim dividend was to have been for the six months ended June 30 and was to have been paid on Jan. 2. The company said in August it was going to pay a half-year dividend of 13.7 pence, or 26 cents, a share. Last year, the interim dividend was 11.3 pence, or 21.5 cents, a share. WPP's decision to omit the dividend surprised analysts. ``This underlines how difficult (a position) the company is in,'' said an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd., who declined to be identified. ``If it has to conserve cash to this extent it's obviously pretty serious.'' WPP also said it could be ``some time before the group can resume the pattern of growth in profits and earnings experienced up until a few months ago.'' WPP reported a 77 percent rise in pre-tax profit to 46 million pounds, or $87 million, for the first six months of the year from 26 million pounds in the same period a year earlier. However, the group warned in November that its full-year pre-tax profit wouldn't match stockbrokers' estimates of about 110 million pounds, or $209 million. The news prompted a 70 percent drop in the value of its stock over two days, and Friday's announcement ignited another decline. The stock, which had been trading at 392 pence before the November announcement, was down another 14 pence on Friday at 47 pence on London's Stock Exchange. Some analysts say WPP may have trouble meeting its debts, which they said totaled 320 million pounds, or about $600 million. Barclays de Zoete Wedd is forecasting WPP will have a 1990 pretax profit of 85 million pounds, or $162 million. WPP's pre-tax profit came to 75 million pounds in 1989. Its 1989 profit after taxes was 40.5 million pounds, or $77 million, on revenue of 4.4 billion pounds, or $8.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Offer $150 Million, With Conditions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout with comments from city official, trims, no pickup; also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Banks want a fiscal oversight board with veto power over Philadelphia's budget as part of a $150 million loan proposal to help the city avoid going broke, a newspaper reported today. An eight-bank consortium also urged spending cuts, tax increases, sale of city assets and privatization of some services to end the city's chronic deficits, The Philadelphia Inquirer said. The banks' demands were spelled out in a 10-page confidential proposal Tuesday, the newspaper said. City Solicitor Charisse Lillie would not discuss the proposal's details, but questioned its legality. ``We are not going to agree to anything in this deal which is illegal,'' she said today. She added that the city wouldn't ``agree to anything that would overstep the bounds in terms of what the mayor is authorized to do under the (city) charter.'' A $375 million note issue collapsed in September amid worries about the city's fiscal condition. The city's credit rating has sunk this year to the lowest level for a major U.S. city. Unless it receives a cash infusion, the city has warned it will not be able to meet the Jan. 4 payroll. The deadline has moved several times as city officials delayed payments to vendors and as some businesses and individuals paid taxes early. Mayor W. Wilson Goode's administration last week proposed selling $300 million in short-term notes to avoid payless paydays for city workers. The notes were to be sold to local banks, two pension boards and Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. The city Board of Pensions and Retirement, which oversees the $1.5 billion city pension fund, scheduled a private meeting for today. Joseph Herkness, a board member and union leader for the city's white-collar employees, said no vote would be taken on a note purchase today. The state Public School Employees' Retirement Board, which oversees the $16 billion state teachers pension fund, was not expected to meet until next week. Merrill Lynch skipped a 9{-hour negotiating session Tuesday, leading to speculation the New York investment firm had lost interest in the deal. Merrill Lynch spokeswoman Monica Prihoda said Thursday the firm is ``still in discussions'' with the city. The Inquirer also reported Fidelity Investments, the Boston mutual fund company, joined discussions on the note sale Thursday. Fidelity spokesman Bill Benintende said Fidelity had not decided whether to participate in the deal.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher in Europe, Gold Dips
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES throughout with closing Europe, midday NY rates; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was broadly higher in late European trading Friday amid political uncertainty in Eastern Europe and the continuing threat of war in the Persian Gulf. Gold fell slightly. Traders said the dollar continued to strengthen on concern about the Soviet Union's political fragility following the resignation of foreign minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze as well as the potential for war in the Middle East. Signs of political volatility abroad tend to encourage currency traders to buy the dollar, which is generally viewed as a safe haven in times of upheaval. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 135.70 Japanese yen from 134.58 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 135.78 yen, and in New York at midday, the dollar was quoted at 135.38 yen. In London, the British pound weakened to $1.8835 from $1.9080 late Thursday. Sterling was quoted at $1.8833 in New York at midday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.5295 German marks, up from 1.4997; 1.3120 Swiss francs, up from 1.2880; 5.1980 French francs, up from 5.1035; 1.7255 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6920; 1,153.00 Italian lire, up from 1,132.25; and 1.1595 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1593. Selected midday rates in New York included: 1.5290 German marks; 1.3125 Swiss francs; 1,153.00 Italian lire; and 1.1602 Canadian dollars. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $381.75 a troy ounce, down from $385.25 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the precious metal fell to a closing bid of $383.50, down from $385.00 bid late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 32 cents to close at $382.30. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.14 a troy ounce, down from $4.18 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: EC Concedes to US in Corn Row; Avoids Trade War
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Friday voted to continue compensating the United States for reduced corn exports into Spain and Portugal, avoiding a costly transatlantic trade war. Washington had been gearing up to increase duties on several EC food and drink products if the EC had decided to end compensations for losses in corn and sorghum exports to Spain and Portugal. The United States will now refrain from such measures and resume negotiations with the Community to settle the issue for good by the end of next year, officials said. The temporary settlement ended one of three farm disputes that have been marring trade relations between the United States and the 12-member EC. The move was also expected to facilitate attempts to restart the world trade talks that collapsed earlier this month. The talks, supervised by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, fell apart over farm subsidies that the United States wants to eliminate but the EC hopes to maintain. The talks are scheduled to resume in Geneva next month. The corn dispute arose after Spain and Portugal joined the trade bloc in 1986 and import duties were increased on U.S. corn and sorghum feedgrains. One year later, the EC trade bloc agreed to compensate the United States for losing an estimated $400 million in annual trade. Two million tons of corn and 300,000 tons of sorghum now are allowed into Spain and Portugal under reduced levies. The EC wanted to end the compensations this year, but granted a one-year extension Friday after the the United States threatened to retaliate with about $400 million in extra duties on EC products. The EC and the United States are still at odds over two other issues. One is the banning of U.S. pork imports for what the EC considers to be unsanitary slaughterhouse conditions in the United States. The other is a U.S. ban on EC sparkling wines that contain a Japanese additive which Washington thinks could be unhealthy.
