DOC.HEAD: The AP
Stock Exchange Raises $120,000 for Christmas Dinners
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange said Friday it raised $120,000 to provide Christmas dinners to 2,100 needy families in the city. In the annual fundraising event, dinners will be delivered to the homes of needy families by the Boys Club of New York, the Children's Aid Society and the Roman Catholic church St. Vincent de Paul. The NYSE last year raised more than $144,000 in the program. But an exchange spokeswoman, Cathy Maroney, said more dinners would be distributed this year because Windows on the World, a restaurant in the World Trade Center, reduced the cost of preparation. The dinners include 16-pound turkeys and will be distributed to families on Saturday and Monday, the NYSE said. Last year, 2,047 dinners were distributed.

DOC.HEAD: General Electric Starts Internal Investigation
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. said Friday it has begun an internal probe as a result of Israel's investigation into whether Israeli military officers accepted bribes while buying U.S.-made equipment. General Electric is a major producer of jet engines used on military and civilian aircraft in the United States and overseas. GE's main jet engine plant is in the Cincinnati suburb of Evendale, with a sister plant in Lynn, Mass. In Israel, prosecutors said Thursday they had agreed to a plea bargain by a senior Israeli Air Force officer accused of accepting millions of dollars in bribes while purchasing U.S. military equipment. According to the deal, Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan will be required to return $10 million in bribes and kickbacks he allegedly accepted while heading the Defense Ministry's department of military acquisitions in New York in 1984-85. The scandal shocked Israel's military establishment and raised concerns it might jeopardize the $1.8 billion in U.S. military aid Israel receives annually. Spokesman George Jamison said GE began an internal investigation upon learning of the Israeli investigation. He declined to discuss any findings so far. ``We've advised the U.S. government of our investigation. We're cooperating fully with the U.S. government,'' Jamison said from GE headquarters in Fairfield, Conn. Col. Rick Oborn, a Defense Department spokesman in Washington, was unavailable for comment early Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Mix-Up Slows Down Mail to Desert Shield
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 10-14 to UPDATE with comments from group's organizer. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 current magazines bound for U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia were hung up in a Minnesota printing plant today because of a mix-up over cigarette advertising on their covers, but a spokesman at the Pentagon said they would be on their way in a week. The magazines were scheduled for shipment overseas by Operation Desert News, an organization formed in Charleston, S.C., to provide U.S. military personnel in the Persian Gulf with reading matter. Officials of the Defense Logistics Agency, which oversees such shipments, discovered Thursday that the magazines were being bound in special outside covers containing a Camel cigarette advertisement but not containing a military disclaimer about tobacco products. The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. is the only corporate sponsor of Operation Desert News. ``We're going to print the declaration on the front and take the camel off the back,'' said Lt. Col. Hery Wyatt, spokesman for Defense Logistics. He said officials of the St. Cloud, Minn., firm that is doing the printing told the agency the task could be done in a week. Wyatt said the covers bear the name of the R.J. Reynolds Co. on the front and the Camel ad on the back. He said lawyers at the Pentagon and at the U.S. Central Command at MacDill Air Force Base, Fla., which screens the content of magazines bound for the gulf, worked out the new arrangement. ``Normally when it's a cigarette company, the Defense Department requires a disclaimer be put on it, that they are not sanctioning the troops smoking,'' said Major Maureen DeCiantis, a public affairs officer for Central Command. ``In this case it was not done, because Desert News didn't know they had to do it, and we didn't know they had a tobacco company as a backer.'' Both Wyatt and Staff Sgt. Jefferson Sammons of the Central Command public affairs office said that as first submitted to Central Command the covers did not bear the advertising matter. Tim Karnes, a Charleston publisher who organized Operation Desert News, said the organization submitted a rough draft of the first page of the cover, which might not have contained the R.J. Reynolds identification, and did not submit the back page. He said the organization did not realize any disclaimer would be needed, but ``everybody involved knew that R.J. Reynolds was the sponsor.'' ``It's magazines that we're sending,'' Karnes said. ``We're not sending cigarettes.'' He said the organization is seeking other corporate sponsors. Karnes, publisher of Auction Guide magazine, spoke by telephone from Acapulco, Mexico, where he is attending a family gathering over the Christmas holiday. ``The communication just kind of got snafued,'' DeCiantis said. Dean Foster, a spokesman for Operation Desert News in Charleston, said, ``The Defense Department and Operation Desert News are working toward the same goal, and that is to get the magazines to the troops as expediently as possible.'' The magazines are sent aboard ships. The ocean passage takes about three weeks.

DOC.NOTE: For Release AMs of Monday, December 24
DOC.HEAD: Federal Reserve Bids For Confidence With Lower Rates
DOC.TEXT: If lower interest rates from the Federal Reserve are going to rescue the economy, the central bank needs help from consumers, banks and businesses. The banks seem to be starting to go along. First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's 13th-largest U.S. banking company, was the first major lender to follow the Fed's lead, lowering its prime rate from 10 percent to 9.5 percent. Smaller banks also moved to ease their prime rates as well. Interest rates on many business and consumer loans, like home equity lines of credit, are tied to the prime. Lower borrowing costs for consumers, combined with optimism that the recession might be short lived, could prompt many to buy a new car, dishwasher or even a new house. Slouching consumer confidence has been one of the darkest clouds hanging over this recession. In November, the Conference Board, a business-supported research group, reported its consumer confidence index fell near levels last seen in the depths of the 1982 recession. The Conference Board's survey found more people expecting higher unemployment and weaker business conditions in the coming months and were scaling back plans for major purchases. Businesses have also started to change their plans based on economic pessimism. The Commerce Department reported last week that businesses planned to increase spending to modernize by a scant 0.4 percent in 1991. This year, modernization spending increased 4.1 percent. ``There are a lot of different ways you send a message. (Lowering) the , fed funds rate is a very technical message. The discount rate is still another way of communicating and the Fed was trying to do something dramatic, but the prime rate is very visible to a lot of people,'' said Maury Harris, chief economist at PaineWebber Inc. Fluctuations in the discount rate - interest the Fed charges to lend money to banks - have little direct affect on the economy and the move to lower the rate from 7 percent to 6.5 percent was seen widely as symbolic. In an economy driven by perceptions, symbols are important. The Fed's message was clear and sent loudly. Announced in the afternoonon on an otherwise slow news day, many editors at newspapers and broadcasting stations treated the move as the day's top story rather than a purely business news development. Recent moves by the Fed to lower the federal funds rate - interest banks charge each other for overnight loans - to 7 percent have been largely left to the business pages. ``The Fed wanted to tell consumers they are going to do something. ... The message to banks was: `think about lowering interest rates,''' said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu, a division of Midland Bank. The message to everyone was that the Fed has made the recession its top priority, rather than the anti-inflation tight money policy. This summer's tight-money policy, which was intended to bring the economy into a ``soft landing'' to squeeze out inflation, was blown off course when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The invasion and higher oil prices, which took money out of consumers pockets, on top of the tight money policy, pushed the economy into recession, Fabbri said. Although lower interest rates may help pull the economy around, they may not hold the quick answer, Fabbri said. It will take six to 12 months for increased borrowing and increased bank profitability to lead the way to recovery, he said.

DOC.HEAD: More on Tap After New Year's
DOC.TEXT: More than 40,000 workers at two of the Big Three automakers will get longer Christmas and New Year's breaks because of anemic car and truck sales. The workers, at 17 General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. assembly plants, will still be getting nearly all of their normal pay through the Supplemental Unemployment Benefit program. But the temporary layoffs have still caused worry about the economy and the auto industry in particular. ``It's scary,'' said Elaine Swiderski, financial secretary for United Auto Workers Local 435 at General Motors Corp.'s assembly plant in Wilmington, Del. ``Sometimes your (SUB) checks are delayed.'' Officials for each of the Big Three have predicted a sharply lower rates of sales for cars and trucks in 1991, even if war does not break out in the Middle East. Sales could plunge if shooting erupts. General Motors Corp. said it would shut down 14 assembly plants the week of Jan. 2, while Chrysler will idle three. The shutdowns will affect 41,650 workers. GM plants down until Jan. 14 are Lansing Reatta, Detroit, Flint, Pontiac East, Lansing B, and most of the Hamtramck factory, all in Michigan; Fort Wayne, Ind.; Fairfax, Kan.; Oklahoma City; North Tarrytown, N.Y.; Van Nuys, Calif.; Linden, N.J.; and a van plant in Lordstown, Ohio. GM said Wilmington will resume production Jan. 7. Chrysler will keep its St. Louis, Mo., car and Toledo, Ohio, Jeep plants down until Jan. 21. The company's Sterling Heights, Mich., car assembly plant will be down until Jan. 28. Ford Motor Co. said Friday all of its plants will operate the shortened work week beginning Jan. 2. All three automakers' plants shut down next week for the traditional holiday vacation. Ford has not announced which plants would operate the week of Jan. 7. Swiderski said a temporary layoff isn't bad if employees know they will be returning to work soon. But if the layoff is extended or the number of temporary layoffs begins to mount, perceptions may be different. ``How is it going to be in the future?'' she wondered. ``The way the economy looks to me, it's scary. People aren't spending (money) like they used to. People don't know what the heck is going to happen.'' The supplemental payments workers will receive are included in United Auto Workers union contracts with the Big Three. The program is aimed at providing employees 95 percent of their regular pay when they are laid off from plants because of slow sales.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
General Dynamics Reports Major Reorganization in Fort Worth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dain is cq in penultimate graf
DOC.TEXT: General Dynamics Corp. on Friday announced a major reorganization of its Fort Worth Division, including the reassignment of the director of the troubled A-12 Avenger bomber program. The St. Louis-based defense contractor said the reorganization would emphasize five business groups considered vital to the division's future, including the A-12 program, which the Pentagon has threatened to scrap because of cost overruns and schedule problems. The company said Charles Anderson, the A-12 program director, was reassigned as division vice president of a new unit called Special Programs and Other Business. His replacement is Ted Webb, the former head of the F-16 fighter jet program, who retired last year. Company spokesman Mike Hatfield said Anderson's transfer was part of an overall restructuring of the A-12 program. He said the reorganization had been in the works for several months and was not tied exclusively to the program. General Dynamics and McDonnell Douglas Corp. are the prime contractors on the troubled $4.8 billion bomber program. On Thursday, the companies announced they were sending notices to 8,000 workers warning they could be laid off if the Navy scrapped the program. A decision is expected as early as Jan. 2. Last week, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ordered the Navy to justify the project or kill it because of what he called intolerable problems. Defense Department audits allege that hundreds of millions of dollars in excess payments have been made to the two companies. Earlier this week, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and Los Angeles Times reported that a separate Pentagon audit concluded that the A-12 contractors have a ``possible chance of bankruptcy.'' Officials of General Dynamics and McDonnell Douglas disagreed with the audit's findings. Both companies have said they were cooperating with reviews of the A-12 and believed they had solved the major technical problems that had surfaced. Under the reorganization announced Friday, a number of related electronic products were combined in a Military Electronics business group. Special projects and other separate business elements were combined in the Special Programs and Other Business unit. Each group will be headed by a division vice president, who will have expanded authority and responsibility and will report directly to company president Herbert F. Rogers, who is also general manager of the Fort Worth Division. The changes are effective immediately and will be followed by other realignments within the division to focus resources on the five key business areas, the company said. Those areas include the F-16 fighter jet and the Advanced Tactical Fighter program. General Dynamics is the nation's second-largest defense contractor behind McDonnell Douglas. It has nine divisions and six major subsidiaries, all involved in defense work except Cessna Aircraft, which makes general aviation aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: General Electric Gets Japanese Contract
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Defense Agency selected a General Electric Co. engine to power the FS-X fighter jet in a deal worth at least $100 million, GE's Aircraft Engines division announced Friday. The F110-GE-129 engine is to be used aboard the FS-X aircraft, which are modeled after General Dynamics Corp.'s F-16 fighter jets. The first production versions are to be completed by 1999. Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan and General Dynamics are jointly developing the FS-X jets. The F110 engines for those aircraft are to be produced in Japan under license from General Electric, the company said. GE Aircraft Engines will provide some engine assembly and technical support. The amount of engine content to be produced by Japanese manufacturers will be subject to guidelines from the U.S. Department of Defense. GE said the Japan Defense Agency had also evaluated the F100-PW-229 engine produced by competitor Pratt & Whitney, a division of United Technologies Corp. of Hartford, Conn. ``We at GEAE are delighted with the decision of the JDA, for which we thank them,'' said Brian Rowe, senior vice president of GE Aircraft Engines, based in Evendale.

DOC.TEXT: Some satellite dish owners in Central and South America no longer will get Cable News Network for free. Turner Broadcasting System Inc., CNN's owner, said Thursday it plans to begin scrambling its CNN feed south of the border. The company said it will make the switch next month when it begins beaming the Turner Network Television movie channel to the region on a scrambled signal. TBS said the dish owners were receiving the service illegally for two years. TBS feeds its 24-hour news channel into about 35,000 hotel rooms and 250,000 homes in the region and sells its signal to about 35 broadcast clients, TV stations and networks. South American satellite dish owners who want to continue receiving CNN would have to buy a receiver and decoder from an equipment company, at a cost of about $1,300, and then enter a contract with CNN to unscramble the feed. Although CNN does not now contract with individuals, spokeswoman Kitsy Riggall said the company would ``certainly work with anybody who wants to receive it.'' TBS, which has been scrambling its signal in the United States for five years, said it was concerned about ``weak copyright laws in the region.'' The company said it has no plans to scramble CNN's signal to the rest of the world.

DOC.HEAD: Big Oil's Move To USSR Might Be Slowed, Not Stopped, by Politics
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's most recent political turmoil has become another wild card faced by Western oil companies examining possible deals for exploring, drilling and exporting crude from its vast reserves. ``I'm sure it delays everything,'' said John Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. ``One of the problems they have with making deals over there is that they didn't know how reliable their partner was, who their partner was.'' Texaco Inc., one of several major petroleum explorers interested in the Soviet Union, is puzzling to figure out who to negotiate with among the many layers of Soviet bureaucracy, spokesman David Dickson said. ``Is it the Soviet government?'' Dickson said. ``Is it the Russian republic? Is it the local authorities?'' Apparently, none of the majors have gone beyond signing agreements that commit them to exploring possibilities of joint ventures, experts said. ``Our discussions are still too preliminary to make any judgments about possible outcomes,'' Exxon Corp. said in a statement. Other oil companies interested in Soviet ventures include Chevron Corp., Amoco Corp., British Petroleum and ARCO. Experts say Chevron might be the most advanced in getting a deal with the Soviets. But, like the others, Chevron will say little about the status of its plans. ``We are in the final stages of negotiations on a joint venture,'' spokesman Larry Shushan said Friday. ``We're not really in a position to speculate as to timing.'' Chevron's deal would be in the large Tengiz oilfield in the northeast Caspian Sea region, which the Soviets have estimated could contain 25 billion barrels of oil. That would be enough to supply all the American oil needs for decades. The uncertainties facing the oil giants were heightened this week, when Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze quit, shocking President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and stirring concerns that a dictatorship could emerge or that more troubles could develop. ``It could be a detriment,'' Exxon spokesman Lance Lamberton said. ``I can't quantify it.'' The Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer, but its industry has fallen on hard times after peaking out at 12.5 million barrels of crude oil a day in 1988. ``It's now down to 11.3,'' Lichtblau said. ``The general assumption is that it will continue to decline to under 10 million barrels a day in couple of years. That's a huge decline. If nothing is done, it could go down to nine perhaps.'' The problem is technology. The Soviets have extracted much of the oil that was relatively easy to obtain and they are unable to get to some additional reserves, which will bring in needed hard currency, without help from the West. Big oil companies looking toward the Soviet Union can envision the potential for vast production, possibly even enough to cut back on the market clout wielded by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The uncertainties of dealing with the Soviets are obvious, but the recent Persian Gulf crisis shows that the West already depends on an uncertain energy supply. Several potentially unstable sources of energy are logically better than only one, strategists say. ``They're not likely to be unavailable at the same time, since their politics are totally different,'' Lichtblau said. It's unclear how much new oil could be found in the Soviet Union, although some experts say higher production could easily equal that of a moderate-sized OPEC member. For now, efforts by U.S. companies involve enhanced production of crude that has already been discovered rather than ``wildcatting,'' or looking for new oil fields. In one such venture, a private company, Synergy Trading Corp., of Greenwich, Conn., hopes to set up a deal worth at least $250 million for enhancing on-shore wells in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, and a deal worth more than $1 billion for developing new off-shore wells there. William F. Wilson, who handles equity crude deals for Synergy, estimated the on-shore project could produce 15 to 20 million barrels of oil a year. ``Off-shore could be double that,'' Wilson said Friday. It remains uncertain how much of the oil Synergy and its partners could obtain. The Soviets will not let Western companies get involved in existing production, but they have expressed a willingness to let oil companies claim a portion of new oil they can produce. Synergy's executives, who have years of experience in making grain and oil deals with the Soviets, said they can get approval for the on-shore project from Azerbaijan authorities, while the off-shore deal needs to be cleared by Soviet authorities in Moscow. Synergy said political troubles in the Soviet Union and its republics can slow things, but the executives don't believe it will stop any deals. ``You've just got a longer fuse in these projects,'' Wilson said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. and British Officials Encounter Turbulence Over Heathrow
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and British government officials suspended negotiations Friday on their dispute over granting United Airlines and American Airlines access to London's Heathrow airport. The two sides, which held talks on Thursday and Friday, discovered a gap in their positions and said they had not set a date for resuming talks. No progress was being made in the negotiations, said Cyril Murphy, a United Airlines executive. ``The United States has indicated it is prepared to pay the British a reasonable price for allowing a timely succession at Heathrow,'' said Murphy. ``The British have come back and put on the table a long list of demands and essentially said, `We want everything on our list.' The U.S. has gone back and said, `The price is too high. Why don't we negotiate?' and that's where progress stops.'' The British offered to meet again in January, said a spokesman for the British Department of Transport, who spoke on condition of anonymity. American said Sunday it would buy TWA's London and other overseas routes for $445 million. United agreed in October to buy most of Pan Am's London routes for $400 million. The airlines are trying to secure access to Heathrow, which is Britain's most attractive airport because it is closer to central London, is served by the subway system and offers more air connections. But British law has barred new entrants from the congested airport since 1977 and diverted them to London's Gatwick and other British airports. United and American are hoping to get in through an air services agreement between the United States and Britain allowing successors to existing U.S. airlines to assume their Heathrow rights. Both airlines have said the deals will not proceed if they don't win access to Heathrow. An American government source knowledgable about this week's negotiations said officials ``identified that there was a gap between our perceptions in the best way to go forward on the issue.'' ``We're still working on resolving the issue. We have not come to an agreement as of yet,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The spokesman for the British Department of Transport said the sides had ``a useful exploratory meeting'' at which they identified and explored their differences. A source at one of the U.S. airlines said the British officials want to restrict the right of U.S. airlines to fly from London onward to continental cities. Britain also wants to give another British carrier access to Heathrow. The government also wants any new U.S.-British routes into Heathrow to be granted to British carriers, and wants more access to the U.S. domestic market, he said. The British goverment is not expected to make a decision until at least mid-January, after the Civil Aviation Authority has completed a report on the allocation of landing slots at Heathrow.

DOC.HEAD: The National Plans to Boost Cover Price to 75 Cents Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Despite falling short of circulation goals, the sports newspaper The National said Friday it will boost the daily cover price by a quarter to 75 cents, effective Jan. 21. In addition, the newspaper said it would test a $1 daily price for one or two of its 10 metropolitan editions. Specific editions have not yet been selected for the test, said spokesman Stephen Hammond. The move comes as the 11-month-old newspaper has yet to prove there are enough readers to sustain the first all-sports daily in the United States. It also comes as the weakest advertising market in 15 years has driven newspapers to find alternate methods of generating more revenue. In boosting prices, The National said it was following the lead of national newspapers such as The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times which have recently either boosted or plan to raise prices. The Journal boosted its price per copy to 75 cents from 50 cents on Dec. 3 while The Times plans to boost the price of its national edition to 75 cents from 50 cents in the Midwes and from 60 cents in the Southwest in January. ``Everybody is going to be more aggressive in circulation pricing next year,'' said Peter Appert, media analyst at C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell. But boosting the cover price may be particularly risky for The National, which is counting heavily on circulation revenue. Only two weeks ago, the newspaper told advertisers that it was reducing its circulation guarantee by 27 percent to 200,000 copies. The admission that it was not making its guaranteed average of 275,000 followed a review that resulted in the elimination of its Sunday edition, the dismissal of the circulation manager and two other top executives and layoffs of 18 other employees. The paper is now publishing five times a week, Monday through Friday. Whether the cover price increase drives away readers remains unclear. The National's Hammond said the newspaper feels it has ``a loyal and dedicated audience'' that will pay the higher price. The media analyst Appert said, ``For the the dedicated sports fanatic 75 cents versus 50 cents won't be a problem, just like it isn't a problem for The Wall Street Journal and dedicated financial readers.'' ``But will they lose some marginal circulation? Absolutely,'' he said. The National premiered Jan. 31 with editions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. It has since added editions in San Diego, San Francisco, Dallas, Detroit, Boston, Miami-Fort Lauderdale and Baltimore-Washington, D.C. It is scheduled to expand next year with editions in Philadelphia, Atlanta, Denver and Seattle, insiders said. The National is owned by National American Sports Communications, a private partnership controlled by Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga. He has declined to be interviewed about the newspaper. It has been reported he was prepared to spend $100 million over five years on the paper, and that first-year losses exceeded his expectations. Media analysts say it remains unclear whether there are enough readers for a sports daily. They say local newspapers and established outlets such as Gannett Co. Inc.'s USA Today newspaper are already providing a heavy dose of sports news. In addition, USA Today disclosed last week it is studying whether to produce a weekly sports tabloid, which could mean even more competition for sports readers. Asked to rate The National's chances for survival, Appert said, ``It's still a long shot.''
Stock prices were mixed today in a session marked by some strength in blue chips. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 10.64 points at 2,640.10.

DOC.HEAD: Say South African Ties Don't Hurt Business Performance
DOC.TEXT: American companies that still do business in South Africa find that economic sanctions haven't hurt their business performance, new investment research findings show. Since 1980, companies with South African business ties saw their return on investment improve by one percentage point per year over companies without business dealings in that nation, researcher John Freeman said in an interview Friday. Return on investment, a commonly used barometer to measure a company's financial performance, is a percentage calculated by dividing assets into net income. The joint research by Freeman, a manager for BARRA, an investment consulting firm in Berkeley, Calif., and Martingdale Asset Management in Boston, sought to ``neutralize all the other things and isolate the South African factor,'' Freeman said. Their unpublished research was conducted for investment fund managers to help them understand the risk of divestiture from South Africa, he said. The study showed that between January 1980 and August 1984, companies with South African ties lost 150 basis points in the return on investment annually when compared with non-South African companies. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The trend then reversed itself. From August 1984 to October 1990, companies with South African ties outperformed the others by 280 basis points per year. Freeman admitted the research results surprised him; activists who oppose apartheid, South Africa's policy of racial separation, were surprised as well. The research raises the question of whether the sanctions were designed to make companies unattractive as investments, hurt their business or merely force them out of South Africa. ``Our view is the goal was to get major companies to leave South Africa,'' said Patrick McVeigh, vice president of Franklin Research and Development Corp. in Boston. Franklin offers what it calls socially responsible investment portfolios for companies without South African connections. He said wounding a company's performance generally was ``a secondary weapon'' of divestment, ``but it never was a primary goal.'' Since 1984, 170 U.S. companies have removed their employees or direct investments in South Africa, said Meg Vorhees, South African research director at the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington, which keeps track of American corporate relations with South Africa. She said 114 U.S. companies maintain direct investments or employees in that nation. The pullout stems from international outrage over the political suppression and human rights abuses of South Africa's blacks. As of June 1990, 19 states and 55 cities have adopted policies calling for full or partial divestiture of securities with South African links, said Ms. Vorhees. The divestment question was posed to numerous government pension funds, endowments and foundations throughout the 1980s. Scattered protests flared on college campuses during the period as students urged school pull South African-related investments. She criticized the Martingdale-BARRA findings, saying most American companies derive a small amount of their business from South African subsidiaries or investments. ``It's hard for me to believe it would make that much of a difference. In general, U.S. companies with operations in South Africa account for less than 1 percent of their assets,'' she said. Franklin says its South Africa-clean investment portfolio has performed slightly better than the Standard and Poor's 500 index during a 15-year period. ``The difference is very small,'' said McVeigh. ``If anything, over time, it's become less of an issue because of the companies that have pulled out of South Africa.''

DOC.HEAD: K-III Holdings Agrees to Buy Field Corp. Publishing Assets
DOC.TEXT: The partnership K-III Holdings said Friday it has agreed to acquire the ``Weekly Reader,'' Funk & Wagnalls encyclopedias and other publishing operations from the privately-held Field Corp. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but one source familiar with the transaction said the price was about $200 million. K-III Holdings is a New York-based investment partnership headed by several former executives of the publishing giant Macmillan Inc. and backed by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. The partnership already has interests in educational publishing, trade magazines and directories for the transportation industry. The deal would more than double the size of its operations, as the assets being acquired generated revenue estimated at nearly $300 million this year compared with K-III's operations with about $230 million in revenue. Field Corp., based in Chicago, is owned by Marshall Field V and the Field family trusts. It put its publishing operations up for sale last summer, reportedly because it was dissatisfied with its return on the operations. The source who spoke on condition that he not be identified said there were believed to be a number of companies interested in parts of the operation being sold but far fewer were interested in all of them. He said Field has been talking exclusively with K-III Holdings for the past six weeks. K-III has agreed to buy the assets of Field Publications LP, which include the ``Weekly Reader,'' a current events publication that reaches more than 8.5 million elementary school children and 700,000 teachers with information designed for use in the classroom. Field Publications, based in Middletown, Conn., is the largest U.S. marketer of children's book clubs and other programs supplied regularly through the mail. K-III's Newbridge Communications business already markets educational materials through book clubs and other direct marketing programs to more than 400,000 teachers. Funk & Wagnalls, based in Ramsey, N.J., publishes encyclopedias for children and markets them primarily through supermarkets. ``These busineses offer a strategic fit with the educational focus'' of Newbridge, said William F. O'Reilly, chairman and chief executive of K-III Holdings. ``This is one of those rare opportunities where there is a real compatibility with existing operations.'' K-III Holdings President Charles McCurdy said no sunstantial changes are planned at either company in terms of product or management. The deal is expected to be completed in early 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Falls Again Before Long Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell below $26 a barrel Friday despite a refusal by Saddam Hussein to withdraw Iraqi forces from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Traders instead withdrew from oil futures positions to avoid losses if the gulf situation changes over the market's four-day Christmas weekend. Light sweet crude oil for February delivery fell 47 cents to $25.92 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was the third straight daily decline. Crude oil prices dropped 63 cents in the week. In an interview with Germany's ZDF television network, Saddam, Iraq's president, was asked if he would pull troops out of Kuwait by a Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations. ``No,'' he answered. ``We are certain that even when (President) Bush pushes his country into war, which he plans, he can't keep it going,'' Saddam said. He did not elaborate. Ed Kevelson, an oil trader at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the market rallied to a high of $26.75 a barrel shortly after the comments were broadcast, but tumbled late in the day. The outbreak of war likely would curtail oil supplies, raising prices. He said oil traders were reluctant to enter into deals that could lose them money should unexpected developments occur in the Persian Gulf over the long weekend. The Mercantile Exchange, a leading market for oil traders, is closed Christmas Eve. In the crude oil market, contracts for later delivery months also fell, though by smaller amounts. Home heating oil contracts showed strength as traders responded to a cold front in parts of the country. Heating oil rose .06 cent to 78.94 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January after rising 1.04 cents on Thursday. Heating oil for delivery in most later months was mixed. ``I think people were waiting to buy in to that market for the first cold snap and here it is,'' Kevelson said. Unleaded gasoline dropped for all delivery months, with January contracts down .44 cent to 66.24 cents a gallon. Natural gas prices, which have declined because of warm fall weather, rose for a second straight day. Natural gas for February delivery was up 4.2 cents at $1.962 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Moves Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished higher Friday on world currency markets in erratic pre-holiday trading. Gold prices declined worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange gold bullion for current deliver fell $3.40 to settle at $382.50 per troy ounce. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $381.25 an ounce, down $2.10. The dollar settled broadly higher in Europe and also gained ground when trading shifted to domestic markets. Traders said the dollar continued to draw support from the uncertainties created by the surprise resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Thursday and from the volatile Persian Gulf situation. The dollar advanced at the expense of the German mark, which was particularly hard hit because of Germany's ties to the Soviet Union. In addition to being a major lender to the Soviets, Germany had been expected to benefit substantially by exporting goods eastward once markets were opened. ``The market is extremely nervous to hold marks, so (traders) are selling marks and buying dollars,'' said Andrew Busch, a trader with Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Trading was particularly thin, accentuating movements in the dollar. ``We're trading in fits and starts,'' said Curtis Perkins, a dealer at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, adding that many investors were squaring up their books ahead of the Christmas holiday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 135.70 Japanese yen from 134.58 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it rose further to 135.78 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 135.50 yen, down from 135.85 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound weakened to $1.8835 from $1.9080 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.8860 to buy one pound, cheaper than Thursday's $1.8930. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5289 German marks, up from 1.5125; 1.3120 Swiss francs, up from 1.2995; 5.1955 French francs, up from 5.1425; 1,153.00 Italian lire, up from 1,139.20, and 1.1598 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1593. DOC.HEAD: Radical Change Needed, Says IMF Study
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The most comprehensive Western study of the Soviet economy ever made concluded Friday that Mikhail Gorbachev's only hope to save it is a radical, ``irreversible break with the past.'' The study called for the besieged Soviet citizens to swallow the bitter economic medicine of ending price controls on basic commodities while accepting the imposition of wage controls. While conceding that unemployment would rise and output would fall, experts at the International Monetary Fund insisted that Gorbachev's more gradual reforms had not worked and must be junked. The report supported President Bush's arguments that large amounts of direct aid should not be given to the Soviet Union without more fundamental reorganization of its economy. In the short term, the report said Western countries should emphasize technical assistance in such areas as banking, law and transportation. Help with environmental problems and modernization of energy production system would be useful, it said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Friday that the report was being distributed to the leaders of the nations which had requested it last July at the seven-nation economic summit in Houston. It was ordered in an attempt to bridge a gap between French and German leaders pushing for endorsement of an immediate $15 billion aid package and a reluctant Bush and others. ``The general recommendations of the report are recommendations that the United States will support and subscribe to,'' Baker said in comments which indicated the document is likely to form the blueprint for Western assistance to the Soviets in the next year. Preparing the report were experts from the 154-nation IMF and its sister organization, the World Bank, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. President Bush and other members of his administration were briefed Thursday by IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus and World Bank President Barber Conable. ``The specific measures that have been adopted do not yet constitute the coherent and comprehensive program which, in our view, is necessary if the transition (to a free-market economy) is to be successful,'' the study said. The old government-controlled economy has collapsed and been replaced by depleted store shelves, rampant growth of the black market and bartering for goods. Gorbachev must move quickly to establish private property rights and reform such vital sectors as farming, the crumbling distribution network, energy production and manufacturing, the study said. Immediate help could be useful in modernizing oil drilling techniques and nuclear power plants and upgrading the natural gas pipeline system, it said. ``These changes cannot be made in a matter of weeks,'' the report said. ``But the imperative is to make sufficient progress at the beginning so that reform is seen as an irreversible break with the past and the process gains an unstoppable momentum.'' In many ways, the report called for the cold-turkey economic reforms that Poland has undertaken over the past year. Those reforms have put goods in the stores, slowed inflation and stabilized the international value of the currency, but at the cost of much pain and disenchantment. It is an open question whether Gorbachev could do the same in the sprawling, more diverse Soviet Union, given the widespread dissatisfaction in the various republics with his leadership. But the International Monetary Fund said the Soviet central government could not return to a directed economy even if it wanted to, and has no essential choice but to accelerate the transition to a market economy. ``Ideally, a path of gradual reform could be laid out which would minimize economic disturbance,'' the report said. ``But we know of no such path, the more particularly given the difficult starting conditions.'' In addition to the United States, Friday's report was requested by Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. A separate study done for the European Economic Community came to the same conclusion Friday that massive amounts of direct Western aid now would be wasted.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Gives Up Recent Gains, Settles Near $4
DOC.TEXT: Silver futures prices fell sharply Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange on profit-taking that erased most of the gains made earlier this week. Gold and platinum futures also retreated. On other commodity markets, soybean futures plunged; grains were mixed; orange juice futures were mixed; energy futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Silver futures ended 17.4 cents to 19 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December down 17.4 cents at $4.025 a troy ounce. Gold settled $2.30 to $2.70 lower on the Commodity Exchange with December at $382.50 a troy ounce; platinum was $11.50 to $11.70 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with January at $407.20 a troy ounce. Silver led the precious metals lower as traders who bought contracts earlier in the week took profits in a market made thin and volatile by the absence of players getting an early start on the long Christmas weekend, said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Spot silver prices had soared nearly 24 cents in the two previous trading sessions after the Federal Reserve Board moved to lower interest rates. Silver has many industrial applications and its price surged amid hopes that lower rates would stimulate the economy. But ``it moved up too fast, it was overbought,'' Raptopoulos said. When a few traders started selling into Friday's thin market, others followed suit and prices plunged, she said. All New York commodities markets will be closed Saturday through Tuesday. The Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange will hold abbreviated trading sessions Monday. Soybean futures plunged on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting frustration over the slack pace of export sales and fears that a political shakeup is brewing in the Soviet Union that could bring a halt to U.S. sales of soybean meal to the Soviets. Wheat futures settled \ cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.61{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $2.34 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $1.11\ a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 8{ cents lower with January at $5.62} a bushel. Orange juice futures for January delivery fell sharply amid profit-taking on the New York Cotton Exchange after several days of strong gains tied to the slim possibility of freezing temperatures in the Florida citrus belt during the Christmas weekend. Other orange juice contracts, which are limited to daily moves of 5 cents a pound, rose moderately to catch up with January, which has no price limits and jumped a total of 16 cents in the three previous sessions. Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 3.6 cents lower to 1.85 cents higher with January at $1.164 a pound. Most petroleum futures prices retreated in the face of few significant developments in the Persian Gulf. Near-term heating oil contracts rallied, though, on forecasts for bitterly cold weather early next week in the Northeast, the biggest heating-oil market. Light sweet crude oil settled 17 cents to 47 cents lower with February at $25.92 a barrel; heating oil was .62 cent lower to .27 cent higher with January at 78.94 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .30 cent to .45 cent lower with January at 66.24 cents a gallon; natural gas futures settled unchanged to 5.7 cents higher with February at $1.962 per 1,000 cubic feet. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed ahead of a monthly Agriculture Department cold-storage report that showed 24.1 million pounds of pork bellies in the nation's commercial freezers as of Nov. 30. The number was near the high end of traders' expectations but far below the 67.5 million pounds in cold storage a year earlier. Live cattle futures settled .02 cent to .15 cent lower with February at 76.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent lower to .17 cent higher with January at 88.62 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .95 cent higher with February at 49.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .07 cent lower to .55 cent higher with February at 64.62 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Owe $55.2 Billion Abroad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With AM-Soviet Economy, Bjt. Stands for story on Business News Digest slugged AM-IMF-Soviet Debt. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union owes $55.2 billion abroad, putting it among the world's top debtors, according to a study Friday from the International Monetary Fund. It said that was the total last June, based on calculations of its own staff. The figure was higher than some previous estimates. The CIA put net Soviet debt last year at $33.3 billion. According to the World Bank, the fund's sister organization, Indonesia's debt - the fifth largest in the Third World - was $53.1 billion last year. Egypt was sixth with $48.8 billion. The top Third World debtor, Brazil, owed $111.3 billion. The bank gave no figure for the Soviet Union, which does not belong to either the bank or the fund. The Soviets would like to join and be able to borrow from them as well as from governments and commercial banks. The United States, the most influential member, has opposed membership for the Soviets. President Bush has proposed a special status which would give Moscow technical aid, but not loans. Many bankers and business people consider the amount that a country has to pay out in the course of a year more important than the total debt. The fund estimated that $13.4 billion in principal and interest was due from the Soviets this year and $9.4 billion in 1989. By way of comparison Brazil, which owes twice as much as the Soviets, had $9.3 billion due last year but has actually been paying only part of it. This year Brazil has not been paying interest at all. There has been no public indication that the Soviets are behind on their debt payments, but the report said trade credits of about $5 billion are overdue. A large amount of the principal of Soviet debt - about $12 billion worth, according to the report - will fall due next year. The fund estimated that in trade with the western world, the Soviets will be buying $6.6 billion to $9.9 billion worth of goods and services more than it sells in 1991. Such a deficit would increase its debt further. ``We must stress that balance of payments assistance should accompany the introduction of a major and comprehensive reform program,'' the report added. ``Without such a reform, additional financial resources would be of little or no lasting value.''

Trading was heavy both early in the morning and late in the session as professional investors engaged in maneuvers involving a group of expiring options and futures on stock indexes. Some of those contracts were settled on the basis of opening stock prices Friday, and others as of the close. The witching hour, which falls on the third Friday of March, June, September and December, was often a turbulent occasion for the market in years past. But recently it has been taking place in more orderly style. Beyond that specialized activity, analysts said it was an uneventful session, with many investors getting an early start on the Christmas holidays. DOC.HEAD: Former Texas Thrift Chief Agrees to Guilty Plea
DOC.TEXT: Former Dallas thrift president Edwin T. McBirney III agreed to plead guilty to fraud and help federal investigators chase other thrift scandal figures, the Justice Department said Friday. McBirney, who led Sunbelt Savings Association, is the second major thrift official in two days to be convicted of wrongdoing that cost taxpayers millions of dollars. A federal court jury on Thursday found former Vernon Savings Association owner Don R. Dixon guilty of 23 counts of fraud and misapplication of funds. A magistrate ordered Dixon held without bond until his Feb. 19 sentencing. ``Federal prosecutors have dealt a one-two punch to the savings and loan crooks this week,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in Washington. Sunbelt's 1986 failure is estimated to have cost taxpayers $2 billion, and Vernon's in 1987 cost $1.3 billion. In return for his help, prosecutors agreed to limit McBirney's penalty to $7.5 million in restitution and $8.5 million to settle civil claims by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. McBirney also may be sentenced to up to 15 years imprisonment. ``We are confident that Mr. McBirney's cooperation is going to lead to the indictment of other major insiders in the next two years,'' said Marvin Collins, U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Texas. McBirney, 37, filed the plea in federal court Friday. A date had not been scheduled for him to appear before a judge. The deal was made last month, but prosecutors arranged not to file or publicize it until Dixon's trial was over, Collins said. They did not want to risk complicating the Dixon trial, which began in October, he said. In September, the fraud conviction of two Vernon borrowers was thrown out when the judge learned the jury had discussed Dixon's indictment during its deliberations. ``We were being perhaps just a little extra cautious,'' Collins said. ``With these very large cases, we are taking extra care.'' McBirney, who was indicted in July on 17 counts, agreed to plead guilty to four counts of bank fraud, filing a false corporate tax return, causing a false statement to be filed by Sunbelt and misapplying $250,000 in Sunbelt funds. The bank fraud count stems from a $700 million deal to finance the purchase of real estate in Southern California by a Sunbelt subsidiary. McBirney agreed to admit that he arranged a fraudulent $30 million reciprocal loan arrangement with Western Savings Association, another former Dallas thrift, to help finance the real estate deal. The former owner of Western Savings, Jarrett Woods, goes on trial next month on 37 charges he misapplied funds and falsified records that led to the thrift's $1 billion failure. Dixon, 52, was convicted of illegally spending money from his Vernon Savings Association on prostitutes and a California beach house. He could be sentenced to as many as 115 years in prison and fined $5.75 million for his convictions on 23 fraud counts.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested in Alleged $2 Million-a-Month Fraud
DOC.TEXT: The FBI arrested three men Friday in an alleged $2 million-a-month scheme to lease nonexistent copy machines to businesses around the country. The FBI said in an affidavit that the defendants purported to sell the copiers to companies that buy used Xerox Corp. machines for leasing. The buyers believed the copiers would be leased for them by a Pennsylvania company, the FBI said. The alleged scam relied on the buyers never having to see the machines, since they supposedly were being leased by a third party. ``This is a typical pyramid scheme where an investor group pays in a large amount and is then paid back on a monthly basis,'' Milt Ahlerich, the FBI's special agent in charge of Connecticut, said. ``They think they are getting a terrific return on their investment, but the money is actually coming out of their original investment,'' he said. Randy T. Hilgert, 32, of Madison; Thomas J. Becker, of North Kingstown, R.I.; and John F. Rodgers, of Arcola, Pa., each was charged with wire fraud, mail fraud and money laundering, Ahlerich said. Hilgert was released Friday on $25,000 bond. The status of the other two men was not known. Federal agents seized property belonging to the three and records from the businesses involved. The alleged victim companies were paid a monthly fee for leasing the nonexistent machines. Sales of the machines averaged about $2 million a month, but in September, for example, lease payments totaled only $570,000. A large percentage of the victims were banks located around the country. Ahlerich said several companies allegedly were victimized, but declined to specify. Hilgert was the broker for the machines, the FBI said. He allegedly deposited about $500,000 a week into an account at the New England Savings Bank in Madison. The bank, which said it knew Hilgert for years as a local carpenter and landscaper, notified the FBI about the deposits. On the same day he made the deposits, the FBI said, Hilgert would wire 90 percent of the money to Becker Associates of Bridgeport, Pa. In one example, Hilgert sold 14 used copiers to Banc One Leasing Corp. of Columbus, Ohio, which believed the machines would be leased by Becker Associates, which was operating under the name Rhino Copy, the affidavit said. Rhino Copy was supposed to be leasing the machines for Banc One and then making monthly payments to the bank, the FBI said. Since it was receiving monthly payments on time, Banc One decided to buy 10 more machines. FBI Special Agent Marilyn Lucht went to Pennsylvania for Banc One to inspect the machines the company thought it owned, the affidavit said. She found about 90 copiers at Rhino Copy, but only six were operational. Lucht said Becker and Rodgers told her all of their machines were leased, had been purchased by Hilgert and were refurbished by Centralized Services Inc. Centralized Services was a vendor and refurbisher of the used copiers sold by Hilgert to the victim leasing companies, FBI said. Lucht said in an affidavit that the company ``only exists on paper.'' Centralized Services' president is a former Xerox repairman, Ralph Sylvestri, the FBI said. He has not been charged and the FBI declined to comment on his role in the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: GM Opens Soviet Offices
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will open permanent offices in Moscow and the Russian auto manufacturing city of Togliatti, the Tass news agency reported Friday. The U.S. automaker received an accreditation permit to open the offices. The document was presented to Ralph Andersen, GM's program director for the Soviet Union, on behalf of the Soviet Foreign Economic Relations Ministry, Tass said. GM in June announced a five-year, $1 billion deal with Volga Auto Works, known by its acronym VAZ, to supply 100,000 to 150,000 engine control systems per year beginning in 1992. Valentin Morozov, first deputy minister for automobile and farm machine building, said GM's presence in the Soviet Union was the result of two years of negotiations, Tass reported. He praised the deal with GM as an important contract that may pave the way for more such agreements. VAZ builds Zhiguli and Lada compact cars and the Niva, a Soviet sport-utility vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: A higher-than-expected federal deficit, tensions in the Middle East, and the holiday season combined to depress bond prices Friday in moderate trading. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was down | point, or $6.25 per $1,000 in face amount, at Friday's closing. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, was up to 8.29 percent from 8.23 percent late Thursday. ``We had more rhetoric coming from Mideast situation, the holiday atmosphere, and a larger-than-expected budget deficit. Put it all together and I think it explains what happened today,'' said Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The federal government reported a $48.1 billion deficit in November, a 62 percent increase over a year earlier. The government blamed the red ink on the Persian Gulf buildup and a failing economy. Traders generally see large deficits as pushing up interest rates because the Treasury must offer attractive yields when it peddles large amounts of debt to finance government operations. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein predicted in an interview broadcast Friday that if war broke out in the gulf, President Bush would be forced to retreat after American casualties reached 5,000. Saddam also refused to pull out of Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for avoiding force. Traders predict a Gulf war will hike the price of oil and increase inflation, which erodes the price of bonds. In addition, the market faced what traders called year-end pressures because banks are scrambling to obtain cash - and in turn bidding up the cost of funds - to fulfill financial obligations before the New Year. Broker Marilyn Cohen viewed the price drop as ``a normal pullback in a bull market for bonds. People were so over-bought in the bond market,'' she said. Ms. Cohen, investment broker for Capital Insight Inc. in Beverly Hills, Calif., said she wasn't distressed over the decline in bond prices because ``clearly interest rates are not going up for the time being.'' ``This is the relief the bond market needs in order to gather full steam and move ahead again,'' she said. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were down 1-16 point to 7-32 point, intermediate maturities fell \ point to 13-32 point and long-term issues lost { point to | point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was down 2.91 to 1,181.99. Yields on three-month Treasury bills held at 6.73 percent as the discount rate rose 1 basis point to 6.54 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 6.91 percent as the discount rose 6basis point to 6.60 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 6.93 percent as the discount was up 4 basis points to 6.51 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, traded at 7\ percent, up from 7[ percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds dropped 1-32 point to 91 9-32. The average yield to maturity held at 7.47 from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Bank Reaches Agreements with Creditors, SEC
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 3rd graf pvs with 3 new grafs on settlement of SEC charges, Adds 5 new grafs
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. would receive an injection of $605 million in capital if the ailing company agrees to a debt-for-equity swap proposed Friday. Committees representing holders of $705 million worth of Bank of New England bonds have agreed to exchange their bonds for stock that will give them 92 percent ownership of the company, said Wilbur Ross, who represents some of the bond holders. Meanwhile in Washington, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced the troubled bank has settled - without admitting or denying wrongdoing - allegations that it didn't disclose financial problems in its quarterly financial statements. Settlement negotiations were reported earlier, but neither the SEC nor the bank would provide details until Friday's announcement in Washington. Under the debt-for-equity swap, the debt would be reduced from $705 million to $100 million. The difference, or $605 million, would be converted to equity capital for the bank. ``That's a huge amount,'' Ross said. ``The bank severely needs capital.'' But an analyst said this deal alone could not solve the bank's problems. Gerard Cassidy, a bank analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc., called the deal ``a major step forward, but I would not say this event in and by itself is a panacea for their problems.'' He said the bank must reduce its troubled loan portfolio and hope that the economy will halt its slide and begin to rebound. James Dorsey, a bank spokesman, said the bank would review the bondholders' offer and discuss it with the board of directors. Ross, reading from a statement, said the deal would provide the bank with ``additional flexibility and financial wherewithal to continue to address its current financial problems.'' At the same time, the finances would be ``saving the federal government enormous taxpayer sums which would otherwise be spent if the (bank or its subsidiaries) were to be closed.'' Bank of New England has struggled for more than a year from bad real estate loans. Analysts say the bank was hurt by a declining real estate market that exposed shoddy lending practices. A congressional report released this week concluded that the bank became insolvent by some measures in June, although the bank disputed the calculations. At the end of its most recent quarter on Sept. 30, the bank had a capital to assets ratio of 1.1 percent, below the 3 percent target set by federal regulators in orders signed by the government and the bank earlier this year. The bank declined to say whether the capital infusion would push the ratio above that goal. Cassidy said it is uncertain whether the added capital would allow the bank to reach the 3 percent target, noting that the bank is expected to report a fourth-quarter loss. Under any proposed debt-for-equity swap, the bank's common shareholders will likely be wiped out, the bank has said. Bank of New England shares were selling for $1, down 25 cents a share, in late trading on the New York Stock Exchange. In the SEC action, the federal stock market watchdog filed a civil lawsuit against the bank at federal court in Washington charging the Bank of New England knowingly understated losses in its loan portfolio in a quarterly financial report in September 1989. Without admitting or denying the allegations, the bank agreed to restate its third quarter financial statements for 1989, to have independent accountants review its internal auditing procedures and to otherwise reform its quarterly financial reporting practices. ``We're pleased we were able to arrive at a satisfactory settlement with the SEC and that we can put this matter behind us,'' said Dorsey, the bank spokesman. ``The SEC settlement has no affect on the company's current business operations and will in no way interfere with our ongoing affairs.'' SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said the agency did not seek monetary penalties from the bank because the allegations pre-dated a 1990 law giving the SEC powers to impose fines. Breeden said the bank's second quarter financial statement in 1989 didn't adequately address trends affecting the bank, including the deteriorating New England real estate market. ``In the third quarter, it failed to contain adequate provisions for losses,'' said Breeden, adding that the bank didn't take a $1 billion writeoff of its loan losses until after it made a $250 million public securities offering.

DOC.HEAD: Airbus May Launch Big Jet To Compete With Boeing
DOC.TEXT: Airbus Industrie said Friday it is considering developing a commercial jet larger than Boeing's 747. The Airbus plane, tentatively dubbed the A350, would be able to carry up to 700 passengers with a range of at least 7,000 miles. The four-engine jet, which could cost $4 billion to develop, could enter service by 2002, Airbus said. Boeing's 747, the world's largest passenger plane, was first put into service 20 years ago. Since launching the 747 program in 1966, Boeing has announced orders for 1,123 for all models of the jumbo jet. Its latest version of the 747, the model 400, technically can hold up to 600 passengers, but achieves an 8,400-mile range with 412 passengers in three classes. McDonnell Douglas Corp. also produces a long-range, high-capacity jet, the MD-11, which can carry up to 405 passengers 5,700 miles. Airbus' largest current model, the A340-300, can carry 295 passengers in three classes up to 7,600 miles. Its first flight is scheduled for next year. Boeing executives have discussed the possibility of building a larger 747 sometime around the turn of the century, but the company is not actively developing such a jet, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokesman Tom Cole said.

DOC.HEAD: Taj Mahal Bondholders Could Select Three of Seven Directors
DOC.TEXT: Bondholders in Donald Trump's Taj Mahal casino will have a say in who sits on the board of the Atlantic City gaming house under a proposed bankruptcy reorganization plan, documents disclosed Friday. A compromise arrangement reached last month between Trump and investors after Trump missed a $47.3 million interest payment called for restructuring the debt in what is known as a ``prepackaged'' bankruptcy filing. The prepackaged plan, which negotiators said would enable the casino to emerge from court protection within weeks, was unveiled Friday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It calls for noteholders to swap bonds paying 14 percent interest for a package of lower paying bonds plus stock in the Taj Mahal. The stock would entitle bondholders to elect three of the seven members of the board of directors. Trump would get to pick the other four. The deal calls for holders of bonds due in 1998, which pay 14 percent interest, to exchange them for bonds due in 1999 that will pay 11.25 percent interest. In addition, for each $1,000 in old bonds investors would get one share of Class B stock, which has voting rights, and one share of Class A common stock. The Taj Mahal has been unable to break even since its April 2 opening in Atlantic City. The deal was reached about 12 hours after Trump missed a $47.3 million interest payment on $675 million worth of high-yield junk bonds used to finance the Taj Mahal. The bondholders had threatened to push Trump into bankruptcy proceedings and seize control of the casino. Under a compromise arrangement, bondholders initially will receive 50 percent of the stock in the casino. But if Trump is able to pay the original 14 percent interest on the bonds, his stake in the Taj Mahal will increase to 80 percent. In a prepackaged bankruptcy, a debtor and creditors agree on a plan to reorganize a company before entering court proceedings. Such arrangments require approval of two-thirds of creditors holding 50 percent of a company's debt. They typically reduce the time a company needs to reorganize its debt.

Pan Am and TWA, two of the oldest and weakest airlines, said they were close to a combination that would end their rivalry and mark a dramatic consolidation in the troubled industry. Trans World Airlines Chairman Carl C. Icahn had proposed a buyout of Pan Am Corp. last weekend in a deal worth about $375 million. Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett responded with a letter Friday saying such an arrangement could be ``advantageous to our shareholders, employees and other constituencies.'' But Plaskett said Pan Am would need an infusion of cash before the purchase could be completed. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The federal government ran up a $48.1 billion deficit in November, a 62 percent increase over a year ago, due in part to the Persian Gulf buildup and a failing economy, the Treasury Department reported. Combined with the October deficit, the imbalance for the first two months of fiscal 1991 totaled $79.5 billion, up 42.5 percent from the comparable period of fiscal 1990, the government said Friday. --- BOSTON (AP) - Bank of New England Corp. would receive an injection of $605 million in capital if the ailing company agrees to a proposed debt-for-equity swap. Committees representing holders of $705 million worth of Bank of New England bonds have agreed to exchange their bonds for stock that will give them 92 percent ownership of the company, Wilbur Ross, who represents some of the bond holders, said Friday. Under the swap, debt would be reduced from $705 million to $100 million. The $605 million difference would be converted to equity capital for the bank. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Infotechnology Inc., the cash-strapped owner of Financial News Network and United Press International, said it could not repay a $20.7 million loan that was called in early. The lenders, Security Pacific National Bank and MidLantic National Bank, said Friday they have the right to foreclose on Infotechnology's 46 percent stock interest in FNN, a cable television network. FNN reported a $72.5 million loss for its 1990 fiscal year. UPI, a news wire service, reportedly has been losing as much as $2.5 million a month. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Soviet Union owes $55.2 billion abroad, putting it among the world's top debtors, according to a study by the International Monetary Fund. The IMF said Friday the total reflected figures from last June, based on calculations of its own staff. The CIA put net Soviet debt last year at $33.3 billion. According to the World Bank, the fund's sister organization, Indonesia's debt - the fifth largest in the Third World - was $53.1 billion last year. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - General Electric Co. says it has begun an internal probe as a result of Israel's investigation into whether Israeli military officers accepted bribes while buying U.S.-made equipment. Israeli prosecutors had said they had agreed to a plea bargain by a senior Israeli Air Force officer accused of accepting millions of dollars in bribes while purchasing U.S. military equipment. GE spokesman George Jamison said Friday that GE began an internal investigation after learning of the Israeli probe. General Electric is a major producer of military and civilian jet engines. --- LONDON (AP) - The advertising and marketing giant WPP Group PLC said it won't pay its shareholders a midyear dividend because of weak cash flow. The owner of the U.S.-based J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide advertising agencies said Friday its priority was to conserve cash. WPP has grown into the largest ad and marketing group in the world through acquisitions over the past five years, but has seen growth in its businesses slowed by the economic weakness in the United States and Great Britain. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Despite falling short of circulation goals, the sports newspaper The National said it will boost the daily cover price by a quarter to 75 cents, effective Jan. 21. In addition, the newspaper said Friday it would test a $1 daily price for one or two of its 10 metropolitan editions. The move comes as the 11-month-old newspaper has yet to prove there are enough readers to sustain the first all-sports daily in the United States and amid an anemic advertising market. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The Horn & Hardart Co., one of America's pioneering restaurant companies and owner of New York City's last Automat, announced plans to divest the last of its eateries. The move, announced Friday, would mark the end of the company's storied foray into food, which dates to the turn of the century when luncheonette owners Joseph Horn and Frank Hardart teamed up in 1902 to open their first Automat in Philadelphia. ---

Stock prices churned through a mixed session Friday amid cross-currents created by a quarterly ``triple witching hour.'' The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 4.20 to 2,633.66. Bonds were lower. The dollar finished higher, as gold prices declined and silver fell sharply. Oil futures fell, soybeans plunged, and grain, orange juice, energy, livestock and meat futures all were mixed.
